10:30.t: There and then every single selfexperiences1what it has previously done. And they were returnedcto Allah, their True Patron, and whatever they used to fabricate strayed away from them.

f.80213: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . every single self reads what it has previously done.”

10:31.t: Saysg, “Who(else then)provides for you from the heaven and the earth? And who controls the hearing and the sight(s)? And who brings out the living from the dead and brings out the dead from the living? And who governs every matter?” So they will say, “Allah.” So saysg, “Will youplnever be mindful(of God)?

10:32.t: For that is Allah, your true Lord, so what is there beyond the truth except misguidance? So how then are you turned away?”

10:33.t: Thus yoursgLord’sWord1proved true against those who defiantly disobeyed: that they do not believe.

f.80214: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Words ”.

10:34.t: Saysg, “Can any of yourplassociates(whom you ascribed to God)originate creation then restore it?” Saysg, “Allah originates creation then restores it, so how can they be averted(from the truth)?”

10:35.t: Say, “Can any of your associates(whom you ascribed to God)guide to the truth?” Say, “Allah guides to the truth. Is the One Who guides to the truth more worthy of being followed or the one whofinds no guidance1(for himself or for others)unless he is guided? So what is the matter with youpl? How do you judge?”

f.80215: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . or the one who cannot guide (anyone) unless he is guided?”

10:36.t: Thus most of them follow nothing but assumptions; indeed, assumptions avail nothing against the truth. Indeed, Allah is All-Aware of what they do.

10:37.t: And never could this Recital1have been fabricated by anyone despite Allah. Rather,(it is)a confirmation of what preceded it and a detailed elaboration of the inscribed(decrees). There is no doubt about it—(it is)from the Lord of all realms.

f.80216: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

10:38.t: Or do they say, “He has fabricated it”? Saysg, “Then produce a single surah1like it and call upon whomever you can apart from Allah, if you are truthful.”

f.80217: Each portion of the Qur’an is called a surah,which is sometimes translated as ‘chapter’.

10:39.t: Rather, they have disbelieved in what they could not encompass with their knowledge and the interpretation of which has not yet reached them. Thus those before them disbelieved as well, so look what the outcome was for the unjustpl.

10:40.t: And of them are those who believe in it, and of them are those who do not believe in it. And yoursgLord knows better of the corrupters.

10:41.t: And if they disbelieve yousg, say, “I have my doing and youplhave your doing; you are innocent of what I do, and I am innocent of what you do.”

10:42.t: And of them are those who listen to yousg. But can you make the deaf hear, even if they do not reason?

10:43.t: And of them are those who look at you. But can you guide the blind, even though they do not see?

10:44.t: Indeed, Allah does not do injustice to mankind in anything, but mankind do injustice to themselves.

10:45.t: And on the day whenHe herds1them,(it will be)as if they had remained for only one hour of a day, getting to know one another. Those who disbelieved in the meeting with Allah have certainly lost, and they were not guided.

f.80218: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . when We herd them . . .”

10:46.t: Whether We do show yousgsome of what We promise them or take you at death, to Us is their return. Then Allah1is witness to whatever they do.

10:47.t: And for every community there is a messenger. So when their messenger comes, matters are decreed between them with justice, and they are not dealt with unjustly.

10:48.t: And they say, “When will this promise be fulfilled, if youplare truthful?”

10:49.t: Say, “I have no power to harm or benefit(even)myself, except as Allah wills. For every community there is a(specified)term. When their term has arrived, they cannot then delay by one hour nor can they advance.

10:50.t: Say, “Have you seen: if His punishment overtakes youplby nighttime or by day, what part of it will the criminals seek to hasten?”

10:51.t: “Then is it only when it befalls that you believe in it? Now? While(challengingly,)you have been asking for it to be hastened?”

10:52.t: Then it was said<sup foot_note="80220">1</sup>to those who committed injustice, “Taste the punishment of eternity. Are you being repaid except in accordance with what you used to earn?”

f.80220: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

10:55.t: Undoubtedly, to Allah does belong whatever is in the heavens and the earth. Undoubtedly, the promise of Allah is indeed true, but most of them do not know.

10:56.t: He gives life and causes death, and to Him youplare returned1.

f.80221: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and to Him you return .”

10:58.t: Saysg, “In Allah’s grace and in His mercy—in that then,let them rejoice; it is better than what they hoard1.”

f.80222: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . let them rejoice; it is better than what you pl hoard .” Roways read it as: “. . . do rejoice pl ; it is better than what you hoard .”

10:65.t: And let not their statements sadden yousg. Indeed, all might belongs to Allah; He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.

10:67.t: It is He Who made the night for youpl, that you may rest therein, and the day allowing sight. Most surely in that are signs for people who(can)hear.

10:68.t: They said, “Allah has taken(for Himself)offspring.” Highly Exalted is He; He is the Self-Sufficient; to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth. Do youplhave any manifestation regarding this? Are you saying about Allah what you do not know?

10:69.t: Saysg, “Those who fabricate lies and attribute them to Allah do not succeed.”

10:70.t: Enjoyment in the Earlier(Life), then to Us is their return, then We make them taste the severe punishment on account of how they used to deny.

10:71.t: And readsgto them the story of Noah, when he said to his people, “O my people, if my presence among you and my reminding you of Allah’s signs is too much for you, then in Allah I have placed my trust. f.80238: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Words ”.

10:97.t: even if every sign comes to them—until they see the painful punishment.

10:98.t: So if only there was one town that believed and benefited by its belief, besides the people of Jonah—when they believed, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in the Earlier Life and We gave them enjoyment for a while.

10:99.t: And had yoursgLord willed, everyone on earth would have believed, all of them, together. Will you compel mankind to become believers?

10:100.t: And never could a single self believe except by Allah’s leave. AndHe lays1abomination upon those who do not reason.

f.80239: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “And We lay . . .”

10:101.t: Saysg, “Lookplat what is in the heavens and the earth.” But signs and warnings are of no avail for people who do not believe.

10:102.t: So do they await anything but the like of the days of those who passed on before them? Saysg, “So waitpl, I am indeed with you among those waiting.”

10:103.t: Then Wedeliver1Our messengers and those who have attained faith. Thus it is binding upon Us tosave2the believers.

f.80240: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “Then We save Our messengers . . .”
f.80241: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . to deliver the believers.”

10:104.t: Saysg, “O mankind, if you are in doubt about my religion, then(know that)I do not worship those you worship apart from Allah; rather I worship Allah, Who takes you at death, and I have been commanded to be of the believers.”

10:105.t: And dedicate yourself to the religion—turning away from all that is false—and never be of the polytheists.

10:106.t: And dosgnot call, apart from Allah, upon what neither benefits you nor harms yousg, for if you do, you are then one of the unjust.

10:107.t: And if Allah touches yousgwith harm, none can remove it except He; and if He wants good for you, none can repel His grace. He makes it reach whomever He wills of His servants, for He is the Oft-Forgiving, the Bestower of mercy.

10:108.t: Saysg, “O mankind, surely the truth has come to you from your Lord, so whoever is guided—he is only guided to his own benefit, while whoever goes astray—he only goes astray to his own detriment; and in no way am I a trustee over you.”

10:109.t: And followsgwhat is revealed to you, and be patient until Allah issues His judgment, for He is the Best of judges.

11:1.t: Alif Lām Ra. A Scripture whose signs<sup foot_note="80242">1</sup>were perfected, then detailed, from One Who is All-Wise, All-Aware:

f.80242: The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah). Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

11:2.t: that youplshall worship none but Allah.(Say), “Indeed, I am to you from Him a warner and a herald of glad tidings.

11:3.t: So askplyour Lord for forgiveness then repent to Him, that He may grant you good enjoyment for a stated term and bestow His grace upon every graceful one. But ifthey1turn2away, then I fear for you the punishment of a supreme day.

f.80244: Qira’at: Al-Bazzi read it as: “But if you pl turn away . . .”

11:4.t: To Allah is your return, and He is All-Powerful over everything.”

11:5.t: Undoubtedly, they do bend their chests to hide from Him. Undoubtedly, even as they cover themselves with their clothes, He knows whatever they keep secret and whatever they make public; He is indeed All-Knowing of what lies within the chests.

11:6.t: And there is no treading creature in the earth but its provision depends on Allah, and He knows its residence and its depository; all is in an evident record<sup foot_note="80245">1</sup>.

11:7.t: And it is He Who created the heavens and the earth in six days1—and His Throne was upon the waters—in order to test you as to which of you is better in conduct. And if yousgwere to say, “Youplwill be resurrected after death,” those who denied would most surely say, “This is nothing but evidentsorcery2.”

f.80246: Six equal intervals of time, which may be six heavenly days, each of them being 1000 earthly years long (see 22:47).
f.80247: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . an evident sorcerer .”

11:8.t: And if We were to defer the punishment from them until a fixed period of time, they would most surely say, “What holds it back?” Undoubtedly, on the day when it comes to them, it is not averted from them, and they became<sup foot_note="80248">1</sup>surrounded by what they used to ridicule.

f.80248: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

11:9.t: And if We were to give man a taste of mercy from Us and then withdraw it from him, he is very truly a constantly despairing, staunch denier.

11:10.t: And if We were to give him a taste of prosperity after some adversity has touched him, he would most surely say, “Troubles have gone away from me;” he is very truly exultant, boastful—

11:11.t: except for those who have been patient and have done righteous deeds; for those there is forgiveness and a supreme reward.

11:12.t: So would yousgpossibly leave out some of what is revealed to you, and would your chest be tightened by it, because they say, “If only a treasure were sent down to him or an angel came with him?” Indeed, you are only a warner, and Allah is aTrustee over everything.

11:13.t: Or do they say, “He has fabricated it?” Saysg, “Then produce ten surahs1like it, fabricated, and call upon whomever you can apart from Allah, if you are truthful.”

f.80249: Each portion of the Qur’an is called a surah,which is sometimes translated as ‘chapter’.

11:14.t: But if they do not respond to youpl, know that it was sent down with Allah’s knowledge and that there is no god but He, so will you then become Muslims1?

f.80250: The Arabic word used is Muslimoonwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

11:15.t: Whoever has been wanting the Earlier Life and its adornment—We will render to them1in full(the reward for)their deeds therein, and therein they will not be defrauded.

f.80251: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

11:16.t: Those are the ones for whom there is nothing in the Hereafter but the Fire, and whatever they used to do therein has been nullified, and worthless is what they used to do.

11:17.t: Is someone who has been relying on evident proof from his Lord, and it is read by a witness from Him, and before it the Scripture of Moses—a guide and a mercy…1? Those believe in it2. But whoever denies it from among the(various)parties—the Fire is his promised place. So do not regard it with skepticism; it is the truth from your Lord, but most of mankind does not believe.

f.80252: This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Beqaʻi and other exegetes its predicate is: “equal to a denier?”

11:18.t: And who is more unjust than someone who fabricated lies about Allah? Those are presented before their Lord, and the notable witnesses say, “These are the ones who lied about their Lord.” Undoubtedly, the curse of Allah is upon the unjust

11:19.t: who bar(others)from the way of Allah and seek to make it crooked, and regarding the Hereafter they are deniers.

11:20.t: Those were never able to thwart(God)on earth, for never did they have any protectors apart from Allah. Punishment for them is multiplied. Never were they able to hear, nor could they see.1

f.80254: According to Al-Alousi and other exegetes it means: Never were they able to hear the word of God, nor could they see His signs.

11:21.t: Those are the ones who lost their(inner)selves, and whatever they used to fabricate strayed away from them.

11:22.t: Without doubt, in the Hereafter they are the biggest losers.

11:23.t: Indeed, those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds and have humbled themselves before their Lord—those are the fellows of theGarden(of Paradise); therein they abide.

11:24.t: The parable of the two groups is that of one who is blind and deaf, and one who is seeing and hearing. Are they equal in similitude? Will you notremind yourselves1?

f.80255: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Will you not constantly remember ?”

11:25.t: And very truly We sent Noah to his people, “I am to you an evident warner:

11:26.t: that you shall worship none but Allah; indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a painful day.”

11:27.t: So the chiefs of his people, who denied, said, “We do not see that you are anything but a human being like us, and we do not see that you are followed except by the lowliest among us, those of immature opinion, and we do not see that youplhave any advantage over us. Rather, we think you are liars.”

11:28.t: He said, “O my people, have you seen? What if I rely on evident proof from my Lord, and He has given me a mercy of His own, but itwas made invisibleto you1—can we compel you to accept it even though you dislike it?

f.80256: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . but it became invisible to you.”

11:29.t: And O my people, I ask of you no wealth for it; my reward lies only with Allah. And I will never expel those who have attained faith; they are bound to meet their Lord, whereas I see that you are a people who act in ignorance.

11:30.t: And O my people, who will support me against Allah if I expel them? Will you notremind yourselvesa?

11:31.t: And I do not say to you, ‘I possess the treasuries of Allah’, and I know not what is hidden; nor do I say, ‘I am indeed an angel;’ nor do I say of those whom your eyes scorn, ‘Allah will never give them any good.’ Allah knows better about what lies within their(inner)selves.(If I were to say so,)then I would indeed be one of the unjust.”

11:32.t: They said, “O Noah, you have argued with us and have kept arguing for too long. Now bring upon us what you promise us, if you have been of the truthful.”

11:33.t: He said, “It is Allah Who brings it upon you if He wills, and you can never thwart(Him).

11:34.t: And my advice will not benefit you—even if I wanted to advise you—in case Allah wants to delude you. He is your Lord, and to Himyou are returned1.”

f.80257: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “and to Him you return .”

11:35.t: Or do they say, “He has fabricated it?” Say, “If I have fabricated it, then upon me falls my crime, and I am innocent of the crimes you commit.”

11:36.t: And it was revealed to Noah: “Certainly, none of your people will attain faith except those who have already attained faith, so do not grieve over what they have been doing.

11:37.t: And build the ship under Our eyes and with Our inspiration, and do not address Me regarding those who have done injustice; they are to be drowned.”

11:38.t: And he builds<sup foot_note="80258">1</sup>the ship, and whenever some chiefs from among his people passed by him, they would mock him. He said, “If you mock us, surely we mock you just as you mock;

f.80258: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of past events.

11:39.t: then you will come to know upon whom shall come a punishment that disgraces him, and upon whom a perpetual punishment shall fall.”

11:40.t: Until, when Our command came and the oven overflowed1, We said, “Carry in it, ofeach kind, a male and female couple2, and your family—except those against whom the sentence has already been passed—and those who have attained faith.” But none attained faith with him except a few.

f.80259: As a sign to embark the ship.
f.80260: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “Carry in it, of each female and male kind, one couple . . .”

11:41.t: And he said, “Embark in it. In the name of Allahshall be its sailing1and its anchorage. My Lord is most surely Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.”

f.80261: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Warsh read it as: “In the name of Allah who causes it to sail and who causes it to anchor .”

11:42.t: And so it sailsbwith them amidst waves like mountains. And Noah called to his son who had kept away, “O my child! Embark with us and do not be with the deniers.”

11:43.t: He said, “I will take shelter on a mountain which can safeguard me from the water.” He said, “There is no safeguard from Allah’s command today, except for the one on whom He has bestowed mercy.” And the waves surged between them, and he became of the drowned.

11:44.t: And it was said, “O land, swallow your waters,” and “O sky, clear up.” And the waters receded, and the matter was concluded, and it settled on(mount)Judei, and it was said: “Away with the unjust people.”

11:45.t: And Noah called to his Lord and said, “O My Lord, my son is indeed of my family, and Your promise is indeed the truth, and You are the Wisest of all judges.”

11:46.t: He said, “O Noah, he is not of your family; surely,it is an unrighteous deed1, sodo not2ask Me about something you know nothing about; I surely admonish you lest you be one of the ignorant.”

f.80262: Qira’at: Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . surely, he acted unrighteously . . .”
f.80263: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . so never ask me about . . .”

11:47.t: He said, “O My Lord, I do seek refuge with You from asking You about what I have no knowledge of, and unless You forgive me and have mercy on me, I will be one of the losers.”

11:48.t: It was said, “O Noah, disembark with peace from Us, and with blessings upon you and upon communities that will spring from those with you. And to(other)communities We shall grant enjoyment, then a painful punishment from Us will touch them.”

11:49.t: That is of the stories of the hidden realm which we reveal to yousg; never were you nor your people to know them before this, so be patient; the future outcome surely belongs to the people who are mindful(of God).

11:50.t: And to ʻĀd, their brother Hud. He said, “O my people, worship Allah; you have no other god but Him; you are nothing but fabricators.

11:51.t: O my people, I ask you no reward for it; my reward is only from the One Who originated me. Do you not reason?

11:52.t: And, O my people, ask forgiveness from your Lord then repent to Him. He will send down abundant rain from the sky for you and will add strength to your strength. But do not turn away as criminals.”

11:53.t: They said, “O Hud, you did not come to us with any evident proof, and we shall not abandon our gods for your words, and we shall not believe in you.

11:54.t: We only say that some of our gods have possessed you with evil.” He said, “I call Allah to witness, and you to witness, that I am innocent of what you associate

11:55.t: apart from Him. So plot against me, all together, then do not reprieve me.

11:56.t: I have indeed placed my trust in Allah, my Lord and your Lord. There is not a treading creature but He holds it by its forelock; indeed, my Lord is on a straight path.

11:57.t: But ifthey1turn away, then I have conveyed to you what I was sent to you with. And my Lord will make other people succeed you, and you will not harm Him at all. My Lord is indeed a Constant Preserver over everything.”

f.80264: Qira’at: Al-Bazzi read it as: “But if you pl turn away . . .”

11:58.t: Thus when Our command came, We delivered Hud and those who had attained faith with him, by mercy from Us, and We delivered them from a harsh punishment.

11:59.t: And that was ʻĀd: they repudiated the signs of their Lord and disobeyed His messengers and followed the command of every stubborn tyrant.

11:60.t: And they were pursued by a curse in this Earlier(Life)and on the Day of Resurrection. Undoubtedly, ʻĀd did deny their Lord. Undoubtedly, away with ʻĀd, the people of Hud.

11:61.t: And to Thamûd, their brother Saleh. He said, “O my people, worship Allah; you have no god other than Him; He initiated you from the earth and assigned you to develop it, so seek His forgiveness and then repent to Him. My Lord is indeed Near, Responsive.”

11:62.t: They said, “O Saleh, we had hopes in you before this. Are you forbidding us from worshiping what our parents worship? And most surely, we are in serious doubt regarding what you are calling us to.”

11:63.t: He said, “O my people, have you seen: if I rely on evident proof from my Lord and He has given me mercy from Him? Who then would support me against Allah if I disobeyed Him? For you add nothing to me except causing losses.

11:64.t: And O my people, this is the she-camel of Allah—a sign for you—so let her graze in Allah’s land and do not touch her with any harm lest an imminent punishment overtake you.”

11:65.t: But they hamstrung her, so he said, “Enjoy yourselves in your home for three days; that is a promise not to be belied.”

11:66.t: Then when Our command came, We delivered Saleh and those who had attained faith with him, by mercy from Us, and from the disgrace of that day. Indeed, your Lord<sup foot_note="80265">1</sup>is the All-Powerful, the Almighty.

11:67.t: And those who had done injustices were taken away by the Shout and became motionless bodies in their homes,

11:68.t: as if they had never prospered therein. Undoubtedly, Thamûd did deny their Lord. Undoubtedly, away with Thamûd.

11:69.t: And very truly, Our messengers came to Abraham with glad tidings. They said, “Peace.” He said, “Peace,” and soon after he came with a roasted calf.

11:70.t: But when he saw their hands not reaching towards it, he distrusted them and conceived a fear of them. They said, “Do not fear; we have indeed been sent to the people of Lot.”

11:71.t: And his wife was standing by, so she laughed. And We gave her glad tidings of Isaac<sup foot_note="80266">1</sup>, and after Isaac, Jacob.

f.80266: The Hebrew word Isaacmeans ‘he will laugh’.

11:72.t: She said, “Woe to me. Shall I give birth when I am an old woman and this, my husband, is an old man? This is truly an amazing thing!”

11:73.t: They said, “Are you amazed at the command of Allah? The mercy and blessings of Allah are upon you, O people of the house. He is indeed Praiseworthy, Glorious.”

11:74.t: And when Abraham’s fear had subsided and the glad tidings had reached him—he argues<sup foot_note="80267">1</sup>with Us concerning the people of Lot.

f.80267: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

11:75.t: Most surely, Abraham is forbearing, imploring, penitent.

11:76.t: “O Abraham, disregard this; surely your Lord’s command has come, and an irreversible punishment shall surely be brought upon them.”

11:77.t: And when Our messengers came to Lot, he was troubled over them and concerned for them, and he said, “This is a dreadful day.”

11:78.t: And his people came rushing towards him, while earlier they were in the habit of doing evil deeds. He said, “O my people, these are my daughters; they are purer for you, so be mindful of Allah and do not disgrace me concerning my guests. Is there not one prudent man among you?”

11:79.t: They said, “You have(long)known that we have no right to your daughters, and surely you know well what we want.”

11:80.t: He said, “If only I had strength against you or could rely on some intense support.”

11:81.t: They said, “O Lot, we are the messengers of your Lord; they will not reach you, so take your family on a journey while yet a part of the nightremains, and let none of you look back. But not your wife1—she will be afflicted by that which afflicts them. Indeed, their appointed time is the morning. Is not the morning near?”

f.80268: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “so take your family on a journey while yet a part of the night remains. And let none of you look back except for your wife—she will be afflicted by . . .”

11:82.t: And when Our command came, We turned it upside down, and We rained down on it stones of baked clay,

11:83.t: marked from yoursgLord1, and never far from the unjustpl.

11:84.t: And to Midian, their brother Shuaib. He said, “O my people, worship Allah—you have no god other than Him—and do not give short measure or short weight. I see you are prospering, but I fear for you the punishment of an encompassing day.”

11:85.t: “O my people, give full measure and full weight with justice, and do not defraud people of their belongings, and do not go wickedly about the land, corrupting it.

11:86.t: A remnant which is granted by Allah is better for you, if you are believers. And I am not a constant preserver over you.”

11:87.t: They said, “O Shuaib,does your prayer1command you that we abandon what our fathers worship or that we should not do with our wealth whatever we will? Very truly, you are the forbearing, prudent one!”

f.80270: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . do your prayers command you . . .”

11:88.t: He said, “O my people, can you see? What if I rely on evident proof from my Lord and He has provided me with good provision from Himself? And I have no desire to do what I forbid you from doing. I desire nothing but reform as far as I can. And in no way is my success with anyone except with Allah.In Him I have placed my trust, and to Him I turn penitently.

11:89.t: And O my people, let not your hostility towards me cause you to suffer what was suffered by the people of Noah or the people of Hud or the people of Saleh; and the people of Lot are not far off from you.

11:90.t: And ask your Lord for forgiveness and then repent to Him; my Lord is indeed Bestowing of mercy, Most Loving.”

11:91.t: They said, “O Shuaib, we do not comprehend much of what you say, and we see that you are weak among us; and were it not for your clan, we would have stoned you, for you have no might against us.”

11:92.t: He said, “O my people, is my clan mightier to you than Allah? And you have turned your backs on Him? Indeed, my Lord is All-Encompassing of what you do.

11:93.t: And O my people, act according to yourposition1; surely, I am also acting(according to mine); you will know to whom will come a punishment that disgraces him and who it is that is a liar. So wait and watch; surely I too am watching out with you.”

f.80271: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “. . . your positions . . .”

11:94.t: And when Our command came, We delivered Shuaib and those who had attained faith with him, by mercy from Us. And the Shout took away those who had done injustices, so they became motionless bodies in their homes

11:95.t: as if they had never prospered therein. Undoubtedly, away with Midian as was done away with Thamûd.

11:96.t: And very surely, We sent Moses with Our signs and an evident manifestation

11:97.t: to Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and never was the command of Pharaoh prudent.

11:98.t: He precedes his people on the Day of Resurrection, and he led<sup foot_note="80272">1</sup>them into the Fire, and what a miserable drinking place to be led to!

f.80272: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

11:99.t: And they were followed by a curse in this(life)and on the Day of Resurrection; what a miserable gift to be gifted!

11:100.t: That is of the stories of the towns—We relate them to you; some are still standing and some have withered away.

11:101.t: And in no way did We do them any injustice, but to themselves they did injustice, so their gods whom they called upon apart from Allah availed them nothing when the command of your Lord arrived, and they did not increase them in anything but ruin.

11:102.t: And such is the seizing of your Lord when He seizes the towns while they are unjust. His seizing is indeed most painful, most severe.

11:103.t: Indeed, in that is a sign for whoever fears the punishment of the Hereafter. That is a day for which mankind will be gathered together, and that is a day to be witnessed,

11:104.t: and we only postpone it until a predetermined term.

11:105.t: On the day when it arrives, not a single self can speak without His leave, so some will be wretched and some will be happy.

11:106.t: So as for the wretched ones, they are in the Fire—they have therein sighing and gasping,

11:107.t: abiding therein for as long as the heavens and the earth remain, except as your Lord has willed. Indeed, yoursgLord is Doer of whatever He wants.

11:108.t: And as for the ones who havebeen granted happiness1, they are in the Garden(of Paradise), abiding therein for as long as the heavens and the earth remain, except as your Lord has willed—an uninterrupted grant.

f.80273: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . the ones who have become happy . . .”

11:109.t: So do not regard what these people worship with skepticism. They do not worship except as their fathers used to worship before, and most surely We will pay them their due in full, undiminished.

11:110.t: And indeed We already brought Moses the Scripture, but it was differed upon. And were it not for a word that had preceded from your Lord, judgment would have been decreed between them, and they are most surely in perplexing doubt concerning it.

11:111.t: Yet indeed1, to every one of them your Lord will certainly render in full(the reward)for their deeds; indeed, He is All-Aware of what they do.

f.80274: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir and Shuʻba read it as: “Yet to every one of them, your Lord will . . .”

11:112.t: So besgupright as you have been commanded, along with whoever has repented with you, and doplnot exceed all limits; indeed, He is All-Seeing of what you do.

11:113.t: And do not rely on those who have done injustices or the Fire will touch you, and you will have no guardians apart from Allah, and you will not be supported.

11:114.t: And establishsgthe prayer at both extremities of the day and in the early hours of the night. Indeed, good deeds do away with evil deeds. That is a reminding for those who remember.

11:115.t: And besgpatient, for surely Allah does not waste the reward of those who excel in doing good.

11:116.t: So if only there were, among the generations before youpl, people with a remnant(of wisdom)forbidding corruption in the land, other than the few of them whom We saved. But the unjust ones pursued the luxuries they were indulged in, and thus became criminals.

11:117.t: And in no way would your Lord destroy towns unjustly while their inhabitants are reformers.

11:118.t: And had yoursgLord willed, He could have made mankind one community, but they continue to differ,

11:119.t: except those upon whom your Lord has bestowed mercy—and for that reason He created them. And the Word of your Lord has been fulfilled: “I will most surely fill Hell with(the race of)unseen beings1and human beings, both together.”

f.80275: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

11:120.t: And all what We relate to you of the stories of the messengers is to strengthen your heart therewith. And the truth has come to you in this, and an admonition and a reminder for the believers.

11:121.t: And say to those who do not believe, “Act according toyour position1; surely, we are also acting(according to ours).

f.80276: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “Act according to your positions . . .”

11:122.t: And wait; indeed, we too are waiting.”

11:123.t: And to Allah belongs the hidden realm of the heavens and the earth, and to Him every matteris returned1. So worshipsgHim and place your trust in Him, for your Lord is not oblivious of whatyoupldo2.

f.80278: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . of what they do .”
f.80277: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ and Hafs read it as: “. . . and to Him every matter returns .”

12:1.t: Alif Lām Ra. Those are the signs<sup foot_note="80279">1</sup>of the Evident Scripture.

f.80279: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

12:2.t: Indeed, We have sent it down as an Arabic Recital1, that youplmay reason.

f.80280: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

12:3.t: We relate to yousgthe most beautiful of stories by revealing to you this Recitalf, although prior to it you were indeed one of the oblivious.

12:4.t: Recall when Joseph said to his father, “O my father, I saw eleven planets and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating to me.”

12:5.t: He said, “O my child, do not relate your vision to your brothers, lest they plot a plot against you; indeed, Satan is an evident enemy to man.

12:6.t: And thus your Lord will choose you and teach you of the interpretation of dreams and perfect His blessing upon you and upon Jacob’s folk, as He perfected it before upon both of your forefathers Abraham and Isaac; indeed, your Lord is All-Knowing, All-Wise.

12:7.t: Very truly,there have been signs1in Joseph and his brothers for the askers.

f.80281: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “Very truly, there has been a sign . . .”

12:8.t: Recall when they said, “Joseph and his brother are certainly dearer to our father than we are, although we are a(whole)band. Most surely, our father is in evident misguidance.

12:9.t: “Kill Joseph or throw him somewhere in the land, and your father‘s attention will be yours, then afterwards you become righteous people.”

12:10.t: One1of them said, “Do not kill Joseph, but cast him into the invisiblecavity2of the unlined well—some travelers may pick him up—if you must do something.”

f.80283: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . invisible cavities . . .”

12:11.t: They said, “O our father, why do you not trust us with Joseph, when we are most surely his advisors?

12:12.t: Send him with us tomorrow, thathe1may eat welland play, and we are most surely his preservers.”

f.80284: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . that we may eat well . . .”

12:13.t: He said, “It surely grieves me that you should go away with him, and I fear the wolf may eat him while you are oblivious of(what happens to)him.”

12:14.t: They said, “If the wolf should eat him while we are a(whole)band, then most surely, we would be losers.”

12:15.t: So when they went away with him and agreed to put him into the invisiblecavitycof the unlined well, and We revealed to him, “You will surely inform them of this affair of theirs while they are unaware.”

12:16.t: And they came to their father in the evening, weeping.

12:17.t: They said, “O our father, we went off racing one another and left Joseph by our belongings, so the wolf ate him. But in no way would you believe us, even if we were truthful.”

12:18.t: And they came with false1blood on his shirt. He said, “Rather, your(inner)selves prompted you(to do)something, so beautiful patience(is most fitting for me), and Allah alone is besought for help against what you describe.”

12:19.t: And there came some travelers, so they sent their water-carrier, then he let down his bucket. He said, “Whatgladtidings1! Here is a boy!” And they hid him as merchandise. Yet Allah is All-Knowing of what they do.

f.80286: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “What glad tidings for me !”

12:20.t: And they sold him for a cheap price—a few coins, and they were of those undervaluing him.

12:21.t: Yet the man from Egypt who purchased him said to his wife, “Tend graciously to his dwelling; hopefully he may be useful to us, or we may take him as a son.” And thus We established Joseph in the land, and so that we might teach him of the interpretation of dreams. And Allah always prevails<sup foot_note="80287">1</sup>in His affairs, yet the majority of mankind does not know.

12:22.t: And when he had attained full strength, We brought him wise judgment and knowledge, for thus do We repay those who excel in doing good.

12:23.t: Then she in whose house he was living sought to seduce him, and she shut the doors and said, “(Everything is)ready for you.” He said, “God is my refuge! He is my lord, who has given me a good dwelling; indeed, the unjust ones never succeed.”

12:24.t: And surely, she advanced towards him, and he would have advanced towards her had he not seen the proof of his Lord. Thus it was, so that We would divert evil and obscenity away from him; indeed, he is one of Oursincere chosen1servants.

f.80288: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . one of Our sincere servants.”

12:25.t: And they raced towards the door, and she tore his shirt from behind, and at the door they ran into her master. She said, “What is the penalty for someone who wanted evil towards your family except imprisonment or a painful punishment?”

12:26.t: He said, “It was she who sought to seduce me.” And a witness from her own family testified: “If his shirt has been torn from the front, then she has told the truth and he is of the liars.

12:27.t: But if his shirt has been torn from the back, then she has lied and he is of the truthful.”

12:28.t: Then when he saw that his shirt had been torn from the back, he said, “This is indeed of your<sup foot_note="80289">1</sup>plotting; indeed, your plotting is great!”

f.80289: The Arabic wording indicates that these words are directed at a group of women.

12:29.t: “Joseph, disregard this. And you(woman), ask forgiveness for your misdeed; indeed, you have been one of the wrongdoers.”

12:30.t: And some ladies in the city said, “The mighty governor’s wife seeks to seduce her young assistant; he has certainly impassioned her with love! Indeed, we do see her in evident misguidance.”

12:31.t: So when she heard of their gossip1, she sent for them and prepared for themreclining cushions2and brought each one of them a knife, and she said, “Come out before them.” So when they saw him, they marveled at him and cut their hands and said, “God forbid! In no way is this a human being; this is but a noble angel!”

f.80291: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and prepared for them citrus fruits and brought each . . .”

12:32.t: She said, “Here he is—the one you blamed me for, and most surely I did seek to seduce him, but he safeguarded(his chastity). Yet if he does not do what I command him, he will most surely be imprisoned, and he will most surely become one of the dishonored.”

12:33.t: He said, “My Lord,prison1is dearer to me than what they call me to, and unless You turn their plotting away from me, I might yield to them and become one of the ignorant.”

f.80292: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “My Lord, imprisonment is dearer to me than what they call me to . . .”

12:34.t: Thereupon his Lord responded to him and diverted their plotting away from him; indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.

12:35.t: Then it occurred to them, after they had seen the signs, to imprison him for a while.

12:36.t: And two young men entered prison with him. One of them said, “I see myself pressing wine.” And the other said, “I see myself carrying on my head bread from which the birds are eating. Tell us their interpretation; we see that you are of those who excel in doing good.”

12:37.t: He said, “No food will be provided for you but I will have informed you about their interpretation before it comes to you. That is some of what my Lord has taught me. Indeed, I have forsaken the creed of people who do not believe in Allah, and regarding the Hereafter they are deniers.

12:38.t: And I have followed the creed of my forefathers, Abraham and Isaac and Jacob. Never was it for us to associate anything with Allah. That is of Allah’s grace upon us and upon mankind, but the majority of mankind does not give thanks.

12:39.t: O my fellow inmates, are diverse lords better or Allah, the One, the Subduer?

12:40.t: You do not worship apart from Him except(mere)names you have named, you and your forefathers, for which Allah has sent down no manifestation. Judgment belongs to none but Allah. He has commanded that you worship none but Him; that is the upright religion, but the majority of mankind does not know.

12:41.t: O my fellow inmates, as for one of you, he will give his lord wine to drink. And as for the other, he will be crucified and the birds will eat from his head. The matter you seek to be elucidated has been settled.”

12:42.t: And he said to the one he thought would be released, “Remember me to your lord.” But Satan caused him to forget the remembrance to<sup foot_note="80293">1</sup>his lord, so he remained in prison for several years.

f.80293: The Arabic text can also be translated as: “But Satan caused him to forget the remembrance of his Lord”, meaning that Yûsuf forgot to say “God willing”.

12:43.t: Then the king said, “I see seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green ears of corn and others dried up. O chiefs, elucidate for me my vision, if you can explicate visions.”

12:44.t: They said, “Jumbles of dreams, and we know nothing of the interpretation of dreams.”

12:45.t: And he of the two who had been released and had recollected after a long time said, “I will inform youplof its interpretation, so send me out.”

12:46.t: “Joseph, O you unwavering believer, elucidate for us: seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green ears of corn and others dried up—so that I may return to the people, that they may know.”

12:47.t: He said, “Youplshall plant for seven consecutive years; but whatever you harvest, leave it in its ear, except for a little from which you eat.

12:48.t: Then after that will come seven hard ones consuming what you have forwarded to them, except for a little of what you have stored.

12:49.t: Then after that comes a year during which people are relieved and during whichthey1press2.

f.80294: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . during which you press.”
f.80295: Press the land’s produce for wine and oil.

12:50.t: So the king said, “Bring him to me.” But when the messenger came to him, he said, “Go back to your lord and ask him, ‘What about the women who cut their hands?’ Surely, my Lord is All-Knowing of their plotting.”

12:51.t: He said, “What happened with you<sup foot_note="80296">1</sup>when you sought to seduce Joseph?” They said, “God forbid! We knew of no evil committed by him.” The mighty governor’s wife said, “Now the truth has come to light. It was I who sought to seduce him, and he is most surely one of the truthful.”

f.80296: The Arabic wording indicates that these words are directed at a group of women.

12:52.t: “That is so he may know that I did not betray him in his absence, for surely Allah does not guide the plotting of the betrayers.<sup foot_note="80297">1</sup>

f.80297: Linguistically, this whole statement can be understood as the words of Yûsuf about his master or the words of the woman about Yûsuf.

12:53.t: Yet I do not consider my(inner)self blameless. Most surely, the self commands to evil, except those upon whom my Lord has bestowed mercy; indeed, my Lord is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.”

12:54.t: So the king said, “Bring him to me so that I can reserve him for myself.” And when he spoke to him, he said, “Surely, today you are—with us—established, trustworthy.”

12:55.t: He said, “Put me in charge of the storehouses of the land; I am indeed a knowledgeable constant preserver.”

12:56.t: And thus We established Joseph in the land to live therein whereverhe1sowilled. We reach2with Our mercy whomever We will, and We never waste the reward of those who excel in doing good.

f.80298: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . wherever We so willed .”

12:57.t: But the reward of the Hereafter is better for those who attained faith and used to be mindful(of God).

12:58.t: And Joseph’s brothers came and presented themselves before him, so he recognized them, but they did not recognize him.

12:59.t: Then when he had supplied them with their supplies, he said, “Bring me a brother of yours from your father. Do you not see that I fill up the measure, and I am the best of hosts?

12:60.t: But if you do not bring him to me, you will have no(more)measure with me, and you will not come near me(again).”

12:61.t: They said, “We will solicit his father for him, and we are sure to do so.”

12:62.t: So he said tohis young assistants1, “Put their goods in their saddlebags; perhaps they will recognize them when they return to their families so that they may come back.”

f.80300: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . to his few young assistants . . .”

12:63.t: So when they returned to their father, they said, “O our father, we were denied measure, so send our brother with us so thatwe1can obtain measure, and we are most surely his preservers.”

f.80301: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . so that he can obtain measure . . .”

12:64.t: He said, “Am I to entrust him to you as I entrusted his brother to you before? Allah isa Better Preserver1, and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful ones.”

f.80302: Qira’at: Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Allah is Better in preservation . . .”

12:65.t: And when they opened their baggage they found that their goods had been returned to them. They said, “O father, what more could we want? Here are our goods, returned to us; we will provide for our family and preserve our brother and have an additional camel-load; that is an easy measure(to obtain).”

12:66.t: He said, “I will not send him with you unless you give me a binding pledge before Allah that you will most surely bring him back to me, unless you get trapped.” So when they gave him their binding pledge, he said, “Allah is the Ultimate Trustee over what we say.”

12:67.t: And he said, “O my children, do not enter through one gate, but enter through different gates, though I cannot avail you anything against Allah; judgment belongs to none but Allah; in Him I have placed my trust, and in Him let those who seek to trust place their trust.”

12:68.t: And when they entered as their father had commanded them, it did not avail them anything against Allah; it was just a need in Jacob’s(inner)self, which he fulfilled. And he is most surely a person of knowledge inasmuch as We have taught him, but the majority of mankind does not know.

12:69.t: And when they presented themselves before Joseph, he drew his brother close to him. He said, “Indeed it is I—I am your brother, so do not be saddened by what they used to do.”

12:70.t: Then, when he had supplied them with their supplies, he placed the drinking-cup in his brother’s saddlebag. Then an announcer called out, “O caravan<sup foot_note="80303">1</sup>, most surely you are thieves.”

f.80303: A metaphor for the people of the caravan.

12:71.t: They said as they came towards them, “What are you missing?”

12:72.t: They said, “We are missing the king’s goblet. And whoever comes up with it will have a camel-load, and I<sup foot_note="80304">1</sup>guarantee it.”

f.80304: A grammatical shift from plural to singular.

12:73.t: They said, “(We swear)by Allah, youplhave most surely known that we did not come to spread corruption in the land, and never have we been thieves.”

12:74.t: They said, “What shall be his repayment, if youplare lying?”

12:75.t: They said, “The repayment should be that he in whose saddlebag it is found, he himself is the repayment<sup foot_note="80305">1</sup>. Thus we repay the unjust ones.”

12:76.t: So he began with their bags before his brother’s bag, then he extracted it from his brother’s bag. Thus We plotted for Joseph; he could not have seized his brother according to the king’s religion1unless Allah wills.We elevate by degrees2whomever We so will. For above everyone who has knowledge, there is One who is All-Knowing.

f.80306: The Arabic word used is deenwhich means ‘a way of life’, ‘religion’ or ‘recompense’.
f.80307: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “We elevate the degrees (ranks) of whomever . . .” Yaʻqub read it as: “He elevates the degrees (ranks) of whomever . . .”

12:77.t: They said, “If he steals, well, actually a brother of his has stolen before.” But Joseph kept it secret within himself and did not reveal it to them. He said(to himself), “Youplare in a worse situation, and Allah knows better of what you describe.”

12:78.t: They said, “O mighty governor, he has a father(who is)a very old man, so take one of us in his place; we see that you are of those who excel in doing good.”

12:79.t: He said, “God is my refuge! Were we to take anyone except him in whose possession we found our property, we would then most surely be unjust.”

12:80.t: So when they completely despaired of him, they conferred privately. Their eldest said, “Do youplnot know that your father took a binding pledge from you before Allah, and in the past you failed with regard to Joseph? Therefore, I will not leave this land until my father permits me or Allah judges for me, for He is the Best of judges.

12:81.t: Go back to yourplfather and say, ‘Our father, your son has indeed stolen. And we did not testify(about the punishment of stealing)except according to what we have learned, and we could not have preserved(him)against what is hidden.’

12:82.t: And ask the town where we were and the caravan in which we came, for indeed, we are truthful.”

12:83.t: He said, “Rather, your(inner)selves prompted you(to do)something, so beautiful patience(is most fitting for me); hopefully Allah will bring them all back to me. Indeed, He is the All-Knowing, the All-Wise.”

12:84.t: And he turned away from them and said, “Alas for Joseph!” And his eyes turned white from grief and he suppressed his anguish.

12:85.t: They said, “(We swear)by Allah, you will continue remembering Joseph until you become totally drained or become of those annihilated.”

12:86.t: He said, “Indeed, I only complain of my anguish and grief to Allah, and I know from Allah what you do not know.”

12:87.t: “O my children, go and ask around about Joseph and his brother and do not despair of Allah’s leniency, for certainly none despair of Allah’s leniency except the denying people.”

12:88.t: Then when they presented themselves before him, they said, “O mighty governor, harm has touched us and our family and we have brought scant merchandise, but give us full measure and be charitable towards us; indeed, Allah rewards the charitable ones.”

12:89.t: He said, “Do you know what you did with Joseph and his brother when you were ignorant?”

12:90.t: They said, “Can it be that you really are Joseph?1” He said, “I am Joseph, and this is my brother. Allah has certainly been gracious to us; indeed, whoever is mindful(of God)and endures patiently—indeed, Allah never wastes the reward of those who excel in doing good.”

f.80308: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “They said, ‘You really are Joseph! ’”

12:91.t: They said, “(We swear)by Allah, Allah has certainly preferred you over us, and we were definitely wrongdoers.”

12:92.t: He said, “There is no blame on youpltoday; may Allah forgive you, for He is the Most Merciful of the merciful ones.

12:93.t: Take this shirt of mine and cast it over my father’s face(and)he will recover his sight. And bring your whole family to me.”

12:94.t: And as soon as the caravan departed, their father said, “I sense the scent of Joseph, though you may deem me senile.”

12:95.t: They said, “(We swear)by Allah, yousgare surely in your old misguidance.”

12:96.t: So when the herald of glad tidings arrived, he cast it over his face and he regained his sight. He said, “Did I not say to youpl, ‘Indeed, I know from Allah what you know not.’”?

12:97.t: They said, “O father, pray for the forgiveness of our misdeeds; we were indeed wrongdoers.”

12:98.t: He said, “I will ask my Lord to forgive you; indeed, He is the Oft-Forgiving, the Bestower of mercy.”

12:99.t: So when they presented themselves before Joseph, he drew his parents close to him and said, “Enter Egypt all of you, Allah willing, feeling secure.”

12:100.t: And he raised his parents on the throne, and they(all)fell prostrate before him, and he said, “O father, this is the interpretation of my vision of long ago. My Lord has certainly made it come true, and He was certainly charitable to me when He brought me out of prison and brought youplfrom the nomadic life after Satan had sown discord between me and my brothers. Indeed, my Lord is Subtle in fulfilling whatever He wills; indeed, He is the All-Knowing, the All-Wise.”

12:101.t: “My Lord, You have surely brought me of kingship1and have taught me of the interpretation of dreams. Initiator of the heavens and the earth—You are my Ultimate Guardian in the Earlier(Life)and the Hereafter; take me back at death as a Muslim and join me with the righteous.”

f.80309: The Arabic word used is mulkwhich means ‘kingship’, ‘authority’ or ‘dominion’.

12:102.t: That is of the stories of the hidden realm which We reveal to you, for you were not with them when they agreed together upon their affair as they were scheming.

12:103.t: And most mankind will not believe, no matter how keen yousgare,

12:104.t: though you ask them no reward for it. It is only a reminder for all realms.

12:105.t: And how many a sign in the heavens and the earth do they pass by while they disregard them?

12:106.t: And most of them do not believe in Allah unless they associate(others with Allah).

12:107.t: Do they feel secure that an overwhelming event of Allah’s punishment will not come upon them, or that the Hour will not come upon them suddenly while they are unaware?

12:108.t: Saysg, “This is my way; I call to Allah with insight—I and whoever has followed me. And Highly Exalted be Allah, and I am not of those who associate(others with Allah).”

12:109.t: And in no way did We send(any messengers)before yousgexcept men to whomWe reveal1, from among the people of the towns. Have they not journeyed through the earth and looked at what the outcome was for those before them? The Home of the Hereafter is surely better for those who have been mindful(of God). Doyouplnot reason2?

f.80311: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Do they not reason ?”
f.80310: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . except men to whom it is revealed , from among . . .”

12:110.t: Until, when the messengers had completely despaired and thought that they had beenlied to1(by their own selves), Our support came to them. Thenwhomever We willed was delivered2, and Our chastisement is never turned back from the criminal people.

f.80312: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and thought that they had been deemed liars . . .”
f.80313: Qira’at: All except for Ibn ʻAmer, ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “Then We save whomever We will . . .”

12:111.t: Most surely, in their narrative there has been a lesson for people of understanding. This was not a fabricated tale, but a confirmation of what came before it and a detailed explanation of everything and guidance and mercy for people who believe.

13:1.t: Alif Lām Mīm Ra. Those are the signs of the Scripture. And what has been sent down to yousgfrom your Lord is the truth, but most of mankind do not believe.

13:2.t: Allah is the One Who raised up the heavens without pillars that you see, then He settled over the Throne, and He has subjected the sun and the moon, each running for a stated term. He governs matters; He details signs, that youplmay be certain of the meeting with your Lord.

13:3.t: And He is the One Who spread the land and made in it firm mountains and rivers, and of all products he made therein two pairs; He causes the night tooverwhelm1the day; indeed, in that are signs for people who reflect.

f.80314: Qira’at: Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . the night to tightly overwhelm the day . . .”

13:4.t: And in the land are neighboring plots and gardens ofvines, and vegetation, and date-palms1—from the same root or from distinct roots—irrigated with the same water, yetWe make2the produce of some taste better than others; most surely, in that are signs for people who reason.

f.80316: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . yet He makes the produce . . .”
f.80315: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . neighboring plots and gardens of vines and (of) vegetation and (of) date-palms . . .”

13:5.t: And if yousgare amazed, then more amazing is their saying: “Can it be thatwhen we have become dust—can it be that1we will really be(resurrected)in a new creation?” Those are the ones who have denied their Lord, and those are the ones with yokes around their necks, for those are the fellows of the Fire; therein they abide.

f.80317: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “Can it be that when we have become dust we will really be . . .” Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “When we have become dust—can it be that we will really be . . .”

13:6.t: And they urge yousgto hasten evil before good, though exemplary punishments have occurred before them. And most surely your Lord is the Possessor of forgiveness to mankind despite their injustice, but most surely your Lord is stern in retribution.

13:7.t: And those who have denied say, “If only a sign<sup foot_note="80318">1</sup>would be sent down to him from his Lord?” Indeed, you are only a forewarner, as for every people there is a guide.

13:8.t: Allah knows what every female carries and what the wombs lose(prematurely)or exceed, and everything with Him is in due measure—

13:9.t: the Knower of the hidden realm and the manifest; the Supreme, the Highly Exalted.

13:10.t: It is the same: whether one of you speaks secretly or aloud, whether he goes into hiding by night or goes out by day.

13:11.t: For each one there is a succession(of angels)before him and behind him, preserving him from Allah’s command. Indeed, Allah does not change the condition of a people until they change what is within themselves. And if Allah wants an evil for a people, there is no turning it back, and apart from Him they have no guardian.

13:12.t: It is He who shows youplthe lightening,(causing)fear and ardent hope, and He produces the heavy clouds.

13:13.t: And the thunder exalts Him with praise, and so do the angels out of fear of Him. And He sends the thunderbolts, striking with them whomever He wills. Yet they argue about Allah, while He is stern in His plan.

13:14.t: To Him belongs the call of truth, while those they call upon apart from Him do not respond to them with anything, except as someone who stretches his hands towards water so that it may reach his mouth, but never will it reach it. Thus the call of the deniers can only go astray.

13:15.t: And to Allah prostrates whoever is in the heavens and the earth, willingly or reluctantly, as do their shadows in the mornings and before sunset.

13:16.t: Saysg, “Who is the Lord of the heavens and the earth?” Say, “Allah.” Say, “Have you taken apart from Him protectors who have no power to benefit or harm(even)themselves?” Say, “Are the blind and the seeing equal? Or are darkness and light equal? Or have they set up to Allah associates who created the like of His creation, so that their creation is indistinguishable to them from His? Say, “Allah is the Creator of everything, and He is the One, the Subduer.”

13:17.t: He sent down water from the sky, so valleys flowed—each according to its capacity—and the current carried swelling froth. And from whatthey1burnin fire, seeking to make ornaments or utensils, comes a similar froth. Thus Allah exemplifies truth and falsehood: so as for the froth—it fades away, and as for what benefits mankind—it remains in the earth; thus Allah sets forth parables.

f.80319: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . what you burn in fire . . .”

13:18.t: For those who have responded to their Lord is the best(reward), but those who have not responded to Him—if they possessed whatever is in the earth, all together and twice as much, they would indeed offer to ransom themselves with it. For those is an evil reckoning, for their shelter is Hell, and what a miserable resting place!

13:19.t: Is someone who knows that what was sent down to you from your Lord is the truth like someone who is blind? Indeed, only those endowed with understanding remind themselves—

13:20.t: those who fulfill Allah’s covenant and do not violate the pledge;

13:21.t: and those who join what Allah has commanded to be joined and are in awe of their Lord and fear evil reckoning;

13:22.t: and those who endured patiently, seeking their Lord’s countenance, and established the prayers and spent of what We provided them, secretly and publicly, and who repel<sup foot_note="80320">1</sup>an evil deed with a good deed; for those is the Ultimate Dwelling:

f.80320: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

13:23.t: everlasting Gardens which they enter, along with whoever was righteous of their forefathers and their spouses and their offspring(s), while the angels enter upon them from every gate.

13:24.t: “Peace be upon youplfor all you have endured patiently, so how excellent is the Ultimate Dwelling!”

13:25.t: And those who violate the covenant of Allah after pledging it, and sever what Allah has commanded to be joined and spread corruption in the land—those, for them there is the curse, and for them there is the Very Evil Home.

13:26.t: Allah extends provision for whomever He wills and He restrains(it). And they rejoiced with the Earlier Life, yet the Earlier Life, compared to the Hereafter, is nothing but(a brief)enjoyment.

13:27.t: And those who have denied say, “If only a sign<sup foot_note="80321">1</sup>would be sent down to him from his Lord?” Say, “Indeed, Allah leads astray whomever He wills, and He guides to Himself whoever has turned penitent:

13:28.t: those who have attained faith and whose hearts become<sup foot_note="80322">1</sup>serene with the remembrance<sup foot_note="80323">2</sup>of Allah. Undoubtedly, it is indeed in the remembrance of Allah that hearts find comfort.”

f.80322: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.
f.80323: The Arabic word zhikrcan be translated as ‘remembrance’, ‘reminder’ or ‘mentioning’.

13:29.t: Those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—for them is blessedness and a beautiful place to return to.

13:30.t: Thus We have sent yousgamong a community before which other communities have passed away, that you may read to them what We have revealed to you, while they deny the All-Merciful1. Say, “He is my Lord; there is no god but He; in Him I have placed my trust and to Him is my repentance.”

13:31.t: And even if there had been a Recital<sup foot_note="80325">1</sup>by which mountains were made to move or by which the land was cut up or by which the dead were spoken to…<sup foot_note="80326">2</sup>. Rather, to Allah belongs all command. Have those who have attained faith not yet given up and realized that if Allah wills, He can guide all mankind? And shocking events continue to afflict those who have denied—on account of what they have done—or fall near their home, until Allah’s promise comes true; indeed, Allah never breaks a promise.

f.80325: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.
f.80326: This sentence is left open-ended; according Al-Alousi and other exegetes its predicate is “they would still disbelieve.”

13:32.t: And very truly messengers before you were ridiculed, so I reprieved the deniers then I seized them, so how was My punishment?

13:33.t: Is the One Who is watchful over what every single self has earned…1? Yet they set up associates to Allah. Say, “Nameplthem! Or are you to inform Him as to what He knows not in the earth? Or is it a show of words?” Rather, the scheming of those who have denied has been adorned for them, and theywere barred2from the way. And whomever Allah leads astray, no guide shall there ever be for him.

f.80327: This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Farra’ and other exegetes its predicate is “as any other?”
f.80328: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and they barred (others) from . . .”

13:34.t: For them is a punishment in the Earlier Life, but the punishment of the Hereafter is harsher, for they have no shield from Allah.

13:35.t: The likeness of the Garden promised to those mindful(of God): rivers flow beneath it; its crops are perpetual, and so is its shade. Such is the ultimate outcome for those who were mindful, while the ultimate outcome for the deniers is the Fire.

13:36.t: And those whom We have brought the Scripture rejoice at what was sent down to you, while of the parties are those who reject parts of it. Saysg, “Indeed, I have only been commanded to worship Allah and to never associate(anything)with Him; to Him I call and to Him is my return.”

13:37.t: And thus We have sent it down as an Arabic code of law. Thus, were yousgto follow their whims after the knowledge that has come to you, you would have against Allah1neither guardian nor shield.

13:38.t: And most surely, We have sent messengers before you and We assigned for them spouses and offspring, and never was it for a messenger to come with a sign except by Allah’sbleave. For every term there is a decreed term.

13:39.t: Allah erases whatever He decides and Hekeeps1(whatever He decides), and with Him is the source2of the Scripture.

f.80330: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and He firmly keeps . . .”

13:40.t: Whether We show you some of what We have promised them or take you at death, your duty is indeed mere proclamation, while Ours is the reckoning.

13:41.t: Do they not see how We approach the land, diminishing it from its edges? Thus Allahajudges; nothing can hold back His judgment, and He is Swift in reckoning.

13:42.t: And the ones who came before them had schemed(as well), yet to Allah belongs all scheming; He knows what every single self earns. And thedeniers1will know to whom belongs the Ultimate Dwelling.

f.80332: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “And thedenier will know . . .”

13:43.t: And those who have denied say, “Yousgare not an emissary.” Say, “Sufficient is Allah as a witness between me and you, and so is whoever has the knowledge of the Scripture.”

14:1.t: Alif Lām Ra. A Scripture that We sent down to yousg,that you may bring mankind out from darkness(es)into light—by the leave of their Lord—to the path of the Almighty, the Praiseworthy:

14:2.t: Allah1—the One to Whom belongs whatever isin the heavens and whatever is in the earth. And woe to the deniers from a severe punishment!

f.80333: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “(He is) Allah—the One to whom . . .” Roways read it as such only when he connected signs 1 and 2.

14:3.t: Those who seek the love of the Earlier Life more than the Hereafter, and bar(people)from the way of Allah and seek to make it crooked—those are in extreme misguidance.

14:4.t: And never did We send any messenger but(he spoke)in the tongue of his people, that he may clarify for them. Then Allah leads astray whom He wills and guides whom He wills, for He is the Almighty, the All-Wise.

14:5.t: And very truly We sent Moses with Our signs: “Bring yoursgpeople out of darkness(es)into light and remind them of the Days of Allah1.” Indeed, in that are signs for everyone who is most patient, constantly thankful.”

14:6.t: And recall when Moses said to his people, “Remember Allah’s blessing upon you when He saved you from Pharaoh’s folk: inflicting on you an evil punishment and slaying your sons and keeping your women alive(in bondage). And in that was a great test from your Lord.

14:7.t: And recall when yourplLord proclaimed, ‘If you give thanks, I will indeed increase you; but if you deny, then indeed My punishment is severe.’”

14:8.t: Thus Moses said, “If youpldeny, together with everyone on earth—then Allah is most surely Self-Sufficient, Praiseworthy.”

14:9.t: Has not the tiding of those before youplcome to you—the people of Noah and ʻĀd and Thamûd and those(who came)after them? None know them except Allah. Their messengers came to them with evident proofs, yet they turned back their hands to their mouths1and said, “We surely deny what you have been sent with, and we are indeed in doubt about whatever suspicious(matter)you are calling us to.”

14:10.t: Their messengers said, “Is there any doubt about Allah, the Originator of the heavens and the earth? He calls youplto forgive you your misdeeds and to defer you until(you fulfill)a stated term.” They said, “You are only human beings like us; you want to turn us away from what our forefathers used to worship, so bring us an evident manifestation.”

14:11.t: Their messengers said to them, “We are only human beings like you,but Allah does a favor to whomever He wills of His servants, and in no way could we come up to you with any manifestation except by Allah’s leave. And in Allah let the believers place their trust.

14:12.t: And how can we not place our trust in Allah when He has guided us in our ways? And we will most surely endure patiently whichever way you hurt us. And let anyone who trusts, place his trust in Allah.”

14:13.t: Yet those who denied said to their messengers, “We will most surely evict you from our land unless you return to our creed.” So their Lord revealed to them: “We will most surely annihilate the unjust ones,

14:14.t: and We will most surely settle you in the land after them. That is for whoever stood in fear of My position and in fear of My threat.”

14:15.t: Thus they sought a legislation<sup foot_note="80336">1</sup>, then every stubborn tyrant failed;

f.80336: The Arabic word used is a derivative of the word fateh, which literally means ‘open’; according to Az-Zamakhshari and other exegetes it means ‘open a way for us to distinguish between good and evil’.

14:16.t: beyond him lies Hell, and he is given, for drink, purulent water

14:17.t: which he sips, though he can barely swallow. And death comes at him from everywhere but he is not to die, and beyond him is a harsh punishment.

14:18.t: The parable of those who denied their Lord: their deeds are like ashes on which thewind1blew severely upon a stormy day; they have no control over anything they have earned. That is the extreme misguidance.

f.80337: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “winds ”.

14:19.t: Have you not seen that Allahcreated1the heavens and the earth with the truth2? If He wills, He can do away with youpland bring a new creation.

f.80338: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . that Allah is the Creator of the heavens . . .”
f.80339: According to Ibn ʻAshour and other exegetes, ‘with the truth’ means ‘for a purpose’.

14:20.t: And that is not too mighty for Allah.

14:21.t: And they emerged<sup foot_note="80340">1</sup>before Allah all together. And the weak said to the arrogant leaders, “We were your followers, so can you avail us in any way against Allah’s punishment?” They said, “Had Allah guided us, we would have guided you. It is the same for us: whether we mourn or are patient, there is no escape for us.”

f.80340: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

14:22.t: Thus Satan said, when the matter had been concluded, “Indeed, Allah promised youplthe promise of truth, and I promised you but I failed you. And never did I have any authority over you except that I called you and you responded to me. So do not blame me, but blame yourselves; I cannot come to your aid nor can you come to my aid;(now)I have indeed denied your earlier association of me(with Allah). Indeed, for the unjust is a painful punishment.”

14:23.t: But those who had attained faith and had done righteous deeds were entered into Gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding therein by their Lord’s leave; their greeting therein is: “Peace.”

14:24.t: Have yousgnot seen how Allah has set forth a parable? A good word is like a good tree—its root is firm and its branches are in heaven,

14:25.t: yielding its crop every season by its Lord’s leave. And Allah sets forth parables for mankind, that they may remind themselves.

14:26.t: And the parable of a nasty word is that of a nasty tree that has been uprooted: it has no stability.

14:27.t: Allah gives firmness to those who have attained faith with the firm statement in the Earlier Life and in the Hereafter, and Allah leads the unjustplastray. And Allah does whatever He wills.

14:28.t: Have yousgnot seen those who exchanged the blessing of Allah for denial and landed their people into the home of perdition?

14:29.t: Hell, wherein they roast, and what a miserable settlement!

14:30.t: And they set up rivals to Allah in order tomake(others)stray1from His way. Say, “Enjoy yourselves, for surely your destiny is to the Fire.”

f.80341: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Roways read it as: “. . . in order to stray from His way . . .”

14:31.t: Tell My servants who have attained faith to establish the prayers and to spend from what We have provided them, secretly and publicly, before a day comes in which there is neither trade nor close friendship.

14:32.t: Allah is the One Who created the heavens and the earth and sent down water from the sky, then brought out with it, of the products, provision for youpl; and He has subjected to you the ships to run in the sea by His command, and He has subjected to you the rivers.

14:33.t: And He has subjected to you the sun and the moon, both moving constantly, and He has subjected to you the night and the day.

14:34.t: And He has brought youplof all what you asked Him, and if you were to count Allah’s blessings, you would not be able to enumerate them. Surely, man is constantly unjust, a relentless denier.

14:35.t: And recall when Abraham said, “O my Lord, make this land safe and keep me and my sons away from worshiping human-shaped idols.”

14:36.t: “My Lord, they have indeed led many people astray. So whoever follows me, then surely he is of me; and whoever disobeys me, then You are Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

14:37.t: Our Lord, I have indeed settled of my offspring in a valley devoid of vegetation at Your House which has been made Inviolable, Our Lord, that they may establish the prayers. So make some people’s burning hearts incline towards them, and provide them with products, that they may give thanks.”

14:38.t: “Our Lord, You surely know whatever we hide and whatever we make public. For nothing is hidden from Allah, whether in the earth or in the heaven.”

14:39.t: “Praise be to Allah Who has given me, in my old age, Ishmael and Isaac; my Lord is indeed All-Hearing of supplication.”

14:40.t: “My Lord, make me one who establishes the prayer, and(also)of my offspring. Our1Lord, and accept my supplication.”

f.80342: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

14:41.t: “Our Lord, forgive me and my parents and the believers on the day when the reckoning takes place.”

14:42.t: Dosgnot ever think that Allah is oblivious of what the unjustplare doing. He only defers them to a day when sight(s)glaze over,

14:43.t: as they rush forward with their necks outstretched, their heads upraised, their eyes unblinking and their hearts void.

14:44.t: And warnsgmankind of the day when punishment comes upon them, and the unjustplsay, “Our Lord, defer us for a little while and we will respond to Your call and follow the messengers.” Did youplnot swear earlier that in no way would you face extinction?

14:45.t: And you settled in the residences of those who were unjust to themselves and it became clear to you how We dealt with them, and We set forth for you the parables.

14:46.t: And very truly they had schemed their scheming, yet their scheming is known to Allah, even though their scheming was enough to remove mountains.

14:47.t: So never thinksgthat Allah will break His promise to His messengers. Indeed, Allah is Almighty, Capable of vengeance

14:48.t: on the day when the earth is changed into another earth, as well as the heavens, and they emerged<sup foot_note="80343">1</sup>before Allah, the One, the Subduer.

f.80343: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

14:49.t: And yousgsee the criminals on that day bound together in fetters,

14:50.t: their attires made of tar, and the Fire covering their faces.

14:51.t: That Allah may repay every single self according to what it has earned. Indeed, Allah is Swift in reckoning.

14:52.t: Thisis a proclamation for mankind, and that they may be warned by it, and that they may know that He is one God, and that people of understanding may constantly remember.

15:1.t: Alif Lām Ra. Those are the signs<sup foot_note="80344">1</sup>of the Scripture and an evident Recital<sup foot_note="80345">2</sup>.
