f.80344: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.
f.80345: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

15:2.t: Perhaps those who have denied will wish they had been Muslims.

15:3.t: Letsgthem eat and enjoy and be distracted by(false)hope, for they willcome to know.

15:4.t: For in no way did We annihilate any town except that it had a known written decree.

15:5.t: No community can advance its time, nor can they delay it.

15:6.t: And they said, “O you upon whom the Reminder has been bestowed from on high, very truly you are insane.

15:7.t: If only you would bring us the angels, if you are one of the truthful!”

15:8.t: We bestow1not the angelsfrom on high except with the truth2, and in no way would they3then be respited.

f.80346: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “The angels are not bestowed from on high except with the truth . . .”
f.80347: According to Ibn ʻAshour and other exegetes, ‘with the truth’ means ‘for a purpose’.

15:9.t: Indeed, We—We alone—have bestowed the Reminder from on high, and We will most surely preserve it.

15:10.t: And most surely We sent(messengers)before yousgto the sects of the ancients,

15:11.t: but no messenger comes<sup foot_note="80349">1</sup>to them but they used to ridicule him.

f.80349: Frequently the Qur’an speaks about the prophets using present tense; this should be pondered by the reader.

15:12.t: Thus We insert it<sup foot_note="80350">1</sup>into the hearts of the criminals—

15:13.t: they do not believe in it, though the rule of(God regarding)the ancients has surely passed before.

15:14.t: And if We were to open for them a gateway into the sky so that they were to continue ascending through it,

15:15.t: they would surely say, “Indeed, our sight(s)have beenstupefied1; rather, we are a people bewitched.”

f.80351: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . have been blocked . . .”

15:16.t: And most surely, We have made constellations in the sky and adorned it to the beholders;

15:17.t: and We have preserved it from every outcast devil,

15:18.t: except the one who eavesdrops and is followed by an evident meteor.

15:19.t: And the land—We spread it and cast firm mountains in it, and We germinated therein of everything in proper measure.

15:20.t: And We made livelihoods for youplin it, as well as for those for whom you are not the providers.

15:21.t: For there is not a thing but with Us are its treasuries, yet in no way do We bestow it from on high except in a known measure.

15:22.t: And We sent thewinds1, fertilizing, then sent down water from the sky and gave it to youplto drink, and in no way are you its keepers.

f.80352: Qira’at: Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “wind ”.

15:23.t: And indeed, We—surely, We—give life and cause death, and We are the Inheritors.

15:24.t: And most surely We have known those of you who passed away, and most surely We have known those who come afterwards;

15:25.t: and indeed, it is yoursgLord Who herds them1together; indeed, He is All-Wise, All-Knowing.

15:26.t: And most surely We created man from potter’s clay, of fermented mud,

15:27.t: while We created the unseen being<sup foot_note="80354">1</sup>before from the fire of the searing wind.

f.80354: The Arabic word used is jānn(the singular of jinn) which is an unseen being that is accountable for its actions.

15:28.t: And recall when yoursgLord said to the angels, “I am creating a human being from potter’s clay, of fermented mud.

15:29.t: So when I have formed him and breathed into him of My spirit, fall down to him, prostrating.”

15:30.t: So the angels prostrated themselves, all of them together—

15:31.t: but not Iblis<sup foot_note="80355">1</sup>. He refused to be with those who prostrated themselves.

f.80355: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.

15:32.t: He said, “O Iblise, what keeps you from being with those who prostrate themselves?”

15:33.t: He said, “Never would I prostrate myself to a human being whom You created from potter’s clay, of fermented mud.”

15:34.t: He said, “Then get out of it<sup foot_note="80356">1</sup>, for indeed you are an outcast,

15:35.t: and indeed the curse is upon you until the Day of Recompense.”

15:36.t: He said, “My Lord, then reprieve me until the day they are resurrected.”

15:37.t: He said, “Then, you are indeed of the ones reprieved

15:38.t: until the Day of the Time Appointed.”

15:39.t: He said, “My Lord, since You have deluded me, I will most surely adorn for them(evil deeds)on earth, and I will most surely delude them all,

15:40.t: except for Yoursincere chosen1servants among them.”

f.80357: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . except for Your sincere servants . . .”

15:41.t: He said, “This is a straight pathwhich is binding on Me1:

f.80358: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “This is a high, straight path.”

15:42.t: over My servants yousghave no authority indeed, except for those who follow you of the deluded ones.

15:43.t: And indeed, Hell is the meeting place for them all.

15:44.t: It has seven gates; for each gate is an assigned class.”

15:45.t: Indeed, the mindful(of God)are amid Gardens and springs.

15:47.t: And We removed<sup foot_note="80359">1</sup>whatever malice was within their chests—as brethren, on couches facing each other.

f.80359: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

15:48.t: No fatigue touches<sup foot_note="80360">1</sup>them therein, nor from it will they ever be brought out.

f.80360: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

15:49.t: InformsgMy servants that I—only I—am the Oft-Forgiving, the Bestower of mercy,

15:50.t: and that My punishment is the painful punishment.

15:51.t: And inform them of the guests of Abraham,

15:52.t: when they entered upon him and said, “Peace.” He said, “We are truly scared of you.”

15:53.t: They said, “Do not be scared; we bring yousgglad tidings of a knowledgeable boy.”

15:54.t: He said, “Have you brought me glad tidings when old age has touched me? So what glad tidings couldyou give1?”

f.80361: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . could you give me ?”

15:55.t: They said, “We brought you true glad tidings, so be not of the despairing ones.”

15:56.t: He said, “And who despairs of his Lord’s mercy except for those<sup foot_note="80362">1</sup>astray?”

f.80362: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

15:57.t: He said, “So what is your business, O emissaries?”

15:58.t: They said, “We have been sent to a people of criminals,

15:59.t: except for Lot’s folk; we will most surelydeliver1them all,

f.80363: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . we will most surely save them all . . .”

15:60.t: except for his wife.” We have determined that she will most surely be of those who linger behind.

15:61.t: So when the emissaries came to Lot’s folk,

15:62.t: he said, “You are an unknown people.”

15:63.t: They said, “Rather, we have come to yousgwith that about which they were skeptical,

15:64.t: and we have brought you the truth, and very truly we are truthful.

15:65.t: So journey with your family at the latter part of the night and follow at their rear, and let none of you turn around, and proceedplwherever youplare commanded.”

15:66.t: And We decreed to him that matter: that the last trace of these would be uprooted by the morning.

15:67.t: And the people of the town came anticipating glad tidings.

15:68.t: He said, “Indeed, these are my guests, so do not embarrass me,

15:69.t: and be mindful of Allah and do not disgrace me.”

15:70.t: They said, “Did we not forbid yousgfrom(receiving)any people1?”

f.80364: The Arabic word used is al-alameenwhich means ‘all realms’ or ‘all communities’.

15:71.t: He said, “These are my daughters, if you must.”

15:72.t: By yoursglife, in their drunkenness they certainly do blunder!

15:73.t: So the Shout took them away at sunrise.

15:74.t: And We turned it upside down and rained down upon them stones of hard clay.

15:75.t: Indeed, in that are certainly signs for those who contemplate.

15:76.t: And indeed, it<sup foot_note="80365">1</sup>is certainly on an existing way.

f.80365: The ruins of the cities of the people of Lot.

15:77.t: Indeed, in that is certainly a sign for the believers.

15:78.t: And indeed, the fellows of the Thicket were certainly unjust,

15:79.t: so We took retribution on them, and indeed, both are certainly in an evident archive.

15:80.t: And most surely, the fellows of Al-Hijr<sup foot_note="80366">1</sup>disbelievedthe emissaries.

f.80366: Al-Hijrmeans the stone city which is located in northern Arabia and was inhabited by the people of Thamûd.

15:81.t: So We brought them Our signs, but they used to disregard them.

15:82.t: And of the mountains they used to carve homes, feeling safe.

15:83.t: But the Shout took them away by the morning,

15:84.t: so all what they used to earn was of no avail to them.

15:85.t: And We did not create the heavens and the earth and whatever lies between them except with the truth1. And indeed, the Hour is coming, so pardonsg(with)gracious pardoning.

f.80367: According to Ibn ʻAshour and other exegetes, ‘with the truth’ means ‘for a purpose’.

15:86.t: Indeed, yoursgLord is the One Who is the All-Creating, the All-Knowing.

15:87.t: And most surely, We have brought yousgseven of the oft-repeated1and the great Recital2.

f.80368: The seven signs of the first surah.
f.80369: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

15:88.t: Dosgnot look longingly at the good things We have given some classes of them to enjoy, and do not grieve over them1, and lower your wing2towards the believers.

f.80371: An expression that implies showing compassion.

15:89.t: And say, “Indeed, it is I—I who am the evident warner.”

15:90.t: So too did We send down to those who divide among themselves—

15:91.t: those who have made the Recitalfinto fragments.

15:92.t: So by yoursgLord, We will surely ask them all

15:93.t: about what they used to do.

15:94.t: So proclaimsgopenly what you are commanded and disregard the polytheists.

15:95.t: Indeed, We have sufficed yousgagainst the mockers:

15:96.t: those who set up another god with Allah. So they will come to know.

15:97.t: And most surely We are aware that yoursgchest tightens with what they say.

15:98.t: So exalt your Lord with praise and be of those who prostrate,

15:99.t: and worship your Lord until Certitude<sup foot_note="80372">1</sup>comes to you.

f.80372: According to Salem Ibn ‘Abdullah and other exegetes this means death.

16:1.t: Allah’s command has come, so doplnot rush it. Highly Exalted is He, and Most High above whatthey1associate(with Him).

f.80373: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . what you pl associate . . .”

16:2.t: Hebestows1the angels from on highwith the Spirit by His command upon whom He wills of His servants: “Giveplwarning that there is no god but Me, so be mindful of Me.”

f.80374: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Roways read it as: “He sends down the angels with the Spirit . . .” Rouh read it as: “The angels are bestowed from on high with the Spirit . . .”

16:3.t: He created the heavens and the earth with truth. Most High is He above what they associate(with Him).

16:4.t: He created man from a sperm-drop, yet he becomes an evident adversary!

16:5.t: And livestock—He created them for youpl. In them are warmth and benefits for you, and of them you eat.

16:6.t: And there is beauty in them for you when you drive them home and when you drive them to pasture.

16:7.t: And they carry your heavy burdens to a land you could not have reached without great hardship to yourselves; indeed, your Lord is truly Compassionate, Bestowing of mercy.

16:8.t: And horses and mules and donkeys—that you may ride them, and as an adornment; and He creates what you do not know.

16:9.t: And it is upon Allah to point out the way, but some of them<sup foot_note="80375">1</sup>are crooked. And had He willed, He would surely have guided you all.

16:10.t: It is He Who sent down to you from the sky water from which is a drink for you and from which are trees where you pasture.

16:11.t: With itHegerminates1for you vegetation and olives and date-palms and grapevines and of all products. Indeed, in that is a sign for people who reflect.

f.80376: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “With it We germinate for you . . .”

16:12.t: And He has subjected to you the night and the dayand the sun1and the moon. And the starsare subjected by His command. Indeed, in that are signs for people who reason.

f.80377: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . the night and the day. And the sun and the moon and the stars are subjected . . .” All except for Hafs and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . the night and the day and the sun and the moon and the stars—(all) subjected . . .”

16:13.t: And(He has subjected)whatever He has scattered for you in the earth of varying colors. Indeed, in that is a sign for people who constantly remember.

16:14.t: And He is the One Who subjected the sea, that you may eat from it tender meat and extract from it ornaments that you wear. And you see the ships plowing through it, and(all this)so that you may seek of His bounties, and that you may give thanks.

16:15.t: And He cast firm mountains into the earth lest it sway with you, and rivers and ways, that you may be guided.

16:16.t: And landmarks<sup foot_note="80378">1</sup>, and by the star they are guided.

16:17.t: Is One Who creates like one who does not create? Will younever remind yourselves1?

f.80379: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Will you not constantly remember ?”

16:18.t: And if youplwere to count the blessings of Allah, you would not be able to enumerate them. Indeed, Allah is certainly Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

16:19.t: And Allah knows whatever you keep secret and whatever you make public.

16:20.t: Yet thosethey1call uponapart from Allah create nothing, while they(themselves)are created.

f.80380: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “Yet those you pl call upon . . .”

16:21.t: (They are, in fact)dead, not alive, and they are unaware of when they will be resurrected.

16:22.t: YourplGod is one God. Therefore, those who do not believe in the Hereafter—their hearts are in denial and they act arrogantly.

16:23.t: Without doubt, Allah knows whatever they keep secret and whatever they make public; indeed, He does not like those who act arrogantly.

16:24.t: And when it is said to them, “What has your Lord sent down?” They say, “Legends of the ancients.”

16:25.t: Let them carry their burdens, complete, on the Day of Resurrection, and some of the burdens of those they lead astray without knowledge. Undoubtedly, evil is what they bear.

16:26.t: Those before them did scheme, but Allah struck at the very foundations of their building, so the roof collapsed upon them from above them, and the punishment came upon them from where they were unaware.

16:27.t: Then, on the Day of Resurrection, He disgraces them and says, “Where are My associates for whose sake you used tooppose1(the believers)? Those who were given knowledge said2, “Today disgrace and misery are indeed upon the deniers

f.80381: Qira’at: Nafieʻ read it as: “. . . for whose sake you used to oppose Me ?”
f.80382: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

16:28.t: whom the angels take at death while they are unjust to themselves.” Then they offered submission1: “We were doing no evil.” Yes! Indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of what youplused to do.

16:29.t: Thus enter the gates of Hell, abiding therein.” And how miserable is the dwelling of the arrogant!

16:30.t: And it was said to those who were mindful(of God), “What did your Lord send down?” They said, “(All that is)good.” To those who have excelled in doing good in this Earlier(Life)is goodness, and the Home of the Hereafter is even better. And indeed, how excellent is the home of the people who are mindful(of God):

16:31.t: Gardens of Perpetuity which they enter, beneath which rivers flow; therein they have whatever they desire. Thus Allah rewards the mindfulpl(of Him):

16:32.t: those whom the angels take up(at death)while they are goodly, saying, “Peace be upon you; enter the Garden(of Paradise)on account of what you used to do.”

16:33.t: Are they but waiting for the angels to come to them, or for the command of your Lord to come? Those before them did likewise. And Allah did not do them any injustice, but to themselves they used to do injustice.

16:34.t: So the evils of what they had done afflicted them, and they became surrounded by what they used to ridicule.

16:35.t: And those who had associated(others with Allah)said, “Had Allah willed, we would never have worshiped anything apart from Him—neither us, nor our forefathers, nor would we have prohibited anything without(permission from)Him.” Those before them did likewise. So are the messengers responsible for anything but evident proclamation?

16:36.t: For very truly, in every community We sent a messenger: “WorshipplAllah and avoid false masters.” So some of them Allah has guided, and some of them have deserved misguidance. So journey1through the earth and look what the outcome was for the disbelievers.

16:37.t: (Even)if yousgare concerned about their guidance,(still)Allah surely does not guide whomever He leads1astray, and they will have no helpers.

f.80385: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . (still) whomever Allah leads astray surely cannot be guided . . .”

16:38.t: And they have sworn by Allah their most solemn oaths that Allah does not resurrect whoever dies. Yes indeed, it is a promise binding on Him, but the majority of mankind does not know.

16:39.t: (This is)to clarify for them what they differ over, and so that those who have denied know that they were liars.

16:40.t: Indeed, Our only saying to anything, once We have wanted it, is to say to it,“Be,” and so it is1.

f.80386: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . is to say to it, ‘Be,’ so it is.”

16:41.t: And those who emigrated for Allah after they had been dealt with unjustly—We will surely settle them in a good place in the Earlier(Life), and the reward of the Hereafter is truly greater, if they only knew.

16:42.t: Those are the ones who endured patiently, and in their Lord they place<sup foot_note="80387">1</sup>their trust.

f.80387: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

16:43.t: And never did We send as messengers before yousgexcept men to whomWe reveal1. So askplthe people of the Reminder if you do not know.

f.80388: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . to whom it is revealed .”

16:44.t: (We sent them)with evident proofs and books. And We sent down to yousgthe Reminder, that you may clarify to mankind what was bestowed upon them from on high, and that they may reflect.

16:45.t: Do those who have schemed evils feel secure that Allah will not cause the earth to cave in beneath them, or that the punishment will not come upon them from where they are unaware?

16:46.t: Or that He will not seize them(suddenly)during their movement so that they cannot thwart(Him)?

16:47.t: Or that He will not seize them gradually? Yet indeed, your Lord is truly Compassionate, Bestowing of mercy.

16:48.t: Havethey1not seenall things that Allah has created—their shadows revolving from the right and the left, prostrating to Allah as they shrink away?

f.80389: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Have you pl not seen . . .”

16:49.t: And to Allah prostrates whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth of every treading creature, as well as the angels, and they do not act arrogantly—

16:50.t: fearing their Lord above them and doing whatever they are commanded.

16:51.t: And Allah has said: “Doplnot take two gods; He is but One God, so of Me1alone be in awe.”

16:52.t: And to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and the earth, and religion is His forever. Are you then mindful of anyone other than Allah?

16:53.t: And whatever blessing youplhave is from Allah, then when harm touches you, it is to Him that you cry for help.

16:54.t: Then when He lifts off harm from you, a group of you associate(others)with their Lord,

16:55.t: so as to deny what We have given them. So enjoy yourselves, for you will come to know.

16:56.t: And they set up to what they do not know a share of what We have provided for them. By Allah, you1will surely be asked about what youplused to fabricate.

16:57.t: And they set up to Allah daughters—Highly Exalted is He—and unto themselves whatever they desire.

16:58.t: But when one of them is given the glad tidings1of a female(infant), his countenance remains darkened as he suppresses his anguish.

16:59.t: He hides himself from people because of the evilness of the glad tidings he has been given. Should he keep it, in shame, or bury it(alive)in the dust? Undoubtedly, evil is the way they judge!

16:60.t: For those who do not believe in the Hereafter is an evil example, while to Allah belongs the highest example. And He is the Almighty, the All-Wise.

16:61.t: And if Allah were to hold mankind for their injustices, He would not leave upon it a single treading creature, but He defers them to a stated term. Then, when their term has arrived<sup foot_note="80393">1</sup>, they cannot delay it by one hour nor can they advance it.

16:62.t: And they set up for Allah what they themselves hate, while their tongues describe the lie that theirs is the best(reward); without doubt, for them is the Fire and(without doubt)they will be driven to it quickly1.

f.80394: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . for them is the Fire and (without doubt) they have been neglecting (their tasks) ”.Nafie read it as: “. . . for them is the Fire and (without doubt) they have gone too far .”

16:63.t: (I swear )by Allah, We sent messengers to communities before yousg, but Satan adorned their deeds for them, so that he is their master today, and they will have a painful punishment.

16:64.t: And We have not sent down to yousgthe Scripture but that you may clarify for them what they have differed over, and as a guidance and a mercy for people who believe.

16:65.t: And Allah has sent down, from the sky, water with which He revived the earth after it was lifeless; indeed, in this is a sign for people who hear.

16:66.t: And indeed, there is a lesson for youplin livestock:We1give you to drinkof what is in their bellies—from between filth and blood—pure milk, palatable to the drinkers.

f.80395: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . livestock: they give you to drink . . .”

16:67.t: And from the products of date-palms and grapevines you make an intoxicating beverage and good food. Surely, in that is a sign for people who reason.

16:68.t: And yoursgLord revealed to the bee: “Take for yourselfsghomes of the mountains, and of the trees and of whatever they trellis,

16:69.t: then eat of all products and go along the ways of your Lord, made smooth”. From their bellies comes out a drink of diverse colors, wherein is a cure for mankind. Surely, in that is a sign for people who reflect.

16:70.t: And Allah created youpl, then He takes you(at death). Yet among you is the one who is turned back to the most abject age, so that he no longer knows anything after having acquired knowledge; indeed, Allah is All-Knowing, All-Powerful.

16:71.t: And Allah has favored some of you over others in provision, yet those who were favored do not give their provision to those whom they rightfully possess, to the extent of making them equal partners in it. Dothey1then repudiatethe blessing of Allah?

f.80396: Qira’at: Shuʻba and Roways read it as: “Do you pl then repudiate . . .”

16:72.t: And Allah has set up for you spouses from among yourselves, and has assigned for you from your spouses, children and grandchildren, and has provided you with good things. Yet is it in falsehood that they<sup foot_note="80397">1</sup>believe, while it is the blessing of Allah that they deny?

16:73.t: And yet they worship apart from Allah what possesses no provisions for them in the heavens or the earth, nor are they capable(of doing anything).

16:74.t: So doplnot set forth any parables for Allah; indeed, Allah knows and you know not.

16:75.t: Allah set forth a parable: an owned bondman who has no power over anything, and(on the other hand)someone to whom We1have given goodly provision from which he gives, secretly and openly. Can they be equal? All praise be to Allah; rather, most of them know not.

16:76.t: And Allah set forth a parable of two men: one of them a mute who has no power over anything, and he is wholly dependent upon his patron; wherever he directs him, he achieves nothing good. Can he be equal to one who commands to justice and is on a straight path?

16:77.t: And to Allah belongs the hidden realm of the heavens and the earth, and the matter of the Hour is only as the twinkling of the eye or even nearer; indeed, Allah is Powerful over everything.

16:78.t: And Allah brought youplout of your mothers’ bellies not knowing anything, and He assigned for you hearing and sight(s)and burning hearts, that you may give thanks.

16:79.t: Havethey1not seenthe birds subjected in the midst of the sky? None holds them up except Allah. Surely, in that are signs for people who believe.

f.80399: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer, Hamza, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “Have you pl not seen . . .”

16:80.t: And Allah has made for you, of your houses,(places of)rest and has assigned for you out of the skins of livestock(portable)homes which you find light on the day you travel and on the day you encamp and, from their wool and fur and hair, furnishings and an enjoyment for a while.

16:81.t: And Allah has made for youpl shades out of what He created, and has made for you shelters of the mountains, and has made for you garments to protect you from the heat and garments to protect you from your violence; thus He completes His blessings upon you, that you may submit.

16:82.t: So if they1turn away, then certainly yoursgonly duty is evident proclamation.

16:83.t: They recognize Allah’s blessing then they deny it, as most of them are the deniers.

16:84.t: And on the day when We raise up a witness from every community —then those who denied are not permitted, nor are they allowed to make amends.

16:85.t: And when those who did injustice see the punishment,(they will realize that)never shall it be lightened for them, nor shall they be given respite.

16:86.t: And when the ones who associated(others with God)see their associates1, they will say, “Our Lord, these are our associates whom we used to call upon apart from You.” So they cast2to them the statement, “Very truly, you are liars.”

f.80402: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

16:87.t: And they cast forth to Allah, on that day,(their)submissiveness, and whatever they used to fabricate strayed away from them.

16:88.t: Those who denied and barred from the way of Allah—We<sup foot_note="80403">1</sup>added punishment to their punishment on account of the corruption they used to cause.

16:89.t: And on a day when We raise in every community a witness against them from among them, and We broughtcyousgas a witness against these. For We have bestowed upon you the Scripture from on high, as an explanation of everything and guidance and mercy and glad tidings for the Muslims1.

f.80404: The Arabic word used is Muslimeenwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

16:90.t: Indeed, Allah commands to justice and excelling in doing good and bringing1(charity)to the relative, and He forbids obscenity and what is deplorable and oppression. He admonishes you, that you mayremind yourselves2.

f.80405: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.
f.80406: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . that you may constantly remember .”

16:91.t: And fulfillplAllah’s covenant when you make a covenant, and do not violate your oaths after ratifying them, for surely you have made Allah your guarantor; indeed, Allah knows what you do.

16:92.t: And doplnot be like she who unravels her yarn, breaking it into pieces after she has spun it strongly, by using your oaths as a means of deception among you because one community is more prosperous than another community. Indeed, Allah is testing you thereby, and He will most surely clarify to you on the Day of Resurrection whatever you used to differ over.

16:93.t: And had Allah willed, He would have made you one community, but He leads astray whom He wills, and He guides whom He wills, and you will most surely be asked about what you used to do.

16:94.t: And do not use your oaths as a means of deception among you, lest a foot slip after being firm and you taste misery for barring(others)from the way of Allah, and for you there will be a great punishment.

16:95.t: And doplnot purchase, in exchange for Allah’s covenant, a small price; indeed, what is with Allah is better for you, if you only knew.

16:96.t: What you have runs out, but what is with Allah remains. AndWe1will most surely repaythose who were patient their reward in accordance with the best of what they used to do.

f.80407: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, ʻAsem, Abu Jaʻfar and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “And He will most surely repay . . .”

16:97.t: Whoever has acted righteously, whether male or female, while being a believer—We will most surely grant him a good life, and We will most surely repay them<sup foot_note="80408">1</sup>their reward in accordance with the best of what they used to do.

f.80408: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

16:98.t: So when yousgrecite the Recital1seek refuge with Allah from Satan, the outcast.

f.80409: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

16:99.t: Indeed, he has no authority over those who have attained faith and in their Lord they place their trust.

16:100.t: Indeed, his authority is only over those who take him as an ally and those who through him associate(others with God).

16:101.t: Yet whenever We substitute a sign in place of another sign—and Allah1knows better what Hebestows from on high2—they say, “Indeed, you are nothing but a fabricator.” Rather, most of them do not know.

f.80411: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . what He sends down . . .”

16:102.t: Say, The Holy Spirit has bestowed it from on high from yoursgLord1, with the truth, in order to strengthen those who have attained faith, and as guidance and glad tidings for Muslims2.

f.80413: The Arabic word used is Muslimeenwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

16:103.t: And most surely, We know that they say, “Indeed, it is a human being who is teaching him.” But the tongue of the one they allude to is foreign, while this is an evident Arabic tongue.

16:104.t: Indeed, those who do not believe in Allah’s signs—Allah does not guide them, and for them is a painful punishment.

16:105.t: Indeed, it is those who do not believe in Allah’s signs who fabricate falsehood, and those are the liars.

16:106.t: Whoever has denied Allah after attaining faith—except for someone who was compelled1while his heart rests securely in faith, but(rather)whoever(willingly)opens a chest to denial—upon them is wrath from Allah, and for them is a great punishment.

f.80414: God excuses anyone who is compelled to renounce his/her faith.

16:107.t: That is because they have sought the love of the Earlier Life over the Hereafter, and because Allah does not guide the denying people.

16:108.t: Those are the ones whose hearts and hearing and sight(s)Allah has sealed, and those arethe oblivious ones.

16:109.t: Without doubt, in the Hereafter they are the losers.

16:110.t: Then surely yoursgLord—for those who emigrated after being persecuted, then strove and patiently persevered—indeed, your Lord thereafter is surely Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

16:111.t: On the day when every single self comes arguing for itself, and every soul is paid in full(for)what it has done, and they are not done any injustice.

16:112.t: And Allah set forth a parable: a town that was safe(and)secure, its provision coming to it abundantly from everywhere. Yet it denied Allah’s blessings, so Allah made it taste the garment of hunger and fear on account of what they used to do.

16:113.t: And very truly, a messenger from among them had come to them, but they disbelieved him, so the punishment seized them while they were unjust.

16:114.t: So eatplof the lawful and good things Allah has provided for you, and be thankful for Allah’s blessing, if it is Him that you worship.

16:115.t: Indeed, He has only forbidden youplcarrion and blood and the flesh of swine and anything consecrated to other than Allah; but if anyone is compelled by necessity without being deliberate or transgressing, then Allah is indeed Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

16:116.t: And do not say lies concerning that which your tongues describe: “This is lawful and this is unlawful,” in order to fabricate lies and attribute them to Allah; indeed, those who fabricate lies and attribute them to Allah do not succeed.

16:117.t: A brief enjoyment, then for them is a painful punishment.

16:118.t: And for the ones who Judaized We have prohibited what We related to yousgbefore, and in no way did We do them any injustice, but to themselves they used to do injustice.

16:119.t: But indeed yoursgLord, towards those who did evil in ignorance and then repented afterwards and reformed—indeed, yoursgLord thereafter is surely Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

16:120.t: Indeed, Abraham was a nation, devout towards Allah, turning away from all that is false, for never was he of the polytheists.

16:121.t: (He was)thankful for His blessings. He elected him and guided him to a straight path.

16:122.t: And We1brought him goodness in the Earlier(Life), and in the Hereafter he is surely of the righteous.

16:123.t: Then We revealed to yousg: “Followsgthe creed of Abraham, who turned away from all that is false, for never was he of the polytheists.”

16:124.t: Indeed, the Sabbath was ordained upon those who differed over it. And most surely, yoursgLord will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection regarding whatever they used to differ over.

16:125.t: Callsgto the way of your Lord with wisdom and good admonition, and debate with them by that which is better. Indeed, it is your Lord Who knows better of those who stray from His way, and it is He Who knows better of those who are guided.

16:126.t: And if youplpunish, then punish with the like of that with which you were punished. But if you resort to patience, it is surely better for the patient ones.

16:127.t: So be patientsg, for your patience is solely from Allah. And do not grieve over them and do not be distressed because of what they scheme.

16:128.t: Indeed, Allah is with those who are mindful(of Him)and those who excel in doing good.

17:1.t: Highly Exalted is the One Who took His servant on a journey by night from the Inviolable Mosque1to the Farthest Mosque2, whose precincts Weahave blessed, in order to show him of Our signs; indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing.

17:2.t: And We brought Moses the Scripture and made it guidance for the Children of Israel: “Take1none for trustee other than Me,

f.80418: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . for the Children of Israel, that they may take none for trustee other than Me.

17:3.t: (O)offspring of those We carried with Noah; indeed, he was a constantly thankful servant.”

17:4.t: And We decreed for the Children of Israel in the Scripture: “You will most surely corrupt in the land twice, and you will most surely rise to a great height.

17:5.t: Then when the promise of the first of the two times came true, We sent against youplservants of Ours possessing intense force, and they ransacked the homes, and it was a promise fulfilled.”

17:6.t: Then We gave youplback your turn against them and supplied you with wealth and offspring and made you more numerous.

17:7.t: If you excel in doing good, you excel in doing good to your own benefit; and if you do evil, you do so against yourselves. Then when the promise of the second time comes true,they1will defileyour faces, and they will enter the Mosque as they entered it the first time, and they will utterly destroy all that falls into their power.

f.80419: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer, Shuʻba, Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “. . . He will defile . . .” Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . We will defile . . .”

17:8.t: Hopefully yourplLord will have mercy on you. But if you revert, We1will revert. And We have made Hell a prison for the deniers.

17:9.t: Indeed, this Recital<sup foot_note="80421">1</sup>guides to what is most upright and gives glad tidings to the believers who do righteous deeds that for them there is a supreme reward,

f.80421: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

17:10.t: and that those who do not believe in the Hereafter—We have prepared for them a painful punishment.

17:11.t: And man calls for evil as he calls for good, and man has always been very hasty.

17:12.t: And We have made the night and the day as two signs, then We erased the sign of the night and made the sign of the day as an eye-opener, that youplmay seek grace from your Lord1and that you may learn the number of years and the calculation; and everything have We explained in detail.

17:13.t: And for every person We have attached his augury to his neck, and on the Day of ResurrectionWe will bring out for him a record1which he will find spread open2.

f.80424: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and on the Day of Resurrection a record, which he will receive spread open, is brought out for him .”Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and on the Day of Resurrection a record, which he will find spread open, comes out for him .”Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . and on the Day of Resurrection We will bring out for him a record which he will receive spread open.”

17:14.t: “Recitesgyour record; today your own self is sufficient as a reckoner.”

17:15.t: Whoever is guided—he is only guided to his own benefit, while whoever goes astray—he goes astray to his own detriment. And no bearer of burden carries the burden of another, for never do We punish until We have sent a messenger.

17:16.t: And when We want to annihilate a town Wecommand1its affluent ones(to be righteous), yet they defiantly disobey(Our commands)in it, so it deserves the decree and We annihilate it completely.

f.80425: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . We make its affluent ones in command , yet they . . .”

17:17.t: And how many generations have We annihilated after Noah? Thus sufficient is your Lord<sup foot_note="80426">1</sup>as All-Aware, All-Seeing of the misdeeds of His servants.

17:18.t: Whoever has been wanting the hasty(life of this world)—We hasten for him therein whatever We will to whomever We desire. Then We assigned1for him Hell where he roasts, condemned, defeated.

f.80427: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

17:19.t: But whoever wanted the Hereafter and, as a believer, pursued it as it should be pursued, those—their pursuit has always been thanked.

17:20.t: To all—these and these(as well)—We extend from the gifts of yoursgLordb, for the gifts of your Lord have never been restricted.

17:21.t: Looksgat how We have favored some of them over others, yet the Hereafter is more superior in degrees(of rank)and more superior in preference.

17:22.t: Dosgnot set up another god with Allah, lest you remain condemned,damned.

17:23.t: And yoursgLord has decreed that youplshall worship none but Him, and(He has decreed)excelling in doing good to both parents. If either of them or both of them reach old age with yousg, then do not say to them “Fie” nor scold them, but speak to them using noble words.

17:24.t: And lower to them the wing<sup foot_note="80428">1</sup>of humility, out of mercy, and say, “My Lord, have mercy on both of them as they raised me when I was a child.”

f.80428: An expression that implies showing compassion.

17:25.t: YourplLord knows better what is within yourselves. If you are righteous—indeed, He has always been Oft-Forgiving to the ones who often turn(to Him).

17:26.t: And givesgthe relative his rights, and the destitutesgand the traveler in need, and do not squander wastefully.

17:27.t: Indeed, the squanderers have always been brethren of the Satans, for Satan has always been a staunch denier of his Lord.

17:28.t: But if yousgdisregard them, seeking mercy1which you expect from your Lord, then speak to them using gentle words.

17:29.t: And do not keep your hand tied to your neck<sup foot_note="80430">1</sup>nor spread it out fully, lest you end up blamed, regretful.

17:30.t: Indeed, your Lord extends provision for whomever He wills and He restrains(it); indeed, He has always been All-Aware, All-Seeing of His servants.

17:31.t: And doplnot kill your children for fear of poverty; We provide for them and for youpl. Indeed, killing them has always been a grave offense.

17:32.t: And doplnot come near fornication; indeed, it is an obscenity and an evil way.

17:33.t: And doplnot kill the self which Allah has made inviolable, except in the course of justice. And if someone is killed unjustly, We have given authority to his kinsman who seeks retribution, buthe1should not be excessivein killing; indeed, he is bound to be aided.

f.80431: Qira’at: Hamza, Al Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . but you sg should not be excessive . . .”

17:34.t: And doplnot come near the orphan’s wealth except with that which is better(for him), until he has attained his full strength. And fulfill every covenant; indeed, the covenant has always been a responsibility.

17:35.t: And giveplfull measure when you measure, and weigh with accurate scales; that is fair and the best determination.

17:36.t: And dosgnot follow what you have no knowledge of; indeed, the hearing and the sight and the burning heart—all of those—(one)is bound to be questioned about.

17:37.t: And dosgnot walk merrily on earth; yousgwill surely not pierce the earth, nor will you match the mountains in height.

17:38.t: All of that—its evil has always been1disliked by your Lord.

f.80432: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “All of thathas always been an evil deed before your sg Lord (and) disliked .”

17:39.t: That is some of the wisdom yoursgLord has revealed to you. And do not set up with Allah another god, lest you be thrown in Hell, blamed, banished.

17:40.t: Has yourplLord favored you with sons and taken for Himself from the angels females? Youplare certainly saying a great1saying.

f.80433: The Arabic word azeemis sometimes used with a negative connotation to denote the seriousness of a matter.

17:41.t: And very truly, We have explained in this Recital1in various ways, that they mayconstantly remember2, but it only adds to their aversion.

f.80434: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.
f.80435: Qira’at: Hamza, Al Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . that they may remember . . .”

17:42.t: Saysg, “If there were other gods with Him asthey1say, they would have sought a way to the Possessor of the Throne.”

f.80436: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir and Hafs read it as: “. . . as you pl say . . .”

17:43.t: Highly Exalted is He. He is Most High, far above what they say.

17:44.t: Exalting Him are the seven heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And there is not a thing that does not exalt Him with praise, but youpldo not comprehend their exaltation. Indeed, He has always been Forbearing, Oft-Forgiving.

17:45.t: And when yousgrecite the Recital1, We place between you and those who do not believe in the Hereafter an invisible barrier.

f.80437: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

17:46.t: And We have placed veils over their hearts preventing them from comprehending it, and heaviness in their ears. And when you mention your Lord1alone in the Recitala, they turn their backs in aversion.

17:47.t: We know better what(intention)it is that they listen with as they listen to you and as they secretly converse, as the unjust say, “Youplare following nothing but a man bewitched.”

17:48.t: Looksgat how they have set forth parables for yousgand gone astray, so they cannot find a way.

17:49.t: And they said, “Can it be thatwhen we have become bones and fragments—can it be that1we will really be resurrected as a new creation?”

f.80439: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “Can it be that when we have become bones and fragments we will really . . .” Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “When we have become bones and fragments—can it be that we will really . . .”

17:50.t: Saysg,“Becomeplrocks or iron

17:51.t: or any sort of creation which is greatly admired in yourplchests.” Then they will say, “Who will restore us?” Saysg, “The One Who originated youplthe first time.” Then they will nod their heads at yousgand say, “When will it be?” Say, “Hopefully, it will be soon,

17:52.t: on the day when He calls youpl, then you respond with His praise and you think that you stayed only a little.”

17:53.t: And tellsgMy servants to say what is better. Indeed, Satan spurs(discord)between them; indeed, Satan has always been, to man, an evident enemy.

17:54.t: YourplLord knows better about you. If He wills, He bestows mercy on you; and if He wills, He punishes you. Thus We never sent yousgas a trustee over them.

17:55.t: And yoursgLord knows better about whoever is in the heavens and the earth. And We1have most surely favored some prophets over others, and to David We gave a Book2.

17:56.t: Say, “Call upon those you claimed apart from Him. But they have no power to lift off harm from you, nor can they change it.”

17:57.t: Those whom they call upon are themselves seeking means of access to their Lord—whichever of them will be nearer—and hoping for His mercy and fearing His punishment; indeed, the punishment of your Lord has always been dreaded.

17:58.t: So there is no town but We are to annihilate it before the Day of Resurrection or punish it with a severe punishment; this has been inscribed in the Scripture.

17:59.t: And nothing prevented Us from sending(miraculous)signs except that the ancients disbelieved in them. So We gave Thamûd1the she-camel as an eye-opener, but they mistreated it. For We never send signs except to frighten(people of destruction).

f.80442: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

17:60.t: And recall when We said to yousgthat your Lord1has encompassed mankind. And We did not make the vision We showed you except as a means of trial for mankind, and(recall)the tree which is cursed in the Recital2. And We frighten them, but that increases them in nothing but supreme transgression.

f.80444: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

17:61.t: And recall when We said to the angels, “Prostrate to Adam,” so they prostrated—but not Iblis<sup foot_note="80445">1</sup>. He said, “Shall I prostrate down to someone You created of clay?”

f.80445: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.

17:62.t: He said, “Do You see this one whom You have honored more than me? If You reprieve me until the Day of Resurrection, I will most surely bridle his offspring, except for a few.”

17:63.t: He said, “Go! Whoever of them follows you—then indeed, Hell is yourplrepayment, an ample repayment.

17:64.t: And entice whomever of them youcan with your voice, and rally against them your cavalry and your infantry, and share with them in wealth and children, and promise them.” But Satan promises them nothing but a deception.

17:65.t: “You surely have no authority over My servants.” And sufficient is your Lord as a trustee.

17:66.t: YourplLord is the One Who propels for you the ships at sea, that you may seek of His grace; indeed, to you He has always been Merciful.

17:67.t: And when harm touches youplat sea,(all)those you call upon become lost except for Him. But when He delivered1you to the shore, you disregarded(Him); thus man has always been a staunch denier.

f.80446: A grammatical shift from present tense to past tense.

17:68.t: Are youplconfident thatHe1will not cause a side of the shore to collapsebeneath you or unleash a tornado against you, and then you find no trustee?

f.80447: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . that We will not cause a side of the shore to collapse . . .”

17:69.t: Or are youplconfident thatHe1will not return youto it once again and unleash a hurricane ofwind2against youanddrown3you for your denial, and then you find no attending followers against Us?

f.80449: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “winds ”.
f.80450: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar and Roways read it as: “. . . against you which then drowns you . . .”
f.80448: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . that We will not return you to it once again and unleash . . .”

17:70.t: Yet very truly We have honored the Children of Adam and carried them on land and sea and provided them with good things and greatly favored them over many of those We have created.

17:71.t: On the day when We call every group of people by their leader, then whoever is given his record<sup foot_note="80451">1</sup>in his right hand—those will read their record, and they will not be dealt with unjustly by as much as the hair upon a date-stone.

17:72.t: But whoever is blind in this(life)—he will be blind in the Hereafter and further astray from the way.

17:73.t: And they almost lured yousgaway from what We have revealed to you so that you would fabricate something else in Our name, and in that case they would have taken you for a close friend.

17:74.t: Had We not given yousgstability, you were about to incline towards them a little.

17:75.t: Then We would have made yousgtaste double in life and double at death, then you would have found for yourself no supporter against Us.

17:76.t: They almost provoked yousgso as to evict you from the land, and in that case they would not have lasted after you except briefly;

17:77.t: such has been Our rule with the messengers We have sent before you, and you never find any change in Our rule.

17:78.t: Establishsgthe prayer at the decline of the sun until the dusk of the night, as well as the Recitation1at dawn; indeed, Recitation at dawn has always been witnessed.

f.80452: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

17:79.t: And keep vigil with it during parts of the night as an extra(deed); hopefully yoursgLord will raise you to a laudable position.

17:80.t: And saysg, “My Lord, let me enter through an entry of truth and let me exit through an exit of truth and grant me from You a supporting manifestation.”

17:81.t: And saysg, “Truth has come while falsehood has withered away; indeed, falsehood is bound to wither away.”

17:82.t: And Webestow from on high1of the Recitaldthat which is a healing and a mercy for the believers, but it does not increase the unjust except in loss.

f.80453: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “And We send down of the Recital that which . . .”

17:83.t: And when We bless man, he disregards(Us)anddistances himself1. But when evil touches him, he staunchly despairs.

f.80454: Qira’at: Ibn Zekwan and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and turns his back (literally ‘his side’).”

17:84.t: Say, “Each does according to his disposition, but yourplLord knows better of the one who is more guided to the way.”

17:85.t: And they ask yousgabout the Spirit; say, “The Spirit is by the command of my Lord, and youplwere not given of knowledge but little.”

17:86.t: And if We will, we can surely take away what We have revealed to yousg, then you would find for yourself no trustee against Us—

17:87.t: except through a mercy from your Lord<sup foot_note="80455">1</sup>; indeed, His grace upon you has been supreme.

17:88.t: Say, “Most surely, if all humans and all unseen beings<sup foot_note="80456">1</sup>were to come together to bring forth the like of this Recital<sup foot_note="80457">2</sup>, they could never bring forth the like of it, even if they backed up one another.”

f.80456: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.
f.80457: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

17:89.t: And most surely, We have diversified for mankind in this Recitalcevery kind of parable, but most of mankind refused anything but constant denial.

17:90.t: And they said, “We will not believe in yousguntil you make a spring gush forth from the ground for us;

17:91.t: or possess a garden of palms and vines, then cause rivers to gush forth, pouring through them;

17:92.t: or make the sky fall on us in pieces, as you claimed; or bring Allah and the angels before us;

17:93.t: or possess a house of gold; or ascend into the sky. Even then, we will not believe in your ascension until youbestowupon usfrom on high1a scripture that we can read.” Say, “Highly Exalted is my Lord. Have I been anything except a human messenger?”

f.80458: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . until you send down upon us a scripture that we can read.”

17:94.t: And what prevented mankind from believing when guidance came to them, except that they said, “Did Allah send a human messenger?”

17:95.t: Say1, “If there were angels on earth walking around in peace, We would have bestowed upon them from heaven an angel messenger.”

f.80459: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “He said . . .”

17:96.t: Say, “Allah is an adequate witness between you and me; indeed, He has always been All-Aware, All-Seeing of His servants.”

17:97.t: And whomever Allah guides is the guided one, and whomever He leads astray—for them<sup foot_note="80460">1</sup>you will find no guardians apart from Him, and We will herd them on the Day of Resurrection on their faces, blind and dumb and deaf; their shelter is Hell; whenever it abates, We intensify the blaze for them.

f.80460: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

17:98.t: That is their repayment for having denied Our signs and for having said, “Can it be thatwhen we have become bones and fragments—can it be that1we will really be resurrected as a new creation?”

f.80461: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “Can it be that when we have become bones and fragments we will really . . .” Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “When we have become bones and fragments—can it be that we will really . . .”

17:99.t: Have they not seen that Allah, Who created the heavens and the earth, is Able to create the likes of them? And He has assigned for them a term in which there is no doubt. But the unjust refused anything but constant denial.

17:100.t: Say, “If youplwere to possess the treasuries of my Lord’s mercy, you would withhold them for fear of spending(them).” And man has always been stingy.

17:101.t: And very truly We gave Moses nine evident signs, so ask the Children of Israel about when he went to them, then Pharaoh said to him, “Indeed, I think that you, O Moses, are bewitched.”

17:102.t: He said, “Yousghave1most surely knownthat nonesent these down except the Lord of the heavens and the earth,(as)insights. And indeed I think that you, O Pharaoh, are doomed to demise.”

f.80462: Qira’at: Al Kesa’i read it as: “He said, ‘I have most surely known . . .’”

17:103.t: So he wanted to provoke them to leave the land, but We drowned him and those with him, all together.

17:104.t: And after him, We said to the Children of Israel, “Settle in the land; yet when the promise of the Hereafter comes, We will bring you forth in a mixed multitude.”

17:105.t: And with the truth We sent it down, and with the truth it descended. Thus We have not sent you but as a bearer of glad tidings and as a warner.

17:106.t: And a Recital1which We apportioned, that yousgmay recite it to mankind leisurely. And We surely bestowed it from on high.

f.80463: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

17:107.t: Saysg, “Believe in it or do not believe.” Indeed, those who were brought knowledge before it—when it is recited to them, they fall to their chins, prostrating.

17:108.t: And they say, “Highly Exalted is our Lord. The promise of our Lord is sure to be fulfilled.”

17:109.t: And they fall to their chins weeping, and it adds to their humility.

17:110.t: Saysg, “Call upon Allah or call upon the All-Merciful; whichever you call upon, to Him belong the most beautiful names.” And be neither loud in your prayer nor silent in it, but follow a way in between.

17:111.t: And saysg, “All praise be to Allah, Who has not taken any offspring(for Himself), nor has He ever had an associate in the dominion, nor has He ever had an ally out of humbleness. And glorify Him constantly.”

18:1.t: All praise be to Allah, Who sent down the Scripture upon His servant and has not made therein any crookedness;

18:2.t: most upright, to warn of a severe chastisement from Himself, and(to)give glad tidings to the believers who do righteous deeds that for them is an excellent reward,

18:4.t: and(to)warn those who have said, “Allah has taken(for Himself)offspring.”

18:5.t: They have no knowledge of it, nor did their forefathers; massive is the word that comes out of their mouths! They say nothing but a lie!

18:6.t: So perhaps yousgwould decimate yourself, sorrowing after them, if they do not believe in this discourse.

18:7.t: Indeed, We have made whatever is on earth as an ornament for it, to test them as to which of them excels in work.

18:8.t: And indeed, We will turn what is on it into barren soil.

18:9.t: Or did yousgthink that the fellows of the cave and the Inscription1were among Our signs a wonder?

18:10.t: Recall when the young men took shelter in the cave, then said, “Our Lord, bring us mercy from Yourself and furnish us with prudence in our affair.”

18:11.t: So We drew(a seal)upon their ears in the cave for a number of years.

18:12.t: Then We resurrected them to know which of the two parties could better enumerate the length of their stay.

18:13.t: We relate to yousgtheir story in truth; they are indeed young men who believed in their Lord and We increased them in guidance.

18:14.t: And We strengthened their hearts when they stood up and said, “Our Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth; we will never call upon any god apart from Him; most surely then we would have spoken untruthfully.

18:15.t: These, our people, have taken for themselves gods apart from Him. If only they would come forth with a clear manifestation of them. So who is more unjust than one who fabricated lies against Allah?”

18:16.t: Now that youplhave withdrawn from them and from whatever they worship but Allah, take shelter in the cave, and your Lord will unfold His mercy for you and will set your affair towards ease.”

18:17.t: And yousgsee1the sun when it rises, veering away from their cave towards the right, and when it sets, moving away from them to the left as they lie in a hollow therein; that is of Allah’s signs. Whomever Allah guides is the(truly)guided one, but whomever He leads astray—for him yousgwill find no guiding guardian.

f.80465: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of past events.

18:18.t: And yousgthink them awake, although they are asleep. And We turn them over to the right and to the left, with their dog stretching its paws across the threshold. Had you looked at them, you would surely have turned away from them in flight and been filled with fear of them.

18:19.t: And thus We made them rise again so that they may ask one another. A speaker among them said, “How long have youplstayed?” They said, “We have stayed a day or part of a day.” They said, “YourplLord knows better how long you have stayed. So send one of you to the city with this silver(coin)of yours and let him look for whichever of them has the purest food and let him bring you some provision thereof. And let him go with discretion so that no one becomes aware of you.

18:20.t: If they prevail over youpl, they will surely either stone you or force you back into their creed, and then you would never succeed, ever.”

18:21.t: And thus We caused them to be discovered, that they<sup foot_note="80466">1</sup>would know that the promise of Allah<sup foot_note="80467">2</sup>is true and that of the Hour there is no doubt. As they were disagreeing with each other about their affair, they said, “Build over them a structure.” Their Lord knows better about them. Those who prevailed over their affair<sup foot_note="80468">3</sup>said, “We will set up over them a mosque<sup foot_note="80469">4</sup>.”

f.80466: The people of the city who discovered them.
f.80468: Literally ‘those who overcame (the others) in their affair’.
f.80469: The Arabic word is masjidwhich literally means ‘a place for prostration’.

18:22.t: Some will say, “Three, their fourth being their dog.” And some will say, “Five, their sixth being their dog,” —guessing at the unknown. And some will say, “Seven, and their eighth being their dog.” Saysg, “My Lord knows better of their exact number”. None knows(the reality about)them except a few. So entersgnot into controversies concerning them except on a matter that is clear, and do not consult any of them1about them.

18:23.t: And never say about anything, “I will do that tomorrow”

18:24.t: without(saying), “God willing.” And remember your Lord if you forget(to say it)and say, “Hopefully my Lord will guide me to something nearer to prudence than this.”

18:25.t: And they remained in their cave for three hundred years, adding nine.

18:26.t: Saysg, “Allah knows better how long they remained; to Him belongs the hidden realm of the heavens and the earth. How clearly He sees and how finely He hears! They have no guardian apart from Him, andHe does1not associateanyone in His judgment.”

f.80471: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . and do not associate anyone in His judgement.”

18:27.t: And readsgwhat was revealed to you from the Scripture of your Lord; none can change His words, and you will find no refuge apart from Him.

18:28.t: And keepsgyourself patient in the company of those who pray to their Lord morning and evening, seeking His Countenance1, and do not turn your eyes away from them, seeking the adornment of the Earlier Life, and do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance2so that he has followed his own whim and his affairs have become confused.

f.80472: Al-Alousi and other exegetes interpreted this expression as ‘to please Him’.
f.80473: The Arabic word zhikrcan be translated as ‘remembrance’, ‘reminder’ or ‘mentioning’.

18:29.t: And saysg, “Truth comes from your Lord. So whoever wills—let him believe, and whoever wills—let him disbelieve”. We have indeed prepared for the unjust a fire whose curtains have hemmed them in, and when they cry for relief, they are relieved with water like molten brass which scalds the faces. What a miserable drink, and what a bad place of rest!

18:30.t: Indeed, those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds…<sup foot_note="80474">1</sup>—indeed, We do not waste the reward of whoever excels in work.

f.80474: This sentence is left open-ended; according Az-Zamakhshari its predicate is sign 31.

18:31.t: For those, there are the Gardens of Eden,rivers flowing beneath them. In it, they are<sup foot_note="80475">1</sup>adorned with bracelets of gold and wear green garments of silk and brocade, reclining therein on couches. What a wonderful recompense, and what an excellent place of rest!

f.80475: A grammatical shift to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of future events.

18:32.t: And setsgforth for them a parable of two men. To one of them We gave two gardens of grapevines, and We bordered them with palm-trees and We placed between them vegetation.

18:33.t: Each of the two gardens brought forth its crops in full and failed not in the least therein, and We caused a river to burst forth throughout them.

18:34.t: And thus he had riches<sup foot_note="80476">1</sup>, so he said to his fellow as he conversed with him, “I am wealthier than you and greater in manpower.”

f.80476: The Arabic word used is thamarwhich can be pronounced as thumror thumuraccording to the majority of reciters, and in all cases it also means ‘produce’.

18:35.t: And he entered his garden while unjust to himself. He said, “I do not think that this will ever perish,

18:36.t: and I do not think that the Hour is ever coming. And even if I am taken back to my Lord, I will most surely find something betterthan it1as a destination.”

f.80477: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . better than them both as . . .”

18:37.t: His fellow said to him as he conversed with him, “Have you denied the One Who created you from dust, then from a sperm-drop, then formed you as a man?

18:38.t: But as for me, He is Allah, my Lord, and I never associate anyone with my Lord.

18:39.t: Now, if only when you had entered your garden you had said, ‘As Allah wills; there is no power except through Allah,’ although you see me inferior to you in wealth and children.

18:40.t: Hopefully my Lord will give me better than your garden and send upon it thunderbolts from the sky so that it becomes slippery soil,

18:41.t: or its water sinks into the ground so that you become unable to draw it.”

18:42.t: And ruin closed in on his riches and he began wringing his hands over what he had spent therein, as it lay fallen upon its trellises, saying, “I wish I had never associated anyone with my Lord.”

18:43.t: And he had no battalion to support him apart from Allah, and he was unable to help himself.

18:44.t: In that situation,protection1belongs to Allah, the Truth; He is better in rewarding and better in requiting.

f.80478: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “In that situation, authority belongs to Allah . . .”

18:45.t: And setsgforth for them a parable for the Earlier Life:(it is)like water that We sent down from the sky, then the plants of the earth were mixed with it, so it became debris scattered by thewind1. And Allah2has always had absolute power over everything.

f.80479: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “winds ”

18:46.t: Wealth and children are the adornments of the Earlier Life, while abiding deeds of righteousness are more rewardable by yoursgLord and worthier of being hoped for.

18:47.t: And on the day whenWe set the mountains1in motionand yousgsee the earth emerging; and We herded2them together and left none of them behind.

f.80481: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “And on the day when the mountains are set in motion . . .”
f.80482: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

18:48.t: And they were presented, lining up before yoursgLord. “Very truly, youplhave come to Us as We created you the first time. No indeed, you claimed We would never set an appointment for you.”

18:49.t: And the record1was placed, and yousgsee2the criminals fearful of whatever is in it, and they say, “Woe to us! What is with this record that leaves nothing, small or big, but it has enumerated it?” And they found3whatever they had done present(before them), for yoursgLord is never unjust to anyone.

f.80484: A grammatical shift to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of future events.
f.80485: A grammatical shift, where the tense reverts to past tense.

18:50.t: And recall when We said to the angels, “Prostrate to Adam.” So they prostrated—but not Iblis<sup foot_note="80486">1</sup>. He was one of the unseen beings<sup foot_note="80487">2</sup>, so he defied the command of his Lord. Will you take him and his offspring as guardians apart from Me when they are an enemy to you? What a miserable bargain for the unjust!

f.80486: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.
f.80487: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

18:51.t: I1did not make them witnessthe creation of the heavens and the earth, nor their own creation, andnever was I to2takethe misguiding people for assistants.

f.80488: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “We did not make them witness . . .”
f.80489: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and never were you to take the misguiding people for assistants.”

18:52.t: And on the day whenHe says1, “Call on My associates whom you have claimed.” So they called2on them, but they did not respond to them. And We3placed between them a barrier.

f.80490: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “. . . when We say . . .”
f.80491: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

18:53.t: Then the criminals saw the Fire, so they realized that they were bound to tumble into it and they found no escape from it.

18:54.t: And We have elaborated in this Recital<sup foot_note="80493">1</sup>for mankind every kind of parable, but man has always been the most argumentative being.

f.80493: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

18:55.t: And what prevented mankind from attaining faith when guidance came to them and from seeking their Lord’s forgiveness? Unless they are waiting for the rule of(God regarding)the ancients to come upon them or to have the punishment come upon themin many types1.

f.80494: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . or to have the punishment come upon them face to face .”

18:56.t: And We do not send emissaries except as bearers of glad tidings and as forewarners. But those who have denied argue using falsehood in order to defeat the truth thereby, and they took<sup foot_note="80495">1</sup>My signs and what they were warned of for a joke.

f.80495: A grammatical shift from present tense to past tense.

18:57.t: And who is more unjust than the one who was reminded of his Lord’s signs then disregarded them and forgot what his hands had put forth? Indeed, We have placed veils over their hearts, preventing them from comprehending it, and heaviness in their ears. And if you call them to guidance they will not be guided, ever.

18:58.t: And yoursgLord is the Forgiver, the Possessor of mercy. Were He to call them to account for what they have earned, He would hasten the punishment for them. Rather, for them is an appointment from which they will find no escape.

18:59.t: And those towns—We annihilated them when they committed injustices, and We set an appointment fortheir moment of annihilation1.

f.80496: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem read it as: “. . . and We set an appointment for their annihilation .”

18:60.t: And recall when Moses said to his young assistant, “I will not give up until I reach the junction of the two seas, even if it takes me eons.”

18:61.t: So when they reached the junction between them, they forgot about their fish, and so it found its way into the sea, slipping away.

18:62.t: Then when they went further, he said to his young assistant, “Bring us our lunch; very truly, we have encountered in our travel much fatigue.”

18:63.t: He said, “Did you see when we rested by the rock? I forgot about the fish, and none except Satan made me forget it. And it found its way to the sea, wondrously.”

18:64.t: He said, “That is what we were looking for.” And so they turned back, retracing their footsteps.

18:65.t: Then they came upon a servant of Our servants whom We had given mercy from Us and whom We had taught knowledge from Our Own.

18:66.t: Moses said to him, “May I follow you so that you may teach me some of the prudence you were taught?”

18:67.t: He said, “Indeed, yousgwill not be able to endure patiently with me.

18:68.t: And how can you endure patiently what you have not encompassed with knowledge?”

18:69.t: He said, “You will find me patient, Allah willing, and I will not disobey you in any command of yours.”

18:70.t: He said, “So if yousgfollow me, thendo not askme1about anything until I bring about a mention of it to you.”

f.80497: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . then do not ever ask me about . . .”

18:71.t: So they both set out until, when they had boarded the ark, he holed it. He said, “Did you hole itso as to drown1its people? You have done something awful.”

f.80498: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Did you hole it so that its people would drown ?”

18:72.t: He said, “Did I not tell you that you would not be able to endure patiently with me?”

18:73.t: He said, “Do not rebuke me for forgetting, and do not make my matters difficult.”

18:74.t: Then they both set out until, as soon as they encountered a boy, he killed him. He said, “Did you killa sinless1self2which killed no one? Most surely, you have done something dreadful.”

f.80499: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Roways read it as: “Did you kill an inherently sinless self . . .”

18:75.t: He said, “Did I not tell you that you would not be able to endure patiently with me?”

18:76.t: He said, “If I ask you about anything after this, then do not keep company with me; certainly, by then you would have had enough of an excuse from me.”

18:77.t: So they both set out until, when they reached the people of a town, they asked them for food, but they refused to offer them hospitality. There they found a wall tending to collapse, so he repaired it. He said, “If you wanted,you could have charged1a reward for it.”

f.80501: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “He said, ‘If you had wanted, you could have taken a reward for it.’”

18:78.t: He said, “This is the parting between you and me. I will tell you the interpretation of what you were unable to endure patiently.

18:79.t: As for the ark, it belonged to some destitute people working at sea, so I wanted to make it defective, for there was a king coming after them, seizing every ark by force.

18:80.t: And as for the boy, his parents were believers and we feared he would overwhelm them with transgression and denial.

18:81.t: So we wanted their Lord to replace him with someone of better purity and nearer to mercy.

18:82.t: And as for the wall, it belonged to two orphaned boys in the city, and beneath it was a treasure that belonged to them, and their father was a righteous man, so your Lord desired that they attain their full strength and(then) extract their treasure—a mercy from your Lord. And I never did it of my own accord. This is the interpretation of what you were unable to endure patiently.”

18:83.t: And they ask yousgabout Zul-Qarnayn. Say, “I will read for you an account of him as a reminder.”

18:84.t: Indeed, We empowered him in the land and brought him all kinds of means.

18:85.t: So he pursued a certain course

18:86.t: until, when he had reached the setting of the sun, he found it setting in amurky1spring, and found a people in its vicinity. We said, “O Zul-Qarnayn, you may either punish or else treat them kindly.”

f.80502: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . in a hot spring . . .”

18:87.t: He said, “As for the one who has committed injustices, we will punish him, then he will be returned to his Lord and He will punish him with a dreadful punishment.

18:88.t: But as for the one who has attained faith and has acted righteously, then for him isthe excellent(reward)as repayment1, and we will speak to him with ease regarding our command.”

f.80503: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Shuʻba and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . then for him is the repayment for the excellent (deed) , and we will . . .”

18:90.t: until, when he reached the rising of the sun, he found it rising on a people for whom We had provided no shelter from it.

18:91.t: So it was. And surely We encompassed what he had with knowledge.

18:93.t: until, when he reached the point separating the two barriers, he found beside them a people who could barelycomprehend1any word.

f.80504: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . who could barely make others comprehend any word.”

18:94.t: They said, “O Zul-Qarnayn, Gog and Magog are corrupting the land, so can we make for you a tribute on condition that you build a barrier between us and them?”

18:95.t: He said, “What my Lord has empowered me with is better.(Just)assist me with(man)power, and I will set a barricade between youpland them.

18:96.t: Bring me blocks of iron.” Then when he had leveled up between the two cliffs, he said, “Blow.” And having turned it into a fire, he said, “Bring me tar to pour over it.”

18:97.t: So neither could they climb it, nor could they penetrate it.

18:98.t: He said, “This is a mercy from my Lord; but when the promise of my Lord comes true, He will turn it intoa flat surface1. And the promise of my Lord has always been true.”

f.80505: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . turn it into rubble .”

18:99.t: And We left<sup foot_note="80506">1</sup>them surging upon one another on that day, and the Trumpet was blown and We gathered them together.

f.80506: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

18:100.t: And We displayed Hell to the deniers on that day in full display—

18:101.t: those whose eyes were covered from My Reminder and were unable to hear.

18:102.t: Did those who have denied think that they could take My servants for masters apart from Me? Indeed, We have prepared Hell for the hospitality of the deniers.

18:103.t: Saysg, “Shall We inform youplof the biggest losers regarding deeds?

18:104.t: Those whose efforts in the Earlier Life have gone astray, while they assume that they are doing well.”

18:105.t: Those are the ones who denied the signs of their Lord and the meeting with Him, so their deeds were nullified, and on the Day of Resurrection We will consider them of no weight.

18:106.t: That is their repayment—Hell—on account of their denial and their taking My signs and My messengers in mockery.

18:107.t: Indeed, those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—the Gardens of Paradise have always been there for their hospitality,

18:108.t: abiding therein, never seeking to leave it.

18:109.t: Saysg, “If the sea were to become ink for the words of my Lord, the sea would run out before the words of my Lord ran out, even if We were to bring the like of it in replenishment.”

18:110.t: Saysg, “Indeed, I am only a human being like youpl. It is revealed to me that your god is One God, so whoever expects to meet his Lord, let him do righteous work and never associate anyone in the worship of his Lord.”
