19:2.t: A reminder of yoursgLord’s mercy towards His servant Zechariah,

19:3.t: when he called out to his Lord a call in seclusion.

19:4.t: He said, “My Lord, my bones have become feeble and my hair is aflame with gray, and never, in calling upon You my Lord, have I been wretched.

19:5.t: And indeed, I am afraid of what my protégés will do when I am gone, for my wife has always been barren. So grant me from Yourself a guardian

19:6.t: to inherit from me and inherit from Jacob’s folk, and make him, my Lord, pleasing.”

19:7.t: “O Zechariah, indeed, We give you glad tidings of a boy whose name is John; We have never made anyone similar to him<sup foot_note="80507">1</sup>before.”

f.80507: At-Tabari mentioned that some exegetessaid that among the meanings of the Arabic word “sameyya” is‘someone with the same name’, so they considered him to be the first ever to be named as such.

19:8.t: He said, “My Lord, how can I have a boy when my wife has always been barren and I have become decrepit with old age?”

19:9.t: He said, “Thus said your Lord, ‘It is easy for Me, andI1have certainly created youbefore when you were nothing.’”

f.80508: Qira’at: Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . and We have certainly created you . . .”

19:10.t: He said, “My Lord, give me a sign.” He said, “Your sign is that you do not speak to people for three nights,(despite)being in perfect shape.”

19:11.t: So he came out to his people from the sanctuary and signaled to them to exalt(God), morning and evening.

19:12.t: “O John, hold on to the Scripture firmly,” and We gave him wise judgment in his youth

19:13.t: and tenderness from Us and purity, and he was mindful(of God),

19:14.t: and was very kind to his parents, and he was never a disobedient coercer.

19:15.t: And peace be upon him the day he was born and the day he dies and the day he is resurrected alive.

19:16.t: And remembersgin the Scripture Mary, when she secluded herself from her family in an eastern location.

19:17.t: And she took a cover for herself away from them, and We sent to her Our spirit, so He appeared to her as a human being in perfect shape.

19:18.t: She said, “I seek refuge from you with the All-Merciful, if you are mindful(of God).”

19:19.t: He said, “I am only a messenger of your Lordto grant1you a pure boy.”

f.80509: Qira’at: Warsh, Abu ʻAmr, Yaʻqub and Qaloun, in one of his narrations, read it as: “. . . of your Lord so that He may grant you . . .”

19:20.t: She said, “How can I have a boy when no human being has touched me, nor have I ever been a harlot?”

19:21.t: He said, “Thus said your Lord, ‘It is easy for Me, and We will make him a sign for humanity and a mercy from Us, and it has been a matter already decreed.’”

19:22.t: So she carried him and secluded herself with him in a remote place.

19:23.t: Then the birth pangs compelled her to come to the trunk of the palm tree. She said, “If only I had died before this and been a thing forgotten, completely forgotten!”

19:24.t: So he called her from beneath her1: “Be not sad; your Lord has made a stream beneath you.

f.80510: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Shuʻba and Roways read it as: “So the one beneath her called her :”

19:25.t: And shake the trunk of the palm tree towards you—it1will drop ripe datesupon you.”

f.80511: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . it (masculine – referring to the trunk) will drop . . .” All others read it as: “. . . it (feminine – referring to the palm tree itself) will drop . . .”

19:26.t: “So eat and drink and let your eye be comforted, but if you see any human being, say, ‘I have vowed a fast to the All-Merciful, so I will not speak to any human today.’”

19:27.t: Then she came to her people, carrying him. They said, “O Mary, you have done something terrible.

19:28.t: O sister of Aaron<sup foot_note="80512">1</sup>, neither was your father an evil man, nor was your mother a harlot.”

f.80512: Aaron, to Jews, was an example of pious people who repent after sinning.

19:29.t: So she pointed to him. They said, “How can we speak to an infant in the cradle?”

19:30.t: He said, “I am Allah’s servant. He has brought me the Scripture and has made me a prophet.

19:31.t: And He has made me blessed wherever I may be and has enjoined upon me prayer and purifying charity<sup foot_note="80513">1</sup>so long as I live.

f.80513: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

19:32.t: And He has made me very kind to my mother and has not made me a wretched coercer.

19:33.t: And peace be upon me the day I was born and the day I die and the day I get resurrected alive.”

19:34.t: That is Jesus, son of Mary—the word1of truth about which they are skeptical.

f.80514: Qira’at: All except Ibn ʻAmer, ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . son of Mary; (that is) the word of truth . . .”

19:35.t: Never was it for Allah to have any offspring—Highly Exalted is He; whenever He decrees a matter, He only says to it, “Be,” and so it is.

19:36.t: “And indeed, Allah is my Lord and yourplLord, so worship Him; this is a straight path.”

19:37.t: But the parties differed among themselves, so woe to those who have denied from the spectacle of a great day.

19:38.t: How well they shall hear and see on the day they come to Us! But the unjust are today in evident misguidance.

19:39.t: And warnsgthem of the Day of Regret, when the matter has been concluded. Yet they are in oblivion, and they do not believe.

19:40.t: Indeed, We—We alone—will inherit the earth and everyone on it, and to Usthey are returned1.

f.80515: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and to Us they return .”

19:41.t: And mentionsgin the Scripture Abraham; he was indeed an unwavering believer(and)a prophet.

19:42.t: Recall when he said to his father, “O my father, why do you worship what can neither hear nor see nor avail you anything?

19:43.t: O my father, most surely there has come to me of knowledge what has never come to you, so follow me and I will guide you to a straight path.

19:44.t: O my father, do not worship Satan; indeed Satan has always been disobedient to the All-Merciful.

19:45.t: O my father, indeed I fear that a punishment from the All-Merciful may touch you so that you would become an ally for Satan.”

19:46.t: He said, “Are you renouncing my gods, O Abraham? If you do not desist, I will certainly stone you, so leave me for a long while.”

19:47.t: He said, “Peace be upon you; I will ask my Lord to forgive you; indeed, He has always been gracious to me.

19:48.t: And I shall withdraw from youpland from what youplcall upon apart from Allah, and I will call upon my Lord; hopefully, in calling upon my Lord, I shall never be wretched.”

19:49.t: So when he withdrew from them and what they worshiped apart from Allah, We granted him Isaac and Jacob, and each We made a prophet.

19:50.t: And We granted them of Our mercy and gave them a high and true renown.

19:51.t: And mentionsgin the Scripture Moses. He was indeeda sincere, chosen one1, and he was a messenger(and)a prophet.

f.80516: Qira’at: All except ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “He was indeed sincere , and he was a messenger . . .”

19:52.t: And We called out to him from the right side of Mount Tûr, and brought him near in communion.

19:53.t: And We granted him, of Our mercy, his brother Aaron as a prophet.

19:54.t: And mention in the Scripture Ishmael; he was indeed true to his promise, and he was a messenger(and)a prophet.

19:55.t: And he used to command his family to prayer and purifying charity<sup foot_note="80517">1</sup>, and with his Lord he was always rendered pleased.

f.80517: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

19:56.t: And mention in the Scripture Enoch; he was indeed an unwavering believer(and)a prophet.

19:57.t: And We raised him to a high position.

19:58.t: Those are the ones whom Allah1blessed ofthe prophets from the offspring of Adam, and from those We2carried with Noah, and from the offspring of Abraham and Israel, and from those We guided and selected. Whenever the signs3of the All-Mercifulbwere recited to them, they would fall down prostrating and weeping.

f.80520: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

19:59.t: Then they were succeeded by generations who wasted the prayers and followed desires, and thus they will encounter(the sequel of their)delusion—

19:60.t: except for whoever repented and believed and acted righteously, for thoseshall enter1the Garden and shall not be dealt with unjustly in any way—

f.80521: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . shall be entered into the Garden . . .”

19:61.t: the Gardens of Eden which have been promised by the All-Merciful to His servants in the hidden realm; indeed, His promise has ever been coming true.

19:62.t: Therein they hear no idle talk, but only peace. And therein they have their own provision, morning and evening.

19:63.t: Such is the Garden(of Paradise)which We give as inheritance to whoever of Our servants who has been mindful(of God).

19:64.t: “And we1do not descend except by the command of yoursgLord; to Him belongs whatever is before us and whatever is behind us and whatever is between them, and your Lord has never been forgetful.”

f.80522: Gabriel speaks about himself and about the angels.

19:65.t: Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, so worship Him and persevere in worshiping Him. Do you know of anyone similar to Him?

19:66.t: And man says, “Can it be that when1I am dead,I willbe brought out alive?”

f.80523: Qira’at: Ibn Zekwan, in one of his narrations, read it as: “. . . says, ‘When I am dead, will I be brought out alive?’”

19:67.t: Does man not remember that We created him earlier when he was nothing?

19:68.t: By yoursgLord, We will surely herd them and the devils, then We will surely bring them around Hell on their knees.

19:69.t: Then out of every sect We will surely snatch those most defiant to the All-Merciful.

19:70.t: Then(they will realize that)We surely know better of those who are most deserving to roast in it.

19:71.t: But every single one of you is bound to approach it; this has been an unavoidable decree of your Lord.

19:72.t: Then We1deliver2those who were mindful(of God)and leave the unjust in it on their knees.

f.80525: Qira’at: Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “Then We save those who . . .”

19:73.t: And when Our signs1are read to them, evident, those who have denied say to those who have attained faith, “Which of the two groupsis better in position2and fairerin company?”

f.80526: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like‘verse’ in poetry or‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.
f.80527: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “‘Which of the two groups has a better dwelling place and is fairer in company?’”

19:74.t: And how many a generation have We annihilated before them who surpassed them in riches and splendor?

19:75.t: Saysg, “Whoever has been in utter misguidance, may the All-Merciful fully extend for him1.” Until, when they see what they were promised—either punishment or the Hour—then they will know who was in a worse position and weaker as an army.

19:76.t: And Allah increases in guidance those who seek guidance. And abiding deeds of righteousness are more rewardable by your Lord and better in return.

19:77.t: Have yousgseen the one who denied Our signs and said, “I will most surely be given wealth and children”?

19:78.t: Has he viewed the hidden realm, or has he taken with the All-Merciful<sup foot_note="80529">1</sup>a covenant?

19:79.t: But no! We will write what he says and keep extending the agony for him exceedingly,

19:80.t: and we will inherit from him whatever he says, and he will come to Us solitary.

19:81.t: And they took, apart from Allah, other gods to be a source of might for them.

19:82.t: But no! They will deny their worship of them and become opponents against them.

19:83.t: Have yousgnot seen that We have dispatched the devils against the deniers, exciting them with incitement?

19:84.t: So do not hurry about them; indeed, We are only counting(down)for them precisely.

19:85.t: On a day when We herd the ones who were mindful(of God)to the All-Mercifulfas a delegation,

19:86.t: and flock the criminals into Hell, thirsty,

19:87.t: with no power of intercession—except for the one who had taken with the All-Merciful a covenant.

19:88.t: And they said, “The All-Merciful has taken(for himself)offspring.”

19:89.t: You1haveplcome up with something monstrous!

19:90.t: The heavens almost rupture at it, and the earth splits and the mountains fall, crumbling:

19:91.t: that they have attributed a son to the All-Merciful!

19:92.t: And in no way is it fitting for the All-Merciful to take(for Himself)a son.

19:93.t: There is none in the heavens and the earth but is bound to come to the All-Merciful as a servant.

19:94.t: He has enumerated them and counted them precisely.

19:95.t: And each one of them is bound to come to Him on the Day of Resurrection solitary.

19:96.t: Indeed, those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—the All-Merciful will give them love.

19:97.t: So indeed, We have made it easy in yoursgtongue, that you may give glad tidings to the ones who were mindful(of God)and warn with it a hostile people.

19:98.t: And how many a generation have We annihilated before them? Can you feel a single one of them or hear from them the slightest whisper?

20:2.t: We have not sent down the Recital1upon yousgfor you to be wretched,

f.80531: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

20:3.t: but only as a reminding for one who fears.

20:4.t: A bestowal from on high by the One Who created the earth and the highest heavens—

20:5.t: the All-Merciful; on the Throne He settled<sup foot_note="80532">1</sup>.

f.80532: How He settled is beyond human understanding.

20:6.t: To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth and whatever is between them and whatever is beneath the ground.

20:7.t: And if yousgspeak aloud, indeed, He knows the secret and the most hidden.

20:8.t: Allah—there is no god but He; to him belong the most beautiful names.

20:9.t: And has the story of Moses reached yousg?

20:10.t: When he saw a fire, so he said to his family, “Stay; I have noticed a fire; perhaps I can bring youpla torch therefrom or find some guidance by the fire.”

20:11.t: So when he reached it, he was called, “O Moses.

20:12.t: Indeed, I—I am your Lord. So take off your sandals; you are indeed in the sacred valley of Tuwa.

20:13.t: AndI1have chosen you, so listen to what is revealed.

f.80533: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “And We have indeed chosen you . . .”

20:14.t: Indeed I—I alone—am Allah. There is no God but I, so worship Me and establish the prayer for My remembrance.

20:15.t: The Hour is indeed coming—I almost hide it—so that every single self is paid for what it endeavors.

20:16.t: So let not the one who denies it and has been following his own whim bar you from it, lest you fall(into doom).

20:17.t: And what is that in your right-hand, O Moses?”

20:18.t: He said, “This is my staff. I lean on it, and I beat down(leaves)for my sheep with it, and I have other uses for it.”

20:20.t: So he cast it, and thereupon it became a moving serpent.

20:21.t: He said, “Pick it up and be not afraid; We will restore it to its original condition.

20:22.t: And press your hand to your side; it will come out white without any bad affliction—another sign,

20:23.t: that We may show you of Our greatest signs.

20:24.t: Go to Pharaoh; indeed, he has exceeded all limits.”

20:25.t: He said, “My Lord, expand my chest for me,

20:26.t: and ease my mission for me,

20:27.t: and untie the knot from my tongue

20:28.t: so that they can comprehend my speech,

20:29.t: and appoint for me an assistant from my family:

20:32.t: and associatehim with me in my mission1,

f.80534: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . .my brother, (so that) I (can) strengthen myself with him 32 and (so that) I (can) associate him with me in my mission.”

20:33.t: that we may exalt You much

20:35.t: Indeed, You have always been All-Seeing of us.”

20:36.t: He said, “Yousghave been granted your request, O Moses.

20:37.t: And most surely, We have conferred favor upon you on another occasion,

20:38.t: when We revealed to your mother what was revealed:

20:39.t: ‘Throw him in the coffer then throw it into the waters, so that the waters will cast it onto the bank where an enemy of Mine and an enemy of his will pick him up.’ For I bestowed upon you love from Me andso that you may be modeled1before My eye.

f.80535: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and (I said): may you be modeled before My eye.”

20:40.t: Recall your sister walking along and saying, ‘Shall I tell you about someone who can foster him?’ So We returned you to your mother, that her eye may be comforted and(that she may)not grieve. And you killed a person, but We delivered you from stress and We tested you thoroughly. Then you stayed for years among the people of Midian. Then you came as ordained, O Moses.

20:41.t: And I modeled you for Myself.

20:42.t: Gosg, you and your brother, with My signs, and dodlnot slacken in remembering Me.

20:43.t: Godlto Pharaoh—he has indeed exceeded all limits—

20:44.t: but saydla lenient word to him, that he may remind himself or be fearful.”

20:45.t: They said, “Our Lord, we fear he may persecute us or exceed all limits.”

20:46.t: He said, “Be not afraid; I am indeed with youdl, hearing and seeing.

20:47.t: So approachdlhim and say, `Wedlare the messengers of your Lord, so send the Children of Israel with us and do not punish them; we have surely brought you a sign from your Lord, for peace is upon whoever has followed the guidance.

20:48.t: It has indeed been revealed to us that punishment falls upon whoever has disbelieved andturned away.’”

20:49.t: He said, “So who is yourdlLord, O Moses?”

20:50.t: He said, “Our Lord is the One Who gave everything its creation then guided(it).”

20:51.t: He said, “So what about the former generations?”

20:52.t: He said, “Knowledge thereof is with my Lord in a record<sup foot_note="80536">1</sup>; my Lord never goes astray nor does He forget.”

20:53.t: (He is)the One Who has made the earth acradle1for youpland traced in it ways for youpl, and sent down from the sky water with which We2brought out pairs of diverse plants.

f.80537: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . a resting place for you . . .”

20:54.t: Eatpland pasture your livestock. Most surely, in that are signs for ones endowed with intelligence.

20:55.t: From it We created youpl, and into it We return you, and from it We bring you out once again.

20:56.t: And very truly We showed him all of Our signs, but he disbelieved and refused.

20:57.t: He said, “Have you come to us to evict us from our land with your sorcery, O Moses?

20:58.t: We will most surely bring you sorcery like it; so make between us and you an appointment which wewill1not break—neither us nor you—in a suitable place.”

f.80539: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . we should not fail . . .”

20:59.t: He said, “Yourplappointment is the day of the festival, so let the people be herded together at forenoon.”

20:60.t: Then Pharaoh turned away and put together his plot, and then he came.

20:61.t: Moses said to them, “Woe to youpl. Do not fabricate lies against Allah or He will destroy youplwith a punishment, and surely, the one who fabricates lies is bound to fail.”

20:62.t: Then they disagreed with each other about their matter and conversed secretly.

20:63.t: They said, “These two are nothing but1sorcerers who want to evict you from your land with their sorcery and abolish your exemplary way of life.

f.80540: Qira’at: All except for Hafs and Ibn Kathir read it as: “They said, ‘Most surely, these two are sorcerers …’”

20:64.t: Sodecide1yourplplot, then come, lined up(in ranks); and the one who gains the upper hand is surely bound to succeed today.”

f.80541: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “So put together your plot . . .”

20:65.t: They said, “O Moses, either you cast or we will be the first to cast.”

20:66.t: He said, “Rather, youplcast.” And suddenly, their ropes and staffswere made to appear1to him, because of their sorcery, to be slithering.

f.80542: Qira’at: Ibn Zekwan and Rouh read it as: “. . . their ropes and staffs appeared to him . . .”

20:67.t: So Moses felt apprehensive within himself.

20:68.t: We said, “Be not afraid; yousgare the highest.

20:69.t: And cast what is in your right hand—it will swallow1what they have crafted; what they have crafted is only asorcerer’s2trickery, for the sorcerer will not succeed wherever he may go.”

f.80543: Qira’at: Ibn Zekwan read it as: “And cast what is in your right hand, to swallow . . .”
f.80544: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . a sorcery trickery . . .”

20:70.t: So the sorcerers fell down prostrate. They said, “We have attained faith in the Lord of Aaron and Moses.”

20:71.t: He said, “Have youplattained faith in him before I have given you permission? He must be your chief who has taught you sorcery. So I will most surely cut off your hands and your feet on alternate sides, and I will most surely crucify you on the trunks of the palm-trees. Then you will most surely know which of us is more severe in punishment and more lasting.”

20:72.t: They said, “We will not prefer you over what has come to us of evident proofs nor(over)the One Who originated us, so decree whatever you decree; you can only decree for this Earlier Life.

20:73.t: We have indeed attained faith in our Lord so that He may forgive us our offenses and what you have compelled us to practice of sorcery, for Allah is better and more lasting.”

20:74.t: Indeed, whoever comes to his Lord as a criminal, then surely for him is Hell, where he neither dies nor lives.

20:75.t: But whoever comes to Him as a believer, having done righteous deeds, then for those1are the highest degrees(of rank):

f.80545: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

20:76.t: Gardens of Perpetuity beneath which rivers flow, abiding therein, for that is the repayment of the one who purifies himself.

20:77.t: And very truly, We revealed to Moses: “Journey by night with My servants and strike for them a dry road across the sea.You will not be1afraidof being overtaken nor apprehensive.”

f.80546: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “Be not afraid of being overtaken . . .”

20:78.t: So Pharaoh pursued them with his troops, but there overwhelmed them of the waters that which overwhelmed them.

20:79.t: Thus Pharaoh led his people astray and never did he guide(them).

20:80.t: O Children of Israel,We1have surely saved youfrom your enemy, and havemade an appointment with2you by the right side of Mount Tûr, and sent down to you manna and quails.

f.80547: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “I have surely saved you . . .”
f.80548: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and have promised you by the right . . .”

20:81.t: Eat of the good things We have provided for youpl, but do not exceed the limits in it lest youdeserveMy wrath upon you, for the one upon whom My wrath isdeserved1has surely fallen.

f.80549: Qira’at: Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . lest My wrath descend upon you, for the one upon whom My wrath descends has surely fallen.”

20:82.t: And very truly I am Forgiving towards the one who repented and attained faith and acted righteously and then remained guided.

20:83.t: “And what made you rush ahead of your people, O Moses?”

20:84.t: He said, “They are following in my footsteps. And I hurried on to You, my Lord, that You may be well pleased.”

20:85.t: He said, “Yet, We have surely tested your people in your absence, and the Samiri led them astray.”

20:86.t: So Moses returned to his people, wrathful(and)sorrowful. He said, “O my people, did your Lord not promise you a good promise? Was the(time of the)covenant too long for you? Or did you want wrath from your Lord to descend upon you, so you broke your promise to me?”

20:87.t: They said, “We did not break our promise to you by our choice, but wewere made to carry1burdens of the people’s ornaments, so we cast them and so did the Samiri cast.”

f.80550: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Rouh and Khalaf read it as: “. . . but we carried burdens . . .”

20:88.t: So he brought out for them a calf—a mere body with a lowing sound. And they<sup foot_note="80551">1</sup>said, “This is your god and the god of Moses, but he has forgotten.”

f.80551: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

20:89.t: Do they not see that it cannot return a word to them, nor does it possess for them harm or benefit?

20:90.t: And Aaron had most surely said to them before, “O my people, you are indeed being tested by this, and indeed your Lord is the All-Merciful, so follow me and obey my command.”

20:91.t: They said, “We will not give up consecrating it until Moses returns to us.”

20:92.t: He said, “O Aaron, what prevented you, when you saw them going astray,

20:93.t: from following me? Have you disobeyed my command?”

20:94.t: He said, “O son of my mother, do not seize me by my beard nor by my head; I feared you would say, ‘You have caused division among the Children of Israel and have not regarded my word.’”

20:95.t: He said, “What do you have to say, O Samiri?”

20:96.t: He said, “I perceived whatthey1did not perceive, so I grasped a handful from the messenger’s traces and I flung it away, and thus my soul prompted me.”

f.80552: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . what you pl did not perceive . . .”

20:97.t: He said, “Be gone! For indeed your lot in this life is to say, ‘No touching’, and indeed you have an appointment that you will notbe allowed to break1. And look at your god that you kept consecrating—we will certainlyburn it up2then blow it away completely into the waters.”

f.80553: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . that you will not break .”
f.80554: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . we will certainly burn it then blow it . . .”

20:98.t: Surely yourplgod is none but Allah, the One besides Whom there is no other god; He has embraced everything in knowledge.

20:99.t: Thus We narrate to yousgof the stories that have passed before, for We have brought you a Reminder from Us.

20:100.t: Whoever has disregarded it will indeed carry on the Day of Resurrection a burden,

20:101.t: abidingplin it, and how bad their load became1on the Day of Resurrection—

f.80555: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

20:102.t: the day whenthe Trumpet is blown1! And We herd the criminals on that day, blue,

f.80556: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . when We blow the Trumpet!”

20:103.t: murmuring among themselves: “Youplhave stayed only for ten.”

20:104.t: We know better what they say, when the most exemplary of them in conduct says, “Youplhave stayed for no more than a day.”

20:105.t: And they ask you about the mountains. So say, “My Lord will blow them away

20:106.t: and leave them as desolate waste.

20:107.t: You will see in them neither crookedness nor deviation.”

20:108.t: On that day, they follow the caller without any crookedness, and voices wered(hushed)in reverence to the All-Merciful, so that yousghear nothing but a murmur.

20:109.t: On that day, intercession does not avail except for the one permitted by the All-Merciful, and He was pleased for him to speak.

20:110.t: He knows what is before them and what is behind them, and they cannot encompass Him with knowledge.

20:111.t: And faces were humbleddto the Living One, the All-Sustaining, and surely whoever carried injustice is bound to fail.

20:112.t: But whoever does righteous deeds while being a believer, then heneither fears1injustice nor curtailment.

f.80557: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . then he should neither fear injustice nor curtailment.”

20:113.t: And thus We have sent it down as an Arabic Recital1, and We have diversified the warnings in it, that perhaps they would become mindful(of God)or it would bring about in them a remembrance.

f.80558: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

20:114.t: Most high above all is Allah, the True King. Dosgnot be hasty with the Recital1beforeits revelation to you is concluded2, and say, “My Lord, increase me in knowledge.”

f.80559: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.
f.80560: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . before We conclude its revelation to you . . .”

20:115.t: And most surely We covenanted with Adam before, but he forgot, and We found in him no resolve.

20:116.t: And recall when We said to the angels, “Prostrate yourselves to Adam.” So they prostrated themselves— but not Iblis<sup foot_note="80561">1</sup>; he refused.

f.80561: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.

20:117.t: So We said, “O Adam, indeed this is an enemy to you and to your spouse. So do not let him get youdlout of the Garden, for then yousgwill1suffer.

f.80562: A grammatical shift from dual to singular.

20:118.t: In it, indeed, yousgwill never go hungry nor be naked.

20:119.t: Nor will you be thirsty in it nor will you swelter.”

20:120.t: But Satan whispered to him. He said, “O Adam, shall I show you the Tree of Immortality and a kingdom that never decays?”

20:121.t: So theydlate from it, whereupon their private parts became exposed to them, and they started covering themselves with the leaves of the Garden. Thus Adam disobeyed his Lord and was deluded.

20:122.t: Then his Lord recalled him and granted him repentance and accepted it from him and guided(him).

20:123.t: He said, “Descend from it, all together, some of you as enemies of some others. But whenever guidance comes to you from Me, whoever follows My guidance will neither go astray nor suffer.

20:124.t: But whoever has disregarded My Reminder—for him is a miserable life, and We<sup foot_note="80563">1</sup>will herd him on the Day of Resurrection blind.”

f.80563: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

20:125.t: He said, “My Lord, why did You herd me blind though I used to see?”

20:126.t: He said, “Just as Our signs came to yousgand you forgot them, today you will be forgotten.”

20:127.t: And thus We repay the one who was an extremist and did not believe in the signs of his Lord. And surely the punishment of the Hereafter is more severe and more lasting.

20:128.t: Did it give them no guidance(to learn)how many generations before them We annihilated, amidst whose residences they walk? Indeed, in that are signs for the ones endowed with intelligence.

20:129.t: And were it not for a word that had preceded from yoursgLord, the inevitable would have happened, but(there is)a stated term.

20:130.t: So bear patiently what they say and exalt yoursgLord with praise before the rising of the sun and before its setting, and during the hours of the night exalt Him, and at the(two)ends of the day, that you may bewell pleased1.

f.80564: Qira’at: Shuʻba and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . that you may be rendered well pleased .”

20:131.t: And never extend your eyes towards what We have given some classes of them to enjoy—the splendor<sup foot_note="80565">1</sup>of the Earlier Life—that We may test them thereby, for your Lord’s<sup foot_note="80566">2</sup>provision is better and more lasting.

20:132.t: And command your people to prayer, and patiently adhere to it; We ask of yousgno provision; it is We who provide for you. For the future outcome is for mindfulness(of God).

20:133.t: And they said, “If only he were to bring us a sign from his Lord!” Were they not given evidence of whatever is in the former scrolls?

20:134.t: Had We annihilated them with a punishment before him, they would have said, “Our Lord, if only You had sent us a messenger so that we would have followed Your signs before we were humiliated and disgraced.”

20:135.t: Saysg, “Everybody is waiting, so waitpl, for you will know who the people of the even path are and who was rightly-guided.

21:1.t: Mankind’s reckoning has drawn near, while they are in oblivion, disregarding(it).

21:2.t: No fresh reminder comes to them from their Lord but they listen to it playfully,

21:3.t: their hearts distracted. And secretly did the unjust converse, “Is this anything but a human being like youpl? Will you go along with sorcery while you see?”

21:4.t: He said1, “My Lord knows what is said in the heaven and the earth, for He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.”

f.80567: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Say sg . . .”

21:5.t: But they said, “A jumble of dreams; rather, he fabricated it; rather, he is a poet, so let him bring us a sign like those sent to the ancients.”

21:6.t: None of the towns We annihilated before them had believed. Will they, then, believe?

21:7.t: And never did We send before yousgbut men to whomWe reveal1, so ask the people of the Reminder if youpldo not know.

f.80568: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . to whom it is revealed , so ask . . .”

21:8.t: And never did We make them a mere body1,(ones)who eatplno food, for never were they immortal.

f.80569: A grammatical shift from plural to singular.

21:9.t: Then We fulfilled the promise to them, so We saved them together with whomever We will<sup foot_note="80570">1</sup>, and We annihilated the extremists.

f.80570: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

21:10.t: Most surely, We have sent down to youpla Scripture containing your reminder. Do you not reason?

21:11.t: And how many an unjust town have We crushed and established thereafter another people?

21:12.t: Thus when they sensed Our force, they immediately ran away from it.

21:13.t: Do not run, but come back to the luxuries youplwere immersed in, and your residences, that you may be questioned.

21:14.t: They said, “Woe to us; indeed, we have been unjust.”

21:15.t: Thus this continued to be their cry until We made them extinguished ashes.

21:16.t: And in no way did We create the sky and the earth and what is between them playfully.

21:17.t: If We wanted amusement, We could have obtained it from very close to Us, were We to do so.

21:18.t: Rather, We hurl the truth against falsehood so that it crushes it, and thus it vanishes. And woe unto youplfor what you describe.

21:19.t: For to Him belongs whomever is in the heavens and the earth. And those in His presence are not too arrogant to worship Him, nor do they grow weary.

21:20.t: They give due exaltation(to Him)night and day, never tiring.

21:21.t: Or have they taken to themselves gods from the earth who(can)resurrect?

21:22.t: If there were in them gods other than Allah, they would have surely become corrupted. So Highly Exalted is Allah, Lord of the Throne, far above what they describe.

21:23.t: He is not asked about what He does, but they shall be asked.

21:24.t: Or have they taken apart from Him other gods? Say, “Bring yourplproof; this1is the reminder of those with me and the reminder of those before me.” Rather, most of them do not know the truth, so they disregard(it).

21:25.t: And never did We send any messenger before yousgbutWe1reveal2to him that: “There is no god but I, so worshipplMe.”

f.80572: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . but it is revealed to him . . .”
f.80573: Frequently the Qur’an speaks about the prophets using present tense; this should be pondered by the reader.

21:26.t: Yet they said, “The All-Merciful has taken to himself offspring.” Highly Exalted is He; rather, they are honored servants

21:27.t: who never speak before Him, and they only act on His command.

21:28.t: He knows what is before them and what is behind them, and they do not intercede except for those whom He approves, and they tremble in awe of Him.

21:29.t: And whoever of them says, “I am a god apart from Him,” We will repay him with Hell; thus We repay the unjust.

21:30.t: Do the deniers not see that the heavens and the earth were one mass, and then We tore them apart? And We made from water every living thing; will they not believe?

21:31.t: And We put firm mountains on the earth, lest it sway with them; and We set broad pathways on it, that they might be guided.

21:32.t: And We made the sky a preserved ceiling, yet they disregard its signs.

21:33.t: And it is He Who created the night and the day, and the sun and the moon, each floating in an orbit.

21:34.t: And never did We grant immortality to any human being before yousg. Should you die, are they then the immortal?

21:35.t: Every single self is bound to taste death, for We test youplwith evil and good as a means of trial, and to Usyou are returned1.

f.80574: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and to Us you return .”

21:36.t: And when those who have denied see yousg, they treat you only with ridicule: “Is this the one who mentions your gods?” For of the reminder of the All-Merciful they themselves are deniers.

21:37.t: Man was created of haste. I will show youplMy signs, so do not ask Me to hasten.

21:38.t: And they say, “When will this promise come true, if you are truthful?”

21:39.t: If those who have denied only knew the time when they will not be able to keep the Fire off their faces nor off their backs, nor will they be supported!

21:40.t: Rather, it will come upon them suddenly and bewilder them, so they will not be able to repel it, nor will they be given respite.

21:41.t: And most surely(other)messengers before yousgwere ridiculed, but those who mocked were surrounded by what they used to ridicule.

21:42.t: Say, “Who guards you by night and day from the All-Merciful?” But they disregard the reminder of their Lord.

21:43.t: Or do they have gods that can defend them against Us? They cannot support themselves, nor will they find anyone to side with them against Us.

21:44.t: Rather, We gave these people and their forefathers enjoyments until time grew long upon them. Do they not see how We gradually reduce the land from its extremities? Are they then the overcomers?

21:45.t: Say, “Indeed, I am only warning youplthrough revelation.” Butthe deafcannot hear1the call when they are being warned.

f.80575: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “But you cannot make the deaf hear . . .”

21:46.t: And if a whiff of your Lord’s punishment touches them, they say, “Woe to us, We have truly been unjust.”

21:47.t: And We set up the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection so that not a single self suffers the least injustice, and even if it be the weight of a mustard seed, We bring it forth. For sufficient are We as reckoners.

21:48.t: And very truly, We gave Moses and Aaron the Criterion and illumination and a reminder for the ones who were mindful(of God):

21:49.t: those who fear their Lord, though Unseen, and are apprehensive of theHour.

21:50.t: And this(too)is a blessed Reminder that We have sent down. Are youplgoing to reject it?

21:51.t: And most surely, We brought Abraham his prudence before, and We well knew of him

21:52.t: when he said to his father and his people, “What are these statues to which you are devoted?”

21:53.t: They said, “We found our forefathers worshiping them.”

21:54.t: He said, “Youpland your forefathers have been in evident misguidance.”

21:55.t: They said, “Have you come to us with the truth, or are you one of the jesters?”

21:56.t: He said, “Rather, your Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth, the One who originated them, and to that, I am one of those who bear witness.

21:57.t: And by Allah, I shall certainly plot against your human-shaped idols after you have turned away, fleeing.”

21:58.t: So he reduced them into pieces, except for their biggest, that they may return to it.

21:59.t: They said, “Who did this to our gods? Indeed, he is certainly one of the unjust.”

21:60.t: They said, “We heard a young man mentioning them; he is called Abraham.”

21:61.t: They said, “So bring him before the eyes of the people, that they may witness.”

21:62.t: They said, “Are you the one who did this to our gods, O Abraham?”

21:63.t: He said, “Rather, it was this biggest of them that did it, so ask them, if they can talk.”

21:64.t: So they turned to one another and said, “Indeed, you yourselves are the unjust.”

21:65.t: But they reverted to their old ideas: “Yousgcertainly know well that these do not talk.”

21:66.t: He said, “Do you worship, apart from Allah, what can neither benefit you in anything nor harm you?

21:67.t: Fie on you and on what you worship apart from Allah. Do you not reason?”

21:68.t: They said, “Burn him and support your gods, if you are going to act.”

21:69.t: We said, “O fire, be cool and peaceful upon Abraham.”

21:70.t: For they wanted to plot against him, so We made them the biggest losers.

21:71.t: And We delivered him and Lot to the land that We blessed for all(people of all)realms.

21:72.t: And We granted him Isaac and Jacob as an additional gift, and each We made righteous.

21:73.t: And We made them leaders, guiding by Our command, and We revealed to them(the command of)performing good works and establishing the prayer and bringing1the purifying charity2, for of Us they were worshipers.

f.80576: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.
f.80577: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

21:74.t: And Lot—We gave him wise judgment and knowledge, and We delivered him from the town that used to practice nasty things. They were indeed a wicked, defiantly disobedient people.

21:75.t: And We entered him into Our mercy; He is<sup foot_note="80578">1</sup>indeed one of the righteous.

f.80578: Frequently the Qur’an speaks about the prophets using present tense; this should be pondered by the reader.

21:76.t: And Noah, when he called before, so We responded to him and delivered him and his family from the great calamity.

23:37.t: There is nothing but our Earlier Life—we die and we live, and we will never be raised.

23:38.t: He is nothing but a man who has fabricated lies against Allah, and never will we believe him.”

23:39.t: He said, “My Lord, support me with what they have disbelieved me about.”

23:40.t: He said, “Soon they will definitely become remorseful.”

23:41.t: So the Shout took them away, according to the true(promise), and We turned them into scum. So away with the unjust people.

23:42.t: Then after them We brought forth other generations.

23:43.t: No community can advance its time, nor can they delay it.

23:44.t: Then We sent Our messengers in succession; every time a messenger came to his community, they disbelieved him. So We made them follow one another<sup foot_note="80631">1</sup>and made them history. So away with a people who do not believe.

23:45.t: Then We sent Moses and his brother Aaron with Our signs and an evident manifestation

23:46.t: to Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they acted arrogantly and they were a haughty people.

23:47.t: So they said, “Are we to believe in two human beings like us while their people are servants to us?”

23:48.t: So they disbelieved them both, and thus they became of those who were annihilated.

23:49.t: And indeed We gave Moses the Scripture, that they may be guided.

23:50.t: And We made the son of Mary and his mother a sign, and We sheltered them in a secure place on a hilltop with a spring.

23:51.t: “O messengers, eat of the good foods and do righteousness; indeed, I am All-Knowing of what youdo1.

f.80632: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . of what you do. And (know) that this community . . .”

23:52.t: For indeed, this community of yours is one community and I am your Lord, so be mindful of Me.”

23:53.t: But they tore themselves into sects, each party rejoicing in what they had.

23:54.t: So leavesgthem in their perplexity for a while.

23:55.t: Do they assume that, in supplying them with wealth and children,

23:56.t: We hasten to give them the good things? In fact, they are unaware.

23:57.t: Indeed, those who, out of awe for their Lord, are fearful,

23:58.t: and those who believe in their Lord’s signs,

23:59.t: and those who associate none with their Lord,

23:60.t: and those who bring whatever they bring while their hearts tremble, knowing that to their Lord they are returning—

23:61.t: those are the ones who hasten towards good works, and it is they who will reach it first.

23:62.t: And We never task any self beyond its capacity, and with Us is a record<sup foot_note="80633">1</sup>that tells the truth, and they will not be dealt with unjustly.

23:63.t: But their hearts are in perplexity as to this, and they have deeds other than that which they are doing,

23:64.t: until when We seize the affluent ones among them with punishment, they promptly begin to groan.

23:65.t: “Do not groan today; indeed, youplwill not be supported by Us.

23:66.t: Surely, My signs<sup foot_note="80634">1</sup>used to be recited to you, but you used to turn back on your heels

f.80634: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

23:67.t: in arrogance regarding it, conversing by night(about it),(yet)deserting1it2.”

f.80636: The pronoun in Arabic may be referring to either the Qur’an or the Prophet (peace be upon him).
f.80635: Qira’at: Nafieʻ read it as: “. . . conversing by night (about it), (yet) blaspheming .”

23:68.t: Have they not pondered the Word? Or has there come to them what came not to their forefathers of old?

23:69.t: Or is it that they did not recognize their messenger so they disacknowledge him?

23:70.t: Or do they say, “He is possessed?” Rather, he has come to them with the truth, but most of them are hateful of the truth.

23:71.t: Yet were the Truth to follow their whims, the heavens and the earth and everyone in them would have become corrupted. Rather, We have come up to them with their Reminder, but they keep disregarding their Reminder.

23:72.t: Or are yousgasking them for a payment? Rather, your Lord’s payment is better, for He is the best of providers.

23:73.t: And indeed, yousgare surely calling them to a straight path,

23:74.t: for those who do not believe in the Hereafter are most surely swerving from the path.

23:75.t: And were We to have mercy upon them and remove whatever harm is upon them, surely they would continue to wander aimlessly while exceeding all limits.

23:76.t: And most surely We gripped them with punishment, but they did not surrender to their Lord, nor do they supplicate(Him)

23:77.t: until, when We have opened before them a gate of intense punishment, they suddenly despair.

23:78.t: And it is He Who initiated for youplthe hearing and the sight(s)and the burning hearts; scarcely do you give thanks!

23:79.t: And it is He Who scattered youplon earth, and to Him you will be herded.

23:80.t: And it is He Who gives life and causes death, and to Him is the alternation of night and day. Do youplnot reason?

23:81.t: Rather, they said the like of what the ancients had said.

23:82.t: They said, “Can it be thatwhen we have died and become dust and bones,can it be that1we will really be resurrected?

f.80637: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “‘Can it be that when we have died and become dust andbones we will really be resurrected?’”Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “‘When we have died and become dust and bones, can it be that we will really be resurrected?’”

23:83.t: Most surely, we were promised this before, we and our forefathers—these are nothing but legends of the ancients.”

23:84.t: Saysg, “To whom does the earth and everyone in it belong, if youplhappen to know?”

23:85.t: They will say, “To Allah.” Saysg, “Will younever remember1?”

f.80638: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Saysg , ‘Will you not constantly remember ?’”

23:86.t: Saysg, “Who is the Lord of the seven heavens and Lord of the Great Throne?”

23:87.t: They will say, “To1Allah.” Saysg, “Will you never be mindful(of God)?”

f.80639: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “They will say, ‘Allah .’”

23:88.t: Saysg, “In whose hand is the dominance of everything, and He grants refuge but cannot be granted refuge, if you happen to know?”

23:89.t: They will say, “ToaAllah.” Saysg, “Then are you bewitched?”

23:90.t: Rather, We have come up to them with the truth, yet they are surely liars.

23:91.t: Never has Allah taken any offspring nor has there ever been any god with Him, for then each god would have taken away what he had created, and some of them would have gained supremacy over others. Highly Exalted is Allah, far above what they describe:

23:92.t: the Knower1of the hidden realm and the manifest. So Most High is He, far above what they associate(as gods with Him).

f.80640: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “. . . describe. (He is) the Knower of . . .”

23:93.t: Saysg, “My Lord, if You would show me what they are promised,

23:94.t: my Lord, do not make me among the unjust people.”

23:95.t: And We are surely able to show yousgwhat We promise them.

23:96.t: Repelsgwhat is bad by what is better. We know better what they describe.

23:97.t: And saysg, “My Lord, I seek refuge with You from the urgings of the devils,

23:98.t: and I seek refuge with You, my Lord, lest they become present with me.”

23:99.t: Until, when death comes to one of them, he says, “My Lord, send me back,

23:100.t: that I may act righteously in that which I have left(behind).” But no! It is just a word that he says, and behind them is a barrier until the day they are resurrected.

23:101.t: So when the Horn is blown, no ties of kinship between them exist on that day, nor do they ask one another.

23:102.t: So the one whose scales weigh heavy—those are the successful.

23:103.t: And the one whose scales weigh light—those are the ones who have lost themselves; in Hell they abide.

23:104.t: The Fire lashes their faces, and therein they grimace.

23:105.t: “Were not My signs1recited to youpl, but you used to disbelieve them?”

f.80641: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

23:106.t: They said<sup foot_note="80642">1</sup>, “Our Lord, our wretchedness overcame us, and we were a people astray.

f.80642: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

23:107.t: Our Lord, bring us out of this, and if we ever return, we would truly be unjust.”

23:108.t: He said, “Be despisedpltherein and do not speak to Me.

23:109.t: Indeed, there was a group of My servants who used to say, ‘Our Lord, we have attained faith, so forgive us and have mercy on us, and You are the best of the merciful.’

23:110.t: But youplmade them a target of ridicule until they made you forget My remembrance, and you used to laugh at them.

23:111.t: Today I have indeed rewarded them for what they endured patiently, forit1is they who are the triumphant ones.”

f.80643: Qira’at: Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . patiently. Indeed, it is they . . .”

23:112.t: He said1, “How long did you remain on earth in terms of number of years?”

f.80644: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “Say sg , ‘How long…’”

23:113.t: They said, “We remained a day or part of a day, so ask those who keep count.”

23:114.t: He said1, “Youplremained but for a little while, if you only knew.

f.80645: Qira’at: Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “Say sg , ‘You remained…’”

23:115.t: Did youplthink that We had created you in vain, and that to Usyou would not be returned1?”

f.80646: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . you would not return ?”

23:116.t: Rather, Most High is Allah, the True King; there is no god but He, the Lord of the Noble Throne.

23:117.t: And whoever calls upon another god with Allah—he has no proof thereof—his reckoning rests with his Lord; indeed, the deniers never succeed.

23:118.t: And saysg, “My Lord, forgive and have mercy, for You are the best of the merciful.”

24:1.t: A surah1that We have sent down andordained2and sent down in it evident signs3, that you mayremind yourselves4.

f.80647: Each portion of the Qur’an is called a ‘surah’, which is sometimes translated as ‘chapter’.
f.80648: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . and did ordain . . .”
f.80649: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.
f.80650: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . that you may constantly remember .”

24:2.t: The fornicating woman and the fornicating man—whip each one of them a hundred lashes and let no compassion towards them keep youplfrom carrying out Allah’s religion, if you(truly)believe in Allah and the Last Day, and let their punishment be witnessed by a group1of believers.

f.80651: The Arabic word used is the same as that translated as ‘faction’.

24:3.t: The fornicating man marries none but a fornicating woman or an idolatress, and the fornicating woman marries none but a fornicating man or an idolater, and that has been prohibited for the believers.

24:4.t: And those who accuse chaste women then cannot bring four witnesses—whipplthem eighty lashes and do not ever accept their testimony, for those are the defiantly disobedient—

24:5.t: except for those who have repented afterwards and reformed, for indeed, Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

24:6.t: And those who accuse their own spouses but have no witnesses except themselves, thenlet the testimony of one of them be four oaths1by Allah that he is surely of the truthful.

f.80652: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . then the testimony of one of them (is binding)—four oaths by Allah . . .”

24:7.t: And the fifth is:may1Allah’s curse indeedbeupon him if he is of the liars.

f.80653: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . may Allah’s curse be upon him . . .”

24:8.t: But what averts punishment from her is that she testifies under oath four times by Allah that he is surely of the liars,

24:9.t: while1the fifth is: may Allah’s wrath indeed beupon her if he is of the truthful.

f.80654: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Yaʻqub and Hafs read it as: “. . . liars. 9And the fifth is: may Allah’s wrath indeed be upon her . . .”Nafieʻ read it as: “. . . liars. 9And the fifth is that Allah’s wrath will have fallen upon her . . .”Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . liars. 9And the fifth is: may Allah’s wrath be upon her . . .”

24:10.t: And were it not for Allah’s grace upon youpl,and His mercy, and that Allah is the Granter and Accepter of repentance, All-Wise. . .1

f.80655: According to Al-Alousi and other exegetes, this sentence is left open-ended in order to magnify the predicate and leave it to the reader’s imagination.

24:11.t: Indeed, those who produced the fabrication are a band of you. Do not consider it bad for youpl; rather, it is good for you. For each person of them is whatever sin he has earned, yet the one who played the major role—for him is a great punishment.

24:12.t: If only when youplheard it, the believing men and the believing women had thought well of themselves1and said, “This is an evident fabrication!”

f.80656: The Qur’an used the term ‘themselves’ rather than ‘each other’ to make the believerssympathizewith one another by considering any defamation of one as defamation of all.

24:13.t: If only they had produced four witnesses against it. Yet since they did not come up with the witnesses, then before Allah they are the liars.

24:14.t: And were it not for Allah’s grace upon youpl,and His mercy in the Earlier(Life)and the Hereafter, you would have been touched by a great punishment for what you have ventured into.

24:15.t: Recall receiving it with your tongues and saying with your mouths what you had no knowledge of, and considering it trivial while with Allah it is greatly serious.

24:16.t: And if only when youplheard it you had said, “It is not lawful for us to speak about this. Highly Exalted are You; this is a great slander.”

24:17.t: Allah admonishes you never to return to the like of it if you are believers.

24:18.t: And Allah clarifies the signs to youpl, for Allah is All-Knowing, All-Wise.

24:19.t: Indeed, those who love that obscenity should spread among the believers—for them is a painful punishment in the Earlier(Life)and the Hereafter, for Allah knows while you know not.

24:20.t: And were it not for Allah’s grace upon youpl,and His mercy, and that Allah is Compassionate, Bestowing of mercy. . .1

f.80657: According to Al-Alousi and other exegetes, this sentence is left open-ended in order to magnify the predicate and leave it to the reader’s imagination.

24:21.t: O you who have attained faith, do not follow Satan’s footsteps, for whoever follows Satan’s footsteps(should know that)indeed he commands to obscenity and what is deplorable. And were it not for Allah’s grace towards you, and His mercy, not one of you would ever have been purified, ever, but Allah purifies whomever He wills. For Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.

24:22.t: And let not the ones endowed with grace and affluence swear not to give to the near relatives and the destitutepland the emigrants in the way of Allah, and let them pardon and let them overlook. Do youplnot love that Allah should forgive you? For Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

24:23.t: Those who accuse chaste, unwary, believing women are indeed cursed in the Earlier(Life)and the Hereafter, and for them is a great punishment

24:24.t: on the day when their tongues and their hands and their feet testify against them regarding what they used to do.

24:25.t: On that day, Allah pays them their true recompense in full, and they learn that it is Allah who is the Evident Truth.

24:26.t: Nasty<sup foot_note="80658">1</sup>ones are for nasty men, and nasty men are for nasty ones, and good ones are for good men, and good men are for good ones. Those are acquitted of what they say; for them is forgiveness and a noble provision.

f.80658: The words ‘nasty’ and ‘good’ are mentioned in feminine form and may refer either to ‘nasty women’ and ‘good women’ or to ‘nasty words and ‘good words’.

24:27.t: O you who have attained faith, do not enter houses other than your own houses until you announce your presence and greet their inhabitants with the greeting of peace. That is better for you, that you may remind yourselves.

24:28.t: But if youplfind no one in them, then do not enter them until you are given permission. And if it is said to you, “Turn back,” then turn back; it is purer for you, for Allah is All-Knowing of what you do.

24:29.t: Youplcommit no sin by entering uninhabited houses in which there is convenience for you, for Allah knows whatever you disclose and whatever you conceal.

24:30.t: Tellsgthe believing men to restrain their sight(s)1and to preserve their private parts; that is purer for them. Indeed, Allah is All-Aware of what they do.

f.80659: Mentioned in plural form in Arabic, denoted by (s) in English for grammatical reasons.

24:31.t: And tellsgthe believing women to restrain their sight(s)and to preserve their private parts, and not display their adornment except what is apparent thereof, and to draw their head coverings over their bosoms and not display their adornment except to their husbands, or their fathers, or their husbands’ fathers, or their sons, or their husbands’ sons, or their brothers, or their brothers’ sons, or their sisters’ sons, or their womenfolk, or those whom they rightfully possess, or their male attendants who have no(sexual)urge, or children who are not yet aware of women’s privacies, and they should not strike their feet to draw attention to their hidden adornment. Thus repent to Allah, all of you, O believers, that you may succeed.

24:32.t: And marry the singles among you and those who are fit among your bondmen and bondwomen. If they are poor, Allah will enrich them from His grace. For Allah is All-Encompassing, All-Knowing.

24:33.t: And let those who do not find the means to marry remain chaste until Allah enriches them from His grace. And if any of those whom youplrightfully possess desire an(emancipation)agreement, write an agreement with them if you recognize some good in them, and give them of Allah’s wealth which He has given you. And do not compel your maids to prostitution, seeking the materials of the Earlier(Life), if they want to remain chaste. But should anyone compel them—then after their compulsion, Allah is indeed Oft-Forgiving1, Bestowing of mercy.

24:34.t: And We have most surely sent down to youplclarifying1signs and a parable from those who passed on before you2, and an admonition for the ones who were mindful(of God).

f.80662: Referring to the story of the slander of Yusuf.
f.80661: Qira’at: All except for Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . clarified signs . . .”

24:35.t: Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth. The parable of His light is as a niche wherein is a lamp; the lamp is in a glass; the glass is like a glittering planet,kindled1from a blessed tree—an olive tree—neither eastern nor western. Its oil would almost illuminate even if no fire were to touch it. Light upon light. Allah guides to His light whomever He wills. Thus Allah sets forth parables for mankind. For Allah is All-Knowing of everything.

f.80663: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar, Yaʻqub, Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Hafs read “kindled” in masculine form referring to the lamp being kindled from the oil of a blessed tree. All others read it in feminine form referring to the glass being kindled.

24:36.t: (Such light shines)in houses which Allah has permitted to be raised up and in which His name is remembered.Highly exalting1Him therein, mornings and before sunset,

f.80664: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer, and Shuʻba read it as: “He is highly exalted therein, mornings and before sunset — 37men whom . . .”

24:37.t: are menwhom neither bargain nor sale distracts from Allah’s remembrance or from establishing the prayers or from bringing1the purifying charity2, fearing a day when hearts and sight(s)are overturned,

f.80665: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.
f.80666: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

24:38.t: (in the hope)that Allah may repay them according to the best of what they have done and increase them from His grace. For Allah provides for whomever He wills without measure.

24:39.t: But those who have denied—their deeds are like a mirage in a desert: the thirsty one thinks it is water until when he has reached it he finds it to be nothing, but there he finds Allah, Who settles his account in full. For Allah is Swift in reckoning.

24:40.t: Or(they are)like darkness(es)1in an abysmal sea, covered by waves, above which are waves, above which areclouds—darkness(es)2, one upon the other. If one holds out his hand, he can hardly see it. For whomever Allah has not granted a light has no light.

f.80667: Mentioned in plural form in Arabic, denoted by (es) in English for grammatical reasons.
f.80668: Qira’at: Al-Bazzi read it as: “. . . above which are clouds of darkness(es) . . .”Qunbul read it as: “. . . above which are clouds. (These) darkness(es) (are) one upon the other.”

24:41.t: Have yousgnot seen how Allah is highly exalted by whoever is in the heavens and the earth and by the birds outstretching their wings, each having come to know its(way of)prayer and exaltation? And Allah is All-Knowing of what they do.

24:42.t: For to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, and to Allah is the destiny.

24:43.t: Have you not seen how Allah propels clouds, then brings them together, then piles them up in heaps so you see rainfall coming out of its midst? And Hesends down1from the sky—from mountains in it— some hail, striking with it whomever He wills and diverting it from whomever He wills? The flash of its lightening almost does away with the sight(s).

f.80669: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “And He bestows from on high, from the sky—from mountains . . .”

24:44.t: Allah alternates night and day. Indeed, in that is a lesson for those endowed with sight(s).

24:45.t: And Allahcreated1every treading creature from water, so of them is one(kind)that treads upon its belly, and one(kind)that treads upon two legs, and one(kind)that treads upon four; Allah creates whatever He wills; Allah is indeed Powerful over everything.

f.80670: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “And Allah is the Creator of every treading creature . . .”

24:46.t: Most surely, We have sent downclarifying1signs2, and Allah guides whomever He wills to a straight path.

f.80672: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.
f.80671: Qira’at: All except for Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . clarified signs . . .”

24:47.t: And they say, “We have attained faith in Allah and in the Messenger, and we have obeyed.” Then a group of them turn away afterwards, for in no way are those ever believers.

24:48.t: And when they are called to Allah and His Messenger in orderto judge1between them, a group of them promptly disregards(it);

f.80673: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . in order to have it judged between them . . .”

24:49.t: but if the truth is in their favor, they come to Him in obedience.

24:50.t: Is there sickness in their hearts? Or have they doubted? Or do they fear that Allah may oppress them, or(that)His Messenger(may do so)? In fact, they themselves are the unjust.

24:51.t: However, the response of the believers when they are called to Allah and His Messenger in order tojudgecbetween them has always been to say, “We have heard and obeyed”, for those are the successful.

For if you obey him, you will be guided, while the only responsibility of the Messenger is evident proclamation.

24:55.t: Allah has promised those of you who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds that He will most surely make them successors in the land asHe made those before them successors1(of others), and that He will most surely establish for them their religion which He has approved for them, and that He will most surely substitute security in place of their fear—as they worship Me2, never associating anything with Me. f.80676: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “. . . as those before them were made successors (of others) . . .”

24:56.t: And establishplthe prayer and bring1the purifying charity2and obey the Messenger, that you may be granted mercy.

f.80678: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.
f.80679: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

f.80680: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Hamza read it as: “Those who have denied should never think that they can thwart . . .”
