f.80681: Qira’at: All except for Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . seek your permission (before entering). Three occasions . . .”

24:59.t: And when the children among you reach puberty, let them seek permission as those before them have sought permission; Allah thus clarifies His signs for you. For Allah is All-Knowing, All-Wise.

24:60.t: And elderly women who do not expect(to be desired in)marriage—they commit no sin by taking off their outer clothing without flaunting their adornment, but to maintain modesty is better for them. For Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.

24:61.t: There is no blame on the blind, nor any blame on the lame, nor any blame on the sick, nor on yourselves for eating at your houses , or your fathers’ houses, or your mothers’ houses, or your brothers’ houses, or your sisters’ houses, or the houses of your paternal uncles, or the houses of your paternal aunts, or the houses of your maternal uncles, or the houses of your maternal aunts, or those whose keys you own, or that of a friend of yours. You commit no sin by eating together or separately. But when you enter such houses, greet yourselves with a greeting from Allah, blessed(and)good; Allah thus explains the signs for you, that you may reason.

24:62.t: Indeed, the believers are but those who have attained faith in Allah and His Messenger and, when they are with him for a matter of common interest, they do not leave until they have sought his permission. Indeed, those who seek yoursgpermission—those are the ones who believe in Allah and His Messenger. So if they seek your permission to attend to some affair of theirs, give permission to any of them you wish and seek Allah’s forgiveness for them; indeed, Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

24:63.t: Do not make the calling of the Messenger among yourselves like your calling of one another. Allah certainly knows those<sup foot_note="80682">1</sup>among you who slip away, concealed by others. So let those who oppose his command beware, lest a trial afflict them or a painful punishment afflict them.

24:64.t: Undoubtedly, to Allah does belong whatever is in the heavens and the earth; surely, He knows yourplcondition. And on the daythey are returned1to Him, He informs them of what they did. For Allah is All-Knowing of everything.

f.80683: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . they return to Him . . .”

25:1.t: Supremely Blessed be the One Who bestowed the Criterion from on high upon His servant, to be a warner<sup foot_note="80684">1</sup>to all realms.

f.80684: The Arabic text can imply either the Prophet (peace be upon him) as a warner, or the Criterion as a warning.

25:2.t: The One to Whom belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, and Who has not taken for Himself any offspring nor has He any associate in the dominion, and He has created everything and determined its measure.

25:3.t: And they have taken apart from Him gods who do not create anything, but are themselves created, and who possess for themselves neither harm nor benefit, and have no power over life or death or resurrection.

25:4.t: Moreover, those who have denied said, “This is nothing but a fabrication that he has forged, while other people have helped him with it.” They have certainly come forth with injustice and falsehood.

25:5.t: And they said, “Legends of the ancients that he has sought to be written down; thus they are dictated to him morning and evening.”

25:6.t: Saysg, “It was sent down by the One Who knows the Secret in the heavens and the earth; indeed, He has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.”

25:7.t: And they said, “What sort of messenger is this who eats food and walks in marketplaces? If only an angel had been sent down to him to be a warner alongside him,

25:8.t: or if a treasure were to be cast to him, or if he had a garden from whichhe eats1.” And the unjust ones said, “Youplare only following a bewitched man.”

f.80685: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “‘…from which we eat .’”

25:9.t: Looksghow they have set forth parables for you and gone astray, so they cannot find a way.

25:10.t: Supremely Blessed be the One Who, if He so willed, would provide yousgwith better than that—Gardens beneath which rivers flow—and make1for you palaces.

f.80686: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer and Shuʻba read it as: “. . . would provide yousg with better than that—Gardens beneath which rivers flow. And He would make for you palaces.”

25:11.t: Rather, they have considered the Hour to be a lie, and We have prepared a blaze for those who have disbelieved in the Hour.

25:12.t: When it sees them from a distant place, they hear its raging and roaring.

25:13.t: And when they are cast, shackled, into a tight place therein, there they plead for demise.

25:14.t: “Do not callplfor one demise today, but call for many demises.”

25:15.t: Saysg, “Is that better or the Garden of Eternity promised to the ones who were mindful(of God)? For them it has always been a repayment anda destiny.

25:16.t: They have therein whatever they desire, as they abide. That has always been yoursgLord’s promise,(worthy)to be requested.

25:17.t: And on the day whenHe1herdsthemand what they worship apart from Allah, thenHesays2, “Was it youplwho misguided these servants of Mine, or was it they who strayed from the way?”

f.80687: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, Hafs, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . when We herd them . . .”
f.80688: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . then We say . . .”

25:18.t: They said1, “Highly Exalted are You. We should nothave taken any2masters apart from You. But you allowed them to enjoy, as well as their fathers, until they forgot the Reminder and became a ruined people.”

f.80689: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.
f.80690: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “We should not have been taken as masters . . .”

25:19.t: Thus they1have certainly disbelieved youplregarding what you say, soyou2can neither avoid(punishment)nor get any support. And whoever of you commits injustice, We will make him taste a supreme punishment.

f.80692: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . so they can neither avoid (punishment) . . .”

25:20.t: And never did We send any emissaries before yousgbut they used to eat food and walk in the marketplaces. And We made some of you a means of trial for others—will you be patient? And your Lord has always been All-Seeing.

25:21.t: And those who do not expect to meet Us said, “If only the angels were sent down to us or we could see our Lord.” They have acted arrogantly regarding themselves and have become excessively defiant.

25:22.t: On the day when they see the angels—no glad tidings for the criminals on that day, and they<sup foot_note="80693">1</sup>say, “an insurmountable separator<sup foot_note="80694">2</sup>.”

25:23.t: And We proceeded<sup foot_note="80695">1</sup>to the work they had done and turned them into scattered dust.

f.80695: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

25:24.t: The fellows of the Garden(of Paradise)on that day have a better residence and are more fairly accommodated.

25:25.t: And it is the day when the sky is cleft with clouds andthe angels werecsent down1in streams.

f.80696: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . and We send down the angels in streams.”

25:26.t: Dominion on that day belongs to the All-Merciful, and it has been a difficult day for the deniers.

25:27.t: And it is the day when the unjust bites his hands, saying, “If only I had followed the way with the Messenger.

25:28.t: Woe to me! I wish I had not taken so-and-so for a close friend;

25:29.t: he definitely made me stray away from the Reminder after it had come to me.” And Satan has always been a betrayer of man.”

25:30.t: And the Messenger saidc, “O My Lord, my people have dealt with this Recital1by deserting it.”

f.80697: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

25:31.t: Likewise, to every prophet We assigned enemies from among the criminals. But sufficient is yoursgLord as a Guide and Supporter.

25:32.t: And those who denied said, “If only the Recitalehad been sent down upon him as one complete whole!” Yet(it is sent in this way)in order to strengthen your heart thereby, and We(revealed it to be)chanted slowly and distinctly.

25:33.t: And whatever similitude they come to yousgwith, We provide you with the truth and a better exposition.

25:34.t: Those who are herded to Hell on their faces—those are in a worse position and further astray from the way.

25:35.t: And surely We gave Moses the Scripture and appointed his brother Aaron as an assistant,

25:36.t: then We said, “Godlto the people who have disbelieved Our signs,” then We destroyed them completely.

25:37.t: And when the people of Noah disbelieved the messengers, We drowned them and made them a sign for mankind. And We have prepared a painful punishment for the unjust,

25:38.t: and(for)ʻĀd1and Thamûd2and the fellows of Al-Russ3and many generations in between.

f.80698: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.
f.80699: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.
f.80700: At-Tabari mentioned that some exegetes said thatAl-Russ was a huge water pit.

25:39.t: Thus to each We set forth parables, and each We devastated utterly.

25:40.t: And indeed they have already come across the city<sup foot_note="80701">1</sup>upon which was rained the woeful rain. Have they not seen it then? Rather, they did not expect any resurrection.

f.80701: The city inhabited by the people of Lot.

25:41.t: And when they see yousg, they take you not except in ridicule: “Is this the one Allah has sent as a messenger?

25:42.t: He was about to make us stray away from our gods, had we not patiently adhered to them.” And they will eventually know, when they witness the punishment, who is further astray from the way.

25:43.t: Have yousgseen the one who took his own whim as his god? Would you be a trustee for him?

25:44.t: Or do yousgassume that most of them hear or reason? They are but like livestock; rather, they are even further astray from the way.

25:45.t: Have yousgnot seen how your Lord extended the shade? And had He willed, He could have made it still. Then We made the sun a guide to it.

25:46.t: Then We drew it to Us easily.

25:47.t: And it is He Who made the night for youplas a garment and sleep for repose, and made the day a(time of)resurrection.

25:48.t: And it is He Who sent thewinds1asheralds of glad tidings2ahead of His mercy. And We3sent down from the sky pure water

f.80702: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “wind ”.
f.80703: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . as revivers ahead of His mercy”.All except for ʻAsem, Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . as a revival ahead of His mercy”.

25:49.t: to revive a lifeless land thereby, and to provide drink for a multitude of animals and humans We have created.

25:50.t: And most surely We have circulated it among them, that they mayconstantly remember1, yet most of mankind refused anything but constant denial.

f.80705: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . that they may remember . . .”

25:51.t: And had We willed, We could have sent to every town a warner.

25:52.t: So do not obeysgthe deniers, but strive against them with it1a supreme striving.

25:53.t: And it is He Who merged the two seas, this one fresh and sweet and this one salty and bitter, and He made between them a barrier and an insurmountable separator.

25:54.t: And it is He Who created of water a human being, then made him related by lineage and marriage. And yoursgLord has always been All-Able.

25:55.t: Yet they worship, apart from Allah, what neither benefits them nor harms them. And the denier has always been a backup against his Lord.

25:56.t: And We have not sent you but as a bearer of glad tidings and as a warner.

25:57.t: Saysg, “I ask of you no reward for this—only that whoever wills may take a way to his Lord.”

25:58.t: And place yoursgtrust in the Ever-Living One Who never dies, and exalt Him with praise. And sufficient is He as the All-Aware of the misdeeds of His servants.

25:59.t: The One Who created the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them in six days1then settled on the Throne. The All-Merciful. So ask about Him one(who is)well aware.

f.80707: Six equal intervals of time, which may be six heavenly days, each of them being 1000 earthly years long (Verse 22:47).

25:60.t: And when it is said to them, “Prostrate yourselves to the All-Merciful,” they say, “And what is the All-Merciful? Shall we prostrate ourselves to whatyou command1us?” And it increases their aversion.

f.80708: Qira’at: Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . what He commands us ?”

25:61.t: Supremely Blessed be the One Who placed constellations in the sky and placed in ita lamp1and an illuminating moon.

f.80709: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . in it lamps and . . .”

25:62.t: And it is He Who made the night and the day alternate—for whoever wants toconstantly remember1or wants to give constant thanks.

f.80710: Qira’at: Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “. . . wants to remember or wants to . . .”

25:63.t: And the servants of the All-Merciful are those who walk the earth gently<sup foot_note="80711">1</sup>, and when the ignorant harassers address them, they say, “Peace.”

25:64.t: And they are those who spend the night prostrating themselves to their Lord and standing(in prayer).

25:65.t: And they are those who say, ‘‘Our Lord, avert from us the punishment of Hell; indeed, its suffering has been ever adhering;

25:66.t: it is indeed bad as a residence and dwelling place.”

25:67.t: And they are those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor stingy, for the upright method has always been between both.

25:68.t: And they are those who do not call upon any other god with Allah and do not kill the self which Allah has made inviolable—except in the pursuit of justice—and do not fornicate. And whoever does that encounters penalties.

25:69.t: The punishment is doubled for him on the Day of Resurrection, and he abides therein humiliated—

25:70.t: except for whoever has repented and has attained faith and has done righteous work, for those—Allah replaces their evil deeds with good deeds. And Allah has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

25:71.t: And whoever has repented and has acted righteously, then surely he repents to Allah a true repentance.

25:72.t: And they are those who do not bear false witness, and when they come across idle talk, they pass by with dignity.

25:73.t: And they are those who, when reminded of the signs<sup foot_note="80712">1</sup>of their Lord, do not fall before them deaf and blind.

f.80712: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

25:74.t: And they are those who say, “Our Lord, grant us in our spouses andour offspring(s)1a comfort to the eyes, and make us a good example of the ones who were mindful(of God).”

f.80713: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . our offspring . . .”

25:75.t: Those are awarded the Chamber(in Heaven)for their patience, andare received1therein with greetings and peace,

f.80714: Qira’at: Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and will encounter therein greetings and peace . . .”

25:76.t: abiding therein—an excellent residence and dwelling place.

25:77.t: Saysg, “What are youplto my Lord without your calling upon Him? But you have certainly disbelieved, so the inevitable is bound to come.”

26:2.t: Those are the signs of the Evident Scripture.

26:3.t: Perhaps yousgare going to destroy yourself with sorrow because they do not believe?

26:4.t: If We will, We canbestow1upon them a sign from heaven, at which their necks would stay bent in humility.

f.80715: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . We can send down upon them . . .”

26:5.t: But no fresh reminder comes to them from the All-Merciful but they disregard it.

26:6.t: Thus they have certainly disbelieved, but soon will come to them the tidings of what they used to ridicule.

26:7.t: Have they not seen the land— how many noble kinds of plants We have germinated therein?

26:8.t: Indeed, in that is a sign, and in no way were most of them believers.

26:9.t: And indeed, it is yoursgLord who is surely the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy.

26:10.t: And recall when Your Lord called to Moses, “Go to the unjust people—

26:11.t: the people of Pharaoh. Will they never be mindful?”

26:12.t: He said, “My Lord, I fear that they will disbelieve me.

26:13.t: And my chest tightens1and my tongueis not fluent, so send for Aaron(too).

f.80716: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “I fear that they will disbelieve me 13and that my chest will tighten and my tongue will not be fluent . . .”

26:14.t: And they hold(a charge of)a misdeed against me, so I fear they will kill me.”

26:15.t: He said, “By no means! So godl, with Our signs; We are with youpl, listening.

26:16.t: So godlto Pharaoh and say, ‘We are indeed the Messenger of the Lord of all realms:

26:17.t: send the Children of Israel with us.’”

26:18.t: He said, “Did we not raise yousgamong us as a child, and you stayed among us for many years of your life?

26:19.t: And yousgcommitted that base deed of yours that you committed while you were one of the deniers1.”

26:20.t: He said, “I did it then while I was one of those astray.

26:21.t: And I fled from youplwhen I feared you, then my Lord gave me wise judgment and made me one of the emissaries.

26:22.t: And is that a favor yousgremind me of: that you have enslaved the Children of Israel?”

26:23.t: Pharaoh said, “And what is the Lord of all realms?”

26:24.t: He said, “The Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, if youpl(can ever)believe with certitude.”

26:25.t: He said to those around him, “Are you listening?”

26:26.t: He said, “YourplLord and the Lord of your ancient fathers.”

26:27.t: He said, “This messenger of yours who has been sent to you is certainly a madman.”

26:28.t: He said, “The Lord of the east and the west and whatever is between them, if youplcan(ever)reason.”

26:29.t: He said, “If yousgaccept any god other than me, I will surely make you of the imprisoned.”

26:30.t: He said, “What if I bring yousgsomething evident?”

26:31.t: He said, “Bring it, if yousgare of the truthful.”

26:32.t: So he cast his staff and thereupon it was an evident serpent.

26:33.t: And he pulled his hand and thereupon it was white for the beholders.

26:34.t: He said to the chiefs around him, “This is indeed a knowledgeable sorcerer

26:35.t: who wants to evict you from your land with his sorcery, so what do you command?”

26:36.t: They said, “Put him off, and his brother, and send summoners to the cities

26:37.t: to bring yousgevery knowledgeable magician.”

26:38.t: So the sorcerers were assembled for the appointment on a specified day.

26:39.t: And people were told, “Are you going to assemble,

26:40.t: that we may follow the sorcerers if they are the overcomers?”

26:41.t: So when the sorcerers arrived, they said to Pharaoh, “Is there a reward for us if we are the overcomers?”

26:42.t: He said, “Yes, and you will then most surely become of those brought near(to me).”

26:43.t: Moses said to them, “Cast whatever you intend to cast.”

26:44.t: So they cast their ropes and their staffs and said, “By Pharaoh’s might, we are most surely the overcomers.”

26:45.t: Then Moses threw his staff, and thereupon it swallowed what they had fabricated.

26:46.t: So the sorcerers fell down prostrating.

26:47.t: They said, “We have attained faith in the Lord of all realms,

26:48.t: the Lord of Moses and Aaron.”

26:49.t: He said, “Have youplbelieved in him before I have given you permission? He must be your leader who taught you sorcery. Well, you will certainly know soon; I will most surely cut off your hands and feet on opposite sides, and I will most surely crucify you all.”

26:50.t: They said, “No problem; indeed, to our Lord we are returning.

26:51.t: We ardently hope our Lord will forgive us our offenses, as we were the first of the believers.”

26:52.t: And We revealed to Moses: “Journey withMy servants by night; youplwill indeed be followed.”

26:53.t: So Pharaoh sent summoners to the cities.

26:54.t: “Indeed, these are just a small gang,

26:55.t: and they certainly do enrage us.

26:56.t: But indeed, we arecautious1.”

f.80718: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hisham, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . we are constantly cautious .”

26:57.t: So We got them out from gardens and springs

26:58.t: and treasures and a noble domicile.

26:59.t: So it was. And We made the Children of Israel inherit them.

26:60.t: And they pursued them at sunrise.

26:61.t: And when the two groups sighted each other, the followers of Moses said, “We are indeed overtaken!”

26:62.t: He said, “By no means! My Lord is indeed with me; He will guide me.”

26:63.t: So We revealed to Moses: “Strike the sea with your staff,” whereupon it split, so that each part was like a great hill.

26:64.t: And thereupon, we brought the others near.

26:65.t: Then We saved Moses and those with him, all of them.

26:67.t: Most surely in that is a sign, and in no way were most of them believers.

26:68.t: And most surely, yoursgLord is the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy.

26:69.t: And relate to them the tiding of Abraham,

26:70.t: when he said to his father and his people, “What do you worship?”

26:71.t: They said, “We worship human-shaped idols and we remain consecrating ourselves to them.”

26:72.t: He said, “Can they hear youplwhen you call?

26:73.t: Or can they benefit you, or can they do harm?”

26:74.t: They said, “Rather, we found our forefathers doing so.”

26:75.t: He said, “Have you seen what you have been worshiping,

26:77.t: They are enemies to me, except for the Lord of all realms,

26:78.t: Who created me and therefore He guides me;

26:79.t: and Who feeds me and gives me to drink;

26:80.t: and when I get sick, He heals me;

26:81.t: and Who makes me die and then revives me;

26:82.t: and Whom I ardently hope will forgive me my offense on the Day of Recompense.”

26:83.t: “My Lord, grant me wise judgment and include me with the righteous,

26:84.t: and make me a reputation of truth among later generations,

26:85.t: and make me of the inheritors of the Garden of Bliss,

26:86.t: and forgive my father—he was indeed one of those astray,

26:87.t: and do not disgrace me on the day they are resurrected:

26:88.t: the day when neither wealth nor children are of help—

26:89.t: except for one who has come<sup foot_note="80719">1</sup>to Allah witha sound heart.”

f.80719: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

26:90.t: And the Garden(of Paradise)was brought near for those who had been mindful,

26:91.t: while purgatory was displayed to the deluded ones.

26:92.t: And they were told, “Where is what you used to worship

26:93.t: apart from Allah? Can they support you or get support for themselves?”

26:94.t: Then they were toppled into it, together with the deluded ones

26:95.t: and the troops of Iblis<sup foot_note="80720">1</sup>, all of them.

f.80720: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.

26:96.t: They said, as they disputed about it,

26:97.t: “(We swear)by Allah, we were surely in evident misguidance

26:98.t: for equating youplwith the Lord of all realms.

26:99.t: But no one misguided us except the criminals.

26:100.t: And now we neither have intercessors

26:102.t: So if only we could have another chance, we would be of the believers.”

26:103.t: Most surely in that is a sign, and in no way were most of them believers.

26:104.t: And most surely, yoursgLord is the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy.

26:105.t: The people of Noah disbelieved the emissaries

26:106.t: when their brother Noah said to them, “Will you never be mindful?

26:107.t: Indeed, I am to you a trustworthy messenger.

26:108.t: So be mindful of Allah and obey me.

26:109.t: And I ask of you no reward for this, for my reward is only from the Lord of all realms.

26:110.t: So be mindful of Allah and obey me.”

26:111.t: They said, “Shall we believe in you, when(only)the lowliest have followed you1?”

f.80721: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “Shall we believe in you and your followers— the lowliest ?”

26:112.t: He said, “What do I know about what they used to do?

26:113.t: Their reckoning rests only with my Lord, if only you were aware.

26:114.t: And in no way would I expel the believers;

26:115.t: I am only an evident warner.”

26:116.t: They said, “If you do not refrain, O Noah, you will most surely be of those stoned.”

26:117.t: He said, “My Lord, my people have disbelieved me.

26:118.t: So legislate between me and them decisively, and deliver me and those who are with me of the believers.

26:119.t: So We saved him and those with him in the laden ship.

26:121.t: Most surely in that is a sign, and in no way were most of them believers.

26:122.t: And most surely, yoursgLord is the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy.

f.80722: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

26:124.t: when their brother Hûd said to them, “Will you never be mindful?

26:125.t: Indeed, I am to youpla trustworthy messenger.

26:126.t: So be mindful of Allah and obey me.

26:127.t: And I ask of you no reward for this, for my reward is only from the Lord of all realms.

26:128.t: Do you build a sign on every height for vanity’s sake?

26:129.t: And you set up fortresses, hoping to live eternally?

26:130.t: And when youplstrike, you strike mercilessly?

26:131.t: So be mindful of Allah and obey me.

26:132.t: And be mindful of the One Who supplied you with whatever you know.

26:133.t: He supplied you with livestock and children

26:135.t: Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a great day.”

26:136.t: They said, “It is equal to us, whether you admonish or be not of those who admonish.

26:137.t: This is nothing but thecharacter1of the ancients,

f.80723: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, ʻAsem, Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “. . . but the creation of the ancients . . .”

26:138.t: and we will never be punished.”

27:5.t: those are the ones for whom is the worst punishment, and in the Hereafter they are the biggest losers.

27:6.t: And indeed, yousgare surely receiving the Recitalbfrom One who is All-Wise, All-Knowing.

f.80735: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . or bring you a firebrand of a borrowed flame . . .”

27:9.t: O Moses, it is indeed I, Allah, the Almighty, the All-Wise.

27:11.t: except for one who did an injustice then substituted kindness for evil—then I am surely Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

27:12.t: And put your hand inside the opening of your garment(and)it will come out white, without any evil affliction—among nine signs to Pharaoh and his people; they have indeed been a defiantly disobedient people.”

27:13.t: So when Our signs came to them as an eye-opener, they said, “This is evident sorcery.”

27:14.t: And they repudiated them, though their(inner)selves were certain of them—out of injustice and haughtiness; so looksgwhat the outcome was for the corrupters.

27:15.t: And indeed, We brought David and Solomon knowledge, and they said, “Praise be to Allah, Who has favored us over many of His believing servants.”

27:16.t: And Solomon succeeded David, and he said, “O mankind, we have been taught the language of birds, and we have been given of everything; this is most surely the evident grace.”

27:17.t: And to the service of Solomon were herded his troops of unseen beings<sup foot_note="80736">1</sup>and men and birds, all held in strict order,

f.80736: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

27:18.t: until, when they came upon the valley of ants, an ant said, “O you ants! Enter into your homes, lest Solomon and his troops crush you while they are unaware.”

27:19.t: So he smiled, laughing at her speech, and said, “My Lord, direct me to be thankful for Your blessings which you have bestowed upon me and upon my parents, and to do righteousness that well pleases You. And include me, by Your mercy, among Your righteous servants.”

27:20.t: Then he inspected the birds and said, “What is it with me? Can I not see the hoopoe, or is he among the absentees?

27:21.t: Most surely, I will either punish him severely or slay him, unless he brings me an evident excuse.”

27:22.t: But he did not stay away for long and he said, “I have encompassed that which you have not encompassed, and I have come to you from Sheba with sure tidings.

27:23.t: I found a woman reigning over them, and she has been given of everything, and she has a great throne.

27:24.t: I found her and her people prostrating to the sun apart from Allah, for Satan has adorned their deeds for them and has thus barred them from the way, so that they are not guided—

27:25.t: that they do not1prostrate themselvesto Allah, Who brings out what is hidden in the heavens and the earth, and knows whateveryou2hide and whateveryoumake public.

f.80738: Qira’at: All except for Hafs and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . whatever they hide and whatever they make public .”

27:26.t: Allah—there is no god but He, Lord of the Great Throne.”

f.80739: The Arabic word used is Muslimeenwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

27:78.t: Indeed, yoursgLord decrees between them by His wise judgment, and He is the Almighty, the All-Knowing.

27:79.t: So place yoursgtrust in Allah; you are indeed upon the evident truth.

28:7.t: And We revealed to Moses’ mother, “Nurse him, then when you fear for him, cast him into the waters and do not fear and do not grieve; We are surely returning him to you and making him one of the emissaries.”

28:8.t: Then Pharaoh’s folk picked him up(only)to be an enemy and a(source of)grief for them. Indeed, Pharaoh and Hamān and their troops were wrongdoers.

28:9.t: So Pharaoh’s wife said, “A comfort to the eye for me and for yousg. Doplnot kill him; hopefully he may be useful to us, or we may take him as a son.” And they were unaware.

28:10.t: And Moses’ mother felt a void in her burning heart so that she almost declared him, had We not steadied her heart, that she may remain of the believers.

28:11.t: Thus she said to his sister, “Trail him.” So she watched him from afar while they were unaware.

28:12.t: And We had forbidden all wet nurses for him, so she said, “Shall I tell youplabout a household that can raise him for you and look after him?”

28:13.t: Thus We returned him to his mother, that her eye might be comforted and that she may not grieve, and so that she would know that Allah’s promise is true; yet most of them do not know.

28:14.t: And when he had attained his full strength and had matured, We gave him wise judgment and knowledge, for thus do We repay thosewho excel in doing good.

28:15.t: And(one day)he entered the city unnoticed by its people and found in it two men fighting—one of his own sect and one from his enemies, so the one of his sect solicited his assistance against the one from his enemies, so Moses struck him and put an end to him. He said, “This is of Satan’s work; he is indeed an evidently misguiding enemy.”

28:16.t: He said, “My Lord, I have indeed been unjust to myself, so forgive me.” So He forgave him; indeed, He is the Oft-Forgiving, the Bestower of mercy.

28:17.t: He said, “My Lord, because of the blessings You have bestowed upon me, I shall not be a backup for criminals.”

28:18.t: So the next morning he was walking about the city, fearful(and)vigilant, when suddenly the man who had sought his support the day before cried out to him. Moses said to him, “You are an evident deluder.”

28:19.t: And as he was about to strike the one who was their enemy, he said, “O Moses, do you want to kill me as you killed someone yesterday? You only want to be a tyrant in the land and do not want to be of the reformers.”

28:20.t: And a man came running from the farthest part of the city; he said, “O Moses, the chiefs are conspiring to kill you, so get out; I am indeed one of those who seek to advise you.”

28:21.t: So he went out of it, fearful(and)vigilant; he said, “My Lord, deliver me from the unjust people.”

28:22.t: And as he headed towards Midian, he said, “Hopefully, my Lord will guide me to the right way.”

28:23.t: And when he arrived at the waters of Midian he found there a crowd of people drawing water, and he found two women holding their flocks on the side. He said, “What is the matter with youdl?” They said, “We cannot draw water until the shepherds depart, and our father is a very old man.”

28:24.t: So he drew water for them and then turned away to the shade and said, “My Lord, I am in dire need of whatever good you have sent down for me.”

28:25.t: Then one of them came to him, walking bashfully. She said, “My father is calling you to repay you, as a reward for drawing water for us.” So when he came to him and narrated to him the narratives, he said, “Do not fear; you are(now)safe from the unjust people.”

28:26.t: One of them said, “Father, hire him; indeed, the best one you can hire is one who is strong (and)trustworthy.”

28:27.t: He said, “I surely wish to marry you to one of these two daughters of mine, provided you work for me for the term of eight pilgrimages; but if you complete ten, that is up to you, for I do not desire to impose any hardship on you. You will find me, Allah willing, one of the righteous.”

28:28.t: He said, “Let this be(an agreement)between you and me; whichever of the two terms I fulfill, I will not have transgressed, and Allah is a trustee over what we say.”

28:29.t: So when Moses had completed the term and journeyed with his family, he noticed a fire by the side of Mount Tûr. He said to his family, “Stay here; I have surely glimpsed a fire. Perhaps I can bring youplsome information from there, or an ember from the fire, that you may warm yourselves.”

28:30.t: So when he reached it, he was called from the right side of the valley at the blessed spot, from the tree: “O Moses, indeed I—I alone—am Allah, Lord of all realms.

28:31.t: So throw down yoursgstaff.” And when he saw it shaking as if it were a snake, he turned away, fleeing, and did not look back. “O Moses, come forward and do not fear; you are indeed of the secure ones.

28:32.t: Put yoursghand inside your garment; it will come out white, without any bad affliction. And clasp to you your arm, that you should not be overawed, for those are two proofs from your Lord to Pharaoh and his chiefs; indeed, they have been a defiantly disobedient people.”

28:33.t: He said, “My Lord, I have in fact killed one of them, and I fear lest they kill me.

28:34.t: And my brother Aaron—he is more eloquent than me, so send him with me as an assistant to confirm me; I do fear that they will disbelieve me.”

28:35.t: He said, “We will strengthen yoursgshoulder with your brother and give youdlauthority so they will not be able to reach you. With Our signs, youdland those who follow you will be the overcomers.”

28:36.t: So when Moses came to them with Our signs, evident, they said, “This is nothing but fabricated sorcery, and We never heard of this among our ancient forefathers.”

28:37.t: ThusMoses1said, “My Lord knows better of the one who brings guidance from Him and who will have the future outcome of the Home; indeed, the unjust never succeed.”

f.80768: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “Moses said . . .”

28:38.t: And Pharaoh said, “O chiefs, I have never known of any god for you other than me. So fire-up clay-bricks for me, O Haman, and build me a tower, that perhaps I may view the God of Moses, though I definitely think he is of the liars.”

28:39.t: Thus he and his troops went arrogantly about the land without any right, and they thought that they would notbe returned1to Us.

f.80769: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . would not return to Us.”

28:40.t: So We took him and his troops and We threw them into the waters, so look what the outcome was for the unjust ones.

28:41.t: And We made them leaders calling to the Fire, and on the Day of Resurrection they are not supported.

28:42.t: And We caused a curse to follow them in this Earlier(Life), and on the Day of Resurrection they are of the despised.

28:43.t: And We certainly brought Moses the Scripture after We had annihilated the earliest generations, as insights for mankind, and guidance and mercy, that perhaps they would remind themselves.

28:44.t: And yousgwere not on the western side(of the Mount)when We decreed the command to Moses, nor were yousgof the witnesses.

28:45.t: Yet We established many generations<sup foot_note="80770">1</sup>, then the ages became seemingly long. Nor were you among the people of Midian, reading Our signs<sup foot_note="80771">2</sup>to them; but We have been sending emissaries.

f.80771: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

28:46.t: Nor were you by the side of Mount Tûr when We called out. Rather, it was a mercy from your Lord so that you may warn a people to whom no warner had come before you, that perhaps they would remind themselves.

28:47.t: And(We have sent you as a messenger)lest a calamity befall them as a result of what their hands have put forth, and they say, “Our Lord, if only You had sent us a messenger, we would have followed Your signs and been among the believers.”

28:48.t: But when the truth came to them from Our Providence, they said, “If only he was given the like of what was given to Moses.” Did they not deny what was given to Moses in the past? They said, “Twoworks1of sorcery2, backing one another.” And they said, “We deny both.”

f.80773: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Two sorcerers , backing . . .”

28:49.t: Saysg, “Then bring a scripture from Allah more conducive to guidance than both of them and I will follow it, if youplare truthful.”

28:50.t: But if they do not respond to yousg, know that they only follow their whims. And who is more misguided than one who follows his own whim without guidance from Allah? Indeed, Allah does not guide the unjust people.

28:51.t: And surely We have conveyed the Word to them, that they may remind themselves.

28:52.t: Those to whom We brought the Scripture before it believe in it,

28:53.t: and when it is recited to them, they say, “We have believed in it; indeed, it is the truth from our Lord; indeed, we were Muslims<sup foot_note="80774">1</sup>prior to it.”

f.80774: The Arabic word used is Muslimeenwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

28:54.t: Those are brought their reward twice on account of how they persevered patiently. And they counter evil with good and they spend from what We have provided them.

28:55.t: And when they hear idle talk they disregard it and say, “We have our deeds and youplhave your deeds; peace be upon you; we do not seek(the company of)ignorant people.”

28:56.t: Indeed, yousgcannot guide whom you love, but Allah guides whom He wills, and He knows better of those who are guided.

28:57.t: And they said, “If we follow the guidance with yousg, we will be snatched from our land.” Did We not establish for them a safe sanctuary to which all kinds of products are brought as provision from Ourself? But most of them do not know.

28:58.t: And how many a town did We annihilate for becoming unappreciative of its livelihood? So here are their residences, uninhabited after them but little, and We have always been the inheritors.

28:59.t: And in no way would yoursgLord annihilate towns until He had sent to their mother-town a messenger reading to them Our1signs2. And in no way would We annihilate towns except if their people are unjust.

f.80776: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

28:60.t: And whatever youplhave been brought is(merely)the enjoyment of the Earlier Life and its adornment, but what is with Allah is better and longer lasting. Doyou1not reason?

f.80777: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “Do they not reason ?”

28:61.t: Can someone to whom We have made a fine promise—which he is bound to encounter—be equal to someone whom We have allowed to enjoy the enjoyment of the Earlier Life, then on the Day of Resurrection will be one of the arraigned?

28:62.t: On the day when He calls to them and says, “Where are My associates whom you used to claim?”

28:63.t: Those against whom the sentence was justified said<sup foot_note="80778">1</sup>, “Our Lord, these are the ones whom we deluded. We deluded them as we ourselves were deluded. We declare our innocence before You; it was not us that they used to worship.”

f.80778: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in past tense, this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

28:64.t: And it was said, “Call on yourplassociates.” So they called them, but they did not respond to them, and they saw the punishment. If only they had sought guidance!

28:65.t: And on the day when He calls<sup foot_note="80779">1</sup>to them and says, “What did you respond to the emissaries?”

f.80779: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

28:66.t: Then all tidings were obscuredafor them on that day so they are unable to ask each other.

28:67.t: But as for one who has repented and has attained faith and has acted righteously—hopefully, he will become of the successful.

28:68.t: And yoursgLord creates whatever He wills and He chooses. Never could the choice be theirs. Highly Exalted is Allah, and Most High is He above the associations they make.

28:69.t: And yoursgLord knows whatever their chests harbor and whatever they make public.

28:70.t: And He is Allah; there is no god but He. To Him belongs all praise in the First(life)and in the Hereafter, and to Himyouplare returned1.

f.80780: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . you return .”

28:71.t: Saysg, “Have youplseen if Allah were to make the night perpetual over you until the Day of Resurrection, which god other than Allah would bring you illumination? Do you not hear?”

28:72.t: Saysg, “Have youplseen if Allah were to make the day perpetual over you until the Day of Resurrection, which god other than Allah would bring you night to rest in? Do you not observe?”

28:73.t: But out of His mercy, He has made for youplnight and day so that you may rest in it and seek of His grace, and that you may give thanks.

28:74.t: And on the day when He calls to them and says, “Where are My associates whom you used to claim?”

28:75.t: And We drewaout from every community a witness, then said, “Produce your proof,” so they realized that the truth belongs to Allah, and whatever they used to fabricate strayed away from them.

28:76.t: Indeed, Qarun was of the people of Moses, but he oppressed them. And We had given him treasures, the keys of which would weigh down a band of strong men. Recall when his people said to him, “Do not exult; surely, Allah does not love the exultant.

28:77.t: And seek in whatever Allah has brought yousgthe Home of the Hereafter, and do not forget your share of the Earlier(Life), and do good as Allah has done good to you, and do not seek corruption in the land; indeed, Allah does not like the corrupters.”

28:78.t: He said, “Indeed, it was only brought to me on account of knowledge I possess.” Did he not know that before him Allah had annihilated many generations who were stronger than he and hadcollected greater riches? And the criminals will not be asked about their misdeeds.

28:79.t: And he came out before his people in his splendor; those who wanted the Earlier Life said, “If only we possessed the likes of what Qarun was given. He is indeed very fortunate.”

28:80.t: But those who were given knowledge said, “Woe to you! The recompense of Allah is better for those who have attained faith and have acted righteously.” Yet none is granted it except the patient ones.

28:81.t: So We caused the earth to swallow him and his home, then he had no battalion to support him apart from Allah, and he was not of those who could help themselves.

28:82.t: And by morning the ones who only yesterday had wished they were in his position were saying, “Indeed, it is Allah who extends His provision for whomever He wills of His servants, and He restrains(it). Had Allah not been gracious to us,He would have caused it to swallow us1. No wonder the deniers never succeed.”

f.80781: Qira’at: All except Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “Had Allah not been gracious to us, we would have been swallowed . No wonder . . .”

28:83.t: That is the Home of the Hereafter—We assign it for those who want no exaltation in the land nor corruption. And the future outcome is for those who are mindful(of God).

28:84.t: Whoever has come with a good deed—for him there is better than it, but whoever has come with an evil deed—those who have done evil deeds will only be rewarded for what they used to do.

28:85.t: Indeed, He Who ordained the Recital1upon yousgwill surely return you to a great place of return. Saysg, “My Lord knows better who brings guidance and who is the one in evident misguidance.”

f.80782: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

28:86.t: And you did not(even)expect the Scripture would be cast to yousg, yet(it was revealed to you)as a mercy from your Lord, so never be a backup for the deniers.

28:87.t: And do not let them bar yousgfrom Allah’s signs1after they have been sent down to you. And call to your Lord, and never be of those who associate(others with God).

f.80783: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

28:88.t: And do not callsgupon any other god with Allah; there is no god but He. All things perish except His Countenance. Judgment belongs(only)to Him, and to Himyouplare returned1.

f.80784: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . you return .”

29:2.t: Do people think that they will be left to say, “We believe” without being tested?

29:3.t: Yet certainly We have tested those before them; thus Allah will surely know the truthful and He will surely know the liars.

29:4.t: Or do those who do evil deeds think that they can outstrip Us? Terrible is their judgment!

29:5.t: Whoever expects the meeting with Allah—the appointed time of Allah is sure to come, and He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.

29:6.t: Thus whoever strives—he only strives to his own benefit; most surely, Allah is Self-Sufficient(without need for any of the creatures)of all realms.

29:7.t: And as for those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—We will certainly remit their evil deeds and We will certainly repay them according to the best of what they used to do.

29:8.t: And We have enjoined upon man kindness towards his parents. But if they urge you1to associate with Me something yousghave no knowledge of, do not obey them. To Me is yourplreturn, and I will inform you of what you used to do.

29:9.t: Those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—We will surely enter them among the righteous.

29:10.t: And among mankind is one who says, “We have attained faith in Allah.” Yet when he is hurt on Allah’s account, he equates the people’s persecution with Allah’s punishment. And if help comes from yoursgLord, he will definitely say, “We were actually with youpl.” Does not Allah know better whatever is within the chests of(all creatures of)all realms?

29:11.t: And Allah will surely know those who have attained faith, and He will surely know the hypocrites.

29:12.t: And those who denied said to those who had attained faith, “Follow our way and we will carry your offenses.” But never will they(willingly)carry any of their offenses; they are indeed liars.

29:13.t: Yet, they will surely carry their own heavy burdens and other heavy burdens with their own heavy burdens, and they will surely be asked on the Day of Resurrection about what they used to fabricate.

29:14.t: And We certainly sent Noah to his people, and He stayed among them for a thousand years, less fifty seasons. Then the Flood took them, for they were unjust.

29:15.t: But We saved him together with the fellows of the Ark, and We made it a sign for(all people of)all realms.

29:16.t: And Abraham—recall when he said to his people, “Worship Allah and be mindful of Him; that is better for you if you only knew.

29:17.t: Indeed, whatever youplworship apart from Allah are nothing but idols, and you create fabrications. Those you worship apart from Allah possess no provision for you, so seek your provision with Allah and worship Him and thank Him; to Himyou are returned1.”

f.80786: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . you return .”

29:18.t: And if youpldisbelieve, other communities before you have also disbelieved. And there is no responsibility upon the messenger except evident proclamation.

29:19.t: Havethey1not seenhow Allah starts creation and then restores it? This is indeed easy for Allah.

f.80787: Qira’at: Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Have you pl not seen . . .”

29:20.t: Saysg, “Journey throughout the earth and look how He started creation.” Then Allah will bring about the next existence; Allah is indeed All-Powerful over everything.”

29:21.t: He punishes whomever He wills and He grants mercy to whomever He wills, and to Him youplare turned back.

29:22.t: And youplcan neither thwart(God)on earth nor in heaven, and apart from Allah you have neither ally nor supporter.

29:23.t: And those who denied Allah’s signs and the meeting with Him—those have despaired of My<sup foot_note="80788">1</sup>mercy, and for those is a painful punishment.

29:24.t: But there was no response from his people except that they said, “Kill him or burn him.” But Allah saved him from the fire; indeed, in that are signs for people who believe.

29:25.t: And he said, “Youplhave chosen idols apart from Allah, as a bond of love for one another in the Earlier Life. Then on the Day of Resurrection you will deny one another and curse one another, and your shelter is the Fire, and you will have no helpers.”

29:26.t: Then Lot believed in him and said, “I am emigrating to my Lord; He is indeed the Almighty, the All-Wise.”

29:27.t: And We granted him Isaac and Jacob, and conferred upon his offspring the prophethood and the scripture, and brought him his reward in the Earlier(Life). And indeed, he is in the Hereafter among the righteous.

29:28.t: And Lot—recall when he said to his people, “Indeed, you do approach1obscenity such as nobody in all communities has ever committed before you.

f.80789: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “Can it be that you do approach obscenity such as nobody in all realms has ever committed before you? ”

29:29.t: Can it be that you do approach men and cut off the way1and commit what is deplorable in your gatherings?” But there was no response from his people except that they said, “Bring upon us Allah’s punishment if yousgare of the truthful.”

f.80790: This may imply cutting off the natural way of reproduction or obstructing the way and attacking travelers.

29:30.t: He said, “My Lord, help me against the corruptive people.”

29:31.t: And when Our messengers came toAbraham1with the glad tidings, they said, “We are going to destroy the people of this town; indeed, its people have been unjust.”

f.80791: Qira’at: Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham ”.

29:32.t: He said, “Yet Lot is in it.” They said, “We know better of who is in it;we will most surelydeliver1himand his family, except for his wife; she has become one of those who linger behind.”

f.80792: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . we will most surely save him . . .”

29:33.t: Then, when Our messengers came to Lot, he was troubled and distressed on their account. But they said, “Do not fear nor grieve; we willdeliver1youand your family, except for your wife; she has become one of those who linger behind.

f.80793: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . we will save you and . . .”

29:34.t: Indeed,We will send1downupon the people of this town a torment from heaven on account of having been defiantly disobedient.”

f.80794: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “Indeed, We will send from on high upon the people of this town . . .”

29:35.t: And We left behind something of it as an evident sign for people who reason.

29:36.t: And to Midian(We sent)their brother Shuʻaib. So he said, “O my people, worship Allah and expect the Last Day, and do not go wickedly about the land, corrupting it.”

29:37.t: But they disbelieved him, so the Tremor overtook them and they became lifeless bodies in their home.

29:38.t: And ʻĀd1and Thamûd2as well, as it has become evident for youplfrom their(ruined)residences. And Satan adorned their deeds for them, barring them from the way, even though they could see.

f.80795: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.
f.80796: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

29:39.t: And Qarun and Pharaoh and Hamān—Moses certainly went to them with clear proofs, but they went about arrogantly in the land, and in no way were they forerunners.

29:40.t: Each We seized by his misdeed: so of them are those upon whom We sent a sandstorm, and of them are those who were taken away by the Shout, and of them are those whom We caused the earth to swallow, and of them are those whom We drowned. For never would Allah do them any injustice, but to themselves they used to do injustice.

29:41.t: The likeness of those who take for themselves guardians apart from Allah is as the likeness of the spider that takes for itself a house, and surely the feeblest of houses is indeed the house of the spider, if they only knew.

29:42.t: Indeed, Allah knows whatever thingthey1call uponapart from Him, and He is the Almighty, the All-Wise.

f.80797: Qira’at: All except Abu ʻAmr, ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . what you pl call upon . . .”

29:43.t: And such parables We set forth for mankind, but none grasps them except the learned.

29:44.t: Allah created the heavens and the earth with truth; indeed, in that is a sign for the believers.

29:45.t: Recite what is revealed to yousgof the Scripture and establish the prayer; indeed the prayer forbids obscenity and what is deplorable. And surely the remembrance of Allah is greater. And Allah knows what youpldo.

29:46.t: And do not argue with the People of the Scripture except in the best manner, unless it be those of them who have done injustice, and say, “We believe in what was revealed to us and what was revealed to you, and our God and your God is One, and to Him we are Muslims<sup foot_note="80798">1</sup>.”

f.80798: The Arabic word used is Muslimoonwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

29:47.t: Likewise, We sent down to yousgthe Scripture. So those to whom We gave the Scripture believe in it, and some of these ones believe in it, but none repudiate Our signs except the deniers.

29:48.t: And yousgnever used to read any Scripture before it, and you never used to write it down with your right hand; otherwise the advocates of falsehood would have doubted.

29:49.t: In fact, it is evident signs in the chests of those given knowledge, and none repudiate Our signs except the unjust ones.

29:50.t: And they said, “Whyare no signs1sent down to him from his Lord?” Saysg, “Surely the signs are only in the Providence of Allah, and surely I am only an evident warner.”

f.80799: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Why is no sign sent down . . .”

29:51.t: Does it not suffice them that We revealed to yousgthe Scripture which is recited to them? Indeed, in that is mercy and a reminding for people who believe.

29:52.t: Say, “Allah suffices as witness between you and me; He knows whatever is in the heavens and the earth. And those who believed in falsehood and denied Allah—it is those who are the losers.”

29:53.t: And they urge yousgto hasten the punishment. And were it not for a stated term, the punishment would have come to them. But it will come upon them suddenly while they are unaware.

29:54.t: They urge you to hasten the punishment, and indeed, Hell is surely encompassing of the deniers.

29:55.t: On the day when the punishment envelops them from above them and from beneath their feet, andHe says1, “Taste what you used to do!

f.80800: Qira’at: All except Nafieʻ, ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and We say . . .”

29:56.t: O My servants who have attained faith: My earth is vast, so worship Me alone.

29:57.t: Every single self is sure to taste death, then to Usyouplare returned1.

f.80801: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “. . . then to Us they are returned .”Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . then to Us you pl return .”

29:58.t: And those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—We willsettle1them in the Garden(of Paradise)in Chambers under which rivers flow, abiding therein; how good is the reward of the workers

f.80802: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . We will lodge them in . . .”

29:59.t: who endured patiently and in their Lord they place their trust!”

29:60.t: How many a treading creature is there that does not carry its provision? Allah provides for it and for youpl, and He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.

29:61.t: And surely, if you were to ask them, “Who created the heavens and the earth and subjected the sun and the moon?” They would say, “Allah.” So how can they be averted(from the truth)?

29:62.t: Allah expands provision for whomever He wills of His servants and He restrains for him; indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of everything.

29:63.t: And surely, if yousgwere to ask them, “Who sent down from the sky water with which He revived the earth after it had died?” They would say, “Allah.” Saysg, “Praise be to Allah.” Rather, most of them do not reason.

29:64.t: This Earlier Life is nothing but a distraction and a game, and indeed the Home of the Hereafter is truly the perennial life, if they only knew.

29:65.t: So when they embark on ships they call upon Allah, devoting religion to Him. But once He has delivered them safely to land, they promptly associate others(with Him),

29:66.t: so that they deny whatever We have brought them andso that they enjoy1, for they will eventually know!

f.80803: Qira’at: Qaloun, Ibn Kathir, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and let them enjoy . . .”

29:67.t: Have they not seen that We have established a safe sanctuary, while all around them people are being snatched away? Do they believe in falsehood and deny the blessings of Allah?

29:68.t: And who is more unjust than one who has fabricated lies and attributed them to Allah or disbelieved the truth when it has come to him? Is there not in Hell a dwelling for the deniers?

29:69.t: And those who strove for Us—We will surely guide them in Our ways, for Allah<sup foot_note="80804">1</sup>is most surely with those who excel in doing good.

30:3.t: in the nearest1land. But after having been overcome, they will overcome(their enemy)

f.80805: The Arabic word used is adnawhich can also mean ‘lowest’.

30:4.t: in a few<sup foot_note="80806">1</sup>years. The command belongs to Allah, in the past and in the future. And on that day, the believers will exult

f.80806: The Arabic word used is bedʻ which stands for numbers more than three and less than ten.

30:5.t: in Allah’s support. He supports whomever He wills, and He is the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy.

30:6.t: The promise of Allah—Allah never breaks His promise, but most of mankind knows not.

30:7.t: They know an outer aspect of the Earlier Life, but they are oblivious of the Hereafter.

30:8.t: Have they not reflected within themselves? Allah did not create the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them except with the truth and for a stated term. But many among mankind do deny the meeting with their Lord.

30:9.t: Have they not journeyed through the earth and looked at what the outcome was for those before them? They were more powerful than them, and they cultivated the land and developed it more than they developed it, and their messengers came to them with evident proofs. For never would Allah do them any injustice, but to themselves they used to do injustice.

30:10.t: Thenabsolute evil was the consequence for those who committed evil1; that is because they rejected Allah’s signs and used to ridicule them.

f.80807: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “Then the consequence for those who committed evil was absolute evil . . .”

30:11.t: Allah originates creation and then restores it, then to Himyouplare returned1.

30:12.t: And on the day when the Hour takes place, the criminals despair.

30:13.t: And they had<sup foot_note="80809">1</sup>no intercessors from among their associate-gods, and they became deniers of their associate-gods.

f.80809: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense . . .” this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

30:14.t: And on the day when the Hour takes place—on that day they separate.

30:15.t: So, as for those who had attained faith and had done righteous deeds—they are in a meadow, delighted.

30:16.t: But as for those who had denied and had rejected Our signs and the meeting of the Hereafter—those are arraigned in the punishment.

30:17.t: So Highly Exalted is Allah when youplreach nightfall and when you reach morning.

30:18.t: And to him is all praise in the heavens and the earth, and in the evening, and when youplreach midday.

f.80810: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Khalaf and Ibn Zekwan read it as: “. . . and likewise you pl come out .”

30:20.t: And of His signs is that He created youplfrom dust, and there you are, human beings spreading about.

30:21.t: And of His signs is that He created for you spouses from among yourselves so that you may find rest with them, and He has set between you love and mercy; indeed, in that are signs for people who reflect.

30:22.t: And of His signs is the creation of the heavens and the earth, and the diversity of yourpltongues1and colors; indeed, in that are signs forthose who know2.

f.80812: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . for (people of) all realms .”

30:23.t: And of His signs is yourplsleep by night and day, and your pursuit of His grace; indeed, in that are signs for people who listen.

30:24.t: And of His signs is that He shows youpllightning, causing fear and ardent hope. And Hebestows1water from the sky, and with it He revives the earth after its death; indeed, in that are signs for people who reason.

f.80813: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and He sends down water . . .”

30:25.t: And of His signs is that the heaven and the earth remain(firm)by His command, then when He calls youplout of the earth, you promptly come out.

30:28.t: He has set forth for youpla parable from yourselves: do you make those whom you rightfully possess full partners in the wealth We have given you, so that you are equal in regard to it, fearing them as you have fear of each other? We thus detail the signs for people who reason.

30:29.t: Yet those who did injustice followed their whims without knowledge. But who can guide those whom Allah has misguided? And they will have no helpers.

30:30.t: So set yoursgface upright towards the religion, turning away from all that is false;(this religion is)the original disposition from Allah upon which He originated mankind. There cannot be any change in Allah’s creation; this is the upright religion, but most of mankind does not know.

30:31.t: (Keep)turningplto Him in penitence, and be mindful of Him and establish the prayer, and do not be of those who associate others(with Him)—

30:32.t: of the ones who havecaused disunity in1their religion and become sects, each party exulting in whatever they have.

f.80814: Qira’at: Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . the ones who have separated from their religion . . .”

30:33.t: And when harm touches people they call upon their Lord, turning to Him in penitence. Thereafter, when He makes them taste mercy from Him, a group of them associate others with their Lord

30:34.t: so as to deny what We have brought them. So take yourplenjoyment, then you will come to know.

30:35.t: Or have We sent down to them any authority which speaks in support of what they have been associating with Him?

30:36.t: And when We make people taste a mercy, they rejoice in it; but when adversity befalls them because of what their hands have put forth, they promptly become despondent.

f.80818: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.
f.80815: Qira’at: Ibn kathir read it as: “And whatever youpl have come up with in usury so that it increases . . .”
f.80816: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . in usury to increase it through people’s . . .”
f.80817: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

30:40.t: Allah is the One Who created youpl, then provided for you, then makes you die, then brings you back to life. Can any of your associate-gods do any of that? Highly Exalted is He, and Most High above whattheyassociate1(with Him).

f.80820: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, and Khalaf read it as: “. . . above what you pl associate . . .”

f.80821: Qira’at: Qunbul and Rouh read it as: “so that We may make them taste . . .”

30:42.t: Saysg, “Journeyplthrough the earth and look what the outcome was for those who came before; most of them were polytheists”.

30:44.t: whoever has denied—upon him falls his denial, and whoever has acted righteously—they<sup foot_note="80822">1</sup>smooth a way for themselves.

f.80822: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

30:45.t: So that He may repay those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds out of His grace. Indeed, He does not love the deniers.

30:48.t: Allah is the One Who sends thewinds1so they stirup clouds, then He spreads them in the sky as He wills and makes them intopieces2, then you see rain drops coming out from their midst; then when He makes it fall upon whom He wills of His servants, there they are, anticipating glad tidings

f.80824: Qira’at: Ibn Zekwan, Abu Jaʻfar and Hisham, in one of his narrations, read it as: “. . . into fragments . . .”

f.80825: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . before it was sent down upon them they were . . .”

f.80826: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . the effect of . . .”

30:51.t: But if We sent a wind and they saw it turning things yellow, they would continue thereafter to deny.

30:52.t: So surely yousgcannot make the dead hear, nor canyou make the deaf hear1the call when they turn away, fleeing.

f.80827: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . nor can the deaf hear the call . . .”

30:53.t: Norwill yousgguide1the blind out of their misguidance; you can make hear only those who believe in Our signs and are thus Muslims2.

f.80828: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “Nor do you sg guide the blind . . .”
f.80829: The Arabic word used is Muslimoonwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

30:54.t: Allah is the One Who created youplout of weakness, then after weakness gave(you)strength, then after strength gave(you)weakness and gray hair. He creates whatever He wills, and He is the All-Knowing, the All-Powerful.

30:55.t: And on the day when the Hour takes place, the criminals swear they had not stayed but for an hour; thus they used to be averted(from the truth).

30:56.t: But(on Judgment Day)those endowed with knowledge and faith said1, “Surely, youplhave remained(in existence from the time of your creation)until the Day of Resurrection(in accordance with the decree)in Allah’s Scripture; so this is the Day of Resurrection, but you did not know.”

f.80830: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

f.80831: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

30:59.t: Allah thus seals the hearts of those who do not know,

30:60.t: so besgpatient. The promise of Allah is true, so do not let those who lack certitude belittle you.

31:3.t: a guidance and a mercy for those who excel in doing good:

f.80832: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.
f.80833: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

f.80835: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Shuʻba and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “and he takes it for . . .”
f.80834: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . to stray from the way . . .”

31:14.t: And We have enjoined upon man the care of his parents. His mother carried him with hardship upon hardship, besides weaning him in two years. So givesgthanks to Me and to your parents; to Me is the destiny.

31:15.t: But if theydlstrive to have yousgassociate with Me whatever you have no knowledge of, do not obey them. Yet accompany them in the Earlier(Life)kindly, and follow the way of the one who has turned to Me in penitence. Then to Me is yourplreturn, and I will inform you of what you used to do.

31:16.t: “O my child,if it be the weight1of a mustard-seed, and be itin a rock or in the heavens or in the earth, Allah brings it forth; indeed, Allah is Subtle, All-Aware.

f.80839: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “O my child, if the weight of a mustard-seed be then in a rock . . .”

31:17.t: O my child, establish the prayer and command to what is fair and forbid what is deplorable, and be patient over what has befallen you; indeed, that is of the matters requiring determination.

31:18.t: And do not turn your cheek away from people(in pride), nor walk about the earth merrily; indeed, Allah does not love every self-admiring boaster.

31:19.t: And moderate your stride and lower your voice; indeed, the most deplorable of all voices is surely the donkey’s voice.”

31:20.t: Have youplnot seen that Allah has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth and showered you withHis blessings1, both manifest and hidden? Yet among mankind is one who argues about Allah without any knowledge nor any guidance norany illuminating Scripture.

f.80840: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr, Hafs and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . with a blessing , both . . .”

31:21.t: And when it is said to them, “Follow what Allah has sent down,” they say, “Rather, we follow what we found our forefathers doing.” Even if Satan has been calling them to the punishment of the Blaze?

31:22.t: And whoever surrenders his face to Allah while excelling in doing good, then he has truly grasped the firmest handhold. And with Allah rests the outcome of all events.

31:31.t: Have yousgnot seen that the ships sail through the sea by the blessing of Allah, to show you of His signs? Indeed, in that are signs for everyone who is most patient, constantly thankful.

31:32.t: And when waves like canopies cover them, they call upon Allah, devoting religion to Him. But when He has delivered them ashore, some of them waver. But no one repudiates Our signs except every perfidious staunch denier.

31:33.t: O mankind, be mindful of your Lord, and fear a day when no parent can repay anything on behalf of his child, nor can a child repay anything on behalf of his parent. The promise of Allah is indeed true, so let not the Earlier Life deceive youpl, and let not the Deceiver deceive you regarding Allah.
