f.80855: The believers who fled Makkah to Madinah.

33:7.t: And recall that We took from the prophets their pledge, and from yousgand from Noah and Abraham and Moses and Jesus, son of Mary, and We took from them a solid pledge,

33:8.t: that He<sup foot_note="80856">1</sup>may ask the truthful<sup foot_note="80857">2</sup>about their truthfulness. Yet He has prepared for the deniers a painful punishment.

33:9.t: O you who have attained faith, remember Allah’s blessings upon you when troops advanced towards you, and We1sent against them a wind and troops that you did not see. And Allah has always been All-Seeing of whatyou do2.

f.80859: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . of what they do .”

33:10.t: When they came upon youplfrom above you and from beneath you, and when sight(s)swerved and hearts reached the larynges, and you assume1about Allah various assumptions.

f.80860: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of past events.

33:11.t: There and then the believers were tested and were made to quake with a severe earthquake,

33:12.t: as the hypocrites and those in whose hearts is sickness say, “Allah and His Messenger promised us nothing but a deception.”

33:13.t: Recall, too, when a faction of them said, “O people of Yathrib, there is nostaying1for you here, so retreat.” And a group of them askfthe Prophet to excuse them, saying, “Indeed, our houses are exposed,” although they are not exposed, but they want nothing but to flee.

f.80861: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . there is no standing-place for you here . . .”

33:14.t: And had it1been invaded from all its sides, then they were asked tribulation, they would havebrought it2and tarried not but a little.

f.80863: Qira’at: Nafie, Ibn Kathir and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . they would have come to it . . .”

33:15.t: And certainly, they had previously covenanted with Allah that they would not turn their backs. And Allah’s covenant must be answered for.

33:16.t: Saysg, “Flight will not benefit youplif you flee from death or killing; even then you will be given no enjoyment but a little.”

33:17.t: Saysg, “Who is it who can safeguard youplfrom Allah if He desires adversity for you or desires mercy for you?” Apart from Allah, they can find for themselves neither guardian nor supporter.

33:18.t: Allah already knows the hinderers among you and those who say to their brethren, “Come along to us,” whereas they do not mobilize for battle but a little,

33:19.t: begrudging support to youpl. And when fear approaches, yousgsee them looking at you, their eyes rolling—like someone fainting at death; then, when panic is over, they scald youplwith sharp tongues, begrudging you any good. Those have not believed, so Allah has nullified their deeds, and this matter has always been easy for Allah.

33:20.t: They assume that the parties have not gone away. But were the parties to come(again), they would wish they were in the desert with the nomadic Arabs,asking1about yourplnews. And if they were among you, they would not combat but a little.

f.80864: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . asking each other about . . .”

33:21.t: Most surely, there has always been an excellent role model for youplin the Messenger of Allah(and)for anyone who has been putting hope in Allah and expecting the Last Day, and has remembered Allah frequently.

33:22.t: And when the believers saw the parties, they said, “This is what Allah and His messenger have promised us, and Allah and His messenger have told the truth.” And it only increased them in faith and submission.

33:23.t: Of the believers are men who have been true to what they have covenanted with Allah: so of them is one who fulfilled his obligation<sup foot_note="80865">1</sup>, and of them is one who still waits, and they have not changed in the least.

f.80865: Fulfilled his obligation by sacrificing his life in battle.

33:24.t: That Allah may repay the truthful for their truthfulness and punish the hypocrites, if He wills, or grant them repentance and accept it from them. Indeed, Allah has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

33:25.t: And Allah repelled those who denied in their rage—they gained no advantage. And Allah thus spared the believers combat, and Allah has always been All-Powerful, Almighty.

33:26.t: And He brought down those of the People of the Scripture who backed them from their strongholds, and threw terror into their hearts,(while)youplkill1one group, and another group you capture.

f.80866: A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of past events.

33:27.t: And He made youplinherit their land and their homes and their possessions and a land you had never trodden. And Allah has always been Powerful over everything.

33:28.t: O Prophet, say to your spouses, “If you want the Earlier Life and its adornment, then come, let me compensate you and release you kindly.

33:29.t: But if you want Allah and His Messenger and the Home of the Hereafter, then indeed, Allah has prepared a great reward for those of you who excel in doing good.”

33:30.t: O wives of the Prophet, if any one of you were ever to commit anevident obscenity1,the punishment for her would be doubled2twofold. And that has always been easy for Allah.

f.80867: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Shuʻba read it as: “. . . to commit an evidenced obscenity . . .”
f.80868: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . We would double the punishment for her twofold.”

33:31.t: But whoever of you is devout towards Allah and His Messenger and acts righteously—We1will bring her her reward twice over, and We have prepared for her a noble provision.

f.80869: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . He will bring her her reward . . .”

33:32.t: O wives of the Prophet, you are not like any of the other women. If you are truly mindful(of God), then do not speak too softly, lest the sick at heart lust after you, but speak forthright words.

33:33.t: Andsettle1in your houses and do not display yourselves as in the former days of pagan ignorance, and establish the prayer and bring2the purifying charity3and obey Allah and His Messenger; indeed, Allah only wants to keep abomination away from you, O people of the(Prophet’s)household, and to cleanse you thoroughly.

f.80870: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, ʻAsem and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “And settle, revered, in your houses . . .”
f.80871: The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.
f.80872: The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

33:34.t: And remember what is recited in your<sup foot_note="80873">1</sup>houses of Allah’s signs<sup foot_note="80874">2</sup>, and wisdom; indeed, Allah has always been Subtle, All-Aware.

f.80873: Plural feminine possessive adjective denoting that once again the addressed are the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him).
f.80874: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

33:35.t: Indeed, Muslim men and Muslim women, and believing men and believing women, and devout men and devout women, and truthful men and truthful women, and patient men and patient women, and reverent men and reverent women, and charitable men and charitable women, and fasting men and fasting women, and men who preserve their private parts1and women who(likewise)preserve, and men who remember Allah frequently and women who(likewise)remember—Allah has prepared for them forgiveness and a great reward.

33:36.t: It is not for any believing man or believing woman, when Allah and His Messenger have decreed a command, to have a choice in their affair. And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger, then he has strayed into evident misguidance.

33:37.t: And recall as you say to the one upon whom Allah had bestowed His grace, and upon whom yousghad(also)bestowed your grace, “Hold on to your spouse and be mindful of Allah,” while hiding within yourself what Allah was to reveal, and fearing mankind, whereas Allah is more worthy of your fear. Then when Zaid ended his relationship with her1, We married her to you, that there may be no blame on the believers regarding the spouses of their adopted sons when their relationship has ended, for the command of Allah has always been fulfilled.

33:38.t: Never has there been any blame on the Prophet regarding what Allah has ordained for him; such is Allah’s rule among those(prophets)who passed on before, and the command of Allah has always been a determined determination.

33:39.t: Those who proclaim the messages of Allah and fear Him and fear no one except Allah. And Allah is sufficient as a Reckoner.

33:40.t: Never has Muhammad been the father of any of yourplmen, but a Messenger of Allah and theseal1of the prophets. And Allah has always been All-Knowing of everything.

f.80877: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem read it as: “. . . the sealer of the prophets.” The same Arabic word khatimalsomeans ‘signet ring’, which serves as a seal and as an adornment.

33:41.t: O you who have attained faith, remember Allah with frequent remembrance,

33:42.t: and highly exalt Him morning and evening.

33:43.t: It is He Who blesses youpl, as do His angels1, to get you out of darkness(es)into light, and He has always been Merciful to the believers.

f.80878: Angels bless people by praying to God for them.

33:44.t: Their greeting on the day they meet Him is, “Peace.” And He has prepared for them a noble reward.

33:45.t: O Prophet, We have sent you as a witness and a bearer of glad tidings and a warner,

33:46.t: and a caller to Allah by His leave and an illuminating beacon.

33:47.t: And givesgthe believers glad tidings that for them is a supreme grace from Allah.

33:48.t: And dosgnot obey the deniers and the hypocrites, and ignore their hurtfulness, and place your trust in Allah, for Allah is sufficient as a Trustee.

33:49.t: O you who have attained faith, if you marry believing women but then divorce them before havingtouched1them2, you have no right to expect a waiting period on their part. But compensate them and release them in a graceful manner.

f.80880: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . before having touched each other . . .”

33:50.t: O Prophet, We have permitted to you your spouses to whom you have given their dowries, and those whom you rightfully possess from what Allah has granted you, and the daughters of your paternal uncle, and the daughters of your paternal aunts, and the daughters of your maternal uncle, and the daughters of your maternal aunts who emigrated with you, and a believing woman—if she grants herself to the Prophet1, if the Prophet wishes to marry her;(this is)exclusively for you, and not for the believers. We already know what We have ordained for them regarding their spouses and those whom they rightfully possess; this is to spare you any discomfort. And Allah has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

f.80881: Granting herself in marriage by forgoing her dowry.

33:51.t: You may defer any of them you wish and receive any of them you wish, and should you desire any of those you had set aside, then no sin is committed by you. This is more proper, so that they are comforted and are not grieved, and are content with what you have brought them—all of them. And Allah knows what is within your hearts, for Allah has always been All-Knowing, Forbearing.

33:52.t: Yousgare not allowed(tomarry)any further women, nor to exchange the spouses you have for others, even if you are impressed by their beauty, except for those whom you rightfully possess. And Allah has always been Watchful over everything.

33:53.t: O you who have attained faith, do not enter the houses of the Prophet unless you are given permission to come for a meal. And do not wait for its preparation, but when you are invited, then go in. And when you have eaten, disperse without seeking to remain for a talk. This used to hurt the Prophet, but he shied away from telling you, but Allah does not shy away from the truth. And when youplask them1for something, ask them from behind a screen; that is cleaner for your hearts and their hearts. For it is not for you to hurt the Messenger of Allah, nor must you ever marry his spouses after him; that would indeed be(a)great(offense)with Allah.

f.80882: The pronoun ‘them’ is mentioned in plural feminine form and therefore refers to the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him).

33:54.t: Whether youpldisclose anything or hide it, indeed, Allah has always been All-Knowing of everything.

33:55.t: No sin is committed by them<sup foot_note="80883">1</sup>regarding their fathers or their sons or their brothers or their brothers’ sons or their sisters’ sons or their women or those whom they rightfully possess. Yet be mindful<sup foot_note="80884">2</sup>of Allah; indeed, Allah has always been a Witness over everything.

f.80883: The wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him).
f.80884: The form of the verb used indicates that Allah is addressing the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him).

33:56.t: Indeed, Allah and His angels give blessings<sup foot_note="80885">1</sup>to the Prophet. O you who have attained faith, pray for blessings upon him and greet him with a prayer of peace.

33:57.t: Indeed, those who hurt Allah and His Messenger— Allah has cursed them in the Earlier(Life)and the Hereafter, and has prepared for them a demeaning punishment.

33:58.t: And those who hurt believing men and believing women for acts they did not earn have surely burdened themselves with perjury and evident sin.

33:59.t: O Prophet, tell your spouses and your daughters and the women of the believers to make their outer garments hang low over them; that is more likely that they will be recognized and not hurt. And Allah has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

33:60.t: If the hypocrites do not desist, as well as those with sickness in their hearts and the rumormongers in the City(of Madinah), We will surely incite yousgagainst them; then they will not neighbor you in it except for a short while.

33:61.t: Accursed; wherever they are found, they should be captured and relentlessly killed outright.

33:62.t: Such has been Allah’s rule with those who passed on before, and yousgwill never find any change in Allah’s rule.

33:63.t: People ask you about the Hour. Say, “Indeed, knowledge thereof rests only with Allah. But what could make yousgrealize? Perhaps the Hour could be near.”

33:64.t: Indeed, Allah has cursed the deniers and has prepared for them a blaze,

33:65.t: abiding therein forever, finding neither ally nor supporter.

33:66.t: On the day when their faces are flipped in the Fire, they say, “If only we had obeyed Allah and obeyed the Messenger.”

33:67.t: And they said1, “Our Lord, indeed we obeyed ourmasters2and our dignitaries, but they led us away from the way.

f.80886: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.
f.80887: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . our many masters and our . . .”

33:68.t: Our Lord, give them double the punishment and curse them with asupreme1curse.”

f.80888: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem read it as: “. . . with a lot of curses .”

33:69.t: O you who have attained faith, do not be like those who hurt Moses, though Allah cleared him of what they had said. And he has been well-esteemed with Allah.

33:70.t: O you who have attained faith, be mindful of Allah and speak for justice;

33:71.t: He will set aright your deeds for you and will forgive you your misdeeds. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger—thenhe has surely triumphed a great triumph.

33:72.t: Indeed, We offered the trust<sup foot_note="80889">1</sup>to the skies and the land and the mountains, but they refused to carry it and were apprehensive of it, but man carried it; he has always been constantly unjust, constantly ignorant.

33:73.t: That Allah may punish the hypocrites, men and women, and the polytheists, men and women. And(that)Allah may grant repentance to the believers and accept it from them, men and women, for Allah has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

34:1.t: All praise be to Allah to Whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth, and all praise be to Him in the Hereafter, and He is the All-Wise, the All-Aware.

34:2.t: He knows what penetrates into the earth and what comes out of it, and what descends from the sky and what ascends to it, and He is the Bestower of mercy, the Oft-Forgiving.

34:3.t: Yet those who have denied have said, “The Hour is not coming upon us.” Saysg, “Yes indeed, by my Lord, the Knower1of the hidden realm, it will come upon you.” Not an atom’s weight in the heavens or in the earth escapes His knowledge, nor anything smaller or larger, except that it is in an evident record2—

f.80890: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Roways read it as: “‘. . . by my Lord, it will come upon you. (He is) the Knower of the hidden realm .’”Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “‘. . . by my Lord, the Superb Knower of the hidden realm, it will come upon you.’”

34:4.t: that He may repay those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds; for those is forgiveness and noble provision.

34:5.t: Those who strove against Our signs, attempting tochallenge1(God)— those ones, for them isa painful punishment of torment2.

f.80892: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . attempting to thwart . . .”
f.80893: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . for them is a punishment of painful torment .”

34:6.t: And those who have received knowledge see that what was sent down to yousgfrom your Lord is the truth and guides to the path of the Almighty, the Praiseworthy.

34:7.t: And those who have denied said, “Shall we point out to youpla man who tells you that, once you are torn into shreds, you will surely be in a new creation?”

34:8.t: Did he invent a lie about Allah or is there madnessin him? Rather, those who do not believe in the Hereafter are in punishment and extreme misguidance.

34:9.t: Have they not seen what lies before them and behind them of the heaven and the earth? IfWe will1, We canmake the earth cave in beneath them, or let fall down on thempieces2from the sky; indeed, in that is a sign for every penitent servant.

f.80894: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “If He wills, He can . . .”
f.80895: Qira’at: All except for Hafs read it as: “fragments ”.

34:10.t: And surely, We bestowed upon David grace from Us: “O mountains, echo with him(My praises), and you birds(too).” And We softened iron for him.

34:11.t: “Makesgcoats of armor and measure the links well, and doplrighteousness1; indeed I am All-Seeing of what youpldo.”

f.80896: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

34:12.t: And for Solomon(I subjected)the wind1—its morning course(reaching a distance otherwise attained in)one month, and its evening course(reaching a distance otherwise attained in)one month. And We made a spring of molten brass flow for him, and there would be unseen beings2working under him by the leave of his Lord. But whoever of them would swerve from Our command, We would make him taste of the punishment of the Blaze.

f.80897: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . the winds . . .”Shuʻba read it as: “And the wind (was subjected) for Solomon —its . . .”
f.80898: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

34:13.t: They would make for him whatever he wished of sanctuaries, and statues, and bowls like pools, and heavy cauldrons. “O David’s folk, work in thankfulness.” But few of My servants are constantly thankful.

34:14.t: Then, when We decreed death for him, nothing indicated his death to them except the woodworm eating his staff. Then, when he fell down, itbecame clear1to the unseen beings that, had theyknown what was hidden, they would not have remained in the demeaning punishment.

f.80899: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . it became clear that, had the unseen beings known what was hidden, they would not have remained . . .”

34:15.t: Surely, there used to be a sign for(the people of)Sheba in theirresidence1: two gardens, on the right and on the left. “Eatplof your Lord’s provision and give thanks to Him.” A good land and an Oft-Forgiving Lord.

f.80900: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . in their residences . . .”

34:16.t: But they disregarded(God), so We sent against them the torrent of the Arim(Dam), and We substituted for them their two gardens with two gardens of bitter crops and thorny shrubs and something of sparse lote-trees.

34:17.t: Thus We repaid them on account of how they denied, anddo We(thus)repay1anyoneexcept the staunch denier?

f.80901: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Shuʻba and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and who is (thus) repaid except the staunch denier?”

34:18.t: And We made between them1and the towns We had blessed2visible towns, and We well determined the journey between. “Journeyplbetween them safely by night and day.”

34:19.t: But they said, “Our Lord,lengthen1the distances of our journeys.” Thus they were unjust to themselves, so We made them history and We scattered them in every direction; indeed, in this are signs for everyone who is most patient, constantly thankful.

f.80904: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “Our Lord has lengthened the distances . . .”

34:20.t: And surely,Iblis1confirmed2his assumption about them. So they followed him, except for a group of believers.

f.80905: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.
f.80906: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “And surely, Iblis’s assumption about them was confirmed .”

34:21.t: And never did he have any authority over them, except that We may know the one who believes in the Hereafter from the one who is doubtful about it. And yoursgLord is a Constant Preserver over everything.

34:22.t: Saysg, “Call upon those whom you claimed(to be gods)apart from Allah; they do not possess an atom’s weight in the heavens nor in the earth, and they do not have therein any association(with God), and He does not have any assistant from among them.”

34:23.t: And intercession cannot be of benefit before Him, except for oneto whom He has given permission1. Until, whenfear has been dispelled2from their hearts, they say3, “What did yourplLord say?” They say, “The truth; and He is the All-High, the Supreme.”

f.80907: Abu ʻAmr, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . except for one who has been given permission .”
f.80908: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “Until, when He has dispelled fear from their hearts, they say . . .”
f.80909: They are either asking one another, or are being asked by the angels.

34:24.t: Saysg, “Who provides for youplfrom the heavens and the earth?” Say, “Allah—and indeed, either you or we are rightly guided or in evident misguidance.”

34:25.t: Saysg, “Youplwill not be asked about the crimes we committed, nor will we be asked about what you do.”

34:26.t: Saysg, “Our Lord will bring us together, then He will legislate1justly for us with the truth, for He is the Legislator2, the All-Knowing.”

f.80910: The Arabic word used is iftahwhich literally means ‘open’; however, according to the dialect of the tribes of Hemyarin Yemen it means ‘judge’.Ibn Abdul-salamsaid that it means ‘open a way for knowledge’, in order to distinguish between good and evil, i.e. legislate for us a legislation.

34:27.t: Saysg, “Show me those you have attached to Him as associates. But no! Rather, He is Allah, the Almighty, the All-Wise.”

34:28.t: And We have not sent you but to the whole of mankind, as a herald of glad tidings and a warner, but the majority of mankind does not know.

34:29.t: Thus they say, “When is this promise due, if youplare truthful?”

34:30.t: Saysg, “Youplare promised a day which you can neither postpone for a while nor bring forward.”

34:31.t: Those who denied said, “We will never believe in this Recital1nor in what came before it.” And if only yousgcould see the unjust as they are brought to stand before their Lord, throwing back allegations at one another: those who had been deemed weak and oppressed say to the arrogant leaders, “Were it not for youpl, we would have been believers.”

f.80912: The Arabic word used isQur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

34:32.t: The arrogant leaders said<sup foot_note="80913">1</sup>to those who had been deemed weak and oppressed, “Did we bar you from guidance after it had come to you? Rather, you yourselves were criminals.”

f.80913: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

34:33.t: And those who had been deemed weak and oppressed said to the arrogant leaders, “Rather, it was your scheming by night and day as you used to command us to deny Allah and to set up rivals to Him.” Thus they hid their remorse when they saw the punishment. And We put the yokes around the necks of those who had denied. Are they being repaid except for what they used to do?

34:34.t: And never have We sent a warner to any town except that its affluent said, “Indeed, we deny what youplhave been sent with.”

34:35.t: And they said, “We have more wealth and more children(than the believers), and never shall we be punished.”

34:36.t: Saysg, “Indeed, my Lord extends provision for whomever He wills and He restrains(it), but the majority of mankind does not know.”

34:37.t: And it is neither yourplwealth nor your children that bring you closer in position to Us—except whoever has attained faith and has acted righteously, for for those1 isa repayment of double(measure)2for what they did, and in theChambers3(of Paradise)they remain safe.

f.80914: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.
f.80915: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . for for those there is double as a repayment . . .”
f.80916: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “Chamber ”.

34:38.t: But those who strove against Our signs1attempting tochallenge2(God)—those are arraigned in the punishment.

f.80917: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.
f.80918: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . attempting to thwart . . .”

34:39.t: Saysg, “Indeed, My Lord extends provision for whomever He wills of His servants and He restrains(it). And anything youplspend(in His cause)He replaces it, and He is the Best of providers.”

34:40.t: And on the day whenHe herds1themall together, then says to the angels, “Is it you that these used to worship?”

f.80919: Qira’at: All except for Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . when We herd them . . .”

34:41.t: They said<sup foot_note="80920">1</sup>, “Highly Exalted are You; You are our Ultimate Guardian, not them. Rather, they used to worship the unseen beings<sup foot_note="80921">2</sup>; most of them are believers in them.”

f.80920: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.
f.80921: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

34:42.t: “So today youplpossess for one another neither benefit nor harm.” And We will say to those who did injustices, “Taste the punishment of the Fire in which you used to disbelieve.”

34:43.t: And when Our signs1are read to them, evident, they say, “This is nothing but a man who wants to bar youplfrom what your forefathers used to worship.” And they say, “This is nothing but a fabricated lie.” And the deniers said of the truth when it came to them, “This is nothing but evident sorcery.”

f.80922: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like‘verse’ in poetry or‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

34:44.t: Yet never before had We given them any books to study, nor had We sent them any warner before yousg.

34:45.t: And those before them also disbelieved, and never did they attain even a tenth of what We gave them. And they disbelieved My messengers, so how terrible was My condemnation!

34:46.t: Saysg, “Indeed, I admonish youplwith one thing: that you rise up for Allah in pairs or individually, then reflect. There is no madness in your fellow. He is just a warner to you before the advent of a severe punishment.”

34:47.t: Saysg, “Whatever reward I have asked of youpl, it is yours; my reward comes only from Allah, and He is Witness over everything.”

34:48.t: Saysg, “Indeed, My Lord projects the truth. He is the Superb Knower of the hidden realms.”

34:49.t: Saysg, “The truth has come, while falsehood can neither originate nor restore.”

34:50.t: Saysg, “If I go astray, I go astray only to my own loss; but if I am guided, it is by what my Lord reveals to me; He is indeed All-Hearing, Near.”

34:51.t: And if yousgcould only see when they were1terrified and there was no escape, and they were seized from a nearby place.

f.80923: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

34:52.t: And they said, “We have believed in it.” But how can they attain it from such a distant place

34:53.t: when they had denied it before<sup foot_note="80924">1</sup>? And they throw about conjectures regarding the hidden realm from such a distant place.

f.80924: In the Earlier Life of this world.

34:54.t: And a barrier was placed between them and what they desire, as was done formerly with their likes. Indeed, they were in disturbing doubt.

35:1.t: All praise be to Allah, Originator of the heavens and the earth, Maker of the angels as messengers with two and three and four wings. He adds to creation as He wills; indeed, Allah is Powerful over everything.

35:2.t: Whatever mercy Allah unfolds for mankind, none can withhold it; and whatever He withholds, none can release it thereafter. And He is indeed the Almighty, the All-Wise.

35:3.t: O mankind, remember Allah’s blessing upon you. Is there a creator other than Allah who provides for you from the heaven and the earth? There is no god but He, so how can you be averted(from the truth)?

35:4.t: And if they disbelieve yousg, surely messengers before you were also disbelieved. And to Allah all mattersare returned1.

f.80925: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . all matters return .”

35:5.t: O mankind, indeed the promise of Allah is true, so let not the Earlier Life deceive you, and let not the Deceiver deceive you regarding Allah.

35:6.t: Indeed, Satan is an enemy to youpl, so take him as an enemy; indeed, he only invites his party to be among the fellows of the Blaze.

35:7.t: For those who have denied is a severe punishment, while for those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds is forgiveness and a supreme reward.

35:8.t: What about the one whose evil deed was adorned for him and so he came to regard it as good? Allah misguides whomever He wills and He guides whomever He wills, solet not your self be wasted1sorrowing over them; indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of what they do.

f.80926: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . so do not waste your self sorrowing over them . . .”

35:9.t: And Allah is the One Who sent thewinds1, stirring up clouds, then We2drove them to a lifeless land whereby We revived the earth after it had died; likewise is Resurrection.

f.80927: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, and Khalaf read it as: “wind ”.

35:10.t: Whoever wants might—to Allah belongs all might. To Him ascends good speech, and righteous work lifts it up. But as for those who scheme evil, there is a severe punishment, and the scheming of those is bound to fail.

35:11.t: And Allah created youplfrom dust, then from a sperm drop, then He made you pairs. And no female carries or delivers except with His knowledge. And no person is given a long life orhas his life cut short1except that it is in a record2; indeed, that is easy for Allah.

f.80929: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “And no person is given a long life nor does He cut his life short except . . .”

35:12.t: And the two waters are not equal: this one is fresh, sweet, good to drink, while this is salty, bitter. Yet from each youpleat tender meat and extract jewelry which you wear, and you see the ships plowing through them, that you may seek of His grace, and that you may give thanks.

35:13.t: He causes the night to penetrate the day and He causes the day to penetrate the night, and He has subjected the sun and the moon, each running for a stated term. Such is Allah, yourplLord; to Him belongs the dominion. But those you call upon apart from Him do not own so much as the mere skin of a date stone.

35:14.t: If youplcall upon them, they do not hear your call; and even if they heard, never would they respond to you. And on the Day of Resurrection, they will reject your polytheism. And none informs yousglike One Who is all-aware.

35:15.t: O mankind, it is you who stand in need of Allah, while Allah is the Self-Sufficient, the Praiseworthy.

35:16.t: If He wills, He can do away with youpland bring about a new creation.

35:17.t: And that would not be too mighty for Allah.

35:18.t: And no bearer of burden bears the burden of another. And even if a heavily laden one calls for help with its load, nothing of it will be carried, even if the one called be a relative. You are only to warn those who fear their Lord, though unseen, and have established the prayer. And whoever purifies himself only purifies himself to his own benefit. And to Allah is the destiny.

35:19.t: Not equal are the blind one and the one who can see,

35:20.t: nor are the darkness(es)and the light,

35:21.t: nor are the shade and the torrid heat,

35:22.t: nor equal are the living and the dead. Indeed, Allah causes whomever He wills to hear, but yousgcannot make those in the graves hear.

35:24.t: Indeed, We have sent yousgwith the truth, as a herald of glad tidings and a warner. And there is no community but a warner has passed through it.

35:25.t: And if they disbelieve yousg, those before them also disbelieved. Their messengers came to them with evident proofs and with the Books and with the illuminating Scripture.

35:26.t: Then I seized those who denied—so how terrible was My condemnation?

35:27.t: Have yousgnot seen that Allah has sent down water from the sky, and with it We1have brought out products of various colors? And in the mountains are streaks of white and red, varying in their hue, and pitch-black.

35:28.t: Likewise, human beings and animals and livestock come in various colors. Indeed, from among His servants, only the learned fear Allah. Indeed, Allah is Almighty, Oft-Forgiving.

35:29.t: Indeed, those who read the Scripture of Allah and have established the prayer and have spent of what We have provided for them, secretly and publicly, expect a bargain that will not fail.

35:30.t: That He may render to them their rewards in full and increase them of His grace; He is indeed Oft-Forgiving, Ever Thankful.

35:31.t: And what We have revealed to yousgof the Scripture is the truth, confirming what preceded it. Allah is most surely All-Aware, All-Seeing of His servants.

35:32.t: Then We gave the Scripture as a heritage to those of Our servants whom We selected: so of them is one who is unjust to himself, and one who follows a middle course, and one who is a forerunner in good deeds—by Allah’s leave. That is what the great grace is.

35:33.t: Gardens of Eden whichthey enter1; they are adorned therein withgold bracelets and pearls2, and their garments therein are of silk.

f.80933: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, ʻAsem and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . with bracelets of gold and (of) pearls . . .”
f.80932: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . into which they are entered . . .”

35:34.t: And they said<sup foot_note="80934">1</sup>, “All praise be to Allah Who has lifted all sorrow from us; our Lord is most surely Oft-Forgiving, Ever Thankful.

f.80934: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

35:35.t: He Who settled us in the Home of Everlasting Stay, by His grace, where neither toil touches us nor fatigue afflicts us.”

35:36.t: And those who have denied—for them is the fire of Hell wherein they are never finished off and thus die, nor is its punishment lightened for them. ThusWe repay every staunch denier1.

f.80935: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “Thus every staunch denier is repaid .”

35:37.t: And they scream aloud therein, “Our Lord, get us out, that we may act righteously, unlike the way we used to act.” “Did We not give youpla lifelong enough to take warning if you were going to? And the warner did come to you, so taste1, for there is no supporter for the unjust.”

35:38.t: Indeed, Allah is the Knower of the hidden realm of the heavens and the earth. Indeed, He is All-Knowing of what lies within the chests.

35:39.t: It is He who made youplsuccessors on earth. So whoever denies—his denial is upon him, and the denial of the deniers adds only to their Lord’s loathing of them, and the denial of the deniers adds only to their perdition.

35:40.t: Say, “Have you regarded those associates of yours that you worship apart from Allah? Show me what they have created on earth.” Or do they have any share in the heavens? Or have We given them a scripture such that they rely onan evident proof1from it? Rather, the unjust promise one another nothing but a deception.

f.80937: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hafs, Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “. . . rely on evident proofs . . .”

35:41.t: Indeed, Allah holds the heavens and the earth, lest they vanish. And were they to vanish, there is none to hold them both except He; indeed, He has always been Forbearing, Oft-Forgiving.

35:42.t: And they swore by Allah their most solemn oaths: that if a warner came to them, they would be more guided than any of the other communities. Yet when a warner came to them, it only increased them in aversion—

35:43.t: behaving arrogantly in the land and scheming evil. But evil scheming surrounds none but its people. So do they expect anything but the precedent of the ancients? For yousgwill never find any change in Allah’s rule, and you will never find any deviation in Allah’s rule.

35:44.t: And have they not journeyed through the earth and observed the consequences for those before them, though they were superior to them in strength? But in no way could Allah be thwarted by anything in the heavens or in the earth. Indeed, He has always been All-Knowing, All-Powerful.

35:45.t: And if Allah were to hold mankind accountable for what they have earned, He would not leave a single treading creature on its surface. But He defers them for a stated term, and then when their term is due—indeed, Allah has always been All-Seeing of His servants.

f.80938: The Arabic word used isQur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

36:3.t: Yousgare indeed of the emissaries

36:5.t: (God bestowed it as)a bestowal1from on high by the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy,

f.80939: Qira’at: All except for Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “(It is) a bestowal from on high . . .”

36:6.t: to warn a people whose forefathers were not warned, so they are oblivious.

36:7.t: Certainly, most of them deserved the decree on them, for they refuse to believe.

36:8.t: Indeed, We placed shackles around their necks up to their chins, so that their heads are forced up.

36:9.t: And We placed a barrier in front of them and a barrier behind them, and thus We blocked their vision so they cannot see.

36:10.t: And it is the same for them whether yousgwarn them or do not warn them—they believe not.

36:11.t: Indeed, yousgcan only warn one who has followed the Reminder and has feared the All-Merciful though unseen—so give him glad tidings of forgiveness and a noble reward.

36:12.t: Indeed, We—We alone—revive the dead and write down what they have put forth and their traces. And everything have We tallied in an evident archive.

36:13.t: And setsgforth for them the parable of the fellows of the town when the Emissaries came to it—

36:14.t: when We sent them two persons but they disbelieved them, soWe reinforced1(them)with a third. Then they said, “Truly, We are emissaries sent to you.”

f.80940: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “. . . so We overpowered with a third.”

36:15.t: They said, “You are nothing but human beings like us, and the All-Merciful did not send down anything; you are only lying.”

36:16.t: They said, “Our Lord knows that we are indeed emissaries sent to you,

36:17.t: and our only duty is evident proclamation.”

36:18.t: They said, “We see an evil omen in youpl; if you do not give up, we will most surely stone you, and a painful punishment from us will most surely afflict you.”

36:19.t: They said, “Your evil omen is within yourselves.Can it be that it is becauseyou werereminded1? Rather, you are an extremist people!”

f.80941: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Is it because you were mentioned ?”

36:20.t: And there came a man rushing from the farthest end of the city. He said, “O my people, follow the emissaries.

36:21.t: Follow those who do not ask youplany reward, and are themselves guided.

36:22.t: And why should I not worship the One Who originated me, and to Whomyouplare returned1?

f.80942: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . you return ?”

36:23.t: Shall I take other gods apart from Him? If the All-Merciful wants harm for me, their intercession does not avail me at all, nor can they rescue me.

36:24.t: In that case, I should indeed be in evident misguidance.

36:25.t: Indeed, I have attained faith in yourplLord, so listen to me.”

36:26.t: It was said, “Enter the Garden(of Paradise).” He said, “Oh if only my people could know

36:27.t: how my Lord has forgiven me and made me one of the honored!”

36:28.t: And after him, We sent down no soldiers from heaven to his people, nor would We ever send any down.

36:29.t: It was just1a single Shout, and suddenly they were extinct.

f.80943: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Nothing happened but a single shout . . .”

36:30.t: Alas for the servants! No messenger comes to them but they ridicule him.

36:31.t: Have they not seen how many generations We annihilated before them—that they will not return to them?

36:32.t: Andnone of them1but will be arraigned before Us, all together.

f.80944: Qira’at: All except for Ibn ʻAmer, ʻAsem, Hamza and Ibn Jammaz read it as: “And all of them , all together, will be arraigned before Us.”

36:33.t: And there is a sign for them in the lifeless land: We have revived it and have brought out from it grains, so from it they eat.

36:34.t: And We have made in it gardens of palm-trees and grapevines, and have caused springs to burst forth in it,

36:35.t: that they may eat from its produce and(from)what1their hands have made2. So will they not give thanks?

f.80945: The word ma in Arabic can mean ‘what’ or ‘not’; if interpreted as the latter, the meaning of the statement becomes “. . . that they may eat from its produce, though their hands have not made it.”
f.80946: Qira’at: Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . from its produce and (from) their own handiwork . . .”

36:36.t: Highly Exalted is He Who created all pairs—of what the earth germinates and of their own selves<sup foot_note="80947">1</sup>and of what they do not know.

36:37.t: And a sign for them is the night: We strip the day out of it—and they are suddenly in darkness.

36:38.t: And the sun runs towards its destination; such is the determining of the Almighty, the All-Knowing.

36:39.t: And We have determined the moon1in phases until it returned like an old palm-branch.

f.80948: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Rouh read it as: “And the moon: We have determined it in phases . . .”

36:40.t: The sun is not to overtake the moon, nor is the night to outpace the day, and each floats in an orbit.

36:41.t: And a sign for them is that We carriedtheir offspring1in the laden ship,

f.80949: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . their offspring(s) . . .”

36:42.t: and We created for them the like of it in which they ride.

36:43.t: And if We will, We can drown them—with no screaming to be heard from them, nor will they be rescued,

36:44.t: except by a mercy from Us and enjoyment for a while.

36:45.t: And when it is said to them, “Be mindful of what lies before you and what lies behind you, that you may receive mercy” . . .<sup foot_note="80950">1</sup>

f.80950: This sentence is left open-ended. Ibn ‘Ateya and other exegetes considered its predicate to be: “. . . they invariably disregard (it).”

36:46.t: Yet never does a sign of their Lord’s signs come to them, but they disregard it.

36:47.t: And when it is said to them, “Spend of what Allah has provided for you,” those who deny say to those who have attained faith, “Shall we feed someone whom Allah could feed, if He so wills? You are but in evident misguidance.”

36:48.t: And they say, “When will this promise be, if youplare truthful?”

36:49.t: All they can expect is a single Shout, which will take them away while they feud,

36:50.t: so that they will neither be able to make a will nor return to their own people.

36:51.t: And the trumpet was blown<sup foot_note="80951">1</sup>, whereupon they walked quickly out from the tombs to their Lord.

f.80951: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

36:52.t: They said, “Woe to us! Who has resurrected us from our resting place?” This is what the All-Merciful has promised, and the emissaries have spoken the truth.”

36:53.t: It was just1a single Shout, and suddenly they were all arraigned before Us.

f.80952: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “It was nothing but a single shout . . .”

36:54.t: So today no soul is dealt with unjustly in the least, and youplare not repaid except for what you used to do.

36:55.t: Indeed, today the fellows of the Garden(of Paradise)are happily busy,

36:56.t: they and their spouses,in shades1, reclining on couches.

f.80953: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . they and their spouses, under sunshades , reclining . . .”

36:57.t: For them are fruits therein, and for them is whatever they call for.

36:58.t: “Peace”—a word from a Lord Bestowing of mercy.

36:59.t: But step aside today, you criminals.

36:60.t: Did I not covenant with you, O Children of Adam, that you shall not worship the devil—indeed, for you he is an evident enemy—

36:61.t: and that you shall worship Me? This is a straight path.

36:62.t: Yet he has certainly led a great multitude of you astray. Did you not use reason?

36:63.t: This is Hell which youplwere promised.

36:64.t: Roast in it today on account of how you used to deny.

36:65.t: Today, We put a seal upon their mouths, and their hands speak to Us, and their feet testify to whatever they used to earn.

36:66.t: And if We will, We can obliterate their eyes, then they race with each other to(find)the Path—but how will they see?

36:67.t: And if We will, We can disfigure them right intheir place1, so that they can neither move forward nor go back.

f.80954: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “. . . in their places . . .”

36:68.t: And to whomever We give long life, We reverse his development—so willthey1not reason?

f.80955: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Zekwan, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “so will you pl not reason ?”

36:69.t: And never did We teach him<sup foot_note="80956">1</sup>poetry, nor is it proper for him; it is but a Reminder and an Evident Recital<sup foot_note="80957">2</sup>—

f.80957: The Arabic word used isQur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

36:70.t: so that it may forewarn1whoever is alive, and so that God’s decree may be deserved by the deniers.

f.80958: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . so that you sg may forewarn . . .”

36:71.t: Have they not seen that We have created for them, of Our Handiwork, livestock, so that they are their owners?

36:72.t: And We made them manageable by them, so some they ride and some they eat.

36:73.t: And they have in them other benefits and drinks, so will they not give thanks?

36:74.t: Yet they have taken to themselves gods other than Allah, that perhaps they may be supported.

36:75.t: They cannot support them, even if they are arraigned for them as an army.

36:76.t: So let not their words sadden yousg. Indeed, We know whatever they keep secret and whatever they make public.

36:77.t: Has man not regarded that We created him from a sperm-drop? Yet he became an evident adversary,

36:78.t: and he set forth a parable for Us and forgot his own creation. He said, “Who can revive the bones when they have decayed?”

36:79.t: Saysg, “He who initiated them the first time revives them, for He is All-Knowing of every creation.”

36:80.t: He who made fire for youplout of green trees, so that with them you kindle.

36:81.t: Is not He Who created the heavens and the earthcapable1of creatingthe like of them? Yes indeed, and He is the All-Creating, the All-Knowing.

f.80959: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “Cannot He Who created the heavens and the earth create the like of them?”

36:82.t: Indeed, His only command once He has desired anything is to say to it,“Be,” and so it is1.

f.80960: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . is to say to it, ‘Be,’ so it is.”

36:83.t: So Highly Exalted is the One in Whose hand is the dominion of everything, and to Himyousgare returned1.

f.80961: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . to Him you pl return .”

37:1.t: By those aligned, lined up in ranks.

37:2.t: Then by the propellers propelling firmly.

37:3.t: Then by the readers of a Reminder—

37:4.t: indeed, yourplGod is surely One,

37:5.t: Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, and Lord of the Easts.

37:6.t: Indeed, We have adorned the lowest1heavenwithan adornment, the planets2,

f.80962: The Arabic word dunyatranslated here as ‘lowest’ is the same word used to describe the life of this world as the ‘Earlier’ Life, as it carries both meanings: lowest and earlier.
f.80963: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “We have adorned the lower heaven by adorning the planets . . .”All except for Shuʻba, Hafs and Hamza read it as: “We have adorned the lower heaven with the adornment of planets . . .”

37:7.t: and as a protection against every defiant devil.

37:8.t: They cannoteavesdrop1onthe Higher Assembly, for they get bombarded from every side—

f.80964: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “They cannot hear the Higher . . .”

37:9.t: repelled, and they will have an unremitting punishment,

37:10.t: except for one who snatched a fragment and was then pursued by a piercing meteor.

37:11.t: So inquiresgof them, “Are they more difficult to create, or the others We created?” Indeed, We created them from sticky clay.

37:12.t: Rather,yousgwere amazed1asthey ridicule.

f.80965: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Rather, I gravely noted as they ridicule .”

37:13.t: And when reminded, they remember not.

37:14.t: And when they see a sign, they exaggerate in ridiculing

37:15.t: and say, “This is nothing but evident sorcery.

37:16.t: Can it be thatwhen we have died and become dust and bones,can it be that1we will really be resurrected?

f.80966: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “Can it be that when we have died and become dust andbones we will really be resurrected?” Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “When we have died and become dust and bones, can it be that we will really be resurrected?”

f.80967: Qira’at: Qaloun, Abu Jaʻfar and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “Or our ancient . . .”

37:18.t: Saysg, “Yes indeed, and you will be totally subdued.”

37:19.t: It is but a single nudge, and there they are looking on(in bewilderment)!

37:20.t: And they said<sup foot_note="80968">1</sup>, “Woe to us! This is the Day of Recompense.”

f.80968: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

37:21.t: “This is the Day of Decision which youplused to deny.

37:22.t: Herdplthose who were unjust and their spouses, and what they used to worship

37:23.t: apart from Allah, and guide them to the path to purgatory.

37:24.t: And stop them—indeed, they are to be questioned.”

37:25.t: “What is the matter with youplthat you do not help one another?”

37:26.t: Rather, on this day, they are submissive.

37:27.t: And they camegto one another, asking one another.

37:28.t: They1said, “Indeed, youplused to come at us from the right2”

f.80970: This may mean that they used to force them or convince them of the rightness of their deeds.

37:29.t: They1said, “Rather, youplyourselves were not believers,

37:30.t: and we had no authority over you; rather, you yourselves were a people who exceeded all limits.

37:31.t: And therefore we deserved our Lord’s decree on us. Most surely we will all get a taste,

37:32.t: for we deluded youpl; indeed, we were deluded.”

37:33.t: So on that day, they are indeed partners in the punishment.

37:34.t: This is what We do with the criminals.

37:35.t: Indeed, when it was said to them, “There is no god except Allah,” they would act arrogantly

37:36.t: and say, “Are we really to abandon our gods for a mad poet?”

37:37.t: In fact, he came with the truth, and he confirmed the emissaries.

37:38.t: Most surely, youplwill taste the painful punishment,

37:39.t: and in no way will you be repaid except for what you used to do,

37:40.t: except for Allah’ssincere chosen1servants.

f.80972: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . except for Allah’s sincere servants.”

37:41.t: For those, there is a known provision:

37:45.t: A drink is passed round among them from a flowing spring:

37:46.t: white, a delight to those who drink,

37:47.t: no headiness in it, norby it are they1drained2.

f.80973: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “nor by it do they drain (themselves) .”

37:48.t: And with them are bashful maidens with lovely eyes,

37:49.t: as if they were closely guarded eggs.

37:50.t: So they came<sup foot_note="80975">1</sup>to one another, asking one another.

f.80975: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

37:51.t: One of them said, “Indeed, I did have a comrade

37:52.t: who would say, ‘Can it be that yousgare really of those who believe?

f.80976: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “Can it be that when we have died and become dust andbones we will really be called to account?”Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “When we have died and become dust and bones, can it be that we will really be called to account?”

37:54.t: He said(to his companions in Paradise), “Can youplview(him)?”

37:55.t: Then he viewed(him)and saw him in the midst of purgatory.

37:56.t: He said,“(I swear)by Allah, yousgalmost ruined me.

37:57.t: And were it not for the blessing of my Lord, I would have been of the arraigned.”

37:59.t: except for our first death? And are we never to be punished?”

37:60.t: It is most surely this which is the great triumph.

37:61.t: For the like of this let the workers work.

37:62.t: Is this a better hospitality or the Tree of Zaqqum<sup foot_note="80977">1</sup>?

f.80977: Trees in Hell which produce hot, bitter, rotten fruit.

37:63.t: Indeed, We have made it a means of trial for the unjust.

37:64.t: Indeed, it is a tree that comes out from the very origin of purgatory.

37:65.t: Its yield is as if it were devils’ heads.

37:66.t: So they are sure to eat from it and fill their bellies with it.

37:67.t: Then, on top of it, they will have a brew of scalding water.

37:68.t: Then their return is sure to be to purgatory.

37:69.t: Indeed, they found their forefathers astray,

37:70.t: so they rush along in their footsteps.

37:71.t: And certainly, most of the ancients before them went astray.

37:72.t: And certainly, We sent among them forewarners.

37:73.t: So looksgat what the outcome was for those who were warned,

37:74.t: except for Allah’ssincere chosen1servants.

f.80978: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . except for Allah’s sincere servants.”

37:75.t: And certainly, Noah called out to Us, so the very excellent of responders are We!

37:76.t: Thus We delivered him and his family from the great calamity,

37:77.t: and We made his offspring the sole survivors,

37:78.t: and We left him thus to be remembered among later generations.

37:79.t: Peace be upon Noah among(all creatures of)all realms.

37:80.t: Indeed, thus do We repay those who excel in doing good.

37:81.t: Indeed, he is one of Our believing servants.

37:83.t: And, indeed, of his kind is Abraham.

37:84.t: Recall when he came to his Lord with a sound heart.

37:85.t: He said to his father and his people, “What are you worshiping?

37:86.t: Is it false gods, instead of Allah, that youplwant?

37:87.t: So what is yourplopinion about the Lord of all realms?”

37:88.t: Then he took one look at the stars

37:90.t: So they turned away from him, fleeing,

37:91.t: whereupon he turned to their gods and said, “Will youplnot eat?

37:92.t: What is it with youpl? Do you not speak?”

37:93.t: Then he turned on them, striking with his right hand.

37:94.t: So they came towards him,dashing1.

f.80979: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “So they came towards him, urging (each other) to dash .”

37:95.t: He said, “Do you worship what you carve,

37:96.t: when Allah has created youpland all that you do?”

37:97.t: They said, “Build a structure for him and throw him into purgatory.”

37:98.t: So they desired to plot against him, but We made them the lowest.

37:99.t: And then he said, “I am going to my Lord—He will guide me.”

37:100.t: “My Lord, give me one of the righteous.”

37:101.t: So We gave him glad tidings of a forbearing boy.

37:102.t: Then, when he was old enough to accompany him, he said, “O my child, I see in a dream that I am sacrificing you, so look—what do you see1?” He said, “O my father, do as you are commanded; you will find me, Allah willing, of the patient ones.”

f.80980: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “so look—what would you show (me) to do ?”

37:103.t: Then, when theydlhad submitted and he laid him down on his forehead,

37:104.t: We then called out to him, “O Abraham!

37:105.t: Yousghave truly fulfilled the vision.” Thus indeed do We repay those who excel in doing good.

37:106.t: Indeed, this was certainly the evident test.

37:107.t: And We redeemed him with a great sacrifice,

37:108.t: and We left him thus to be remembered among later generations:

37:110.t: Thus We repay those who excel in doing good.

37:111.t: Indeed, he is one of Our believing servants.

37:112.t: And We gave him glad tidings of Isaac, a prophet, one of the righteous.

37:113.t: And We blessed him and Isaac. But of their offspring is one who excels in doing good and one who is evidently unjust to himself.

37:114.t: And We certainly conferred Our favor upon Moses and Aaron,

37:115.t: and We delivered themdland their people from the great calamity.

37:116.t: And We supported thempl, so they were the overcomers.

37:117.t: And We gave themdlthe evidential Scripture,

37:118.t: and We guided themdlupon the straight path.

37:119.t: And We left themdlthus to be remembered among later generations:

37:121.t: Thus do We repay those who excel in doing good.

37:122.t: Indeed, they are of Our believing servants.

37:124.t: Recall when he said to his people, “Will you not be mindful(of God)?

37:125.t: Do youplcall upon Baʻl1and leave the best of creators—

37:126.t: Allah, your Lord1and the Lord of your ancient fathers?”
