37:128.t: except for Allah’ssincere chosen1servants.

f.80983: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . except for Allah’s sincere servants.”

37:129.t: And We left him thus to be remembered among later generations:

f.80984: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “Peace be upon Elijah’s folk .”

37:131.t: Thus do We repay those who excel in doing good.

37:132.t: Indeed, he is one of Our believing servants.

37:133.t: And Lot is indeed one of the emissaries.

37:134.t: Recall when We delivered him and all of his family,

37:135.t: except for an old woman<sup foot_note="80985">1</sup>who lingered behind.

37:137.t: And most surely youplpass by them in the morning

37:138.t: and at night. Do you not reason?

37:139.t: And Jonah is indeed one of the emissaries.

37:140.t: Recall when he fled to the overloaded ship,

37:141.t: and he drew lots and was of those who lost.

37:142.t: Then the whale took him into its mouth, and he was to blame.

37:143.t: And had he not been one of those who highly exalt God,

37:144.t: he would have stayed in its belly until the day they are resurrected.

37:145.t: Then We threw him into the wilderness while he was sick,

37:146.t: and We germinated a gourd tree over him.

37:147.t: Then We sent him to a hundred thousand or more.

37:148.t: And they attained faith, so We gave them enjoyment for some time.

37:149.t: So inquiresgof them, “Are the daughters for yoursgLord while for them are the sons?”

37:150.t: Or did We create the angels as females while they witnessed?”

37:151.t: Undoubtedly, it is out of their utter falsehood that they do indeed say,

37:152.t: “Allah has begotten.” But they are most surely liars.

37:153.t: Has He selected daughters over sons?

37:154.t: What is it with youpl? How do you judge?

37:155.t: Will you notremind1yourselves?

f.80986: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Will you not constantly remember ?”

37:156.t: Or do youplhave an evident manifestation?

37:157.t: Then bring yourplscripture, if you have been truthful.

37:158.t: And they invented a relationship between Him and(the race of)unseen beings1. And certainly,(the race of)unseen beings knew that they(who made the claims)would surely be arraigned—

f.80987: The Arabic word used is jinnahwhich is the race of unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

37:159.t: Highly Exalted is Allah far above what they describe—

37:160.t: except for Allah’ssincere chosen1servants.

f.80988: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . except for Allah’s sincere servants.”

37:161.t: Thus surely, youpland what you worship

37:162.t: can never seduce(anyone)away from Him,

37:163.t: except for one who is to roast in purgatory.

37:164.t: “And there is not one of us<sup foot_note="80989">1</sup>but has an assigned position.

37:165.t: And we are indeed the aligned.

37:166.t: And we are indeed those who exalt God.”

37:167.t: Even though they<sup foot_note="80990">1</sup>used to say,

37:168.t: “Had we received a Reminder from the ancients<sup foot_note="80991">1</sup>,

37:169.t: we would have been Allah’s sincere chosen servants.”

37:170.t: But they denied it, so they will find out.

37:171.t: And most surely Our Word has already gone out to our servant emissaries:

37:172.t: indeed, it is they who shall surely be supported,

37:173.t: and indeed it is Our soldiers who shall surely be the overcomers.

37:174.t: So turnsgaway from them for some time,

37:175.t: and watch them—for they will soon see.

37:176.t: Do they seek to hasten Our punishment?

37:177.t: Yet, when it descends into their courtyard, miserable shall be the morning of those forewarned<sup foot_note="80992">1</sup>.

37:178.t: And turnsgaway from them for a while,

37:180.t: Highly Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, far above what they describe.

37:181.t: And peace be upon the emissaries.

37:182.t: And all praise be to Allah, Lord of all realms.

38:1.t: Sād. By the Recital<sup foot_note="80993">1</sup>containing the Reminder.

f.80993: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

38:2.t: Yet those who denied are in a state of might<sup foot_note="80994">1</sup>and opposition.

38:3.t: How many generations have We caused to perish before them, so they called out when it was too late to escape!

38:4.t: And they marveled that a forewarner had come to them from among them, and the deniers said, “This is a sorcerer, a sheer liar.

38:5.t: Did he make all the gods into one God? Surely this is indeed something strange.”

38:6.t: And the chiefs among them proceeded,(saying), “Walk away(from the Prophet)and hold fast to yourplgods; indeed this is certainly something planned.

38:7.t: Never have we heard of this in the former creed. This is nothing but an invention.

38:8.t: Was the Reminder sent down to him out of all of us?” Rather, they are doubtful about My Reminder; rather, they have not yet tasted My punishment.

38:9.t: Or do they possess the treasuries of yoursgLord’s mercy, the Almighty, the Giver?

38:10.t: Or do they possess the dominion of the heavens and the earth and what is between them? Then let them ascend by any means.

38:11.t: An army of confederates will be defeated there.

38:12.t: Before them the people of Noah disbelieved, as did ʻĀd<sup foot_note="80995">1</sup>, and Pharaoh of the stakes,

f.80995: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

38:13.t: and Thamûd<sup foot_note="80996">1</sup>and the people of Lot and the fellows of the thicket. Those were the parties.

f.80996: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

38:14.t: None of them but disbelieved the messengers, so My punishment was deserved.

38:15.t: For these await nothing but a single shout, from which there is no recovery.

38:16.t: Yet they said, “Our Lord, hasten for us our share of punishment before the Day of Reckoning.”

38:17.t: Enduresgpatiently what they say and remember Our servant David who was endowed with strong faith; indeed, he often turns1to Us.

f.80997: Frequently the Qur’an speaks about the prophets using present tense; this should be pondered by the reader.

38:18.t: Indeed, We subjected the mountains to give due exaltations(to God)with him in the evening and at daybreak,

38:19.t: with the birds made to flock, each often turning to Him.

38:20.t: Thus We strengthened his dominion and brought him wisdom and decisive speech.

38:21.t: And has the tiding of the disputants reached yousg, as they climbed the sanctuary—

38:22.t: as they entered upon David, and he was startled by them? They said, “Do not fear; two disputants, one of whom has oppressed the other. So judge between us with the truth and do not be untrue, and guide us to the right path.”

38:23.t: “Indeed, this is my brother; he has ninety-nine ewes and I have just one ewe, and he said, ‘Entrust it to me,’ and he pressured me with words.”

38:24.t: He said, “He has done yousgwrong by asking your ewe in addition to his ewes, and indeed many partners do oppress one another— except those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds, but these are so few.” And David realized that We were testing him, so he sought forgiveness from his Lord and fell down to his knees and turned penitent.

38:25.t: So We forgave him that, and indeed there is most surely for him nearness to Us and a beautiful place to return to.

38:26.t: “O David, We have appointed you as a viceroy in the land, so judge between mankind with the truth and do not follow the whim, lest it misguide you from the way of Allah. Indeed, for those who stray from the way of Allah there is a severe punishment for their having forgotten the Day of Reckoning.”

38:27.t: And in no way have We created the heaven and the earth and whatever is between them in vain. That is the assumption of those who have denied. So woe to those who have denied from the Fire!

38:28.t: Or are We to make those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds equal to those who spread corruption in the earth? Or are We to make the people who are mindful(of God)equal to the wicked?

38:29.t: A Scripture that We sent down to yousg, blessed, thatthey1may ponderits signs2and that those endowed with understanding may remind themselves.

f.80998: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . that you pl may ponder . . .”
f.80999: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

38:30.t: And to David We gave Solomon, an excellent servant; indeed, he often turns<sup foot_note="81000">1</sup>to Us.

f.81000: Frequently the Qur’an speaks about the prophets using present tense; this should be pondered by the reader.

38:31.t: Recall when the beautiful horses were paraded before him in the evening,

38:32.t: so he said, “Indeed, I have loved the good things with a love more than the remembrance of my Lord, until it1disappeared behind the veil(of night).

38:33.t: Bringplthem back to me.” And he started to stroke their legs and necks.

38:34.t: And surely, We tested Solomon and cast a body on his throne, then he turned penitent.

38:35.t: He said, “My Lord, forgive me and grant me a dominion never to be attained by anyone after me; indeed, You— only You—are the Giver.”

38:36.t: So We subjected to him thewind1, flowing gently by his command wherever he directed;

f.81002: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “winds ”.

38:37.t: and the demons—every builder and diver;

38:38.t: and others bound together in fetters.

38:39.t: “This is Our gift, so givesggenerously or withhold, without measure.”

38:40.t: And indeed, for him is nearness to Us and a beautiful place to return to.

38:41.t: And recall Our servant Job, when he called out to his Lord, “Satan has touched me with toil and suffering.”

38:42.t: “Stamp your foot—this is a cool washing-place and drinking-place.”

38:43.t: And We gave him back his family and doubled them—a mercy from Us and a reminding for those endowed with understanding.

38:44.t: “And take with yoursghand a bundle of grass, and strike with it so as not to breach(your oath).” Indeed, We found him patient. What an excellent servant; indeed, he often turnsaunto Us.

38:45.t: And recallsgOurservants1Abraham and Isaac and Jacob—those endowed with strong faith and with sight(s).

f.81003: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “And recallsg Our servant Abraham . . .”

38:46.t: Surely We distinguished them witha distinct quality1—the remembranceof the(final)Home.

f.81004: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Hisham and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . with the distinct quality of the remembrance . . .”

38:47.t: And indeed, to Us they are of the elect, the outstanding.

38:48.t: And recallsgIshmael and Elisha and Ezekiel—and all are of the outstanding.

38:49.t: This is a Reminder. For indeed, for the mindful(of God)is a beautiful place to return to:

38:50.t: the Gardens of Eden, with their doors wide-open for them,

38:51.t: relaxing therein and calling for abundant fruit and beverage.

38:52.t: And with them are bashful maidens of equal age.

38:53.t: This is whatyou1are promisedfor the Day of Reckoning.

f.81005: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “This is what they are promised . . .”

38:54.t: Indeed, such is Our provision, inexhaustible.

38:55.t: All this. But indeed, for those who exceed all limits is a miserable place to return to:

38:56.t: Hell, in which they roast—so what a miserable resting place!

38:57.t: All this, so let them taste it—scalding water and purulence.

38:58.t: Andanother1(torment)similar to it, of diverse kinds.

f.81006: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “And other (torments) similar . . .”

38:59.t: “This is a crowd rushing headlong with youpl.” They are not welcome; indeed, they are to be roasted in the Fire.

38:60.t: They said, “But it is youplwho are not welcome! It is you who brought it upon us! So what a miserable end!”

38:61.t: They said, “Our Lord, whoever brought this upon us, give him double punishment in the Fire.”

38:62.t: And they said, “What is it with us that we do not see men whom we used to count among thevillains?

38:63.t: Did we take them with mockery1, or have our sight(s)swerved from them?

f.81007: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . used to count among the villains— 63whom we took with mockery, or have our sight(s) swerved from them?Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . used to count among the villains? Did we abuse them , or have our sight(s) swerved from them?Hamza, Al Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . used to count among the villains— 63whom we abused , or have our sight(s) swerved from them?

38:64.t: Indeed, that is certainly true: the disputing among the inhabitants of the Fire.

38:65.t: Saysg, “Indeed, I am only a forewarner, for there is no god except Allah—the One, the Subduer,

38:66.t: Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, the Almighty, the Forgiver.”

38:67.t: Saysg, “It is a great tiding

38:69.t: I have had no knowledge of the Highest Assembly as they disputed.

38:70.t: It is only revealed tomethat1I am an evident warner.”

f.81008: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “It is only revealed to me: indeed, I am an evident warner.”

38:71.t: Recall when YoursgLord said to the angels, “Indeed, I am creating a human being from clay.

38:72.t: So when I have formed him and breathed into him of My spirit, fall prostrate before him.

38:73.t: So the angels fell prostrate, all of them, entirely—

38:74.t: but not Iblis<sup foot_note="81009">1</sup>; he acted arrogantly and became one of the deniers.

f.81009: Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.

38:75.t: He said, “O Iblis, what prevented you from prostrating before what I created with My Own hands? Have you acted arrogantly, or have you become one of the exalted?”

38:76.t: He said, “I am better than him; You created me from fire and created him from clay.”

38:77.t: He said, “Then get out of it, for you are indeed an outcast!

38:78.t: And indeed, My curse is upon you until the Day of Recompense.”

38:79.t: He said, “My Lord, then reprieve me until the day they are resurrected.”

38:80.t: He said, “Then indeed, you are of those reprieved

38:81.t: until the Day of the Time Appointed.”

38:82.t: He said, “Then, by Your majesty, I will most surely delude them all,

38:83.t: except for yoursincere chosen1servants among them.”

f.81010: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . except for your sincere servants among them.”

38:84.t: He said, “Sothe truth1is—and only the truth I say—

f.81011: Qira’at: All except ʻAsem, Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “So (by) the truth —and only the truth I say . . .”

38:85.t: I will surely fill Hell with yousgand with whoever of them who follows you, all together.”

38:86.t: Saysg, “I ask of you no reward for this, and I am not a pretender.

38:87.t: It is but a Reminder to(all creatures of)all realms.

38:88.t: And youplwill certainly know its tiding after a while.”

39:1.t: The bestowal of the Scripture from on high is by Allah the Almighty, the All-Wise.

39:2.t: Indeed, We have sent down to yousgthe Scripture with the truth, so worship Allah, devoting religion to Him.

39:3.t: Undoubtedly, faithful religion is due to Allah! And those who take guardians apart from Him—(they say,)“We only worship them so that they may bring us closer to Allah.” Indeed, Allah will judge between them regarding whatever they used to differ over. Indeed, Allah does not guide one who is a liar, a relentless denier.

39:4.t: Had Allah desired to have a child, He would have selected whatever He so willed from whatever He created. Highly Exalted is He; He is Allah, the One, the Subduer.

39:5.t: He created the heavens and the earth with truth; He rolls the night around the day, and He rolls the day around the night. And He has subjected the sun and the moon, each running for a stated term. Undoubtedly, He is the Almighty, the Forgiving.

39:6.t: He created youplfrom a single self, then made from it its spouse, and sent down to you of livestock eight kinds in pairs. He creates you in your mothers’ bellies, one act of creation after another, in threefold darkness(es). That is Allah, yourplLord; to Him belongs the dominion; there is no god but Him, so how then are you turned away?

39:7.t: If youpldeny, then indeed Allah is Self-sufficient without(any need of)you, yet He does not approve denial on the part of His servants, and if you are thankful He approves it for you. And no bearer of burden bears the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, whereupon He informs you of what you used to do; indeed, He is All-Knowing of what lies within the chests.

39:8.t: And when some harm touches man, he calls upon his Lord, in penitence to Him. But then, when He confers on him a blessing of His, he forgets what he was previously calling upon for, and he sets up rivals to Allah in order tomake(people)stray1from His way. Say, “Enjoyyoursgdenial for a little while; you are one of the fellows of the Fire.”

f.81012: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Roways read it as: “. . . in order to stray from His way.”

39:9.t: Or what1about one who worships devoutly during the watches of the night, prostrating himself and standing up, wary of the Hereafter and hoping for the mercy of his Lord? Saysg, “Are those who know and those who do not know equal?” Indeed, only those endowed with understanding remind themselves.

f.81013: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir and Hamza read it as: “What about one who . . .”

39:10.t: Saysg(on My behalf), “O My servants who have attained faith, be mindful of your1Lord. For those who do good in this Earlier(Life)is goodness, and Allah’s land is vast. Indeed, the patient ones will be rendered their reward in full without measure.”

39:11.t: Saysg, “Indeed, I have been commanded to worship Allah, devoting religion to Him,

39:12.t: and I was commanded to become the first of the Muslims<sup foot_note="81015">1</sup>.”

f.81015: The Arabic word used is Muslimeenwhich means ‘those who willingly submit to God’.

39:13.t: Say, “I fear, if I disobey my Lord, the punishment of a great day.”

39:14.t: Saysg, “It is Allah I worship, devoting my religion to Him.”

39:15.t: “So worshipplwhatever you wish apart from Him.” Saysg, “Indeed, the losers are those who lost themselves and their people on the Day of Resurrection.” Undoubtedly, that is the evident loss.

39:16.t: They have layers of fire above them, and layers beneath them. That is how Allah puts fear into His servants. “O My servants, therefore, be mindful of Me!”

39:17.t: And those who avoided false masters—that they should worship them, and turned to Allah in penitence—for them are glad tidings. So givesgglad tidings to My servants

39:18.t: who listen to what is said and follow the best of it; those are the ones whom Allah has guided, and those are the people of understanding.

39:19.t: What about the one who has deserved the decree of punishment? Is it yousgwho(can)rescue those in the Fire?

39:20.t: But those who were mindful of their Lord—for them are compartments above which are compartments built high, with rivers flowing beneath them:the promise of Allah; Allah never breaks a promise.

39:21.t: Have youplnot seen that Allah has sent down water from the sky, then He made it flow into springs in the earth, then He brings out with it vegetation of various colors, then they wither and you see them yellowing, then He turns them into debris? Indeed, in this is a reminding for the people of understanding.

39:22.t: What about someone whose chest Allah has expanded to(accept)Islam, so that he follows a light from His Lord? So woe to those whose hearts are hardened against the remembrance of Allah; those are in evident misguidance.

39:23.t: Allah has bestowed the most beautiful of all teachings from on high: a Scripture consistent and paired. The skins of those who fear their Lord shiver from it, then their skins and their hearts soften up to the remembrance of Allah. Such is Allah’s guidance; He guides with it whomever He wills. But whomever Allah misguides, no guide shall there ever be for him.

39:24.t: What about someone who covers his face against the terrible punishment of the Day of Resurrection? And it was said1to the unjust, “Taste what youplused to earn.”

f.81016: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

39:25.t: Those before them disbelieved, so the punishment came up to them from where they were unaware.

39:26.t: So Allah made them taste disgrace in the Earlier Life, and surely the punishment of the Hereafter is more grievous, if they only knew.

39:27.t: And surely, We have put forth in this Recital<sup foot_note="81017">1</sup>for mankind all kinds of parables, that they may remind themselves:

f.81017: The Arabic word used isQur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

39:28.t: an Arabic Recitalb, free from any distortion, that they may become mindful(of God).

39:29.t: Allah set forth the parable of a man owned by quarreling associates, and a man belonging exclusively to one man. Are they equal in status? All praise be to Allah. But most of them do not know.

39:30.t: Yousgwill certainly die, and they will certainly die.

39:31.t: Then certainly on the Day of Resurrection you will dispute with one another in the presence of your Lord.

39:32.t: So who is more unjust than one who lied about Allah and disbelieved the truth when it came to him? Is there not in Hell a dwelling for the deniers?

39:33.t: But the one who came with the sincere belief and sincerely believed in it—those1are the mindful(of God).

f.81018: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

39:34.t: For them, with their Lord, is whatever they will; such is the repayment for those who excel in doing good.

39:35.t: So that Allah may remit the worst of what they have done and repay them their reward in accordance with the best of what they used to do.

39:36.t: Is not Allah enough for Hisservant1? And they(seek to)frighten yousgwith those apart from Him. Thus whomever Allah misguides, no guide shall there ever be for him.

f.81019: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “servants ”.

39:37.t: And whomever Allah guides, for him there is no misleader. Is Allah not Almighty, Capable of vengeance?

39:38.t: And if yousgasked them, “Who created the heavens and the earth?” they would say, “Allah.” Say, “Have youplseen those whom you call upon apart from Allah? If Allah desired any harm for me, would they be capable of preventing His harm? And if He desired a blessing for me, would they be capable of preventing His mercy?” Say, “Allah suffices for me; those who trust, place their trust in Him.”

39:39.t: Say, ‘My people, act according to yourposition1; surely, I am also acting(according to mine). Then you shall come to know

f.81020: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “positions ”.

39:40.t: who will receive a punishment that disgraces him, and upon whom a perpetual punishment shall fall.”

39:41.t: Indeed, We have sent down the Scripture upon yousgfor mankind with the truth. So whoever seeks guidance does so to his own benefit, while whoever goes astray—he only does so to his own detriment, and you are not a trustee over them.

39:42.t: Allah takes up the selves at the time of their death, and those that have not died(He takes up)during their sleep. Then He retains thosefor which He has decreed1deathand releases the others to(fulfill)a stated term. Most surely, in that are signs for people who reflect.

f.81021: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Then He retains those for which death has been decreed . . .”

39:43.t: Or have they chosen intercessors other than Allah? Saysg, “Even though they have no power over anything, nor do they reason?”

39:44.t: Saysg, “All intercession is up to Allah; to Him belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, then to Himyouplare returned1.”

f.81022: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . then to Him you pl return .”

39:45.t: And when Allah is mentioned alone, the hearts of those who do not believe in the Hereafter are disgusted. But when those apart from Him are mentioned, they promptly start anticipating glad tidings.

39:46.t: Saysg, “Our God, Originator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the hidden realm and the manifest, You judge between Your servants regarding whatever they used to differ over.”

39:47.t: If those who were unjust owned whatever is in the earth, all together, and the like of it with it, they would(seek to)redeem themselves with it from the terrible punishment on the Day of Resurrection. But there appeared1to them from Allah what they never anticipated.

f.81023: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

39:48.t: And there appeared to them the evil deeds of whatever they had earned, and so they became surrounded by what they usedto ridicule.

39:49.t: And when harm touches man, he calls upon Us; then when We grant him a blessing from Us, he says, “I have been brought it solely because of(my)knowledge.” Rather, it is a means of trial, but most of them do not know.

39:50.t: Those before them previously said that, but what they used to earn did not avail them,

39:51.t: so they were afflicted by the evil deeds of whatever they had earned. And the unjust among these will also be afflicted by the evil deeds of whatever they have earned, and in no way can they thwart(God).

39:52.t: Have they not come to know that Allah extends provision for whomever He wills, and He restrains(it)? In that are signs for people who believe.

39:53.t: Saysg, “O My servants who have gone to extremes against themselves: despair not of Allah’s mercy, for indeed Allah forgives all misdeeds; indeed, He is the Oft-Forgiving, the Bestower of mercy.”

39:54.t: And turn penitent to yourplLord and submit to Him before the punishment comes upon you and you are not supported.

39:55.t: And follow the best of what was sent down to youplfrom your Lord before the punishment comes upon you suddenly while you are unaware.

39:56.t: So that no soul may say, “Alas, for having neglected my duty towards Allah and for having been of the mockers.”

39:57.t: Or it may say, “Had Allah guided me, I would have been of the mindful(of God).”

39:58.t: Or it may say, when it sees the punishment, “If only I had another chance, I would be of those who excel in doing good.”

39:59.t: Yes indeed! My signs did come to yousg, but you disbelieved in them and acted arrogantly and were of the deniers.

39:60.t: And on the Day of Resurrection yousgsee those who told lies about Allah with their faces blackened. Is there not in Hell a dwelling for the arrogant?

39:61.t: And Allahdelivers1those who were mindful(of Him)to theirplace2of triumph; no harm touches them, nor do they grieve.

f.81024: Qira’at: Rouh read it as: “And Allah saves those . . .”
f.81025: Qira’at: Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . to their places of triumph . . .”

39:62.t: Allah is the Creator of everything, and He is the Ultimate Trustee over everything.

39:63.t: To Him belong the treasures of the heavens and the earth. But those who have denied the signs of Allah—it is they who are the losers.

39:64.t: Saysg, “Is it other than Allah, then, that you command me to worship, you ignorant ones?”

39:65.t: And it was revealed to yousgand to those before you that if yousgassociate(others with God), your work will certainly be nullified, and you will certainly be of the losers.

39:66.t: Rather, worship Allah and be of the appreciative.

39:67.t: Yet they did not render to Allah the respect that He deserves, for the entire earth is in His grip on the Day of Resurrection, and the heavens are folded in His right. Highly Exalted is He and Most High beyond the associations they make.

39:68.t: And the Trumpet was blown<sup foot_note="81026">1</sup>, so all who were in the heavens and the earth were stunned, except whomever Allah willed. Then it was blown another time, whereupon they all stood looking on.

f.81026: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

39:69.t: And the earth shone with the Light of its Lord, and the record<sup foot_note="81027">1</sup>was placed, and the prophets and the witnesses<sup foot_note="81028">2</sup>were brought in, and it was judged between them in truth, and they were not dealt with unjustly.

f.81028: The Arabic word used is shuhada’, which literally means ‘witnesses’ and is usually used to describe martyrs.

39:70.t: And every soul was fully compensated for what it had done, for He knows better what they do.

39:71.t: And those who denied were driven to Hell in throngs, until, when they had reached it, its gates wereopened1and its keepers said to them, “Did not messengers from among you come to you, reading to you the signs2of your Lord and warning you of the meeting of this day of yours?” They said, “Yes, indeed!” But the word of punishment proved true against the deniers.

f.81029: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . its gates were opened wide and . . .”
f.81030: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

39:72.t: It was said, “Enter the gates of Hell, abiding therein.” So how miserable is the dwelling of the arrogant!

39:73.t: And those who were mindful of their Lord were driven to the Garden(of Paradise)in throngs, until, when they had reached it and its gates wereopened1and its keepers said to them, “Peace be upon you, you have been good, so enter it, to abide.”

f.81031: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and its gates were opened wide and . . .”

39:74.t: And they said, “All praise be to Allah Who has fulfilled His promise to us and made us inherit the land, enjoying the Garden(of Paradise)as we please.” So how excellent is the reward of the workers!

39:75.t: And yousgsee1the angels hovering around the Throne, exalting their Lord with praise. And it was judged between them equitably, and it was said, “Praise be to Allah, Lord of all realms.”

f.81032: A grammatical shift to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of future events.

40:2.t: The bestowal of the Scripture from on high is by Allah the Almighty, the All-Knowing,

40:3.t: the Forgiver of(every)misdeed and the Granter and Accepter of repentance, the Severe in punishment, the Bountiful in bounty; there is no god but He; to Him is the ultimate return.

40:4.t: None argues against Allah’s signs except those who have denied, so dosgnot be deceived by their movement in the land.

40:5.t: Before them the people of Noah disbelieved, as did the parties after them. And every community sought after their<sup foot_note="81033">1</sup>messenger in order to capture him, and they argued using falsehood to defeat with it the truth. But I seized them, so how was My punishment!

f.81033: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

40:6.t: Thus yoursgLord’sWord1came true against those who denied: that they are the fellows of the Fire.

f.81034: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Words ”.

40:7.t: Those who carry the Throne and those around it exalt their Lord with praise and believe in Him and ask for forgiveness for those who have attained faith: “Our Lord, You have encompassed everything in mercy and knowledge, so forgive those who have repented and followed Your way, and protect them from the punishment of purgatory.

40:8.t: Our Lord, and enter them into the Gardens of Eden which You have promised them—and the righteous among their forefathers and their spouses and their offspring(s); indeed, it is You, You(alone),who are the Almighty, the All-Wise.

40:9.t: And shield them from evil deeds, for whomever You shield from evil deeds on that day, You have had mercy on him. And that is the great triumph.”

40:10.t: Indeed, those who denied will be addressed, “The loathing of Allah is greater than your loathing of yourselves—for you were invited to the faith, but you refused.”

40:11.t: They said<sup foot_note="81035">1</sup>, “Our Lord, you caused us to die twice, and you gave us life twice. Now we have acknowledged our misdeeds, so is there any way out?”

f.81035: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

40:12.t: That is because whenever Allah alone was called upon, youpldenied. But if others are associated with Him, you believe. But judgment rests with Allah the All-High, the Supreme.

40:13.t: It is He who shows youplHis signs andbestows1—from on high—provision from heaven for you. But none reminds himself except whoever is penitent.

f.81036: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and sends down provision from heaven . . .”

40:14.t: So callplupon Allah, devoting religion to Him, even if the deniers hate it.

40:15.t: Exalted in degrees(of rank), Owner of the Throne—He casts the spirit(of inspiration)by His command upon whomever He wills of His servants to warn of the Day of Encounter:

40:16.t: the day when they emerge; nothing about them is hidden from Allah. “To whom does the dominion belong today?” “To Allah, the One, the Subduer.”

40:17.t: Today, every soul is repaid for what it has earned. There is no injustice today; indeed, Allah is Swift in reckoning.

40:18.t: And warnsgthem of the Day of the Inevitable Event, when hearts are at throats, while they block them1. The evildoers will have neither intimate(friend)nor intercessor to be obeyed.

f.81037: Lest their hearts jump out of their throats, out of fear.

40:19.t: He knows the treacherous look of the eyes and whatever the chests hide.

40:20.t: And Allah decrees with the truth, while those whomthey1call uponapart from Him do not decree at all. Indeed, it is Allah who is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing.

f.81038: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Hisham read it as: “. . . while those whom you pl call upon . . .”

40:21.t: Have they not journeyed through the earth and looked at how the outcome was for those before them? They were superior tothem1in strength and in the traces which they left in the land, but Allah seized them for their misdeeds, for they had no shield from Allah.

f.81039: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “They were superior to you pl in strength . . .”

40:22.t: That is because their messengers used to come to them with evident proofs, but they denied, so Allah seized them. He is All-Powerful, Stern in retribution.

40:23.t: And We sent Moses with Our signs and an evident manifestation

40:24.t: to Pharaoh and Hamān and Qarun, but they said, “A sorcerer, a sheer liar.”

40:25.t: Then when he came to them with the truth from Us, they said, “Kill the sons of those who have attained faith with him and keep their women alive(in bondage).” But the plotting of the deniers can only go astray.

40:26.t: And Pharaoh said, “Let me kill Moses, and let him call upon his Lord; indeed, I am afraid that he may exchange yourplreligionor that he may cause corruption to appear1in the land.”

f.81040: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . religion and that he may cause corruption to appear in the land.” Ibn Kathir and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . religion and that corruption may appear in the land.” Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . religion or that corruption may appear in the land.”

40:27.t: And Moses said, “I have sought refuge with my Lord and yourplLord from every arrogant one who does not believe in the Day of Reckoning.”

40:28.t: And a believing man from Pharaoh’s folk who had concealed his faith said, “Do youplkill a man for saying, ‘My Lord is Allah,’ and he has come to you with evident proofs from your Lord? If he is a liar, then his lying is upon him. But if he is truthful, then some of what he promises you will befall you; indeed, Allah does not guide anyone who is an extremist, a sheer liar.

40:29.t: O my people, yours is thedominion today, prevailing in the land. But who will help us against Allah’s chastisement, should it fall upon us?” Pharaoh said, “I do not show youplexcept what I see, and I do not guide you except to the way of prudence.”

40:30.t: But the one who had attained faith said, “O my people, I fear for you the like of the Day of the Parties—

40:31.t: like the custom of the people of Noah and ʻĀd<sup foot_note="81041">1</sup>and Thamûd<sup foot_note="81042">2</sup>and those after them. For Allah wants no injustice for the servants.

f.81041: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.
f.81042: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

40:32.t: O my people, I fear for you the Day of Calling Out—

40:33.t: the day when you turn away, fleeing, with no safeguard from Allah. And whomever Allah misguides, no guide shall there ever be for him.

40:34.t: And surely Joseph did come to youplwith the evident proofs, but you continued to doubt what he came to you with, until when he perished, you said, “Allah will never send a messenger after him.” Thus Allah misguides whoever is an extremist, constantly doubting.

40:35.t: Those who argue against Allah’s signs without any manifestation having come to them—this is most loathsome to Allah and to those who have attained faith; thus Allah seals theheart1of every arrogant compeller.

f.81043: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr and Ibn Zekwan read it as: “. . . thus Allah seals every arrogant compelling heart .”

40:36.t: And Pharaoh said, “O Hamān, build me a tower, that I may reach the means—

40:37.t: the means of the heavens,so that I may view1the God of Moses, though I surely think he is a liar.” And thus Pharaoh’s evil deeds were adorned for him andhe was barred2from the way, for Pharaoh’s plotting is in nothing but ruin.

f.81045: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . and he barred (others) from the way . . .”
f.81044: Qira’at: All except Hafs read it as: “. . . of the heavens, and view the God of Moses . . .”

40:38.t: And the one who had attained faith said, “O my people, follow me and I will guide you to the way of prudence.

40:39.t: O my people, this Earlier Life is nothing but(fleeting)enjoyment, while the Hereafter is indeed the Home of Permanence.

40:40.t: Whoever has committed an evil deed will not be repaid except with its like, but whoever has acted righteously, whether male or female, while a believer—then thoseshall enter1the Garden(of Paradise)where they shall be provided for without measure.

f.81046: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . then those shall be entered into the Garden . . .”

40:41.t: And O my people, how is it that I call you to salvation and you call me to the Fire?

40:42.t: Youplcall me to deny Allah and associate with Him what I have no knowledge of, while I call you to the Almighty, the Forgiver.

40:43.t: Without doubt, what youplcall me to has no say in the Earlier(Life)or in the Hereafter, and that our turning back is to Allah, and that it is the extremists who are the fellows of the Fire.

40:44.t: Youplwill remember what I am telling you. So I entrust my affairs to Allah; indeed, Allah is All-Seeing of the servants.”

40:45.t: So Allah shielded him from the evils of their scheming, while an awful punishment surrounded Pharaoh’s folk:

40:46.t: the Fire—they are exposed to it in the early morning and at nightfall, and on the day the Hour takes place(it is said): “EnterplPharaoh’s folk1into the most intense punishment.”

f.81047: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer and Shuʻba read it as: “Enterpl , O Pharaoh’s folk . . .”

40:47.t: And as they debate in the Fire, the weak say to the arrogant leaders, “Indeed, we were followers of yours, so will you now spare us a portion of the Fire?”

40:48.t: The arrogant leaders said<sup foot_note="81048">1</sup>, “We are all in it; indeed, Allah has judged between the servants.”

f.81048: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

40:49.t: And those in the Fire said to the keepers of Hell, “Call upon your Lord to lighten one day of the punishment for us.”

40:50.t: They said, “Did not your messengers come to you with evident proofs?” They said, “Yes.” They said, “Then call.” But the calling of the deniers is but in vain.

40:51.t: Most surely, We support Our messengers and those who have attained faith in the Earlier Life and on the day when all sorts of witnesses arise—

40:52.t: the day when the excuses of the unjust do them no benefit, and for them is the curse, and for them is the worst(final)Home.

40:53.t: And certainly We gave Moses the guidance and made the children of Israel inherit the Scripture,

40:54.t: as guidance and a reminding for those endowed with understanding.

40:55.t: So be patientsg; indeed the promise of Allah is true. And ask forgiveness for yoursgmisdeed and exalt your Lord with praise evening and morning.

40:56.t: Indeed, those who argue against Allah’s signs without any manifestation having come to them—there is nothing in their chests but a feeling of greatness which they will never attain. So seeksgrefuge in Allah; indeed, it is He who is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing.

40:57.t: The creation of the heavens and the earth is certainly greater than the creation of humanity, but the majority of mankind does not know.

40:58.t: And in no way are the blind and the seeing equal, nor are those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds(equal)to the evildoer. How littleyou1remind yourselves!

f.81049: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “How little they remind themselves !”

40:59.t: Indeed, the Hour is coming—no doubt about it—but the majority of mankind does not believe.

40:60.t: Yet your Lord has said, “Call upon Me(and)I will respond to you. Indeed, those who are too arrogant to serve Me willenter1Hell in humiliation.”

f.81050: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Shuʻba, Abu Jaʻfar and Roways read it as: “. . . will be entered into Hell . . .”

40:61.t: It is Allah Who made the night for youpl, that you may rest therein, and the day allowing sight; indeed, Allah is certainly Gracious towards mankind, but the majority of mankind does not give thanks.

40:62.t: Such is Allah, yourplLord, Creator of everything; there is no god except Him, so how can you be averted(from the truth)?

40:63.t: Thus are averted those who used to repudiate the signs of Allah.

40:64.t: It is Allah who made the earth a habitat for youpl, and the sky a structure, and He designed you and perfected your designs, and He provided you with the good things. Such is Allah, your Lord, so supremely blessed be Allah, Lord of all realms.

40:65.t: He is the Living One; there is no god except He, so callplupon Him, devoting religion to Him. All praise be to Allah, Lord of all realms.

40:66.t: Saysg, “Indeed, I have been forbidden to worship those whom youplcall upon apart from Allah, now that the evident proofs have come to me from my Lord. And I have been commanded to submit to the Lord of all realms.”

40:67.t: It is He Who created youplfrom dust, then from a drop of semen, then from a clinging form, then He brings you out as infants, then He lets you attain your full strength, then you become elderly—although some of you are taken(at death)sooner—and that you may reach a predetermined age, and so that you may reason.

40:68.t: It is He who gives life and death, so whenever He decrees a matter, He only says to it,“Be,” and so it is1.

f.81051: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “He only says to it, ‘Be,’ so it is.”

40:69.t: Have yousgnot seen those who argue regarding Allah’s signs? How are they turned away?

40:70.t: Those who disbelieved the Scripture and what We sent Our messengers with, for they will come to know

40:71.t: when the yokes are around their necks, as well as the chains, as they are dragged

40:72.t: into the scalding water, then in the Fire they are seethed.

40:73.t: Then it was said<sup foot_note="81052">1</sup>to them, “Where are those you used to associate

f.81052: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in pasttense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

40:74.t: apart from Allah?” They said, “They have strayed from us. In fact, we were calling upon nothing before.” Thus Allah misguides the deniers.

40:75.t: “That is on account of how youplused to rejoice on earth in untruth and on account of how you used to behave with vanity.

40:76.t: Enterplthe gates of Hell, abiding therein. So how miserable is the dwelling of the arrogant!”

40:77.t: So be patientsg; indeed, the promise of Allah is true. So whether We show you some of what We have promised them or take you up to Us, to Usthey are returned1.

f.81053: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . to Us they return .”

40:78.t: And surely We sent messengers before yousg, some of whose stories We related to you, and some We did not. And it was never for any messenger to bring about a sign except by Allah’s leave. So when the command of Allah comes, matters are decreed between them with fairness, and there and then the advocates of falsehood will lose.

40:79.t: It is Allah who made livestock for youpl, that you may ride some of them and of some you eat.

40:80.t: And in them you have benefits, and through them you satisfy a need within your chests, and on them and on ships you are carried.

40:81.t: And He shows youplHis signs, so which of Allah’s signs do you deny?

40:82.t: Have they not journeyed through the earth and looked at how the outcome was for those before them? They were superior to them in strength and in the traces which they left in the land, but what they had achieved availed them nothing.

40:83.t: When their messengers came to them with evident proofs they rejoiced in the knowledge they had, so they became surrounded by what they used to ridicule.

40:84.t: Then when they witnessed Our chastisement they said, “We believe in Allah alone and we deny what we used to associate with Him.”

40:85.t: But their faith could not help them once they witnessed Our chastisement; such has been Allah’s rule in(dealing with)His servants, and there and then did the deniers lose.

41:2.t: A bestowal from on high by the All-Merciful, the Bestower of mercy—

41:3.t: a Scripture whose signs<sup foot_note="81054">1</sup>were detailed as an Arabic Recital<sup foot_note="81055">2</sup>for people who know.

f.81054: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.
f.81055: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

41:4.t: A herald of glad tidings and a warner, but most of them disregard(it),so they do not hear.

41:5.t: And they said, “Our hearts are screened from what yousgcall us to, and in our ears is deafness, and between us and you is a barrier. So do what you want, and so will we.”

41:6.t: Saysg, “I am only a human being like youpl. To me it is revealed that your god is One God. So be upright towards Him and seek forgiveness from Him.” And woe to the polytheists—

41:7.t: those who do not bring about the purifying act<sup foot_note="81056">1</sup>, and regarding the Hereafter they are deniers.

f.81056: The Arabic word here, zakāt, is the same word used for purifying charity, and which literally means purification and growth.

41:8.t: Indeed, those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds—for them is an unfailing reward.

41:9.t: Say, “Can it be that youplreally deny the One Who created the earth in two(heavenly)days and attribute rivals to Him? That is the Lord of all realms.”

41:10.t: And He made therein firm mountains on top of it, and He blessed it and determined its sustenance infour days, equal,1for those who ask.

f.81057: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . in four days; (they are) equal for those who ask.”Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . in four equal days for those who ask.”

41:11.t: Then He settled<sup foot_note="81058">1</sup>to the heaven while it was smoke, and said to it and to the earth, “Come, willingly or reluctantly.” They said, “We have come willingly.”

f.81058: How He settled is beyond human understanding.

41:12.t: So He decreed them as seven heavens in two days, and He revealed within each heaven its command. And We adorned the lowest<sup foot_note="81059">1</sup>heaven with lamps, and for preservation; that is the determining of the Almighty, the All-Knowing.

f.81059: The Arabic word dunyatranslated here as ‘lowest’ is the same word used to describe the life of this world as the ‘Earlier’ Life, as it carries both meanings: lowest and earlier.

41:13.t: But if they disregard(you), then saysg, “I have warned you of a thunderbolt like the thunderbolt of ʻĀd1and Thamûd2.”

f.81060: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.
f.81061: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

41:14.t: Recall when their messengers came to them from before them and from behind them, saying, “Do not worship anyone but Allah.” They said, “Had our Lord willed, He would have sent down angels; therefore, of what you are sent with, we are deniers.”

41:15.t: So, as for ʻĀd, they turned unjustifiably arrogant in the land andsaid, “Who is more powerful than us?” Had they not seen that Allah, who created them, is more powerful than them? And they used to repudiate Our signs,

41:16.t: so We sent upon them a screaming wind for a few days of unrelenting misfortune, to make them taste the punishment of disgrace in the Earlier Life. But the punishment of the Hereafter is surely more disgraceful, and they will not be supported.

41:17.t: But as for Thamûd, We had guided them, but they preferred blindness over guidance. So the thunderbolt of the degrading punishment seized them on account of what they used to earn.

41:18.t: Meanwhile, We delivered those who had attained faith and had been mindful(of God).

41:19.t: And the day whenAllah’s enemies are herded1into the Fire in an organized manner—

f.81062: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Yaʻqub read it as: “And the day when We herd Allah’s enemies into the Fire . . .”

41:20.t: until, when they reach it, their hearing and their sight(s)and their skins testify against them regarding what they used to do.

41:21.t: And they say to their skins, “Why did you testify against us?” They say, “Allah, Who made everything speak, made us speak.” It is He Who created youplthe first time, and to Himyou are returned1.

f.81063: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and to him you return .”

41:22.t: And youplwere unable to hide yourselves in a way that neither your hearing nor your sight(s)nor your skins were prevented from testifying against you, and you thought that Allah does not know much of what you do.

41:23.t: And it is that thought of yours about yourplLord that led you to ruin—so you became of the losers.

41:24.t: So even if they endure patiently, the Fire is(still)a dwelling for them; and if they ask to make amends, they will not be allowed to amend.

41:25.t: And We assigned for them comrades who then adorned for them what was before them and what was behind them, and the Word came to pass against them among communities of unseen beings<sup foot_note="81064">1</sup>and humans that passed away before them; indeed, they were losers.

f.81064: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

41:26.t: Those who denied said, “Do not listen to this recitation1and speak noisily during it so that youplmay overcome.”

f.81065: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

41:27.t: We will certainly make those who have denied taste a severe punishment, and We will certainly repay them for the worst of what they used to do.

41:28.t: Such is the repayment of Allah’s enemies—the Fire; therein for them is the Home of Eternity, a repayment on account of how theyused to repudiate Our signs.

41:29.t: And those who denied said, “Our Lord, show us those two(groups)which misguided us—among unseen beingsaand humankind—so that we can trample them both under our feet so they become of the lowest.”

41:30.t: Indeed, those who said: “Our Lord is Allah,” and then led a righteous life—the angels descend upon them: “Do not fear and do not grieve, but have glad tidings of the Garden(of Paradise)which you were promised.

41:31.t: We are your allies in the Earlier Life and in the Hereafter, and you have therein whatever your(inner)selves desire, and for you therein is whatever you claim,

41:32.t: as hospitality from One Who is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.”

41:33.t: And who is better in speech than one who called to Allah and did righteousness and said, “I am of the Muslims<sup foot_note="81066">1</sup>”?

f.81066: The Arabic word used is Muslimeenwhich means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

41:34.t: For good and evil are never equal. Repel(evil)with that which is better, and thereupon the one between whom and yousgis enmity becomes like an intimate ally.

41:35.t: But none receives it except those who were patient, and none receives it except the very fortunate.

41:36.t: And if yousgare ever spurred by a spurring from Satan, take refuge with Allah; indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.

41:37.t: And of His signs are the night and the day and the sun and the moon. Do not prostrate yourselves to the sun nor to the moon, but prostrate yourselves to Allah Who created them, if it is Him that you worship.

41:38.t: But if they act arrogantly, then those in the presence of yoursgLord highly exalt Him with praise night and day, and never do they tire.

41:39.t: And of His signs is that yousgsee the land still1, but when We send down water upon it, it shakes andswells2. Indeed, He Who revived it will certainly revive the dead; indeed, He is All-Powerful over everything.

f.81068: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . it shakes and becomes higher .”

41:40.t: Indeed, those who blaspheme Our signs are not hidden from Us. Is one who is cast into the Fire better, or one who comes safely on the Day of Resurrection? Do as you wish; He is All-Seeing of what you do.

41:41.t: Indeed, those who denied the Reminder when it came to them . . .<sup foot_note="81069">1</sup>—whereas it is indeed a mighty Scripture

f.81069: This sentence is left open-ended; according Ar-Rāzi and other exegetes its predicate is “—those are being called out from a distant place” mentioned in sign 44.

41:42.t: which falsehood cannot approach from before it or behind it—a bestowal from on high by One Who is Wise, Praiseworthy.

41:43.t: Nothing is said to yousgbut was said to the messengers before you. Indeed, yoursgLord is certainly Possessor of forgiveness and Possessor of painful retribution.

41:44.t: Had We made it a Recital1in a foreign language, they would have said, “If only its signs2were detailed.” A foreign language while(the messenger is)an Arab? Saysg, “For those who have attained faith, it is guidance and healing. But as for those who do not believe—there is deafness in their ears, and it is blindness upon them. Those are being called out from a distant place.”

f.81070: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.
f.81071: The Arabic word used isayat(singularayah). Ayahmeans ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an,like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose.Each such unit isconsidered a ‘sign’from God.

41:45.t: And surely, We brought Moses the Scripture, but it was differed upon. And were it not for a word that had preceded from yoursgLord, judgment would have been decreed between them. But indeed, they are surely in perplexing doubt concerning it.

41:46.t: Whoever acts righteously does so to his own benefit, while whoever commits evil does so to his own detriment. And yoursgLord is never a tyrant unto the servants.

41:47.t: To Him is referred(all)knowledge of the Hour. Andno products1come out of their sheathsnor does any female carry or deliverbut with His knowledge. And on the day when He calls out to them, “Where are My associates?” They said2, “We declare to You, none of us is a witness.”

f.81072: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “And no product comes out of its sheaths nor does anyfemale conceive or deliver but with His knowledge.”
f.81073: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

41:48.t: And whatever they used to call upon earlier strayed away from them, and they realized that there was no escape for them.

41:49.t: Man never tires of supplication for good things, but if evil touches him, he becomes despairing, despondent.

41:50.t: And if We do let him taste a mercy from Us after an adversity that has touched him, he will surely say, “This is mine, and I do not think that the Hour is coming. And even if I am returned to my Lord, I will have the very best with Him.” We will inform those who denied of what they did, and We will make them taste a harsh punishment.

41:51.t: And when We bestow Our blessings upon Man, he disregards(Us)and distances himself. But when evil touches him, he has lengthy supplication.

41:52.t: Saysg, “Have youplseen? If it is from Allah and then you deny it—who is more misguided than he who is in profound discord?”

41:53.t: We will show them Our signs in the horizons and in themselves until it becomes evident to them that He1is the Truth. Is it not sufficient that yoursgLord is witness over everything?

f.81074: The Arabic pronoun can mean ‘He’ for God or ‘it’ for the Qur’an or Islam.

41:54.t: Undoubtedly, they do regard the meeting with their Lord with skepticism. Undoubtedly, He is indeed All-Encompassing of everything.

42:3.t: Thusreveals1—to yousgand to those before you—Allah the Almighty, the All-Wise.

f.81075: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “Thus it is revealed to you sg and to those before you: Allah the Almighty, the All-Wise— 4to Him belongs . . .”

42:4.t: ToHim belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth, and He is the All-High, the Great.

42:5.t: The heavens almostsplinter1from above them, while the angels exalt their Lord with praise and ask forgiveness for those on earth. Undoubtedly, Allah is indeed the Oft-Forgiving, the Bestower of mercy.

f.81076: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba and Yaʻqub read it as: “The heavens almost split apart from above them . . .”

42:6.t: And those who take guardians apart from Him—Allah is a Constant Preserver over them, for yousgare not a trustee over them.

42:7.t: And thus We revealed to yousgan Arabic Recital1, that you may warn the Mother of Towns2and those around it and warn of the Day of Assembly, of which there is no doubt: a group in the Garden(of Paradise)and a group in the Blaze.

f.81077: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

42:8.t: And had Allah willed, He could have made them one community, but He enters into His mercy whomever He wills, while the unjust have neither ally nor supporter.

42:9.t: Or have they taken others as guardians apart from Him? Yet Allah is the Ultimate Guardian, and He gives life to the dead, and He is All-Powerful over everything.

42:10.t: And whatever matter youpldiffer over— its judgment rests with Allah. “Such is Allah, my Lord; in Him I have placed my trust and to Him I turn penitently.”

42:11.t: The Originator of the heavens and the earth; He has made for you spouses from among yourselves, and of the animals mates<sup foot_note="81079">1</sup>, by means of which He multiplies you. The like of Him has nothing like him, and He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing.

f.81079: The Arabic word used is the same as that translated as ‘spouses’ for humans.

42:12.t: To Him belong the treasures of the heavens and the earth. He extends provision for whomever He wills and He restrains(it); indeed He is All-Knowing of everything.

42:13.t: He legislated for youplthe same religion He enjoined upon Noah, and what We revealed to yousg, and what We enjoined uponAbraham1and Moses and Jesus: “You shall establish the religion and not be disunited therein.” To the polytheists, outrageous is what you call them to. Allah chooses to Himself whomever He wills, and He guides to Himself whoever is penitent.

f.81080: Qira’at: Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham read it as: “Abraham ”.

42:14.t: And they did not become disunited except after knowledge had come to them, thereby oppressing one another. And were it not for a word that had preceded from yoursgLord(to defer judgment)to a stated term, judgment would have been decreed between them. And indeed, those who were made to inherit the Scripture after them are in grave doubt about it.

42:15.t: So, because of that, gosgon calling, and be upright as you have been commanded, and do not follow their whims, and say, “I have attained faith in what Allah has sent down in every Scripture, and I have been commanded to judge between you equitably. Allah is our Lord and your Lord; we have our deeds and youplhave your deeds; there is no debate between us and you; Allah will bring us together, for to Him is the destiny.”

42:16.t: And those who continue to debate about Allah after He has been responded to—their argument is invalid with their Lord, and upon them falls wrath, and for them is a severe punishment.

42:17.t: It is Allah who sent down the Scripture with the truth, and the Balance1. But what could make yousgrealize that perhaps the Hour is near?

f.81081: Balance by which to weigh conduct.

42:18.t: Those who do not believe in it seek to hasten it, but those who have attained faith are apprehensive of it and know it to be the truth. Undoubtedly, those who cast doubts about the Hour are most surely far astray.

42:19.t: Allah is Subtle towards His servants; He provides for whomever He wills, and He is the All-Powerful, the Almighty.

42:20.t: Whoever wants the harvest of the Hereafter—We increase for him his harvest, and whoever wants the harvest of the Earlier(Life)—We give him thereof, yet he has no share of the Hereafter.

42:21.t: Or is it that they have associates who have legislated for them as religion that which Allah has not given permission? And were it not for the conclusive decision, it would have been settled between them. For indeed, there is a painful punishment for the unjust.

42:22.t: Yousgsee the unjust apprehensive of what they have earned, and it is sure to befall them. But those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds are in the meadows of the Gardens(of Paradise). For them is whatever they will in the presence of their Lord; that is what the supreme grace is.

42:23.t: Those are the glad tidings Allah gives to His servants who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds. Saysg, “I ask of you no reward for it except the genuine love offered among those of kinship.” And whoever scores a good deed, We will increase its goodness for him; indeed, Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Ever Thankful.

42:24.t: Or do they say, “He has fabricated lies about Allah.” Yet if Allah so willed, He could seal yoursgheart. But Allah erases falsehood and upholds the truth by His Words; indeed, He is All-Knowing of what lies within the chests.

42:25.t: And it is He who accepts the repentance of His servants, and pardons evil deeds, and knows whatyoupldo1;

f.81082: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and knows what they do . . .”

42:26.t: and He responds(to)those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds, and He increases them of His grace. But for the deniers is a severe punishment.

42:27.t: And if Allah were to extend provision for His servants, they would oppress(others)on earth. Rather, Hebestows1from on highin precise measure whatever He wills; indeed, regarding His servants, He is All-Aware, All-Seeing.

f.81083: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . but He sends down in precise measure whatever He wills . . .”

42:28.t: And it is He whobestows1rainfrom on high,after they have despaired, and unfolds His mercy, and it is He Who is the Ultimate Guardian, the Praiseworthy.

f.81084: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, ʻAsem and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . He who sends down rain after they . . .”

42:29.t: And of His signs are the creation of the heavens and the earth and the treading creatures He has spread throughout them, for He is All-Able to gather them at will.

42:30.t: And whatever disaster befalls youpl—it is because of what your hands have earned, yet He pardons much.

42:31.t: And youplcannot thwart(God)on earth, and apart from Allah you have neither ally nor supporter.

42:32.t: And of His signs are the ships sailing the sea like flags.

42:33.t: If He wills, He can still thewind1, leaving them motionless on its surface; indeed, in that are signs for everyone who is most patient, constantly thankful.

f.81085: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “winds ”.

42:34.t: Or He can wreck them on account of what they have earned, yet He pardons much—

42:35.t: so that those who dispute Our signs may know1that there is no escape for them.

f.81086: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer, and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . yet He pardons much. 35Thus those who dispute Our signs know that there is no escape for them.

42:36.t: So whatever you are given of anything is only an enjoyment of the Earlier Life, but what Allah has is better and more lasting for those who have attained faith and in their Lord they have placed their trust;

42:37.t: and those who avoidthe gravest1of sinsand obscenities, and if they feel wrathful, they(then)forgive;

f.81087: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and those who avoid the grave kind of sin and . . .”

42:38.t: and those who responded to their Lord and established the prayer, and whose affairs are conducted by mutual consultation, and of what We<sup foot_note="81088">1</sup>have provided them they spend;

42:39.t: and those who, when oppression befalls them, defend themselves.

42:40.t: And the repayment of an evil deed is an evil deed equivalent to it. But whoever has pardoned and made reconciliation—his reward lies with Allah; indeed, He does not love the unjust.

42:41.t: And for one who has defended himself after being dealt with unjustly—on those<sup foot_note="81089">1</sup>there is no blame.

f.81089: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

42:42.t: Rather, blame lies on those who do injustice to mankind and commit unjustified aggression in the land; for those is a painful punishment.

42:43.t: But whoever has endured patiently and has forgiven—that is certainly a sign of real resolve.

42:44.t: And whoever Allah misguides has no guardian apart from Him. And yousgsee the unjust when they have seen the punishment, saying, “Is there a way of going back?”

42:45.t: And yousgsee them exposed to it1, reverent with humility, looking with a stealthy glance. And those who had attained faith said2, “Indeed, the losers are those who lost themselves and their families on the Day of Resurrection.” Undoubtedly, the unjust are indeed in a lasting punishment.

f.81091: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

42:46.t: And they had no allies to support them against Allah. And whomever Allah misguides has no way out.

42:47.t: Respond to yourplLord before there comes from Allah a day that cannot be turned back. You will have neither refuge on that day, nor possibility of denial.

42:48.t: But if they disregard(you)—We have not sent yousgas a constant preserver over them; your only duty is proclamation. And indeed, whenever We let man taste a mercy from Us, he rejoices in it. But when something evil befalls them as a consequence of what their hands have put forth, then man is indeed a staunch denier.

42:49.t: To Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth; He creates whatever He wills. He grants females to whomever He wills, and He grants males to whomever He wills.

42:50.t: Or He pairs them, males and females, and He makes whomever He wills barren; indeed, He is All-Knowing, All-Powerful.

42:51.t: And it is not for any human that Allah should speak to him except by revelation or from behind aveil or by sending1a messenger to reveal by His permission whatever He wills; indeed, He is All-High, All-Wise.

f.81092: Qira’at: Nafieʻ read it as: “. . . a veil, or He sends a messenger then reveals to him by His permission.”

42:52.t: And thus have We revealed a spirit to yousgby Our command. Yousgdid not know what the Scripture was nor what faith was, but We made it a light with which We guide whomever We will of Our servants. And most surely, you guide to a straight path—

42:53.t: the path of Allah to whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth. Undoubtedly, to Allah are destined all commands.

43:3.t: indeed, We made it an Arabic Recital1, that youplmay reason.

f.81093: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

43:4.t: And indeed, it is with Us in the Source of Scriptures, all-high, all-wise.

43:5.t: So shall We ignore reminding youpl,for having been1an extremist people?

f.81094: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “. . . youpl , if you have been an extremist people?”

43:6.t: And how many a prophet did We send to the ancients!

43:7.t: Yet not a prophet came to them but that they used to ridicule him.

43:8.t: Thus We annihilated people more powerful than them, and so the example of the ancients has passed away.

43:9.t: And were yousgto ask them, “Who created the heavens and the earth?” They would say, “The Almighty, the All-Knowing created them.”

43:10.t: He Who made the earth acradle1 for youpland traced in it ways for you, that you may be guided.

f.81095: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Al Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . a resting place for you . . .”

43:11.t: And He Who sent down water from the sky in due proportion, whereby We revived a lifeless land; thusyouplare brought out1.

f.81096: Qira’at: Ibn Zekwan, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . thus you come out .”

43:12.t: And He Who created all pairs and provided youplwith ships and livestock on which you ride,

43:13.t: that youplmay mount their backs then remember the blessing of your Lord as you settle upon them and say, “Highly Exalted is the One Who has subjected this to us, and in no way could we have done it by ourselves,

43:14.t: and indeed to our Lord we are certainly returning.”

43:15.t: Yet they ascribed to Him a portion of His servants. Surely, man is indeed an evidently staunch denier.

43:16.t: Or has He chosen for Himself daughters from what He creates, and favored youplwith sons?

43:17.t: Yet when one of them is given glad tidings<sup foot_note="81097">1</sup>of what he ascribed to the All-Merciful, his face becomes dark as he suppresses his anguish,

43:18.t: (thinking)“What! Someonebrought up1amid adornments and, in conflict, cannot be evident?”2

f.81098: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Someone growing up amid . . .”
f.81099: Pagans looked at women in a demeaning way.

43:19.t: And they considered the angels, who areservants1ofthe All-Merciful, to be females.Did they witness2their creation? Their claim will be recorded and they will be asked.

f.81100: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . who are with the All-Merciful . . .”
f.81101: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Were they made to witness their creation?”

43:20.t: And they said, “Had the All-Merciful willed, we would not have worshiped them.” But they have no knowledge of that; they are merely conjecturing.

43:21.t: Or have We brought them a scripture prior to this one<sup foot_note="81102">1</sup>, so that they are adhering to it?

43:22.t: Rather, they said, “Indeed, we found our forefathers on a course<sup foot_note="81103">1</sup>, and indeed we are being guided in their footsteps.”

43:23.t: Likewise, We sentno warner before yousgto any town but its affluent ones said, “Indeed, we found our forefathers on a courseb, and indeed we are following in their footsteps.”

43:24.t: He would say1, “Even ifI2have come to youplwith better guidance than what you found your forefathers following?” They would say, “Indeed, we deny what youplare sent with.”

f.81104: Qira’at: All except Hafs and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “Say sg , “Even if I . . .”
f.81105: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Even if we have come to you . . .”

43:25.t: Thus We took retribution on them, so looksgat what the outcome was for the disbelievers.

43:26.t: And recall when Abraham said to his father and his people, “I am innocent of what you worship

43:27.t: except for the One Who originated me, for He will guide me.”

43:28.t: And he made it an enduring word in his posterity, so that they may return.

43:29.t: Yet I let these and their forefathers enjoy(life)until the truth and an evident messenger came to them.

43:30.t: But when the truth came to them, they said, “This is sorcery, and indeed we are deniers of it.”

43:31.t: They also said, “If only this Recital<sup foot_note="81106">1</sup>had been sent down to any great man from the two towns<sup foot_note="81107">2</sup>.”

f.81106: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

43:32.t: Is it they who allocate the mercy of yoursgLord? It is We who have allocated their livelihood in the Earlier Life. And We elevated some of them by degrees above others, that some of them may employ one another in service. But your Lord’s mercy is better than what they hoard.

43:33.t: Were it not that humanity would become a single(ungodly)community, We would have provided those who deny the All-Merciful withroofs1of silver to their houses, and stairways(of silver)by which they ascend,

f.81108: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . with a roof of silver . . .”

43:34.t: and doors(of silver)to their houses, and furnishings on which they recline,

43:35.t: and(golden)decorations.Yet all that is nothing1butthe enjoyment of the Earlier Life, whereas the Hereafter with yoursgLord is for the ones who are mindful(of God).

f.81109: Qira’at: All except for ʻAsem, Hamza and Hisham in one of his narrations read it as: “. . . decorations. Indeed all that is merely the enjoyment . . .”

43:36.t: And whoever shuns the remembrance of the All-Merciful,We assign1for him a Satan who then becomes his comrade.

f.81110: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . He assigns for him . . .”

43:37.t: And indeed, they certainly bar them from the way, though they think they are guided.

43:38.t: Until, when he comes to Us, he says, “If only there were between me and yousgthe distance of the two easts.” What a miserable comrade!

43:39.t: Yet never will it benefit youplon that day, since you have committed injustices, that you are partners in the punishment.

43:40.t: Can yousgmake the deaf hear, or guide the blind and one who has been in evident misguidance?

43:41.t: So We will either take yousgaway, then surely wreak vengeance upon them,

43:47.t: Yet, as soon as he came to them with Our signs, they promptly started laughing at them,

43:48.t: even though each sign We showed them was more supreme than its counterpart, and We took hold of them with the punishment, that possibly they would return.

43:49.t: And they said(to Moses), “O sorcerer, pray to your Lord for us according to His covenant with you, and then we will surely be guided.”

43:50.t: But when We lifted the punishment from them, they promptly broke their promise.

43:51.t: And Pharaoh called out among his people; he said, “O my people, do I not have the dominion over Egypt, and are these rivers not flowing beneath me? Do you not see?

43:52.t: Or am I not better than this one who is despicable and can barely express himself?

43:53.t: So, if only some bracelets of gold had been cast on him, or if angels had come with him in comradeship!”

43:54.t: Thus he fooled his people, and they obeyed him; indeed they were a defiantly disobedient people.

43:55.t: So when they displeased Us, We took vengeance on them and We drowned them all.

43:56.t: So We made themaprecedent1and an example for later people.

43:65.t: But the parties differed among themselves, so woe to those who committed injustices from the punishment of a painful day.

43:66.t: Are they only waiting for the Hour to come upon them suddenly, while they are unaware?

43:67.t: On that day, close friends will be enemies to one another, except for the ones who were mindful(of God).

43:68.t: O My servants, no fear shall be upon you today, nor shall you grieve.

43:70.t: enter the Garden(of Paradise), you and your spouses, filled up with joy.

43:83.t: So leavesgthem to blunder and play until theymeet1their day which they are promised.

f.81120: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . until they encounter their . . .”

43:85.t: And supremely blessed be the One to Whom belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them, and Who alone has knowledge of the Hour, and to Whomyouplare returned1.

f.81124: This night is known as the night ofQadr (Surah number 97), in the month of Ramadan.

44:10.t: So waitsgand watch out for the day when the sky produces evident smoke

44:14.t: then they turned away from him and said, “(He is)taught(by others), a madman!”

44:19.t: And do not consider yourselves to be above Allah; indeed, I come to you with an evident manifestation.

44:22.t: Then he called upon his Lord—that these people are criminals.

44:23.t: (Then His Lord commanded,)“Journey with My servants by night; indeed, youplwill be followed.

44:24.t: And leavesgthe sea parted(behind you); indeed, they are an army to be drowned.”

44:25.t: How many gardens and springs did they leave behind,

44:26.t: as well as vegetation(s)and a noble domicile

44:27.t: and a blessing they used to enjoy?

44:28.t: So it was. And We made another people inherit it.

44:29.t: So neither heaven nor earth wept over them, nor were they reprieved.

44:30.t: And surely, We delivered the Children of Israel from the demeaning punishment—

44:31.t: from Pharaoh; indeed, he was of the extremists.

44:32.t: And We chose them knowingly over all communities,

44:33.t: and gave them of the signs that which was an evident test.

44:35.t: “There is nothing but our first death, for we will not be resurrected.

44:36.t: So bringplback our forefathers, if you are truthful!”

44:40.t: Indeed, the Day of Decision is the appointed time for them all—

44:41.t: a day when no patron will avail a protégé in any way, and they cannot be supported,

44:42.t: except for one upon whom Allah has had<sup foot_note="81128">1</sup>mercy; indeed, He is the Almighty, the Bestower of mercy.

44:48.t: then pour over his head some of the punishment of scalding water!”
