f.81141: Qira’at: All except for Ibn Kathir, Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . for them is a punishment of a painful torment .”

45:12.t: Allah is the One Who has subjected to youplthe sea, that ships may run in it by His Command, and that you may seek of His grace, and that you may give thanks.

f.81145: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Will you not constantly remind yourselves?”

46:2.t: The bestowal of the Scripture from on high is by Allah, the Almighty, the All-Wise.

46:3.t: We did not create the heavens and the earth and what lies between them except in accordance with truth and for a stated term. But the deniers continue to disregard the warnings which they have received.

46:6.t: And when mankind is herded, those(false gods)become enemies to them and deny their worship of them.

46:10.t: Saysg, “Have youplseen: if it is truly from Allah and you deny it? And a witness from the Children of Israel has testified to its like and has attained faith, while you have acted arrogantly. Indeed, Allah does not guide the unjust people.”

Until, when he has attained his full strength and has reached forty years, he says, “Lord, enable me to appreciate the blessings with which You have blessed me and my parents, and to do righteousness that well pleases You, and grant me righteousness in my offspring. 46:27.t: And most surely We have annihilated many towns around youpland diversified the signs, that they may return(to the truth).

46:28.t: Why then did those whom they worshiped as means of nearness to Allah not support them? Rather, they abandoned<sup foot_note="81163">1</sup>them. It was their lie, a fabrication of their own making.

46:29.t: And recall when We dispatched towards yousgseveral unseen beings1to listen to the Recital2. When they came in its presence, they said, “Listenplquietly!” Then, when it was concluded, they turned to their people, forewarning them.

f.81164: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.
f.81165: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

46:30.t: They said, “O our people, we have heard a Scripture, sent down after Moses, confirming what came before it. It guides to the truth and to a straight path.

46:31.t: O our people, respond to the caller to Allah and believe in Him, and He will forgive you your misdeeds and grant you protection from a painful punishment.”

46:32.t: And he who does not respond to the caller to Allah cannot incapacitate(God)on earth and has no protectors apart from Him; those are in evident misguidance.

46:33.t: Have they not seen that Allah, Who created the heavens and the earth and was never tired by creating them, iscapable1ofreviving the dead? Yes indeed; He is indeed powerful over all things.

f.81166: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . by creating them, can revive the dead?”

46:34.t: And on the day when those who denied are presented to the Fire: “Is this not real?” They said, “Yes, indeed, by our Lord.” He said, “Then taste the punishment on account of how youplused to deny.”

46:35.t: So besgpatient, as the messengers with resolve were patient, and do not be hasty regarding them. On the day when they witness what they are promised, it will seem as if they had lasted for only an hour of a day. A proclamation: will any be annihilated except the defiantly disobedient people?

47:1.t: Those who denied and barred(others)from the way of Allah—He made their deeds go to waste.

47:2.t: And those who attained faith and did righteous deeds, and attained faith in what was sent down to Muhammad—and it is the truth from their Lord—He remitted their evil deeds and set aright their state of mind.

47:3.t: That is because those who denied followed falsehood, while those who attained faith followed the truth from their Lord. Allah thus sets forth for mankind their examples.

47:4.t: Thus, when youplencounter those who have denied, strike at their necks. Then when you have subjugated them, bind them firmly1. Then either release them by grace or by ransom until war lays down its burdens. Had Allah willed, He could have defeated them Himself, but He thus tests some of you by means of others. As for those whowere killed2in the way of Allah, He will not let their deeds go to waste.

f.81168: Qira’at: All except for Abu ʻAmr, Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “As for those who combated in the way of Allah . . .”

47:5.t: He will guide them and set aright their state of mind

47:6.t: and will enter them into the Garden(of Paradise)—He has identified it for them.

47:7.t: O you who have attained faith, if you support Allah, He will support you and strengthen your foothold.

47:8.t: But as for those who denied, for them is perdition, and He made their deeds go to waste.

47:9.t: That is because they hated what Allah had sent down, so He nullified their deeds.

47:10.t: Have they not journeyed through the earth and looked at what the outcome was for those before them? Allah poured destruction upon them. For for the deniers there is something comparable.

47:11.t: That is because Allah is the Patron of those who have attained faith, while the deniers have no Patron.

47:12.t: Indeed, Allah enters those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds into Gardens beneath which rivers flow. And those who have denied enjoy themselves and eat as cattle eat, but the Fire is a dwelling for them.

47:13.t: And how many a town was more powerful than your town1which evicted yousg? We annihilated them, and there was no helper for them.

f.81169: Addressing Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) about the town which evicted him (Makkah).

47:14.t: Is someone who relies on evident proof from his Lord like someone the evil of whose work was adorned for him? And they<sup foot_note="81170">1</sup>followed their own whims.

f.81170: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

47:15.t: The likeness of the Garden(of Paradise)that the mindfulpl(of God)have been promised: rivers of water,notstaling1; and rivers of milk whose taste has not changed; and rivers of wine, a delight for those who drink; and rivers of honey, clarified and pure. And they have therein of all products and forgiveness from their Lord.(How can this be)compared to the fate of those abiding in the Fire and were given, for drink, scalding water, so that it tore their bowels?

f.81171: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . rivers of water, never staling . . .”

47:16.t: And among them is one who listens to yousg, but when they1depart from your presence, they say to those given knowledge, “What did he say just now?” Those are the ones whose hearts Allah has sealed, and they followed their own whims.

f.81172: A grammatical shift from singular to plural. The difference between this shift and the one in sign number 14 should be pondered by the reader.

47:17.t: But as for those who wanted guidance, He has increased them in guidance and has brought them their mindfulness(of God).

47:18.t: So are they but waiting until the Hour comes to them suddenly? In fact, its tokens have already come. But how will they be reminded when it has come to them?

47:19.t: So knowsgthat there is no god but Allah, and ask forgiveness for your misdeed, and for believing men and believing women. For Allah knows your moving about and your dwelling.

47:20.t: And those who have attained faith say, “If only a surah1was sent down.” Yet when a decisive surah is sent down and combat is mentioned in it, yousgsee those in whose hearts is sickness looking at you with the look of someone fainting at death. Yet worthier of them would be

f.81173: Each portion of the Qur’an is called a ‘surah’, which is sometimes translated as ‘chapter’.

47:21.t: obedience and upright speech. Then, when the matter is settled, had they been true to Allah, it would have been better for them.

47:22.t: Would youplthen, in caseyou became in charge1, spread corruption in the earth andsever2your family ties3?

f.81174: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . in case you were made in charge , spread corruption . . .”
f.81175: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and cut your family ties?

47:23.t: Those are the ones whom Allah has cursed, so He made them deaf and blinded their sight(s)1.

f.81177: Mentioned in plural form in Arabic, denoted by (s) in English for grammatical reasons.

47:24.t: Will they not ponder the Recital<sup foot_note="81178">1</sup>, or are there locks upon their hearts?

f.81178: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means recital or recitation.

47:25.t: Indeed, those who turned on their heels after guidance became evident to them—Satan has enticedthemand has filled1themwith false hopes.

f.81179: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “Satan has enticed them. Thus they were filled with false hopes.”Yaʻqub read it as: “Satan has enticed them. Thus I filled them with false hopes.”

47:26.t: That is because they said to those who hated what Allah had bestowed from on high, “We will obey you in certain matters.” But Allah knows theirsecret exchanges1.

f.81180: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . their secrets .”

47:27.t: How will it be when the angels take them at death, beating their faces and their backs?

47:28.t: That is because they followed what angered Allah, and they disliked His good pleasure, so He nullified their deeds.

47:29.t: Or did those in whose hearts is sickness think that Allah would not bring out(to the open)their malice?

47:30.t: Had We willed, We could have shown them to yousg, and you would have recognized them by their marks. Yet you will recognize them by their tone of speech, and Allah knows all yourpldeeds.

47:31.t: AndWe1will certainly test youpluntilWe knowthose of you who strive and those who are steadfastlypatient, and(until We)test2your reactions.

f.81181: Qira’at: Shuʻba read it as: “And He will certainly test you pl until He knows those of you who strive and those who are steadfastly patient, and (until He) tests your reactions.”
f.81182: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . those who are steadfastly patient. And We will test your reactions.”

47:32.t: Indeed, those who denied and barred(others)from the way of Allah and opposed the Messenger after guidance had become clear to them—they will not harm Allah at all, but He will nullify their deeds.

47:33.t: O you who have attained faith, obey Allah and obey the Messenger, and do not let your deeds go to waste.

47:34.t: Indeed, those who denied and barred(others)from the way of Allah and then died as deniers—Allah will not forgive them.

47:35.t: So do not waver and call for peace while youplhave the upper hand; Allah is with you and He will not divest you of your deeds.

47:36.t: Indeed, the Earlier Life is nothing but a game and a distraction. But if youplattain faith and are mindful(of God), He will grant you your rewards, and He will not ask you for your possessions.

47:37.t: Were He to ask youplfor it and press you, you would become miserly, and He would bring out(to the open)your malice.

47:38.t: Here youplare, being called to spend in the way of Allah. Among you are those who become miserly, but whoever becomes miserly, becomes miserly only against himself. And Allah is the Self-Sufficient, while you are the needy. And if you turn away(from Him), He will replace you with another people, then they will not be like you.

48:1.t: Indeed, We haveunlocked for yousgan evident conquest,

48:2.t: that Allah may forgive you what has passed of your misdeeds and what is yet to come, and complete His blessing upon you and guide you to a straight path

48:3.t: and support you with mighty support.

48:4.t: It is He who sent down tranquility into the hearts of the believers, to add faith to their faith, for to Allah belong the troops of the heavens and the earth, and Allah has always been All-Knowing, All-Wise.

48:5.t: So asto enter believing men and believing women into Gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding therein, and to remit their evil deeds. And that, with Allah, has always been a great triumph.

48:6.t: And to punish hypocritical men and hypocritical women and idolatrous men and idolatrous women—those who harbor evil thoughts about Allah; they are encircled by evil, and Allah’s wrath is upon them and has cursed them and has prepared for them Hell, and what an evil destiny.

48:7.t: For to Allah belong the troops of the heavens and the earth, and Allah has always been Almighty, All-Wise.

48:8.t: Indeed, We have sent yousgas a witness and a bearer of glad tidings and a warner,

48:9.t: that youplmay believe1in Allah and His Messenger, and rally to Him and honor Him and highly exalt Him morning and evening.

f.81183: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . .that they may believe in Allah . . .”

48:10.t: Indeed, those who pledge allegiance to yousgare actually pledging allegiance to Allah: the hand of Allah is over their hands. So whoever reneges in fact reneges to his own detriment. And whoever fulfills what he has covenanted with Allah, thenHe1will grant hima great reward.

f.81184: Qira’at: Nafie’, Ibn Kathir, Abu Ja’far and Rouh read it as: “. . . then We will grant him a great reward.”

48:11.t: The nomadic Arabs who lagged behind will say to yousg, “Our belongings and our families have preoccupied us, so ask forgiveness for us.” They say with their tongues what is not in their hearts. Saysg, “Who can avail you anything against Allah if He desires harm for you or desires benefit for you?” In fact, Allah has always been All-Aware of what you do.

48:12.t: But youplthought that the Messenger and the believers would never return to their families, and that was adorned in your hearts. And you harbored evil thoughts, for you have always been a worthless people.

48:13.t: And whoever has not believed in Allah and His Messenger— We have prepared for the deniers a Blaze.

48:14.t: And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth; He forgives whomever He wills, and He punishes whomever He wills, for Allah has always been Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

48:15.t: Those who lagged behind will say when youpldepart to collect the gains1, “Let us follow you.” They want to change theSpeech2of Allah. Saysg, “You will not follow us; Allah has said so before.” Then they will say, “Rather, youplenvy us.” In fact, they have not comprehended except a little.

f.81186: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . the Words of Allah.”

48:16.t: Saysgto the nomadic Arabs who lagged behind, “You will be called against a people of intense force to combat them, unless they surrender. So if you obey, Allah will give you an excellent reward. But if you turn away as you turned away before, He will punish you with a painful punishment.”

48:17.t: There is no blame on the blind, nor any blame on the lame, nor any blame on the sick. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger—He1will enter himinto Gardens beneath which rivers flow. But whoever turns away—Hewill punish himwith a painful punishment.

f.81187: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . We will enter him ...We will punish him . . .”

48:18.t: Surely, Allah was well pleased with the believers as they pledged allegiance to yousgunder the tree, and He knew what was in their hearts, so He sent down tranquility upon them and rewarded them with an imminent conquest

48:19.t: and a multitude of gainsafor them to capture. For Allah has always been Almighty, All-Wise.

48:20.t: Allah has promised youpla multitude of gainsato capture, so He has expedited this for you and has restrained people’s hands from you, that it may be a sign to the believers, and to guide you to a straight path.

48:21.t: And other(war booty)of which youplwere incapable(of capturing), but Allah has encompassed it, and Allah has always been Powerful over everything.

48:22.t: And if those who have denied had combated you, they would have turned their backs, then they would find neither ally nor supporter.

48:23.t: Such has been Allah’s rule that has passed on before, for yousgwill never find any change in Allah’s rule.

48:24.t: And it is He who withheld their hands from youpland your hands from them in the valley of Makkah after giving you advantage over them, for Allah has always been All-Seeing of whatyou1do.

f.81188: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . what they do .”

48:25.t: It is they who have denied, and barred youplfrom the Inviolable Mosque, and prevented the offering from reaching its destination. And were it not for(the presence among them of)some faithful men and some faithful women whom you did not know of and whom you would have hurt, thus incurring dishonor unknowingly on their account . . .1—that Allah may enter into His mercy whomever He wills. If they had been apart, We would have punished those of them who denied with a painful punishment.

f.81189: This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Qurtubi and other exegetes the predicate is elided but can be understood as: “I would not have prevented you from retaliating.”

48:26.t: Those who denied filled their hearts with chauvinism—the chauvinism of paganignorance1. But Allah sent His tranquility down upon His Messenger and upon the believers and imposed on them the word of mindfulness(of God)of which they were most worthy and deserving, for Allah has always been All-Knowing of everything.

f.81190: The Arabic word used is jahiliyahwhich is derived from jahlor ‘ignorance’ and refers to the pre-Islamic phase of paganism.

48:27.t: Surely, Allah has fulfilled His Messenger’s vision in truth: “Youplwill surely enter the Inviolable Mosque by the will of Allah in security, heads shaven or hair cut short, not fearing anything. Yet He knew what you did not know and so set up for you, apart from that, a near conquest.”

48:28.t: It is He who sent His Messenger with the guidance and the religion of truth to make it prevail over all religions, for Allah suffices as Witness.

48:29.t: Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and those with him are stern against the deniers, merciful to one another; yousgsee them kneeling, prostrating, seeking grace from Allah and(His)good pleasure; their marks are on their faces from the effect of prostration. Such is their description in the Torah and their description in the Gospel: like vegetation that sprouted, then became strong, then grew thick, then rested on its stem, impressing the farmers. Through them He enrages the deniers. Allah has promised those of them who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds forgiveness and a great reward.

49:1.t: O you who have attained faith, do not proceed ahead of Allah and His Messenger, and be mindful of Allah; indeed, Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.

49:2.t: O you who have attained faith, do not raise your voices above the voice of the Prophet, and do not speak loudly to him as you speak loudly to one another, lest your deeds be nullified while you are unaware.

49:3.t: Indeed, those who lower their voices before Allah’s Messenger—those are the ones whose hearts Allah has tested for mindfulness(of Him); for them is forgiveness and a great reward.

49:4.t: Indeed, those who call yousgfrom behind the chambers—most of them do not reason.

49:5.t: Had they remained patient until yousgcame out to them, it would have been better for them. But Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

49:6.t: O you who have attained faith, if an ungodly person brings you any news,investigate1(the matter), lest you harm a people out of ignorance and thus become regretful for what you have done.

f.81191: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . brings you any news, ascertain (the truth) . . .”

49:7.t: And know that among you is the Messenger of Allah; if he were to obey you in many matters, you would suffer hardship. But Allah has endeared faith to you and adorned it in your hearts and made denial and ungodliness and rebellion hateful to you; those are the prudent ones.

49:8.t: A grace from Allah and a blessing, and Allah is All-Knowing, All-Wise.

49:9.t: And if two factions of believers fall to fighting each other, reconcileplbetween them. But if one group oppresses the other, then combat the one which oppresses until it complies with the command of Allah. But once it has complied, reconcile between them with justice and be equitable; indeed, Allah loves the equitable.

49:10.t: Indeed, all the believers are but brothers, so reconcile betweenyourpltwo brothers1and be mindful of Allah, that you may receive mercy.

f.81192: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . so reconcile between your pl brothers . . .”

49:11.t: O you who have attained faith, no people shall ridicule other people, for they may be better than them. Nor shall any women ridicule other women, for they may be better than them. Nor shall you defame yourselves<sup foot_note="81193">1</sup>, nor shall you insult one another by nicknames. What a miserable label ungodliness is after attaining faith! And whoever has not repented—then those<sup foot_note="81194">2</sup>are the unjust.

f.81193: The Qur’an used the term ‘yourselves’ rather than ‘each other’ to make the believers sympathize with one another byregarding any defamation of one as defamation of all.
f.81194: A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

49:12.t: O you who have attained faith, avoid making too many assumptions—indeed, some assumptions are sinful. And do not spy on one another nor backbite one another. Would any of you like to eat the flesh of his dead brother? You would detest it. So be mindful of Allah; indeed, Allah is Granting and Accepting of repentance, Bestowing of mercy.

49:13.t: O mankind, We have created you from a male and a female and made you into races and tribes, that you may know one another; indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah are the most mindful(of Him)among you; indeed, Allah is All-Knowing, All-Aware.

49:14.t: The nomadic Arabs said, “We have attained faith.” Saysg, “You have not attained faith; rather say, ‘We have become Muslims,’ for faith has not yet entered into your hearts. But if you obey Allah and His Messenger, He will not diminish any of your deeds; indeed, Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.”

49:15.t: The believers are those who have attained faith in Allah and His Messenger, and then have not doubted and have striven with their wealth and their lives in the way of Allah; those are the truthful.

49:16.t: Saysg, “Are youplgoing to teach Allah about your religion, when Allah knows whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth, for Allah is All-Knowing of everything?”

49:17.t: They keep reminding yousgof the favor they did you by becoming Muslims. Say, “Do not consider your submission(to Allah)a favor to me; it is Allah who does you a favor by guiding you to the faith, if you are truthful.”

49:18.t: Allah knows the hidden realm of the heavens and the earth, for Allah is All-Seeing of whatyou1do.

f.81195: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . what they do .”

50:1.t: Qāf. By the Glorious Recital<sup foot_note="81196">1</sup>. . .<sup foot_note="81197">2</sup>

f.81196: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.
f.81197: That which is sworn is omitted so that the reader may ponder.

50:2.t: But they marveled that a forewarner had come to them from among them, so the deniers said, “How strange!

50:3.t: Can it be that when we have died and become dust . . .<sup foot_note="81198">1</sup>? This is a far-fetched return.”

f.81198: This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Alousi and other exegetes the predicate is elided but can be understood as: “. . . that we shall be brought back again?”

50:4.t: We have already known what the earth consumes of them, and with Us is a constantly preserving record<sup foot_note="81199">1</sup>.

50:5.t: But they rejected the truth when it came to them, so they are in a state of confusion.

50:6.t: Have they not looked at the sky above them—how We constructed it and decoratedit and how it has no fractures?

50:7.t: And the earth—how We spread it out and set on it firm mountains and germinated therein all kinds of lovely plants,

50:8.t: an eye-opener and a reminder for every penitent servant?

50:9.t: And We brought down from the sky blessed water and germinated with it gardens and grain to harvest,

50:10.t: and the soaring palm trees with clustered dates—

50:11.t: provision for the servants. And We revived thereby a lifeless land; likewise is the emergence.

50:12.t: Before them the people of Noah disbelieved, and(so did)the fellows of Al-Russ and Thamûd

50:13.t: and ʻĀd and Pharaoh and the brethren of Lot

50:14.t: and the fellows of the Thicket and the people of Tubbaʻ; they all disbelieved the messengers, so My threat came true.

50:15.t: Were We fatigued by the first creation? Rather, they are in doubt of a new creation.

50:16.t: And surely We created man and know what his(inner)self whispers to him, for We are nearer to him than his jugular vein.

50:17.t: As the two receptors1receive(him), one on the right and one on the left, constantly seated.

f.81200: Two angels who receive everyone’s words and deeds during his/her life and record them.

50:18.t: Not a word does he utter, but close to him is a watcher, constantly ready.

50:19.t: Then came the daze of death with the truth: “That is what yousgwere trying to avoid.”

50:20.t: And the Trumpet was blown<sup foot_note="81201">1</sup>: “That is the Day of the Threat.”

f.81201: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense, this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

50:21.t: And every soul came forward, accompanied by a driver and a witness<sup foot_note="81202">1</sup>.

f.81202: Two angels: one drives the person to the place of assembly and the other is a witness to all his/her deeds.

50:22.t: “Indeed, yousgwere oblivious to this, so We removed your veil and your sight today is(as sharp as)iron.”

50:23.t: And His comrade<sup foot_note="81203">1</sup>said, “This is what I have ready with me.”

f.81203: According to Ibn ʻAshour, some exegetes said that this comrade is an angel, and others said it is his intimate friend in life, while others said it is his devil which used to whisper to him.

50:24.t: “Castdlinto Hell, every stubborn relentless denier,

50:26.t: who has set up another deity with Allah. So castdlhim into the severe punishment.”

50:27.t: His comrade said, “Our Lord, I did not make him exceed all limits, but he was in extreme misguidance.”

50:28.t: He said, “Do not dispute in My presence, for I have warned youplin advance.

50:29.t: The decree from Me cannot be changed, and I am not a tyrant unto the servants.”

50:30.t: On the day whenWe say1to Hell, “Are you full?” And it says, “Are there any more?”

f.81204: Qira’at: Nafieʻ and Shuʻba read it as: “. . . when He says to Hell . . .”

50:31.t: And the Garden(of Paradise)was brought closer to those mindful(of God), not far away.

50:32.t: This is whatyouplare promised1—for every constant preserver who often turns to God,

f.81205: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir read it as: “This is what they are promised . . .”

50:33.t: the one who inwardly feared the All-Merciful and came with a penitent heart.

50:34.t: “Enterplit in peace; that is the Day of Eternity.”

50:35.t: Therein they have whatever they desire, and We have even more.

50:36.t: And how many generations before them who were more powerful than they did We destroy! And they explored the lands—was there any escape?

50:37.t: Indeed, in that is a reminder for whoever possesses a heart or cares to listen and witness.

50:38.t: And surely We created the heavens and the earth and what is between them in six days<sup foot_note="81206">1</sup>, and never were We touched by any fatigue.

f.81206: Six equal intervals of time, which may be six heavenly days, each of them being 1000 earthly years long (see 22:47).

50:39.t: So enduresgwhat they say, and highly exalt your Lord with praise before the rising of the sun and before sunset.

50:40.t: And highly exaltsgHim with praise in the night andafter1prostrations.

f.81207: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Hamza, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and at the ends of prostrations.”

50:41.t: And listensgon the day when the caller calls from a nearby place.

50:42.t: The day when they hear the Shout in all truth; that is the Day of Emergence.

50:43.t: Indeed, We—We alone—give life and cause death, and to Us is the destiny.

50:44.t: The day the earthruptures1open from above them, letting them rush out; that is an easy exodus for Us.

f.81208: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . the earth vigorously ruptures open . . .”

50:45.t: We know better what they say, and yousgare not a compeller over them, so remind by the Recital1whoever fears My warning.

f.81209: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

f.81210: The first four signs are interpreted as the winds spreading the clouds, carrying them, moving them and distributing them.

51:2.t: and by those bearers of loads,

51:4.t: and by those distributing as commanded—

51:5.t: what youplare promised is true.

51:6.t: And, indeed, the Recompense is sure to come.

51:7.t: By the heaven comprising interwoven tracks,

51:8.t: indeed, youplare of different opinions1.

51:9.t: Averted from it is he who is averted.

51:11.t: Those who are unmindful and in perplexity,

51:12.t: asking, “When is the Day of Recompense?”

51:13.t: The day they are heated on the Fire:

51:14.t: “Taste your trial; this is what youpl,(challengingly)have been asking to be hastened.”

51:15.t: Indeed, the mindful(of God)are amidst Gardens(of Paradise)and springs,

51:16.t: taking what their Lord has given them. Indeed, before that, they used to excel in doing good:

51:17.t: they used to lie down but little of the night,

51:18.t: and at dawn they would seek forgiveness,

51:19.t: and in their wealth was a share for the asker and the deprived.

51:20.t: And on earth are signs for those who believe with certitude,

51:21.t: and within yourselves; do you not see?

51:22.t: And in the heaven is your provision and what you are promised.

51:23.t: So by the Lord of the heaven and the earth, indeed, it is as true as the fact that youpl(can)pronounce.

51:24.t: Has the story ofAbraham’s1honored guests reached yousg?

f.81213: Qira’at: Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham ”.

51:25.t: When they entered upon him they said, “Peace.” He said, “Peace, strangers.”

51:26.t: And he slipped away to his family and brought a fatted calf

51:27.t: and set it before them. He said, “Will you not eat?”

51:28.t: And he was filled with apprehension towards them. They said, “Do not be afraid,” and they announced to him the glad tidings of a knowledgeable boy.

51:29.t: So his wife came forward with a shriek, then clasped her face and said, “A barren old woman!”

51:30.t: They said, “Thus your Lord has said; He is the All-Wise, the All- Knowing.”

51:31.t: He said, “So what is your business, O emissaries?”

51:32.t: They said, “We have been sent to a criminal people,

51:33.t: to unleash upon them rocks of clay,

51:34.t: marked by yoursgLord for the extremists.”

51:35.t: Then We brought out all the believers who were in it.

51:36.t: Yet We found in it only one household of Muslims,

51:37.t: and We left in it a sign for those who fear the painful punishment.

51:38.t: And in Moses(there is also a sign)—when We sent him to Pharaoh with an evident manifestation.

51:39.t: But he turned away with his warlords and said, “A sorcerer or a madman.”

51:40.t: So We seized him and his troops and flung them into the waters, and he was to blame.

51:41.t: And(likewise)in(the people of)ʻĀd1—We sent against them the Barren Wind,

f.81214: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

51:42.t: sparing nothing it came upon without rendering it like decayed ruins.

51:43.t: And(likewise)in(the people of)Thamûd1—they were told, “Enjoy yourselves for a while.”

f.81215: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

51:44.t: But they defied the command of their Lord, so theLightningstruck1them as they looked on,

f.81216: Qira’at: Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . so the strike of lightning struck them as they . . .”

51:45.t: and they could not rise up, nor could they help themselves.

51:46.t: And(recall)before that, the people1of Noah—indeed, they were a defiantly disobedient people.

f.81217: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “And (likewise) before that, (in) the people of Noah . . .”

51:47.t: And the universe—We constructed it with power, and We are surely expanding it.

51:48.t: And the earth—We spread it out. So how excellent are We who prepared it!

51:49.t: And We created all things in pairs, that you mayremind1yourselves.

f.81218: Qira’at: All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . that youpl may constantly remember .”

51:50.t: “So flee to Allah; I am to youplfrom Him an evident warner.

51:51.t: And do not set up any other god with Allah; I am to you from Him an evident warner.”

51:52.t: Likewise, no messenger came to those before them but they said, “A sorcerer or a madman.”

51:53.t: Did they recommend it to one another? In fact, they are a people who exceed all limits.

51:54.t: So turn away from them, for yousgare not to blame.

51:55.t: And remind, for the reminder benefits the believers.

51:56.t: And I did not create the unseen beings<sup foot_note="81219">1</sup>and humans but to worship Me.

f.81219: The Arabic word used is jinnwhich are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

51:57.t: I need no provision from them, nor do I need them to feed Me.

51:58.t: Allah is the All-Providing, the Possessor of power, the All-Firm.

51:59.t: So, indeed, those who do injustice will have their lot like the lot of their fellows, so let them not hasten Me.

51:60.t: So woe to those who have denied from that day of theirs which they are promised.

52:4.t: By the frequented House(of God).

52:6.t: By the sea flared up with fire—

52:7.t: the punishment of yoursgLord is sure to come;

52:8.t: there is nothing to avert it

52:9.t: on the day when the sky sways in agitation

52:10.t: and the mountains go into motion.

52:11.t: So woe on that day to the disbelievers

52:12.t: who are indulged in vain talk, playing.

52:13.t: The day when they are shoved into the Fire of Hell forcefully.

52:14.t: “This is the Fire in which youplused to disbelieve.

52:15.t: Is this magic, or do youplnot see?

52:16.t: Roast in it, and be patient or be impatient—it is the same for youpl; indeed, you are only being repaid for what you used to do.”

52:17.t: Indeed, the mindful(of God)are in Gardens and bliss,

52:18.t: enjoying what their Lord has brought them, and their Lord has shielded them from the punishment of purgatory.

52:19.t: “Eat and drink pleasantly on account of what youplused to do.”

52:20.t: Relaxing on luxurious furnishings, and We coupled them with spouses with lovely wide eyes.

52:21.t: And those who attained faith andwhose offspring1followed themin faith—We have united2them withtheiroffspring3, and We have not deprived them of anything of their work; every person is in pledge for what(deeds)he has earned.

f.81220: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and whose offspring(s) followed them . . .”Abu ʻAmr read it as: “And those who attained faith and whom We followed (with) their offspring(s) in faith . . .”
f.81221: Frequently, the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.
f.81222: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . their offspring(s) . . .”

52:22.t: And We have supplied them with fruit and meat such as they desire.

52:23.t: They exchange therein a cup which does not lead to any idle talk or recrimination.

52:24.t: And serving them are youths like nestled pearls.

52:25.t: And they approached one another, inquiring.

52:26.t: They said, “When we were still with our families<sup foot_note="81223">1</sup>we used to live in fear<sup foot_note="81224">2</sup>,

52:27.t: so Allah has conferred favor upon us and has shielded us from the punishment of the Scorching Fire.

52:28.t: Indeed, before this we used to pray to Him;indeed ,1 He is the Fulfiller of promises, the Bestower of mercy.”

f.81225: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . to Him, for He is . . .”

52:29.t: So remind, for yousgare neither a soothsayer nor a madman.

52:30.t: Or do they say, “A poet<sup foot_note="81226">1</sup>for whom we await a calamity of time”?

f.81226: Some pagans claimed that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a poet who authored the Qur’an.

52:31.t: Saysg, “Go on awaiting, for I am with youplamong those awaiting.”

52:32.t: Or is it that their discerning minds command them to this? Or are they a people who exceed all limits?

52:33.t: Or do they say, “He made it up”? In fact, they do not believe.

52:34.t: So let them produce a discourse like it if they are truthful.

52:35.t: Or were they created out of nothing? Or are they the creators?

52:36.t: Or did they create the heavens and the earth? In fact, they are not certain.

52:37.t: Or do they possess the treasuries of your Lord? Or are they the controllers?

52:38.t: Or do they have a stairway(to heaven)by means of which they listen? Then let their listener bring an evident manifestation.

52:39.t: Or is He to have the daughters and youplthe sons?

52:40.t: Or do yousgask them for a reward so that they are weighed down by debt?

52:41.t: Or do they have(knowledge of)the hidden realm and they are writing it down?

52:42.t: Or do they want a plot? Rather, the plot will only befall the deniers.

52:43.t: Or do they have a god other than Allah? Highly Exalted is Allah above what they associate.

52:44.t: And if they were to see lumps of sky falling, they would say, “A mass of clouds.”

52:45.t: So leavesgthem untilthey meet1their day in which they are stunned—

f.81227: Qira’at: Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . until they encounter their . . .”

52:46.t: the day when their plots avail them nothing, nor are they supported.

52:47.t: And indeed, for those who did injustice there is a punishment apart from that, but most of them do not know.

52:48.t: So wait patiently for the decree of yoursgLord, for you are before Our Eyes. And highly exalt your Lord with praise when you arise,

52:49.t: and highly exalt Him during the night and at the receding of the stars.

53:1.t: By the star as it goes down,

53:2.t: yourplfellow has not gone astray, nor has he been deluded,

53:3.t: nor does he speak out of whim.

53:4.t: It is but a revelation being revealed,

53:5.t: taught to him by the extremely powerful,<sup foot_note="81228">1</sup>

53:6.t: the one of vigor. He settled

53:7.t: while he was at the highest horizon,

53:8.t: then he came near and descended

53:9.t: so that he was within two bows’ length or closer.

53:10.t: Then He revealed to His servant that which He revealed.

53:11.t: The burning heart did notlie1aboutwhat it saw.

f.81229: Qira’at: Hisham and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “The burning heart did not disbelieve what it saw.”

53:12.t: Will youplenter into controversies1with himdespitewhat he sees?

f.81230: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Khalaf and Yaʻqub read it as: “Will youpl discredit him despite what he sees?”

53:13.t: And he saw him on another descent,

53:14.t: at the Lote-tree of the Extremity<sup foot_note="81231">1</sup>,

f.81231: The Lote-tree of the Extremity is a spot above the seven firmaments; none has ever crossed it, and it is where Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) saw Angel Gabriel in the heavens at the night of his ascendance (Mi’raj).

53:15.t: near which is the Garden of Shelter,

53:16.t: when there covered the Lote-tree what covered it.

53:17.t: The sight(of the Prophet)did not swerve, nor did it exceed.

53:18.t: He certainly saw some of the great signs of his Lord.

53:19.t: Have youplseen Al-Lāt and Al-ʻUzza?

53:20.t: And Manāt<sup foot_note="81232">1</sup>, the third one, the other?

f.81232: Al-Lāt, Al-ʻUzzaand Manātwere names of three goddesses in Arabia.

53:21.t: Are youplto have the males and He the females1?

f.81233: Though pagan Arabs considered having daughters to be shameful, they attributed it to God, so the Qur’an is debating them according to their own logic.

53:23.t: These are nothing but names which youplhave named, you and your forefathers, for which Allah sent down no manifestation. They follow nothing but assumptions and what the(inner)selves desire, even though guidance has come to them from their Lord.

53:24.t: Or is there for man whatever he wishes?

53:25.t: To Allah belong the Hereafter and the first(life).

53:26.t: And how many an angel is there in the heavens whose intercession avails nothing except after Allah gives permission to whomever He wills and is well pleased with.

53:27.t: Indeed, those who do not believe in the Hereafter name the angels with female names,

53:28.t: though they have no knowledge of that. They only follow assumptions, yet surely assumptions do not substitute for the truth.

53:29.t: So disregardsgthe one who has turned away from Our Reminder and has wanted nothing but the Earlier Life.

53:30.t: That is the extent of their knowledge. Indeed, yoursgLord is the One Who knows better who has strayed from His way and He is the One Who knows better who has accepted guidance.

53:31.t: And to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth, that He may repay those who have done evil according to what they have done and repay those who have excelled in doing good with the best.

53:32.t: Those who avoidthe gravest1of sinsand obscenities—except for minor lapses—yoursgLord is of vast forgiveness. He knows better about youpl, ever since He initiated you from the earth, and ever since you were fetuses in your mothers’ bellies. So do not acclaim your own purity—He knows better who is mindful(of Him).

f.81234: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Those who avoid the grave kind of sin and . . .”

53:33.t: Have yousgseen the one who turned away

53:34.t: and gave a little, then held back?

53:35.t: Does he possess knowledge of the hidden realm and can therefore foresee?

53:36.t: Or was he not informed of what is in the Scrolls of Moses,

53:37.t: and ofAbraham1who fulfilled(conveying the commandments):

f.81235: Qira’at: Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham read it as: “Abraham ”.

53:38.t: that no bearer of burden bears the burden of another;

53:39.t: and that man attains only what he has striven for;

53:40.t: and that surely his pursuit will eventually be seen,

53:41.t: then he is repaid for it with the fullest repayment;

53:42.t: and that to yourplLord is the finality;

53:43.t: and that it is He Who caused laughter and weeping;

53:44.t: and that it is He Who caused death and gave life;

53:45.t: and that He created the two spouses<sup foot_note="81236">1</sup>—the male and the female,

f.81236: The Arabic word, zawjayn,can also mean ‘two kinds’ or ‘two types’.

53:46.t: from a sperm drop when emitted;

53:47.t: and that upon Him is the next creation;

53:48.t: and that it is He Who enriched and impoverished;

53:49.t: and that it is He Who is the Lord of Sirius<sup foot_note="81237">1</sup>;

f.81237: Sirius was a star worshiped by pagan Arabs.

53:50.t: and that He annihilated ancient ʻĀd<sup foot_note="81238">1</sup>

f.81238: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

53:51.t: and Thamûd<sup foot_note="81239">1</sup>, sparing no one;

f.81239: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

53:52.t: and the people of Noah before that; indeed, they were more unjust and more exceeding of all limits<sup foot_note="81240">1</sup>.

f.81240: Comparing their injustices and atrocities to those of the people of Quraysh, the tribe of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

53:53.t: And He brought down the Ruined Cities<sup foot_note="81241">1</sup>

f.81241: Where the people of Prophet Lot lived.

53:54.t: and covered them by that which He covered.

53:55.t: So which of yoursgLord’s marvels do you enter into controversies about?

53:56.t: This is a warning just like the first warnings.

53:58.t: none apart from Allah can unveil it.

53:59.t: Do youplmarvel at this discourse,

53:60.t: and laugh and do not weep,

53:62.t: So prostrate yourselves to Allah and worship!

54:1.t: The Hour has drawn near and the moon has ruptured.

54:2.t: Yet whenever they see a miracle, they disregard(it)and say, “Continuous magic!”

54:3.t: And they disbelieved and followed their whims. And everymatter is bound to settle[1666]

54:4.t: And most surely there have come to them tidings containing a deterrent—

54:5.t: profound wisdom, but warnings are of no avail.

54:6.t: So turn awaysgfrom them. On the day when the Summoner summons to something terrible,

54:7.t: with their sight(s)(subdued)in reverence they come out of the tombs like swarming locusts,

54:8.t: scrambling towards the Summoner; the deniers say, “This is a hard day.”

54:9.t: The people of Noah disbelieved before them, so they disbelieved Our servant and said, “A madman!”, and he was rebuked.

54:10.t: So he called upon his Lord, “I am overcome, so bestow help!”

54:11.t: So Weopened1the gates of the sky with water pouring down,

f.81242: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “So We widely opened the . . .”

54:12.t: and We made the earth burst with springs, so the waters met for a matter already determined.

54:13.t: And We carried him on a craft of planks and nails,

54:14.t: sailing before Our eyes—a repayment for the one who had been denied.

54:15.t: And most surely We have left it as a sign, so is there anyone to remind himself?

54:16.t: So how were My punishment and My warnings!

54:17.t: And most surely We have made the Recital<sup foot_note="81243">1</sup>easy for remembrance, so is there anyone to remind himself?

f.81243: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

54:18.t: ʻĀd<sup foot_note="81244">1</sup>disbelieved, so how were My punishment and My warnings!

f.81244: The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

54:19.t: Indeed, We sent against them a screaming wind on a day of unrelenting misfortune,

54:20.t: plucking people away as though they were trunks of uprooted palm trees.

54:21.t: So how were My punishment and My warnings!

54:22.t: And most surely We made the Recitalceasy for remembrance, so is there anyone to remind himself?

f.81245: The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

54:24.t: and said, “Are we to follow a human being from among us? Indeed, we would then be astray and insane!

54:25.t: Has the Reminder been cast to him out of all of us? Rather, he is a wicked sheer liar.”

54:26.t: They1will knowtomorrow who the wicked sheer liar is.

f.81246: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer and Hamza read it as: “You pl will know tomorrow . . .”

54:27.t: We are sending the she-camel as a means of trial for them, so watchsgthem and be patient.

54:28.t: And informsgthem that the water is to be shared between them1; each one should drink in turn.

f.81247: The water is to be shared between them and the she-camel.

54:29.t: But they called their fellow, and he dared and hamstrung(it).

54:30.t: So how were My punishment and My warnings!

54:31.t: Indeed, We sent against them a single Shout, and they ended up like a fence-maker’s dry sticks.

54:32.t: And most surely We made the Recital<sup foot_note="81248">1</sup>easy for remembrance, so is there anyone to remind himself?

f.81248: The Arabic word used is Qur’anwhich literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

54:33.t: The people of Lot disbelieved in the warnings.

54:34.t: Indeed, We sent against them a shower of stones, except for Lot’s folk–We delivered them at dawn—

54:35.t: a blessing from Us; thus We repay whoever gives thanks.

54:36.t: And most surely he<sup foot_note="81249">1</sup>had warned them of Our onslaught, but they entered into controversies about the warnings.

54:37.t: And most surely they solicited of him his guests, so We obliterated their eyes— “So taste My punishment and My warnings.”

54:38.t: And most surely an abiding punishment came upon them in the morning—

54:39.t: “So tasteplMy punishment and My warnings.”

54:40.t: And most surely We made the Recitalaeasy for remembrance, so is there anyone to remind himself?

54:41.t: And most surely the warnings came to Pharaoh’s folk—

54:42.t: they disbelieved all Our signs. So We seized them(with)the seizure of an Almighty, Invincible One.

54:43.t: “Are yourpldeniers better than all those? Or do you have immunity in the Books?”

54:44.t: Or do they say, “We, all together, will be victorious”?

54:45.t: The multitude will be defeated, and they will turn their backs.

54:46.t: Nay, the Hour is their appointed time, and the Hour is more disastrous and more bitter.

54:47.t: Indeed, the criminals are in confusion and insanity.

54:48.t: The day when they are dragged upon their faces into the Fire: “Taste the touch of Saqar<sup foot_note="81250">1</sup>.”

f.81250: Saqaris one of the names which the Qur’an gave to the fire of Hell.

54:49.t: Indeed, We have created everything in due measure.

54:50.t: And Our command is but once, like the twinkling of an eye.

54:51.t: And most surely We have annihilated yourpllikes, so is there anyone to remind himself?

54:52.t: And everything they have done is in the Books—

54:53.t: for everything, small or large, is written down.

54:54.t: Indeed, the mindful(of God)are amidst Gardens and rivers,

54:55.t: in a seat of truth, in the presence of an Invincible King.

f.81507: The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

55:5.t: The sun and the moon move according to plan,

55:6.t: and the plants<sup foot_note="81251">1</sup>and the trees prostrate themselves.

f.81251: The Arabic word used is najmwhich also means ‘star’; notice the suitability of the term which connects what is before it with what is after it.

55:7.t: And the sky—He raised it and set up the balance,

55:8.t: so doplnot exceed in the balance,

55:9.t: but maintain the weights justly and do not fall short in the balance.

55:10.t: And the earth—He set it up for living creatures;

55:11.t: in it are fruits and sheathed palm trees,

55:12.t: and grains1in the blades, and fragrant plants.

f.81252: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . palm trees. 12 And (He created) grains in the blades, and (he created) fragrant plants .”Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and (grains of) fragrant plants .”

55:13.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in1?

f.81253: The Qur’an is addressing the two types of responsible creatures: humans and jinn.

55:14.t: He created man from potter’s clay like pottery

55:15.t: and created the unseen being<sup foot_note="81254">1</sup>from a smokeless flame of fire.

f.81254: The Arabic word used is jānn(the singular of jinn), which is an unseen being that is accountable for its actions.

55:16.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:17.t: Lord of the two Easts and Lord of the two Wests.

55:18.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:19.t: He merged the two waters<sup foot_note="81255">1</sup>, converging together;

f.81255: Either the fresh water of rivers and the salty water of seas, or the waters of two different oceans.

55:20.t: between them is a barrier which they do not overrun.

55:21.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:22.t: From themcome out1pearls and corals.

f.81256: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “From them are brought out pearls and corals .”

55:23.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:24.t: His are the running ships,whose sails are raised1in the sea like banners2.

f.81257: Qira’at: Hamza and Shuʻba in one of his narrations read it as: “His are the running ships that raise their sails in the sea like banners.”
f.81258: The Arabic word used is Aʻlāmwhich also means ‘tall mountains’.

55:25.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:26.t: Everyone upon it<sup foot_note="81259">1</sup>is bound to perish,

55:27.t: and all that remains is yoursgLord’s Countenance, the Possessor of majesty and nobility.

55:28.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:29.t: Everyone in the heavens and the earth asks Him; every day He is bringing about a matter.

55:30.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:31.t: We1will attendto youpl, O two huge communitiesc.

f.81260: Qira’at: Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “He will attend to you . . .”

55:32.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:33.t: O society of unseen beings and humans, if youplcan penetrate the bounds of the heavens and the earth then go ahead and penetrate; you will never penetrate except with authority1.

f.81261: The Qur’anic style involves leaving part of the meaning to be deduced by the listener; Ar-Rāzi and other exegetes said that this may mean ‘except with authority from God’, or ‘except with authority that you do not have’.

55:34.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:35.t: Flares of fire, and brass1, will be sent upon youdl, and you will not find help.

f.81262: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Rouh read it as: “Flares of fire and (of) brass . . .”

55:36.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:37.t: And when the sky ruptures and becomes rose-colored like oil—

55:38.t: so which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:39.t: On that day neither any human nor unseen being<sup foot_note="81263">1</sup>is asked about his misdeeds.

f.81263: The Arabic word used is jānn(the singular of jinn), which is an unseen being that is accountable for its actions.

55:40.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:41.t: The criminals are recognized by their marks then taken by the forelocks and the feet.

55:42.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:43.t: This is Hell in which the criminals disbelieve;

55:44.t: they circulate between it and an intensely scalding water.

55:45.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:46.t: But for whoever feared standing before his Lord there are two Gardens(in Paradise).

55:47.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:49.t: So which of your Lord’s marvels do youdldisbelieve in?

55:50.t: In them are two flowing springs.

57:1.t: Whatever is in the heavens and the earth has been highly exalting Allah, and He is the Almighty, the All-Wise.

57:2.t: To Him belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth; He gives life and causes death, for He is All-Powerful over everything.

57:3.t: He is the First and the Last and the Manifest and the Innermost, and He is All-Knowing of everything.

57:4.t: It is He Who created the heavens and the earth in six days1then settled over the Throne. He knows what penetrates the earth and what comes out of it, and what descends from the sky and what ascends to it, for He is with youplwherever you may be. And Allah is All-Seeing of what you do.

f.81277: Six equal intervals of time, which may be six heavenly days, each of them being 1000 earthly years long; (see 22:47).

57:5.t: To Him belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, and to Allah all mattersare returned1.

f.81278: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, ʻAsem and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . all matters return .”

57:6.t: He causes the night to penetrate the day and He causes the day to penetrate the night, and He is All-Knowing of what lies within the chests.

57:7.t: Believe in Allah and His Messenger, and spend of that over which He has made you trustees, for those of you who have attained faith and spent—for them is a supreme reward.

57:8.t: And what is the matter with youplthat you do not believe in Allah when the Messenger calls you to believe in your Lord—whenHe has taken1your pledge2— if you are believers?

f.81279: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . your Lord—when your pledge has been taken . . .”
f.81280: God took a pledge from all humans in a pre-earthly existence; see (Verse 7:172).

57:9.t: It is He whobestows1upon His servant evident signs from on highto bring youplout of darkness(es)into light. And towards you Allah is truly Compassionate, Bestowing of mercy.

f.81281: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “It is He who sends down upon His servant evident signs to bring . . .”

57:10.t: And why is it that youpldo not spend in the way of Allah when to Allah belongs the inheritance of the heavens and the earth? Not equal among you are those who spent before the conquest and combated; those are higher in degrees(of rank)than those who spent afterwards and combated, yet to each1Allah has promisedthe best(reward), and Allah is All-Aware of what you do.

f.81282: Qira’at: Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . and combated. Yet each—Allah has promised (him) . . .”

57:11.t: Who is it that will lend Allah a good loan, that He may multiply it for him, and for him is a noble reward?

57:12.t: On the day when yousgsee the believing men and believing women with their light radiating ahead of them and to their right: “Glad tidings for you today: Gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding therein; it is that which is the great triumph.”

57:13.t: On the day when the hypocritical men and hypocritical women say to those who believed, “Wait for1us so that we may borrow from your light.” They were told2: “Go back behind you and seek light.” Then a wall with a door was raised between them: within it is mercy and outside of it is punishment.

f.81283: Qira’at: Hamza read it as: “Reprieve us so that . . .”
f.81284: Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense, this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

57:14.t: They<sup foot_note="81285">1</sup>call to them<sup foot_note="81286">2</sup>, “Were we not with you?” They said, “Yes, but you tempted yourselves and waited and doubted and became deceived by fancies until the command of Allah arrived, and the deceiver<sup foot_note="81287">3</sup>deceived you regarding Allah.

57:15.t: So today no ransom is accepted from youplnor from those who have denied. The Fire is your shelter; it is your patron—and what a miserable destiny!”

57:16.t: Is it not time for those who have attained faith: that their hearts should become reverent towards Allah’s Reminder and to that whichcame down1of thetruth, and not be2like those who were given the Scripture previously, but for whom time became prolonged so that their hearts hardened, and many of them are defiantly disobedient?

f.81288: Qira’at: All except for Nafieʻ and Hafs read it as: “. . . to that which He bestowed from on high of the truth . . .”
f.81289: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . of the truth. And do not be like those . . .”

57:17.t: Know that Allah revives the earth after its death; We have made the signs evident for you, that you may reason.

57:18.t: Indeed,charitable men and charitable women1who have loaned Allah a good loan—it will be multiplied for them, and for them is a noble reward.

f.81290: Qira’at: Ibn Kathir and Shuʻba read it as: “Indeed, men who believe and women who believe, who have loaned . . .”

57:19.t: And as for those who have attained faith in Allah and His messengers—those are the unwavering believers and the witnesses<sup foot_note="81291">1</sup>who will come as witnesses with their Lord; for them is their reward and their light. But as for those who denied and rejected Our signs—those are the fellows of purgatory.

f.81291: The Arabic word used is shuhada’, which literally means ‘witnesses’ and is usually used to describe martyrs.

57:20.t: Knowplthat the Earlier Life is only a game and a distraction and an adornment and boasting among you and rivalry in wealth and children: like a rainfall producing plants that delighted the farmers, then it withers and you see it yellowing, then it becomes debris. But in the Hereafter is severe punishment and forgiveness from Allah and(His)good pleasure, for the Earlier Life is nothing but the enjoyment of deception.

57:21.t: Race towards forgiveness from yourplLord and a Garden(of Paradise)whose width is like the width of the heavens and the earth—prepared for those who have attained faith in Allah and His messengers. That is Allah’s grace; He bestows it upon whomever He wills, and Allah is the Possessor of great grace.

57:22.t: No calamity occurs on earth or among yourselves but it is already written in a Record<sup foot_note="81292">1</sup>before We make it— indeed, that is easy for Allah—

57:23.t: so that youpldo not grieve over what you have missed nor exult over whatHe has given1you. And Allah does not love every self-admiring boaster—

f.81293: Qira’at: Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . nor exult over what has come to you.”

f.81294: Qira’at: Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . indeed, Allah is the Self-Sufficient, the Praiseworthy.”

57:25.t: And We certainly sent Our messengers with evident proofs, and We sent down with them the Scripture and the Balance, that mankind may uphold justice. And We sent down iron in which there is intense force and benefits for humanity, and that Allah may know who supports Him and His messengers, though unseen. Indeed, Allah is All-Powerful, Almighty.

57:26.t: And We certainly sent Noah andAbraham1and established Prophethood and Scripture among their offspring, so some of them are rightly guided, while many of them are defiantly disobedient.

f.81295: Qira’at: Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham read it as: “Abraham ”.

57:27.t: Then We sent in their wake Our messengers and followed them with Jesus, son of Mary, and We gave him the Gospel and instilled in the hearts of those who followed him compassion and mercy. But the monasticism which they invented was only to seek Allah’s good pleasure—We did not ordain it for them— yet they did not observe it with its due observance. So We gave those of them who attained faith their reward, but many of them are defiantly disobedient.

57:28.t: O you who have attained faith, be mindful of Allah and believe in His Messenger: He shall(then)bring you a double share of His mercy and shall make for you a light by which you walk and shall forgive you, for Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

57:29.t: So that the People of the Scripture may know that they have no power whatsoever over Allah’s grace and that all grace is in Allah’s hand; He brings it to whomever He wills, for Allah is the Possessor of great grace.

58:1.t: Allah has surely heard the statement of she who argues with yousgconcerning her spouse and complains to Allah, and Allah hears yourdlconversation; indeed, Allah is All-Hearing, All-Seeing.

58:2.t: Those of you who estrange their wives by equating them with their mothers—they are not their mothers; their mothers are only those who gave birth to them. And indeed, what they say is truly a deplorable thing to say and a blatant lie. But indeed, Allah is Pardoning, Oft-Forgiving.

58:3.t: And those who estrange their wives by equating them with their mothers then go back on what they have said—a slave must be set free before they may touch one another. With this youplare admonished, and Allah is All-Aware of what you do.

58:4.t: But whoever cannot find the means must fast for two consecutive months before they may touch one another, and if he is unable—then the feeding of sixty destitute people. This is to affirm yourplfaith in Allah and His Messenger, and these are the limits of Allah. And for the deniers is a painful punishment.

58:5.t: Indeed, those who oppose Allah and His Messenger have been subdued as those before them were subdued. And we have certainly sent down evident signs. And for the deniersis a demeaning punishment

58:6.t: on the day when Allah resurrects them all and informs them of what they did. Allah has kept count of it, but they have forgotten it, and Allah is Witness over all things.

58:7.t: Have yousgnot seen that Allah knows whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth? There is no secret conversation between three but He is their fourth, nor between five but He is their sixth, nor less thanthat nor more1but He is with them wherever they may be. Then on the Day of Resurrection He will inform them of what they did; indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of everything.

f.81296: Qira’at: Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . nor less than that, nor (is there) more but He is with them . . .”

58:8.t: Have yousgnot seen those who were prohibited from conversing secretly but then revert to what they were prohibited from? Theyconverse secretly1in sin and hostility and(in)disobedience to the Messenger. And when they come to yousgthey greet you with a greeting that Allah never greeted you with, and they say within themselves, “Why does Allah not punish us for what we say?” Hell is enough for them; they will roast in it—so what a miserable destiny!

f.81297: Qira’at: Hamza and Roways read it as: “. . . they converse with one another secretly in sin . . .”

58:9.t: O you who have attained faith, when you converse secretly, do notconverse secretly1in sin and hostility and(in)disobedience to the Messenger, but converse in virtue and mindfulness(of God), and be mindful of Allah to Whom you will be herded.

f.81298: Qira’at: Roways read it as: “. . . do not converse with one another secretly in sin . . .”

58:10.t: Indeed,(malicious)private conversations are from Satan,that those who have attained faith may be sad1. But he cannot harm them at all except by Allah’s leave. And in Allah let the believers place their trust.

f.81299: Qira’at: Nafieʻ read it as: “. . . that he may make those who have attained faith sad .”

58:11.t: O you who have attained faith, when you are told, “Make room for one another inassemblies1,” then make room so that Allah makes room for you. And when you are told, “Arise,” then arise. Allah elevates by degrees those of you who have attained faith and those given knowledge. And Allah is All-Aware of what you do.

f.81300: Qira’at: All except ʻAsem read it as: “. . . in the assembly .”

58:12.t: O you who have attained faith, when you converse privately with the Messenger, give a donation ahead of your private conversation. That is better for you and cleaner. But if you do not find the means, then Allah is indeed Oft-Forgiving, Bestowing of mercy.

58:13.t: Are youplreluctant to give donations before your private conversation? If you do not do so and Allah pardons you, then establish the prayer and bring1the purifying charity2and obey Allah and His Messenger. And Allah is All-Aware of what you do.
